HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Rumor That Yeltsin Had Died Briefly Lifts Dollar vs. the Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed against most leading currencies yesterday, despite a brief rally on rumors circulating in the market that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia may have died, currency traders said.
The dollar surged at midmorning in New York when stories circulated that Mr. Yeltsin's health had sharply deteriorated and even that he had died. The rumor, quickly denied by the Kremlin, briefly lifted the dollar and the Swiss franc while hurting the German mark. 
 Traders bought dollars and Swiss francs as currencies of refuge. Signs of political turmoil in Russia typically weaken the mark because of the close economic ties between Russia and Germany.
The dollar made two pushes to shatter the ceiling of this week's narrow trading range against the mark. But when Russian authorities denied the rumors, it fell back to previous levels.
"It took hold for about 10 minutes," said Ben Strauss, trader at Bank Julius Baer & Company. "The impact was very limited. I blinked, and we were back to where we started."
Late in New York yesterday afternoon, the dollar settled at 1.5287 marks, down slightly from 1.5290 marks on Tuesday.
John Nelson, a dealer at the ABN-Amro Bank in New York, said such rumors typically had more effect on quiet trading days like yesterday.
Against the Japanese yen, the dollar remained in a narrow trading range, closing slightly lower at 111.55, compared with 111.65 yen on Tuesday.
The denial of yet another rumor -- which had caused a dollar rally against the yen late Tuesday -- sent the dollar back down to its previous level, dealers said.
The director general of the International Finance Bureau of the Japanese Finance Ministry, Eisuke Sakakibara, said yesterday that a rumor American officials had told him they could tolerate the dollar at an exchange rate of 120 yen was groundless. If that account were true, it would have strengthened the dollar.
Also in early trading, a spate of institutional buying buoyed the dollar above critical exchange levels with the mark, but the move was short-lived and the dollar quickly gave up its gains, dealers said.
They noted that the dollar held relatively firm against the mark despite heavy buying of marks against other European currencies. "It does still look like the dollar will continue to trade up," said Stephen Flanagan, senior foreign exchange dealer at Credit Agricole.

HEADLINE: Christopher Drops In, But Africa Is Unmoved

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: BAMAKO, Mali, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Since Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrived in this West African country two days ago, he has seemingly struggled at each public appearance to erase the impression that this continent matters little to a Clinton Administration preoccupied with problems elsewhere.
Over and over, Mr. Christopher, the first American Secretary of State to visit sub-Saharan Africa in more than six years, spoke of his joy at being in the region, and of his admiration for Mali, a crushingly poor country that in recent years has improbably pulled off a peaceful transition to democracy. 
 But as he moved from stops like a courtesy call on the President, Alpha Oumar Konare, to a visit with Peace Corps volunteers in a dusty village just outside the capital, Mr. Christopher has instead been a reminder that an Administration that pledged to pay greater attention to Africa has arguably let the continent slip even farther off the radar screen of major foreign policy concerns.
The issues Mr. Christopher took up here, and will discuss on stops in Ethiopia, Tanzania, South Africa and Angola, range from a recent United States proposal to create an all-African crisis response force to African attempts to isolate the military leadership of Burundi in an effort to avert a full-blown ethnic war there.
But Mr. Christopher, with his slight but regular mispronunciations of President Konare's name and his deferral of journalists' questions on the African peace force to aides, may only have reinforced the impression of Washington's distant and even casual attention to this continent's affairs.
"The French are constantly worrying that Washington wants to horn in on Africa, which they virtually consider their property," said an African diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But Paris will not have anything to worry about for a long time. Say what you like about their policies, but French leaders know their African counterparts' names, and they sustain a dialogue with the continent."
Across this continent, African officials had been cheered by what was billed as a major trade initiative earlier this year. But the project, introduced by the Secretary of Commerce, Ron Brown, shortly before he was killed in a plane crash in April, seems to have passed with Mr. Brown's death, like Washington's attention to the continent generally, the diplomat said.
Given perceptions like these, officials traveling with Mr. Christopher have been at pains to say that the United States has not lessened its commitment to Africa, and have attributed minor missteps to the scarce time that Mr. Christopher had to prepare for his African visit because of a last-minute trip to the Middle East.
Aides noted that Africa had also been visited recently by Mr. Christopher's deputy, Strobe Talbott, by Vice President Al Gore, and by Mr. Cinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake.
Africans, who are accustomed to far more regular high-level contacts with European governments, are not the only ones unmoved by explanations like these, however.
By appointing Mr. Lake, an Africa specialist, as national security adviser, and by organizing a White House conference on the continent in 1994, Mr. Clinton fed high expectations among African policy experts that his Administration would work hard to engage a continent that has seen a wave of democratization and widespread reforms aimed at economic liberalization since the end of the cold war.
"With the exception of Ron Brown, and his kind of advocacy work, they just seem to wander in from time to time and do these kind of ad hoc trips and efforts," said Walter Kansteiner, a former National Security Council director for Africa under the Bush Administration. "I think this is partially a result of the Clinton Administration's lack of strategic policies toward the continent, especially in the economic area. They have had very little success in fostering policies that would help African countries enter the free-market world."
What is more, many Africa experts say, the apparent political disengagement of Washington from African affairs under Mr. Clinton, and recent declines in United States economic assistance to the continent, have worked in the favor of a resurgence of undemocratic governments across the continent whose leaders have felt less pressure to respect human rights or allow fair elections.
"The political openings that we had after 1989 in Africa were very much connected to the end of the cold war and to the fact that external powers, in the U.S. and in Europe, were willing to encourage positive change," said Richard Joseph, an Africa specialist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "Since then, France has been playing a very negative role, supporting the return of authoritarianism, while the United States has just dropped out of the picture."

HEADLINE: Stock Drop Is Worst in Over a Month as Dow Falls 36.15

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks suffered their worst drop in more than a month yesterday as profit taking on the market's recent exploits intensified, muffling enthusiasm over new signs of strength in the semiconductor industry.
The Dow Jones industrial average showed a decline of 36.15 points, to 5,930.62 -- its worst one-day point loss since a nearly 50-point drop on Sept. 5 -- halting a three-day assault on the 6,000 mark. On Monday and Tuesday, the Dow made its first forays past 6,000, but quickly slipped below again. 
 Broader measures of blue-chip and other large companies also retreated sharply, with analysts attributing the selling pressure to another weak day in the bond market and continuing worries over whether coming reports on third-quarter earnings will support the market's lofty heights.
"The buy side is not going to commit until they have confirmation that the numbers for the quarter are O.K.," said Joe Battipaglia, chief investment strategist at Gruntal & Company.
"That will carry on until we start hearing from Intel, I.B.M., Microsoft and the big industrials. Once those numbers start coming in, the market will get its footing back and start its assault on 6,000."
The technology-dominated Nasdaq market's decline was cushioned by a report late on Tuesday that showed an increase of 9 percent in new orders of computer chips during September.
The increase buoyed the Semiconductor Industry Association's book-to-bill ratio -- a widely watched comparison of the flow of chip orders compared with shipments -- to its highest level since December.
Investors were also moving to the sidelines just in case the current tame inflation and interest rate outlook is thrown off track by any surprises in tomorrow and Tuesday's reports on the direction of producer and consumer prices.
"I would think the market is going to focus on every report over the coming weeks because the jury is still out over whether the economy is slowing" enough to keep inflation under control, said Ricky Harrington, a technical analyst with Interstate-Johnson Lane in Charlotte, N.C.
Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a 5-to-3 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 408.5 million shares.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.90 points, to 696.74, its worst point loss since early September and its first drop below 700 since breaking that level for the first time on Friday.
The Nasdaq composite index fell just 2.17, to 1,237.98, with the prospect of improving demand for semiconductors and computers turning the technology sector into one of the session's best performers.
"The book-to-bill is decent and chip prices are firming, so there's got to be better margins," Mr. Battipaglia of Gruntal said.
The most active Nasdaq issue was Intel, down 3/4 at 100 7/8. In New York Stock Exchange trading, Micron Technology was unchanged at 32 3/8 as the most active issue; LSI Logic rose 1 3/4, to 25 7/8, and Texas Instruments rose 2, to 57 1/8.
Tellabs surged 6, to 79, after posting strong third-quarter earnings.
 U.S. Surgical added 2 1/8, to 45 3/4, on news that it was introducing the first set of instruments for minimally invasive coronary bypass graft surgery and the chairman's forecast that 1997 sales would accelerate.
Shares of Santa Anita Companies, were up 2 1/4 at 20 1/2. Santa Anita, operator of the Santa Anita race track, received a buyout offer from Apollo Real Estate Advisers. The company had already agreed to sell a controlling interest to Colony Capital and other investors. The new bid, valued at $19 a share, offers a $14-a-share cash dividend for a 55 percent stake and calls for possible future investment of up to $150 million.
In an initial public offering, Lason Holdings rose 2 3/4, to 19 3/4.

HEADLINE: British Prudential Fund to Invest in Troubled U.S. Companies

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
PPM America, the Chicago subsidiary of the Prudential Corporation of Britain, is raising $300 million to invest in the securities of financially troubled companies.
Prudential, Britain's largest institutional investor, is not related to the American insurer of the same name. In the style of such "vulture" investors, PPM America's Special Investments Fund will seek to influence the outcome of financial restructurings for the benefit of its investors. 
 PPM's new fund, which started up in late June, has so far taken in $154 million. That includes $25 million from Prudential, PPM's parent company and Britain's largest life insurer, $75 million from the Jackson National Life Insurance Company, a Prudential subsidiary based in Lansing, Mich., and $50 million of debt from two American institutional investors, the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association and the Transamerica Insurance Company.
Prudential set up PPM in 1990 to help unwind a $674 million troubled loan portfolio for Jackson Life. That portfolio, PPM says, has been reduced to $100 million with PPM getting an annualized return of 33 percent on the underlying securities. By starting the new fund, PPM is seeking to capitalize on its experience from such work.
F. John Stark 3d, a PPM senior vice president and the firm's general counsel, said this was a particularly opportune time to start such a fund. "The issuance of high-yield securities has continued to rise the last several years," he said, adding that only around 5 percent of such securities rated single B default. Also, Mr. Stark said, "we have been riding a tremendous wave in terms of the economy." He added, "If there is any lessening of that wave, or a downturn, it would tend to make for more opportunities" for investing in distressed securities.
Some in the investment business agree with Mr. Stark, citing the current mature economic expansion and the likelihood of more bankruptcies, particularly among highly leveraged companies. "I think the prospects are much better," said T. K. Duggan, chief executive of the Delaware Bay Company. "I think we're going to see a lot more of those situations." Morrison Knudsen, for example, is "a blue-chip situation with a bad balance sheet," he said, adding, "If there is an economic downturn, you'll see a lot of things fall out of bed."
But some bankruptcy experts disagree. "Bankruptcies are nowhere near where they were in the 80's," said Christopher M. McHugh, director of research at New Generation Research, a bankruptcy research and investing boutique. "There are a lot of high-yield securities out there, but today the coupons are 8 percent or 9 percent, and they don't croak a company at that level."
As for the volume of bankruptcies, Mr. McHugh said, "Since the end of the great era of leveraged buyout bankruptcies between 1987 and 1992, volume has been moderate with no real trend."
Through September, 60 public companies with assets of $10.8 billion had filed for bankruptcy this year, according to New Generation, compared with 85 bankruptcy filings in all of 1995 with collective assets of $23.5 billion. That is up substantially from 70 bankruptcies with collective assets of $8.3 billion in 1994, but down notably from the big bankruptcy years of 1989 to 1992, when companies with collective assets of more than $50 billion went into bankruptcy each year.
The new fund will be run by three managers, a PPM spokesman said: Brian Schinderle, 35, who previously managed a $75 million distressed securities fund for the Sanwa Business Credit Corporation's special situations group; Brad Scher, 36, who was director of distressed loans for T.I.A.A., and Levoid Robinson, 30, who previously managed a $250 million fund for the First Chicago Capital Corporation.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Hints About a 'Surprise' For Clinton at the Next Debate

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WHEATON, Ill., Oct. 9

 BODY:
Bob Dole said today that he might have some "surprises" for President Clinton when the two meet in their second and last debate next Wednesday in San Diego.
Mr. Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, was speaking to a small gathering of women, most of whom own businesses, at a forum here at the Acme Screw Company to help him get his message out to female voters. 
 His statement came in response to a question from Carol Higgins, 55, of nearby Palos Park, who described herself as a concerned parent.
"You're such a nice guy, and you walk around with the kid gloves on, and you've got Clinton to deal with, 'Slick Willie,' " she said. "When are you going to put the boxing gloves on and give him what he deserves?"
Mr. Dole said: "I've had a lot of people tell me that the last few days. It's a very fine line, because there's a myth out there that Bob Dole is mean. I never thought I was mean. The people who work in the Capitol voted me the nicest Senator two times in a row. These are people who work there. Not the media, but the people who work there. So, we may have a few surprises next Wednesday."
The statement came a day after Mr. Dole toured New Jersey and delivered some of his harshest words yet against Mr. Clinton. He indicated then that at next week's debate he would be raising questions about Whitewater and the White House misuse of confidential F.B.I. files.
Mr. Dole's aides were besieged today with questions about whether the candidate's comments on Tuesday prefigured a shift in strategy toward a more aggressive phase of the campaign.
Nelson Warfield, Mr. Dole's campaign spokesman, said: "Throughout the campaign, he has avoided personal attacks about the President's private life; as he has said repeatedly, that's not his bag. He's not going to do it."
In an interview on Tuesday on the Don Imus radio program, Mr. Dole said he was reluctant to be too harsh because women did not like it.
"We found that in our surveys, if you go on the attack with Clinton -- maybe it's the same if he attacks me, but we haven't seen it -- that the first people who jump overboard are women," he said. "They want the issues, they want us to talk about the issues. That's why we've been trying to talk about the economic package and the child credit and things that we can do to help women in the work force, women who stay at home."
Mr. Dole practiced that philosophy here before an audience of a couple of hundred people, answering a dozen friendly questions.
He was introduced by Loleta Didrickson, the state comptroller, who raised the subject of the sexual harassment suit brought against Mr. Clinton by Paula C. Jones.
She started off speaking about the phenomenon of female voters preferring President Clinton to Mr. Dole. "Why is there a gender gap?" she asked. "As women, isn't character a strong issue for us? Character is the core of who we are."
Noting that the President has asked the courts to defer the sexual harassment case until after he leaves office, she said: "Why not get it behind him? Why not have it out in front? I think it speaks to the heart of the matter of the character issue."
Mr. Dole did not take up the matter. Among the things he said were that as President, he would speak out "at least once a month" against drugs. And, on the issue of taxes, he promised to reinstate the home-office deduction.
One of the questions came in the form of a testimonial from Lisa Gengler, 56, a sculptor who lived in Coburg, Germany, in World War II.
"Because of you, Senator, and men like you, my life was saved when I was 5 years old," she told Mr. Dole, who was wounded in Italy during the war. "It's an honor to support you, and I will sleep much safer when you're President."
Earlier, Mr. Dole was interviewed by G. Gordon Liddy on his conservative radio program. According to the digest "Talk Daily," Mr. Dole told Mr. Liddy he was making progress in California, Illinois and other states, adding: "Your listeners are beginning to focus, and they're the active ones. And if they'll just go out and activate one other person, it will be a big, big help."

HEADLINE: High Court Case Raises Issue of Stripping Charities of Tax Exemptions

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
A case that began as a minor tax dispute between a Christian Science summer camp and a small town in Maine had the eyes of much of the nonprofit sector focused on the Supreme Court today.
The Justices heard arguments on whether state and local governments can strip a charity of its exemption from property tax if most of the people it serves are not state residents. 
 The camp, Newfound/Owatonna, is appealing its $22,000-a-year property tax bill from the town of Harrison and challenging the law as an unconstitutional discrimination against interstate commerce. Ninety-five percent of its campers are from outside Maine. The camp would pay no property taxes if most of its campers were from Maine, a development that is unlikely "without a massive conversion to Christian Science in the state," the camp's lawyer, William H. Dempsey, told the Court.
Supreme Court precedent, which has interpreted the Constitution's commerce clause as barring state economic protectionism in a variety of contexts, would seem to support the camp's challenge. In its most recent such ruling, earlier this year, the Court unanimously struck down a North Carolina tax law that gave proportional discounts on a stock tax based on the proportion of the issuing company's income that was earned in North Carolina.
But Maine's Supreme Judicial Court took a different approach, upholding the 39-year-old property tax law last year in a ruling that alarmed religious groups and other nonprofit organizations around the country.
In friend-of-the-court briefs, organizations including the United Way, the Y.M.C.A., the American Council on Education and a variety of religious groups warned the Court that if other states took the same approach, many organizations that served an out-of-state population -- colleges, for example -- could find themselves suddenly liable for taxes on valuable real estate.
Although he later modulated his tone, Justice Antonin Scalia got the argument off to a rather aggressive start, asking the camp's lawyer: "Why should the taxpayers of Maine subsidize people from outside Maine? I don't know why they should be required to do that."
Mr. Dempsey replied that while the state had a legitimate interest in making sure that local residents got the benefit of tax policies, the question for the Court was whether the state's approach was permitted by the commerce clause. The Court could only uphold the law, he said, by reinterpreting the commerce clause to make it somehow not apply to nonprofit organizations.
"It shouldn't make a difference whether you're dealing with profits or nonprofits," Mr. Dempsey said, adding, "Nonprofits in this country are big business in every sense of the word, except they don't make a profit."
By the end of the argument, the Justices appeared to agree that the question did, indeed, come down to whether the Court should take the drastic step of carving out a new commerce clause doctrine for charities. Whatever their concerns about the camp's position, the Justices seemed unlikely to go that far, in part because the town's defense of the law raised even more concerns.
The state itself did not appeal a state trial judge's original ruling, in 1994, that the law was unconstitutional, and it did not appear in defense of the law in the Supreme Court. That left the job to the town of Harrison, which is about 40 miles northwest of Portland and has a population of 2,200.
The town's lawyer, William L. Plouffe, managed to startle, rather than persuade, the Justices with his casual dismissal of the analysis behind the Court's leading commerce clause precedents.
At one point, Mr. Plouffe suggested that the commerce clause should not apply to real estate taxes, because real estate stayed in one place and did not move across state lines. Justice David H. Souter objected that the question was not whether the camp moved, but whether people traveled to Maine to attend the camp.
"Interstate commerce is the movement of people back and forth across state lines," Justice Souter said to Mr. Plouffe as if addressing a beginning law student. "Are you challenging that?"
"I certainly am," Mr. Plouffe replied. For a moment, no Justice had anything to say.
Throughout his argument, Mr. Plouffe stressed that the law's rationale was to make sure that the taxpayers got some benefit from organizations that enjoyed a tax exemption. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg offered the hypothetical example of two nonprofit camps in Maine, each serving blind children. The smaller camp had 50 campers, all from Maine. The larger camp also had 50 campers from Maine, as well as 60 campers from outside the state.
Observing that both camps would be "rendering exactly the same benefits to the state of Maine," Justice Ginsburg asked whether the larger camp would lose its tax exemption. Yes, Mr. Plouffe replied. But he also indicated that an otherwise ineligible camp might earn a tax exemption in return for offering a public benefit like access to its beach.
Justice Scalia eventually became exasperated. "How long has this law been in effect?" he asked. "It seems to me more trouble than it's worth. Maybe we should strike it down for foolishness."
Nonprofit organizations have property tax concerns beyond this case, Camps Newfound.Owatonna v. Town of Harrison, No. 94-1988. They are watching a voter referendum on the ballot in Colorado next month, which would extend property taxes to most charitable, religious, and nonprofit social service organizations in the state. Sponsored by a talk show host, John Murphy, who argues that "God is not broke" but that Colorado cities are, the proposed state constitutional amendment gained a place on the ballot after receiving 88,104 signatures.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A tax dispute at Newfound/Owatonna Camp in Harrison, Me., has raised the question of whether nonprofit institutions that mainly serve people from other states can be denied exemptions from state and local property taxes. The Supreme Court heard arguments in the case yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
A 'Net Surfer' Puts a Republican Spin on Torricelli's Record

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

 BODY:

This is a 30-second commercial that Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican nominee for the United States Senate seat in New Jersey, began broadcasting on Sunday. Mr. Zimmer's Democratic opponent is Representative Robert G. Torricelli.
 
PRODUCER -- Jamestown Associates, Princeton
 
ON THE SCREEN -- Seated in front of a computer screen, a man, identified as "net surfer," clicks his mouse on the word "liberal. Mr. Torricelli appears on the computer screen, saying that he supports a "variety of positions that are liberal." The man clicks three icons, "crime," "welfare" and "taxes." Each time, text appears describing Mr. Torricelli's "too liberal" positions. The ad closes with the words "Foolishly Liberal" flashing on the computer screen.
 
THE SCRIPT -- Net Surfer: "O.K., let's see, liberal . . . liberal . . . Torricelli."
Mr. Torricelli: "I certainly have a variety of positions that are liberal."
Net Surfer: "All right, let's see what your liberal positions are. Torricelli voted to let violent criminals go free on technicalities. . . . That's too liberal. Torricelli doesn't want people to work for their welfare benefits. He is a liberal. Torricelli voted for the biggest tax increase ever. . . . Now that's very liberal. No doubt about it. Torricelli is foolishly liberal."
 
ACCURACY -- Mr. Torricelli was more liberal than 72 percent of House members last year on economics, 78 percent on social issues and 70 percent on foreign policy, the National Journal's Almanac of American Politics said. Mr. Zimmer was more liberal than 49 percent of his colleagues on economics, 54 percent on social issues and 51 percent on foreign policy.
Mr. Torricelli voted against allowing the police to bypass the constitutional protections involving unlawful seizures if the police can show they made a "good faith" effort to comply. He voted in favor of the final version of the welfare bill, which places a five-year limit on cash benefits. He voted for President Clinton's 1993 budget, which increased taxes by $241 billion over five years, which was the largest tax increase in American history -- by one measure. But an increase signed in 1982 by President Ronald Reagan was actually larger, $286 billion, when adjusted for inflation.
 
SCORECARD -- The word "liberal" is used eight times in 30 seconds. To be cast as a liberal is not such a terrible thing in New Jersey, particularly on social issues. Taxes and government spending are another issue, however, and the ad succeeds in artfully misrepresenting Mr. Torricelli's voting record on welfare spending and taxes.
 JENNIFER PRESTON

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Bill Be Limbo

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Bill Clinton has given us the Limbo Presidency. (Bill be limbo, Bill be quick, Bill go under the limbo stick.)
Slowly, inch by inch, he lowers the bar and we bend to accommodate his failings. We decided we would rather change our attitude toward the Presidency than change the President. We would rather have a smiling, shape-shifting Democrat we don't trust than a frowning, laconic Republican we trust more. 
 Mr. Clinton has worn us down with so many messy eruptions from his improvident life that we have come to think of the President more as C.E.O. than role model. That may be his legacy. A new poll shows that most Americans no longer want their kids to grow up to be President. They would prefer just about anything else -- carpenter, cop, mayor, minister, athlete, even lawyer. The only profession rated lower than President was movie star.
Given this disregard for the Presidency, deepened by our knowledge of other Presidents' great flaws, it's hard to imagine that Bob Dole's sad, desperate tactic of slashing at Mr. Clinton's character will work.
Everyone has a clear understanding now of Bill Clinton's good points and bad. We pretty much know that the Clintons did something wrong in Whitewater. We pretty much know that they obfuscated about the search of Vincent Foster's office and the disappearing Rose Law Firm billing papers and the travel office and the F.B.I. files on Republicans and the matter of who hired Craig Livingstone. We've gotten used to sleazy aides, special prosecutors and Clinton loyalists racking up legal bills protecting their bosses.
We understand Bill Clinton's serial sincerity and constant expediency, his childish compulsion to tell tales, even on small things.
Now it turns out that the President who promised campaign reform let his Democratic National Committee rake in some big (and some illegal) bucks from foreign individuals and companies, some of whose executives have enjoyed unusual access to top Clinton officials.
This latest tawdriness won't help the clueless Dole campaign. If Bill Clinton has the Limbo Presidency, Bob Dole has, to borrow his latest appellation for the President, the Bozo Candidacy.
As Mr. Clinton glides through sunny economic climes, Mr. Dole wanders a blighted landscape. His New Jersey bus tour attracted paltry crowds before getting washed out by driving rain.
Mr. Dole should be running in France, where they like bleak. The '96 race has a Henry James Old-World-versus-New-World feel -- the jaded, resentful Europeans against the brash, hopeful Americans.
The Dole campaign says it needs to fix Bob Dole's dark, sour image. But it's not an image. It's him. Mr. Dole's experiences in life have left him with a bitter, fatalistic outlook, and he continually makes sardonic, self-sabotaging asides about how ridiculous his pursuit is.
He weeps a lot and tries to be touchy-feely. He even begged to get on Oprah. But this isn't the real Bob Dole. The real Dole, biting and candid, was vividly on display in '88, when he said Jack Kemp must have forgotten to wear his helmet if he believed in supply-side economics and when he called George Bush a pampered preppy making reckless no-tax pledges. In '88, he snarled but was truthful. Now he makes nice, but he's as dissembling as the man he's trying to defeat. He's promising tax cuts he doesn't believe in and proposing anti-affirmative-action legislation that belies his record.
Mr. Dole has no overarching idea where he wants to take the country. No strategy for unseating a popular President. No agenda on the Republican social and cultural issues.
His campaign is not really about voters. It's about Bob Dole, and what Bob Dole thinks he's owed because he had it hard growing up, hard in the war and hard in politics, where he kept getting passed over for people who always took the easy way in life, people like Bill Clinton.
We may not revere the President anymore but we still want him to reflect qualities that conjure up a romantic image of America -- optimism, charm, humor, magnanimity, a little swagger. That's what Bill Clinton is selling. That's why we forgive the Limbo President.
Bob Dole is selling the opposite. And maybe what he's selling is just as much America. But we don't elect the twilight of our souls.

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Essay;
Absence of Outrage

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In our last episode about the penetration of the White House by Asian interests, we saw how the President of the United States had been personally involved in the solicitation of an illegal campaign contribution of $250,000 by a foreign national.
That was pretty scandalous, I thought, especially since the facts are not in dispute: (1) John Huang, the Indonesian Riady family's man here, left his foreign economic post at Commerce to resume fund-raising for the Clinton campaign. (2) That phantom fund-raiser introduced the President to a wealthy South Korean businessman in April of this year. (3) The alien shelled out. (4) When caught by The Los Angeles Times, his hot money was returned -- and no crime is charged. 
 Evidently the Wall Street Journal reporters Glenn R. Simpson and Jill Abramson were also working on this story. Under the headline "Asian Interests Are Providing Huge Campaign Gifts, Gaining Political Clout," they added rich detail this week to the sale of access to Clinton by favor-hungry foreigners.
I had been wondering why the Secret Service was hanging out so often in the lobby of the Hay-Adams Hotel, across the street from the White House. It turns out that Mr. Huang (who will not speak to reporters, and has not been asked to speak to Craig Donsanto's Elections Crimes branch of the Department of Justice) has been holding posh Presidential dinners there with a $25,000 price tag.
Many of the "donors" may be front men with green cards, resident aliens of modest means passing along huge gifts of soft money supplied them by the Asian connection. One $425,000 gift came from the son-in-law of a big shot in the Lippo Group, the Indonesian conglomerate that came to Webster Hubbell's financial rescue after looming prosecution forced that tight-lipped Clinton confederate to quit the Justice Department.
Such unprecedented largess to American politicians from aliens, and their private access to the President and his top aides at a Jakarta conference of Asian leaders, used to be called a scandal. Though TV investigation lags, several newspapers in addition to The Journal are digging after the sleazy sale of influence to foreigners.
But what is lacking -- in the press and in the public -- is an outdated emotion called outrage. Even when caught red-handed, the White House can be expected to dismiss the latest revelations -- as Mr. Clinton did with the F.B.I. files of 900 Republicans -- as an "honest bureaucratic snafu." And even as it reeks of wrongdoing, the Clinton Asian connection will get a shrug from the public: "Too complicated." Or "Everybody does it." Or "All a bunch of politics." Or "Old stuff."
Ennui is in; outrage is out. Why?
One reason is that the Department of Justice has shoveled all corruption over to the Independent Counsel, a part-time prosecutor who won't bring indictments until after the election -- after the President has thoroughly blackened the prosecutor's reputation, and after Mr. Clinton hopes to claim pre-emptive vindication at the polls.
Another reason is scandal overload. The ripoff of taxpayers in Whitewater as shown by the convictions in Little Rock; the Travel Office abuse of police power; the Vincent Foster mystery; the obstructing of justice in long-concealed billing records; the abuse of executive privilege to conceal political embarrassment; the refusal of a lawyer, Randy Turk, to show Congress the contributors to Craig Livingstone's defense fund; the missing six months of records protecting the political operatives who looked into the F.B.I. files -- never have so few concealed so much from so many.
Another reason the voters' gorge has not risen is that the opponent has been too eager to become likable to make his case. Bob Dole raised the pardon issue in the first debate and then backed away. At his final face-to-face chance, Dole should say: "I pledge to you never to abuse the Presidential pardon power by using it to protect myself from criminal prosecution, and I call on Mr. Clinton right here and now to promise the same."
Will anything so old-fashioned as moral outrage ever make a comeback? The fault, dear Brutus, lies not in our investigative stars but in ourselves, that we are benumbed.

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 5374 words

HEADLINE: For Landlords, Hard Numbers and Obligations

SERIES: BARELY FOUR WALLS: Housing's Hidden Crisis -- Fifth of Six Articles.

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
In a tenement in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, tenants lay out a daily offering of rice and beans on hard hallway tiles. The food is given in thanks to Susie, a dog, who has taken over responsibility for killing rats from a landlord who has not been seen in years.
In the part of Queens known as the Rockaways, a landlord charges $575 a month for an illegal basement apartment. The air is close, the toilet settles slowly into rotting floorboards, and the scuttling of mice inside the walls creates a subterranean equivalent of the patter of raindrops on a roof. 
 And in a generally well-kept building in the Tremont section of the Bronx, the elevator keeps malfunctioning because people urinate down the shaft, short-circuiting the wiring. Vandals repeatedly shatter the plate-glass front door, so the landlord is forever installing new panes. It is shattered; he replaces it; it is shattered, again.
New York City is a metropolis of renters; more than two-thirds of its seven million residents pay someone else to provide them with shelter. But in the poorest neighborhoods of the city, the uneasy contract between landlord and tenant is strained to the breaking point.
Traditional adversaries, the two are yoked together at the bottom of the housing market, in buildings that few want to inhabit or own. Tens of thousands of poor tenants spend half their small incomes and more for shelter that is substandard, dangerous or illegal. And many landlords -- the well meaning and venal, the shrewd and hapless -- find it increasingly difficult to provide decent homes and still make a profit.
Tabloid "10 worst" lists, along with tenement horror stories that occasionally come to light, have shaped public perceptions about these landlords. The images that endure are of the likes of Jack Ferranti, convicted of planning a fatal arson fire in Queens, or Andonis Morfesis, whose style of managing buildings in Harlem earned him the nickname Dracula Landlord.
But experts say the anecdotes tend to obscure the root problems of housing the city's very poor.
"I think we have a problem that goes beyond a few unscrupulous and predatory elements," said David R. Jones, director of the Community Services Society, a nonprofit social-service agency. "I don't care how ethical a landlord is -- if he's depending in large part on his revenue stream from people on public assistance, he's in desperate trouble."
The economic equation is simple and stark. The tenants can afford to pay very little, while low-income landlords struggle to do business in the notoriously difficult New York housing market. The aged buildings need constant repair; some properties still carry heavy debt from the speculation frenzy of the 1980's; taxes and water charges are rising, and expenses must factor in vandalism, security problems and unpaid rents.
In pursuit of profits, the landlords take different routes. Some fit the classic "slumlord" mold -- collecting rent without providing services as basic as heat. Some rent illegal spaces to people who cannot afford legal quarters. Some find the business so difficult that they simply abandon their buildings, leaving tenants to fend for themselves.
Even the best of the low-income landlords -- those with efficient operations and well-tended buildings -- struggle to preserve thin profit margins.
Meanwhile, government is fading from this grim scene. Waiting lists for space in public housing projects, which many tenants consider a step up from most privately owned tenements, can be years long. The city has stopped seizing buildings from tax-delinquent landlords, partly because its maintenance record often rivaled those of the worst slumlords. Budget cuts have gutted code enforcement efforts, emboldening the more willfully negligent owners.
The harsh economics of low-income housing are not measured only in a ledger's debit column. A landlord's business problems often hurt tenants already living in barely acceptable conditions. If the owner of a distressed building is struggling to pay the mortgage or the tax bill -- or if he simply pockets the rent money -- maintenance is likely to suffer. That leak from the bathroom ceiling will continue to foul the air; that radiator will remain cold to the touch.
 
The Bottom Line
Struggling to Solve A Ruthless Equation
In the risky business of low-income housing, David T. Diamond and Robert C. Rosenberg are counted among the landlords who have figured it out: their buildings are generally well kept, and they make a profit. Mr. Diamond lives on the North Shore of Long Island and drives a late-model Mercedes. Mr. Rosenberg lives on the East Side of Manhattan and has an eye for works of art. And they make no apologies for living well.
"We're entitled to a profit," Mr. Rosenberg said. "We work damned hard. I have pride in ownership."
Together they own and operate about 3,000 apartments in buildings scattered throughout the Bronx. They have more than 100 employees, including 50 building superintendents, and a computer system that tracks both the company's response to code violations and the heat levels in its buildings. They also retain two "tenant relations specialists" who work out rent-payment plans, help fill out forms for government subsidies and even provide rides to doctors' offices.
The partners adhere to a credo of enlightened self-interest. For example, they offer to pay college application fees for tenants, figuring that education can lead to better jobs that will make paying the rent easier. They give out T-shirts that say "Junior Tenant Patrol," hoping to instill children with pride in their homes. They plant trees and shrubbery in their concrete courtyards.
But even the Rosenberg-Diamond model is showing cracks. It is getting harder and harder, they say, to make the numbers work.
For the first time in their 20-year partnership, the two men have fallen significantly behind in their taxes -- as much as $1 million -- and are refinancing some buildings to pay off those taxes. They suddenly face unpalatable choices, Mr. Rosenberg said: "Do we pay our fuel, or do we pay our taxes?"
A ruthless arithmetic is at the root of the problem. The city estimates that the average cost of operating a rent-stabilized apartment in a building built before World War II is about $386 a month, not including mortgage payments or profit. But the state's shelter allowance for welfare, that inefficient yet indispensable element of the low-income housing equation, has remained static for almost a decade, at $286 for a family of three.
To make an investment worthwhile, explains Dan Margulies, an advocate for landlords, "the owner has to beat that $386 every month." But with low-income housing, that can prove almost impossible.
"There are whole neighborhoods in the city where the household income is nowhere near enough to pay a $386 monthly rent," said Frank P. Braconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council.
The prospect of further cuts in welfare and other subsidies has forged an unusual alliance between landlords and tenants; both say they rely on that money.
"It is an anomaly to think of private landlords providing low-income people with decent and affordable housing," said Michael McKee, a longtime tenant advocate. "It's very difficult. And without some kind of government subsidy, it's almost undoable."
Over all, as the city has enjoyed an economic upswing in the last couple of years, so too has the housing market. Indeed, the Rent Guidelines Board, which sets rates for rent-stabilized and rent-controlled apartments, heralds the improvement in an upcoming report.
But that optimism does not trickle down to the very low end of the housing market. Board officials and housing experts alike say the income is still too low, the expenses too high.
Officials often use the number of tax-delinquent buildings as a measure of the city's distressed housing, and that measure suggests a disturbing trend.
In 1989, the city counted 2,069 multiple-dwelling buildings in serious tax arrears; 245, or 12 percent, were at least three years behind in taxes. By 1994, the numbers were 4,306 buildings tax delinquent, with 1,384, or 32 percent, at least three years behind. Then, last year, the overall number dropped to 3,874, but the most seriously delinquent rose to 1,633 buildings -- or 42 percent.
Mr. Rosenberg and Mr. Diamond readily acknowledge that, so far, their salvation stems from experience and volume; operating 3,000 apartments allows them to buy in bulk and to economize. But they say the realities of low-income housing inflate their cost-per-apartment well above the citywide estimate of $386.
They have as many as 300 rent-nonpayment cases pending in Housing Court at any given time, which translates into tens of thousands of dollars in lost income a year. Even if they succeed in having a tenant evicted -- which occurs about six times a month -- their expenses, from moving and storage costs to the $65 fee for the services of a marshal, continue. In recent years, they have also paid more than $50,000 in fines for not having window guards, which they say tenants constantly remove.
Some of their buildings are in areas where crime is common and drug dealing a way of life. That is why, they say, they go door-to-door collecting rent with "PPD's" -- personal protection devices -- or guns.
Responding to tenant complaints about drug dealing on the roof of a building in the Fordham section, the landlords put up a chain-link fence; the dealers hacksawed through. The landlords countered with bars; the dealers hacksawed through. Now the roof is secured with reinforced iron bars, a chain-link fence and razor wire.
At another building, in Tremont, someone keeps smashing the glass front doors. And Mr. Rosenberg, who refuses to use Plexiglas because, he says, it looks cheap, keeps replacing the panes. "You break a window, I'll have it replaced in an hour," he said, his voice raised. "You will tire before I do."
The partners lobby constantly for the elimination of rent regulations, which they and other landlords say skew the housing market and prevent them from collecting fair rents. Tenant advocates counter that regulations are needed to protect the poor.
At the same time, the precarious Rosenberg-Diamond empire relies heavily on government subsidies; more than two-thirds of their tenants receive welfare payments, vouchers or some other government assistance. If there are significant cuts in those subsidies, Mr. Diamond said, "I don't know what would happen."
Although they say some of their buildings are losing money, the partners say they have no intention of selling their properties. "We buy for long-term investment," Mr. Diamond said. "We have a vested interest in the Bronx."
 
Studies in Disrepair
Lured by 80's Market, Soured by 90's Reality
There are many landlords whose outlook is decidedly narrower than that of Mr. Rosenberg and Mr. Diamond. Chasing the elusive profits of low-income housing, they routinely flout the laws designed to insure habitable conditions for the poor.
The notices arrive at Mark Seidenfeld's Brooklyn address with disturbing regularity. The return address for the certified mail is always the housing code office of the City of New York. And the letters are always written in that awkward language reserved for landlords in trouble.
"Abate the nuisance consisting of vermin mice and roaches thru out 3rd sty southeast apt 7c . . . Provide hot water at all hot water fixtures 3rd sty north apt 3c kitchen & bathroom north section . . . Repair the broken or defective plastered surfaces and paint in a uniform color ceiling and walls 4th story front apt thru out."
Most of the six buildings that Mr. Seidenfeld owns in the Bronx are studies in despair. At 2265 Morris Avenue, hallway haggling over drugs replaces the cup-of-sugar requests of past decades; at 735 Bryant Avenue, the front doors are broken, the intercom is smashed, the elevators are sealed shut; at 1220 College Avenue, all that brightens the dreary fifth-floor corridor are the empty crack vials, red, green and blue.
Perhaps out of fear for his safety, his tenants say, Mr. Seidenfeld rarely enters his own buildings. That is why Catherine Olivencia sometimes begins the month by walking around the corner from her apartment, on College Avenue in Morrisania, to a green 1995 Lincoln Continental parked near a bakery. She hands her rent check to the man behind the wheel, Mr. Seidenfeld.
City records show that Mr. Seidenfeld has been fined time and again for housing code violations; in several of his buildings, the infractions count into the hundreds. In the last year alone, he has been ordered to pay $13,000 for falsely certifying that violations had been corrected in three of his buildings, and another $2,100 for not providing tenants with adequate heat.
Mr. Seidenfeld and his lawyer declined repeated requests to be interviewed for this article. But the landlord is by no means alone in owning buildings where the poor live in substandard conditions. There are hundreds.
In a Bronx building across Morris Avenue from one of Mr. Seidenfeld's properties, a family of six lives in a rear apartment facing an alley, struggling to keep rats at bay. The rodents squeeze through the rotting floorboards and gaping holes that riddle the apartment. Janet Carcano said she sometimes stays up at night to make sure the rats do not go near the children. She is not always successful; rats have chewed the nipples off baby bottles left on a dresser. And early one recent morning, there were drops of blood on the sheets in the crib where her infant grandchild lay crying. He had been bitten on the toe.
The owner, Robert Heimann, calls the Carcano apartment -- for which he collects $800 a month in rent, mostly from a Federal subsidy -- the worst in the building. "It's not an apartment I'm satisfied with at all," he said. Although he accepted responsibility for the collapsing floor, he blamed the rats on the tenants' poor housekeeping.
The landlord added that he had frequently provided Ms. Carcano with blocks of rat poison.
Housing experts say that much of the current landscape of low-income housing was shaped by a frenzy of speculation that swept over the city's real estate market in the mid-1980's. Banks dangled tantalizing loans before eager investors, while housing values skyrocketed. Mr. Heimann and Mr. Seidenfeld were among the many who bought their properties during this overheated period. But the giddiness turned to panic after the stock market crash of 1987.
Many buyers "got caught up in the euphoria and are now caught in an impossible situation," said Dr. James W. Hughes, dean of the School of Planning and Public Housing at Rutgers University. "You don't see how they can work themselves out, with the debt load and the rent rolls. There's a huge gap there, unless you can really raise rents and get those rent hikes to stick."
One businessman lured by the prospect of getting in on a good thing and diversifying his portfolio was Lawrence G. Chan, owner of garment companies and a restaurant. In 1986, Mr. Chan and his Chan Brothers Realty Corporation paid $218,000 for 210 Humboldt Street, a five-story walk-up that looms over a street corner in Bushwick. But the gambit proved to be a loser.
Within a few years, Mr. Chan had used the increasingly squalid property as collateral for two mortgages. As far as his tenants could tell, Mr. Chan himself had disappeared. The building superintendent collected the rent for a while, tenants say, but he did little maintenance in return. And then he, too, vanished.
As conditions deteriorated, visitors to the building were greeted by the stench of dead rats inside the walls. Indeed, at times it seemed that a battle for dominion was being waged between residents and rats. Tenants used BB guns and sharpened sticks to kill the rodents and brought in dogs, including the mongrel Susie, to patrol the floors.
Last spring, the tenants learned that a court-appointed receiver had taken over the building and was demanding $950 in back rent from each of them. They formed an association instead, reasoning that the only way to improve the building's condition was to do it themselves, said Diana Acevedo, a housing advocate for the St. Nicholas Neighborhood Preservation Corporation. A spokesman for the receiver declined to comment.
Mr. Chan, of Forest Hills, Queens, eventually resurfaced. Last summer, he began serving a one-year prison sentence for trying to bribe a Federal official as part of a plan to smuggle undocumented immigrants and tainted food into the country.
At his sentencing, Mr. Chan's lawyer explained that the landlord had become involved in illegal activity "at a time when he was failing as a businessman."
 
Defining a Landlord
Game of Square Feet And Few Square Deals
Some landlords have found profit in housing the poor illegally by carving up their buildings and renting out space that is too small and dangerous for those who can afford better, but passable for those with no choice. With the supply of affordable housing shrinking, these illegal conversions have become increasingly common, particularly in Queens.
This shadowy market, which thrives on the commodity of space, has created many permutations of what is generally meant by the term landlord. Building superintendents make extra money by quietly squeezing bodies into space next to the boiler; tenants sublease rooms in their own apartments; "fixers" try to match up desperate tenants with dismal quarters.
Some landlords, though, break the law so overtly that illegally converted apartments have become their trademark.
Michael Andrews rents to the poor of the Rockaways, a section of southeastern Queens that long ago lost much of its appeal as a summer resort. He and his real estate company, Sue Me Inc., have been cited repeatedly for code violations, and this year he has amassed more than $50,000 in fines. When the community board compiled a list of the 12 worst single-room-occupancy hotels in the Rockaways, seven of the properties were either owned or managed by Mr. Andrews.
"His name is mud in the Rockaways," says Jonathan L. Gaska, district manager for Community Board 14 in Queens. "He's certainly one of the biggest violators of the public trust in this community."
Typical, officials say, is a 90-year-old house Mr. Andrews owns at 96-18 Rockaway Beach Boulevard.
One day in January, a gust of wind snapped off the Atlantic Ocean and blew out the window of the third-floor apartment. Glass fell to the floor, rain covered the bed, and Donna Russo began to scream.
Her wails carried past the bucket her elderly father used for a toilet, down a dark stairwell to the second floor -- where five other people, living in three separate units, all shared the same filthy bathroom -- and then to the first floor, which had been split into two apartments.
In the back apartment, which rented for $500 a month, fetid water from the second-floor toilet leaked through the ceiling of the room where Elisa Rodriguez and her asthmatic grandson slept. The dripping water was caught in a strategically placed bucket, which she sprayed several times a day with a can of room freshener called "Spring Garden."
The wails settled in the $575-a-month basement home of Margaret O'Connor, her husband, Dominick, and their two children. The building's boiler sat behind the couch. Stained wastepipes crisscrossed the room. Water dripped from the bathroom ceiling. And there were mice within the walls. "At nighttime, when you're in bed, you can hear them running," Mr. O'Connor said.
If the tenants in all seven units paid their rent in full, Mr. Andrews would collect more than $30,000 a year for a house he and his partners bought in 1991 for $87,500. But the full amount is rarely paid. The rent for the squalid basement, for example, was $575 a month, but the tenants paid only the $286 provided by the mother's public-assistance housing allocation.
Mr. Andrews, of Manalapan, N.J., disputes the city's contention that the house is zoned for single-family use, but he does not deny having illegally rented the basement in this building and in others.
"God, everybody's been doing that for years," he said. "This is not a new story, it's an old story. If you don't know that, you don't know anything about real estate."
Mr. Andrews, who acknowledges that he is making a profit in the Rockaways, blames the poor conditions in some of his buildings on the tenants. "They're alcoholics," he said. "They're crack addicts. They're everything. They're all on public assistance."
"I feel I'm really doing a service" by housing the less fortunate, he said. "Not that I want to. I'm forced into it."
Several of the tenants at 96-18 Rockaway Beach Boulevard have since moved on, and Mr. Andrews has put the building up for sale. But his troubles continue; in a house he owns nearby, city officials found two families being charged $600 a month each for illegal basement apartments.
Another variation on the theme of illegal housing played out last winter in Flatbush, Brooklyn, where seven Russian immigrants were living in five cubicles carved out of a one-bedroom apartment. Each room was no wider than a man's outstretched arms, and each had a door with a padlock. Other Russians lived in similarly divided apartments elsewhere in the well-kept building at 39 Turner Place -- until the owner, Star Realty Inc., found out and evicted them.
The illegal tenants were paying rent -- $250 a month for a cubicle of one's own, $150 to share -- to Mark Ruditsky, a "fixer" who had no legal claim to the property but who held keys to several apartments. He said he was merely watching the apartments for friends who had returned to Russia, and had decided to make practical use of the empty space by renting it at bargain rates.
"One hundred fifty dollars a month for a room!" he exclaimed. "It's free, nearly. Where else can you find living in New York like that? Who can complain?"
 
The Small Landlord
Easier to Get In Than to Succeed
In low-income housing, the most vulnerable landlord is the small landlord. She might be a retiree who thinks she cannot go wrong with a real estate investment. Or he might be an immigrant building superintendent who believes that to own a 20-unit complex is to own a piece of America.
City housing studies show that small owners tend to pay slightly higher real estate taxes and have higher vacancy rates and more collection losses, accounting for three-quarters of all residential buildings in tax arrears. Their tenants, meanwhile, are poorer and move more frequently.
Mr. Margulies, director of the Community Housing Improvement Program, an owners' advocacy group, said that immigrants have traditionally gravitated toward becoming small landlords. "But the requirements have changed," he said. "You need to be computer literate, you need to be able to correspond with city agencies and state agencies to straighten out mistakes, you need to be able to hire lawyers and accountants.
"There is money to be made there -- in volume -- but, in my estimation, almost no money to be made in small buildings."
Ivan Matetic knows this better than most. He owns one building, a turn-of-the-century tenement in the South Bronx that he bought in 1986. And it has all but wiped him out.
He sleeps in the basement, in a makeshift supply room crammed with broken sinks, copper pipes, and jugs of grease remover. His shower, little more than a faucet connected to a garden hose, is next to the building's boiler. Down the narrow corridor, there is a low roar from a broken water pipe.
Mr. Matetic, an immigrant from Yugoslavia, is also a porter, making $33,000 a year mopping the floors of a luxurious apartment complex in Brooklyn Heights. Virtually every dime he earns is invested in his property, he said, and to prove his point, he pulled out a plastic bag from inside his shirt. The bag, which he calls his "office," contains income-tax statements, correspondence with the city and other documents related to his building.
But Mr. Matetic's humble life style has not been enough to make his investment profitable; he is awash in debt and violations. He owes $66,000 in taxes, is behind on mortgage payments and has a $6,000 bill from an oil company. As for the thousands of dollars he owes in fines, he raises his hands in surrender and says, "Come and get me."
There are several reasons the 35-unit walk-up at 555 Southern Boulevard has been a losing proposition. It is in a poor neighborhood with a history of drug-related violence. Eleven of its units are vacant because Mr. Matetic does not have enough money to finish much-needed renovations. Seven tenants have not paid rent in years, but Mr. Matetic cannot try to evict them because he distrusts bureaucracy, and has never properly registered his building with the state as a multiple-dwelling residence.
He collects about $375 a month for each of the other units, although he allows a few to pay much less. "It's so poor here," he explained. "If they have little money, it's hard to pull it out."
A local community organization, convinced of Mr. Matetic's good intentions, is trying to help him improve the building and make it more profitable. "This is a good man here," said Blanca Ramirez, the director of the group, the Citizens Advice Bureau. "He knows what people go through here. We need more landlords like him."
Meanwhile, Mr. Matetic continues to sleep in the basement, dreaming of what could be. "If I can get $400 each from every apartment," he said, "then I have no problem anymore."
 
In Search of Solutions
Salvaging Buildings Before It's Too Late
There is a pair of buildings in Washington Heights that embodies the desperation in low-income housing: crumbling interiors, rampant drug dealing, insufficient rent income and the struggles of a series of landlords. A high-ranking housing official describes the buildings at 548-552 West 163d Street as the worst in the city.
But they may soon serve as a testing ground for one possible solution to those problems: a joint effort between government and nonprofit organizations to salvage the worst buildings.
"There's an inherent conflict between low-income housing and the profit motive," said Dr. Elizabeth A. Roistacher, a professor of economics at Queens College. "There's just not enough of a margin to make it economically viable. That's why the nonprofits are so important: they don't need the rate of return."
On West 163d Street, a stranger's appearance elicits whistles and shouts, the urban birdsong of lookouts for drug dealers at work. For years, much of their work has been conducted inside the five-story walk-ups at 548-552 West 163d.
There, in the rank hallways and decrepit bathrooms, that uneasy contract between landlord and tenant has been broken. At one point, there were no front doors. The Postal Service refused to deliver because the mailboxes had been ripped away. Ceilings neared collapse, leaking pipes flooded the basement, and shoddy wiring posed a fire hazard.
A drug dealer nicknamed Yaya stood with arms folded at the doorway; visitors needed his permission to enter. Inside, there was Suyapa Rivera, seven months pregnant, who feared leaving her apartment because the stairs shook; she and her husband, a truck driver, paid $400 a month. There was Francisco DeLeon, paying $94 a month for the rent-controlled unit he has lived in for two decades; heat was sporadic last winter, so he spent the season wrapped in blankets. And there was the family of 16 Mexican immigrants living in a two-bedroom apartment. They were paying $500 a month to the leaseholder, who lived 12 blocks away.
Over the last decade, as conditions worsened, the property was passed from one landlord to another like a lit firecracker. The only constant has been Barry H. Levites, whose large real estate company either owned the buildings or held the mortgage.
Mr. Levites runs his business out of a cluttered second-story office that overlooks East 149th Street in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx. He works at a frenetic pace, barking orders to employees over an intercom, negotiating deals over the telephone, and signing documents all at once. Next to his desk he keeps a machine that measures blood pressure.
Mr. Levites, who has not been inside the buildings in years, said he tried to salvage them several times, turning them over to a succession of landlords, but each one collected the rent without providing maintenance. Soon "the building was infested with drug dealers," he said.
Indeed, the apartments taken over by the dealers are easy to identify; the door frames have been reinforced with concrete to thwart police battering rams.
"At one point, we wanted to sell it for whatever we could get," Mr. Levites said, with a dismissive wave of his hand. "Then we got Isaac White."
A casual agreement in 1994 placed the property and its 38 apartments in the hands of Mr. White, a retired construction worker with little experience as a landlord. At first, Mr. White just collected the rent and did repairs, but eventually Mr. Levites was able to sell the troublesome property to Mr. White. The sales price could not be learned; the new owner described it as "a little song."
Mr. White's song became a dirge. The drug dealers warned him not to meddle, and tenants refused to pay their rent because conditions were deplorable. Trying to maintain the buildings cost him his life savings of $40,000, he said, and ruined his family life. What's more, city housing officials sought to have him fined and imprisoned for not doing agreed-upon repairs in buildings that were notorious long before they were his.
"I ain't got no home and I'm dead broke," Mr. White said one day last spring as he sat on a bench outside Housing Court, hat on his head and cigar in his mouth. "Those buildings broke me."
The buildings were so far gone that the city's housing agency made plans to vacate the premises and board the front doors shut. But the nonprofit Northern Manhattan Improvement Corporation, which had organized the tenants, intervened, as did the local City Councilman, Guillermo Linares.
After a meeting with the Housing Commissioner, Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, the principals reached a series of agreements. In exchange for the city's dropping its overwhelming case against him, Mr. White agreed to sell the property to a nonprofit group for a dollar. The city, meanwhile, agreed to work with the group as part of a new program to salvage distressed properties.
Housing officials say they have done $150,000 in emergency repairs, and are hoping to provide a $1.6 million loan, an amount based on the estimated $40,000 in repairs needed by each apartment. They are considering waiving more than $480,000 in outstanding taxes.
"The best plan for a building is never to shut it down and let it rot," Ms. Barrios-Paoli said, "just as the best plan for a person is never to go to a shelter."
There was one other detail in the matter of West 163d Street: Barry Levites still held a $150,000 mortgage. But when told of the arrangement between the city and the nonprofit group, he agreed to declare the mortgage satisfied.
"He's had enough," a city official explained. "He's letting it go."
 
Many Offer Their Help
More than 100 people have called to offer help to the tenants whose lives and living conditions have been chronicled this week in The New York Times. The Children's Aid Society has agreed to manage donations or other offers of help. Inquiries or donations may be sent to Philip Coltoff, Executive Director, Children's Aid Society, 105 East 22d Street, New York, 10010.

HEADLINE: Southern Co. Unit Getting Role in Asia

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 9

 BODY:
The Southern Company said today that its Southern Electric International unit had agreed to buy a majority interest in Consolidated Electric Power Asia Ltd. in a deal worth $2.7 billion.
Consolidated Electric, one of Asia's largest independent power producers, is now 60.4 percent owned by Hopewell Holdings Ltd. in Hong Kong, whose managing director is Gordon Wu, the Hong Kong entrepreneur. 
 Southern's announcement said Consolidated Electric shareholders "will receive $2.1 billion from Southern and $600 million in dividends for 80 percent of the company. Hopewell will become the largest minority shareholder of C.E.P.A."
Company executives were not immediately available to explain how the transaction would be carried out.
"Combining the assets of Southern Electric International and C.E.P.A. will create one of the world's largest independent power producers, supplying electricity to the heart of Asia -- including three of the world's most populated countries -- as well as Europe, North America and South America," A. W. Dahlberg, Southern's chief executive, said.
The company is betting that Asia's strong economic growth will continue to increase demand for electricity, analysts said.
Consolidated Electric owns and operates generating plants in China and the Philippines and has projects under development in Pakistan and Indonesia.
The company was established in 1993 as a holding company for Hopewell's electricity projects.
Southern, based in Atlanta, said the transaction was subject to approval by the Hong Kong Stock Exchange and by shareholders of Consolidated Electric.
Southern, the largest producer of electricity in the United States, is the parent of five Southeastern utilities: Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power and Savannah Electric. It also owns power plants and transmission systems in Britain, Argentina, Chile, Trinidad and Tobago and the Bahamas. Southern's stock lost 62.5 cents to close at $21.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Hopewell is a major developer in Asia with projects as diverse as highways, bridges, mass transit projects, hotels and retail, residential and commercial properties. The sale would provide much needed funds for the cash-strapped company.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
When politicians seek to please on medical benefits.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
"I TRUST the people," remonstrated Bill Clinton in response to Bob Dole's charge during Sunday's Presidential debate that he put more faith in government. "But I do think we are right when we try to, for example, give mothers and newborns 48 hours before they can be kicked out of the hospital," Mr. Clinton added.
Don't expect Mr. Dole to press the issue of the President's inclination to depend on Washington to end what Mr. Clinton called "drive-by deliveries." After all, it was Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, a rising star in the Republican Party, who led the drive at the state level to bar health maintenance organizations from sending mothers and newborns home without a second day to recuperate. Remember, too, that parallel Federal legislation, signed by the President in September, was widely supported by Congressional Republicans. 
 On the other hand, don't expect the broader issue of Government micro-management of minimum health care benefits to disappear without a trace. For in a period of relentless efforts to contain health insurance costs, everything points toward more of the same. "It's sad," said Uwe Reinhardt, an economist at Princeton, that "at the first sign of discomfort we get meat-ax regulation."
Sending new mothers home the day after they deliver has drawn fire from some medical professionals, but the practice has hardly been confined to health maintenance organizations run by followers of Dr. Mengele. It has virtually become the norm in California, where H.M.O.'s have been leaders in cost-cutting.
The majority view goes more or less like this: When the delivery is vaginal and uncomplicated, and the newborn's health can be adequately monitored at home, the risks are very small. The trick for H.M.O.'s is to prevent the ambiguous cases -- mostly low-income mothers who had little prenatal care and are unlikely to head for the doctor at the first sign of distress -- from slipping though the cracks.
That said, drive-by deliveries were rapidly becoming a public relations disaster for H.M.O's in the Northeast, a mistake that Mr. Reinhardt argues was largely driven by their failure to analyze costs and bargain with hospitals for changes in pricing practices. Deliveries themselves are expensive, he acknowledges, but a day for rest in the hospital does not use valuable medical services. "It's more like a stay in a hotel," Mr. Reinhardt suggests.
Thus H.M.O.'s would have been well advised to concede an extra day of hospitalization for women who insisted, and then to have used their financial leverage with hospitals to bargain down the cost to a few hundred dollars.
Is there a lesson here, apart from the cynic's observation that health maintenance organizations ought to pay more attention to their patients' concerns in election years? Most economists, including Mark Pauly of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, think the first line of defense against the inclination to micro-manage treatment is more and better information: Consumers of medical care need to know what they'll get in advance, particularly in gray areas where comfort and convenience are paramount. "This is often a problem that can be best solved by informed buyers," he suggested.
There are exceptions, though. Joseph Newhouse, an economist at Harvard, points to cases where it is clear in advance that the vast majority of consumers would opt for the same medical protocol, and giving them a choice would simply be wasted effort. Hardly anyone, presumably, would choose to opt out of the right to trauma care in the emergency room in order to save on insurance premiums.
But there are tougher calls here, too -- circumstances where it is difficult to believe that the competitive market alone would satisfy diverse preferences at the lowest possible cost. In many cases, health care comes as a take-it-or-leave-it package, as a fringe benefit to employment. Thus the employer decides what benefits to buy with only indirect input from the actual consumer.
In theory, employees can always voice their complaints, or even quit if they are not satisfied. Few, though, are going to risk the boss's wrath because their H.M.O. will not promise, say, replacements for lost contact lenses or surgery for deviated septums.
Society as a whole may claim a stake in setting minimum health care standards for individuals. Certainly there is a long history of state intervention in setting medical priorities, particularly in life-and-death decisions. "We probably wouldn't approve of the Kevorkian H.M.O.," Mr. Newhouse suggested, only half-joking.
Legislating a two-day minimum maternity stay will raise health insurance costs by just a fraction of 1 percent. The real danger here is the precedent in an era of tight government budgets. Elected officials who cannot please constituents with additional spending or tax cuts still have the option of currying favor by mandating private benefits. And as long as there is a plausible rationale along with emotional appeal, minimum-benefit creep will be hard to resist.
