HEADLINE: Investors Are Calling for WMX to Stick to Its Core Business

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
This morning, Phillip B. Rooney, the chief executive of WMX Technologies Inc., will be visited by Robert A. G. Monks, a principal of Lens Inc., an investment partnership that owns $25 million in WMX stock. Lens often comes down hard on the chiefs of companies that underperform, and Mr. Monks has no plan to coddle Mr. Rooney.
Mr. Monks wants WMX to pull back from any business that is not directly related to trash disposal. He wants WMX to buy back a lot of its stock as well as the various parts of its subsidiaries, including Wheelabrator Technologies and WMX International, that it had taken public. 
 In other words, he wants WMX to go back to being plain old Waste Management Inc., the company it started as in 1968 and that, while just about half of its $10.2 billion in sales, is still its most profitable operation.
"It isn't clear that this company can run businesses beyond domestic trash," Mr. Monks said.
Mr. Monks has some high-powered support. Soros Fund Management, George Soros's deep-pocketed investment fund, owns about 5 percent of WMX. Soros executives rarely discuss their investments, but other investors familiar with Soros say its expectations are even higher than those of Mr. Monks.
Yet the meeting may yet turn out to be civilized. WMX's recent actions seem right along the lines of what Mr. Monks and Soros want.
WMX has sold its water-treatment equipment business to the U.S. Filter Corporation, its scaffolding business to an investment group, and its process engineering and construction business to Raytheon Engineers and Constructors. Mr. Rooney says he expects to sell WMX's industrial cleaning business.
WMX has already bought back five million shares of stock. And, analysts predict it will generate $700 million in cash this year.
All the moves, Mr. Rooney said, are in line with his plan -- articulated last spring -- to sell $1 billion in underperforming assets by mid-1998 and increase productivity in those that remain, slash capital spending, reduce debt, generate more free cash and buy back stock.
"Bob Monks and I are in agreement about a lot of things," said Mr. Rooney, a 27-year WMX veteran who says that he, too, owns $20 million worth of stock. "I guess everyone just wants us to move faster."
They certainly do. "He says $1 billion by 1998, and we say dispose of $4 billion minimum," said one big investor who also strongly suggested that the company should replace Mr. Rooney, an operations maven, with a financial whiz.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Rooney insists that operations experience is what WMX most needs right now. He notes that WMX has already increased the productivity of its trash business by 15 percent, by computerizing truck routing and applying other technologies. And he says he is pushing WMX's disparate businesses to sell their services as a package.
Mr. Rooney has some Wall Street converts. "WMX is finally a positive story," said Leone Young of Smith Barney. William Gencoof Merrill Lynch agreed, saying, "He is executing what he said he will execute."
WMX shares, which were mired in the mid-$20's until a few months ago, closed at $34 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. But the stock's rise seems less a sign of faith in management than a reaction to the buyback and to the idea that Lens and Soros are on WMX's case -- and to an unsubstantiated rumor that Mr. Rooney would be replaced.
One sign of lingering investor caution: U.S. Filter's stock rose when it bought the water equipment business, yet WMX stock did not budge. "The sale of the water business could be the beginning of a turnaround, but the market did not react," Mr. Monks said. Another investor added, "If they could clear away more of the kudzu cluttering this company up, it could be a $50 stock."
Such clearing would take a powerful weed-cutter. Throughout the 1980's, WMX invested heavily in hazardous-waste disposal and in European operations. "No one thought the hazardous-waste business would fall apart or that the European Community would not offer unified regulations and economies of scale," said Marc H. Sulam, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Yet that is what happened. Processors learned to generate fewer hazardous by-products and Washington pushed toxic-waste disposal down its priority list. Europeans retained their own rules, and preferences for home-grown disposal companies.
Mr. Rooney thinks WMX should stick it out in Europe. But over all, he agrees that WMX's real future rests with its past: Waste Management. The trash-disposal behemoth's biggest competitor, Browning-Ferris Industries, has had problems stemming from overinvestment in recycling. And with landfill space running out, few new competitors are likely to usurp WMX's domestic franchise.
It is that franchise that still attracts Mr. Monks. "WMX is an intriguing company," he said. "It is one that can be fixed and ought to be fixed."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Atom Plant Likely to Close

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
The owners of the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant in Haddam Neck, one of four troubled nuclear reactors in the state, said yesterday that they would probably shut down the 28-year-old plant because it had become too expensive to operate.
Connecticut Yankee is the oldest operating full-scale commercial nuclear power plant in the nation, but it has been shut down since July 22 for safety reasons, along with the three Millstone reactors in Waterford, Conn., leaving the state with no operating reactors. 
 Anthony E. Nericcio, a spokesman for the Connecticut Yankee Atomic Power Company, the consortium of eight utilities that own Connecticut Yankee, said the final decision to decommission the plant will not be made for at least a month, but that the likelihood that the 582-megawatt reactor would not be shut down was "very slim."
The plant's fate highlights not only the increased scrutiny of nuclear plants in Connecticut, but also the fact that nuclear power has become relatively expensive compared with other fuels, like oil and gas.
Mr. Nericcio said the decommissioning would probably take at least two years. He added that the 350 employees there had been told that they would continue to have jobs for at least another six months. After that, they face several possibilities: they might continue to work during the shutdown, they might be terminated, they might be offered buyouts, or they could be transferred to the Millstone plants or the Seabrook nuclear power plant in Seabrook, N.H. Those plants are either owned outright by Northeast Utilities, of Berlin, Conn., the largest member of the consortium that owns Connecticut Yankee, or by other consortiums that include Northeast Utilities.
He also said that employees working on a contractual basis at the plant would be let go soon.
"It was received quietly," he said, when asked about the response from employees at the plant. "It was a surprise."
Mr. Nericcio stressed that the decision to shut down the reactor, which sits hard by the Connecticut River in the eastern part of the state, was based on economic factors and was not tied to the safety concerns that have recently dogged the plant.
Simply put, prices of natural gas and oil have fallen so low and remained low for so long that nuclear power is no longer a comparatively cheap source of energy.
"Oil is cheaper than bottled water," said Charles Komanoff, an energy economist in Manhattan who has long followed the nuclear industry.
Bruce D. Kenyon, president and chief executive of Connecticut Yankee, said in a statement released yesterday: "The owners of Connecticut Yankee have done an analysis of the economics involved in running this plant for the next 10 years. At this point, the economic picture does not seem favorable."
To a degree, though, the economics of operating Connecticut Yankee have hinged on increased costs stemming from shutdowns and increased regulatory scrutiny. Much, but not all of that scrutiny, has been sparked not by safety problems at the Haddam plant but by concerns about the Millstone reactors, which have a spottier safety record.
Connecticut Yankee was licensed to operate until 2007. It began operations on Jan. 1, 1968, the same day as the San Onofre reactor in Southern California, which was shut down for similar economic reasons in 1990; the two reactors were the first full-scale commercial nuclear reactors to operate in the nation. Since San Onofre's shutdown, a handful of other reactors have been shut down because they were not cost-effective.
"This is a surprise because Connecticut Yankee represented the best of the nuclear power industry for its first two decades," Mr. Komanoff said.
A shutdown of Connecticut Yankee is not expected to have much effect on electricity rates for any of the companies that own part of the plant. Besides Northeast Utilities, the owners include the New England Power Company, the United Illuminating Power Company, the Boston Edison Company, the Central Maine Power Company, the Montauk Electric Company, the Cambridge Electric Company and the Central Vermont Public Service Corporation.
"The costs of decommissioning are expected to be offset by being able to buy cheaper energy," Mr. Nericcio said.
Mr. Kenyon, in his statement, said that the decision to shut the plant stemmed from meetings in September of representatives of the utilities in the consortium. The owners analyzed the costs associated with operating and maintaining the plant, and compared those with the cost of purchasing replacement power.
Under many of the scenarios evaluated, Mr. Kenyon said, continuing to run the plant would have saddled the operators with extra costs that ranged from tens of millions of dollars to $100 million, depending on assumptions made about plant operations, expenses and the cost of replacement power.
Moreover, he added that since the last economic analysis, projected fuel costs have dropped even further, while the rate of growth in demand for power has slowed in New England and more efficient technologies are being developed.
"Regardless of the outcome, Connecticut Yankee employees should be proud of the contribution they have made and service they have provided to the people and businesses of New England."

HEADLINE: Mexican Drug Wars Creep Near U.S. Border

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: TIJUANA, Mexico, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The swaggering adolescent in cowboy boots shoved past a stream of American tourists and stepped into the nine lanes of traffic inching through the afternoon heat toward the United States border. Suddenly, he pushed a 9-millimeter pistol through a car window and fired four times at the driver's head.
As the driver slumped bleeding to the seat, the San Ysidro border crossing between Tijuana and San Diego erupted in shrieks. The gunman slid his pistol under his belt, sauntered back to the sidewalk and climbed into a waiting van that sped away up a side street. 
 The shooting last Thursday of a Tijuana man who the police said was a minor drug trafficker was unusual, coming as it did just 50 yards from American soil, under the noses of United States Customs officials. It even seemed to startle the jaded youths who stand at pay telephones, reporting to the Tijuana drug cartel on the carloads of cocaine moving north from the Mexican state of Baja California.
But it has been all but forgotten in the days since as several other Tijuana youths have been killed in a drug war that has also seen the slaying of several senior narcotics officials. The growing violence is rocking Mexico and threatens to spill over into the United States.
"This is the equivalent of what we experienced in Chicago in the 30's," said Alan D. Bersin, the United States Attorney in San Diego. "And given the increasing integration between Baja California and California, it affects us. We're not quite at the point where, when Tijuana sneezes, San Diego catches a cold, but the risks of cross-border violence are certainly perceived."
The violence also threatens Tijuana's economic boom. In recent years foreign businesses, attracted by a minimum wage of only $2.90 a day, have made Tijuana one of the hemisphere's fastest-growing industrial centers. But the drug killings here and the August kidnapping of a Japanese executive have aroused "a great deal of nervousness," Mayor Jose Guadalupe Osuna said.
"We're having to battle harder to get new industries," Mr. Osuna said. "They're asking a lot of questions, and they want us to boost our police presence in the industrial parks."
According to Mexican and American officials, the bloodshed is being driven by a turf war in which rival gangs are muscling in on the Arellano Felix family, whose drug organization has long controlled the Tijuana border, and a parallel conflict raging among corrupt factions within Mexico's Federal Judicial Police.
Seven Mexican officials who have worked on drug cases in Tijuana have been slain in as many months, along with more than a dozen state and municipal police officers and scores of minor traffickers.
The killings last month in Mexico City of two top Mexican commanders who worked closely with American agents in Tijuana to track the Arellanos has forced American officers to tighten security.
"When you work side by side with a comandante who gets killed, you have to be alarmed," an American official said.
The Arellano brothers -- Francisco Rafael, Ramon, Benjamin and Javier, natives of the state of Sinaloa -- settled in Tijuana in the late 1970's, according to documents filed with Benjamin's 1987 indictment on cocaine charges in San Diego. The family took control of the Baja border in 1985, when the trafficker for whom Benjamin was working, Leonardo Contreras, fled Mexico after killing two Mexican police officers.
The Arellano brothers bought Government protection and attained immense wealth, and although their narcotics activities were widely recognized, they mingled openly with the cream of Tijuana society and resorted to violence only infrequently, said Victor Clark, a human rights activist who has studied the narcotics trade here.
But a struggle that broke out in 1992 between the Arellanos and a rival trafficker, Joaquin Guzman Loera, grew into a vicious vendetta. It attracted widespread attention in 1993 after a Roman Catholic cardinal was killed at the Guadalajara airport when Ramon Arellano's gunmen fired on the cardinal's car, mistakenly identifying it as Mr. Guzman's, prosecutors said.
In the crackdown that followed, the authorities arrested Rafael Francisco in December 1993 and confiscated Arellano family properties sprawling all across northwest Mexico, including five ranches, 91 vehicles and 118 houses. Over the years, the other brothers have eluded arrest, despite a reward of about $666,000 for their capture.
But this year, an aggressive federal commander, Ernesto Ibarra Santes, appeared to be closing in. Mr. Ibarra headed a 30-man mobile intelligence unit that with the help of Drug Enforcement Administration agents was focusing on the Arellano organization. On March 1, Mr. Ibarra's unit swept through Tijuana, confiscating 20 houses said to belong to Arellano associates. In another operation on Aug. 5, Mr. Ibarra arrested two top Arellano associates in the central state of Aguascalientes.
As Mr. Ibarra turned up the pressure, a string of current or former Mexican law enforcement officials based in Tijuana were killed.
Then on Aug. 15, as part of a nationwide purge of the federal police, 30 of the 120 officers based in Baja California were dismissed on suspicion of accepting bribes from drug traffickers. Among those let go was the federal police's Baja California commander. Mr. Ibarra was elevated to the job.
On Sept. 13, Mr. Ibarra received a call from Attorney General Antonio Lozano's headquarters, ordering him to report immediately to Mexico City. When Mr. Ibarra arrived in the capital late the same day, no security detail was waiting to escort him, so he left the airport in a cab. Minutes later, a car pulled alongside the taxi and gunmen sprayed it with automatic rifle fire, killing Mr. Ibarra, his two bodyguards and the driver.
The police later found $50,000 in the bullet-riddled taxi, giving rise to speculation that Mr. Ibarra might have been accepting payments from the Arellano brothers' rivals.
On Thursday, amid great fanfare, Mr. Lozano announced the arrest in Mexico City of two men he identified as Arellano lieutenants who had taken part in Mr. Ibarra's murder. Mr. Lozano also vowed to restore order in Tijuana, but American officials said they doubted that the killings would end soon.
"We're not going to get caught in the crossfire," one official said.

HEADLINE: A Rehearsal for 2000

 BODY:
The Vice-Presidential candidates devoted most of their 90-minute debate last night to arguing about Bob Dole's tax plan, the value of government regulation and the future of the inner cities. It was the debate about vision that Mr. Dole and President Clinton might have had this week, but did not.
On the G.O.P. side, the vision on display was mostly that of the Vice-Presidential candidate, Jack Kemp, not his running mate. Comparing Mr. Kemp's passionate defense of the 15 percent tax-cut plan with Mr. Dole's vague explanations of how it would work, voters would have the right to wonder how many members of the Republican ticket actually believe in its most central economic plank. 
 Mr. Kemp's advocacy was the center of last night's debate. He repeatedly envisioned an America where business is unfettered, where the highest tax rate is 25 percent and where the fast-churning economy gives even inner-city residents access to credit and capital to start their own business. Mr. Gore stuck mainly to pointing out the obvious danger of this attractive but "risky" approach.
Those regulations Mr. Kemp dislikes, Mr. Gore noted, help insure workplace safety, clean water and the right of employees to deal with family emergencies without worrying about being fired. The 15 percent tax-cut plan, he said repeatedly, would "blow a hole in the deficit" while sending interest rates skyrocketing. When Mr. Kemp said tax cuts had worked for John Kennedy, Mr. Gore pulled him back to earth by pointing out that Mr. Dole himself had voted against the Kennedy tax cut.
In sum, it was an earnest wonkfest in which Mr. Kemp provided the soaring rhetoric and Mr. Gore scored with a prudent, reality-based view of government. Mr. Dole might have wished for a debate in which Mr. Kemp launched the "character" attacks Mr. Dole has avoided. But Mr. Kemp has his eye on the year 2000 and was not about to sully his chances by becoming Mr. Dole's Doberman. At the beginning of the debate he even announced it was "beneath Bob Dole to go after anyone personally." The announcement was no doubt a shock to the Dole campaign's emerging plan, field-tested this week in New Jersey, to get down and dirty.
Like Mr. Kemp, Mr. Gore hopes to run for President in 2000. The combined pressure of both men's ambitions was enough to smother any high drama. The most frequently used phrase of the evening was "with all due respect." While Mr. Kemp sometimes got tangled up in verbal spaghetti, Mr. Gore was much easier to follow. Yet his slow, didactic tone suggested he sees America as one vast first grade.
But we don't want to be too picky. It was encouraging to see the two men spend so much time fencing about urban policy and the need to extend the benefits of capitalism to every segment of American society. At every opportunity, Mr. Gore reminded the audience that 10.5 million jobs had been created over the last four years. Mr. Kemp seemed to recognize the potency of that number for 1996. But it also seemed clear that both men were thinking that a lot of statistics -- including the No. 1 spot on their tickets -- would be different four years from now. It was a promising rehearsal for those who believe that the politics of substance is worth pursuing, no matter how dull it gets.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Canada Strike Against G.M. Widens as Two Sides Harden

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WINDSOR, Ontario, Oct. 9

 BODY:
A week-old strike by Canadian workers of the General Motors Corporation spread further this evening, as the auto maker's chairman signaled that the company would not quickly back down in the dispute.
John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said the company needed a labor pact that would let it keep cutting costs, notably by selling two parts factories in Canada. "We've got certain things that will cripple the company if we don't get fixed right," he said at a news conference in the Detroit area this afternoon. 
 The Canadian Automobile Workers union, which now has all of its 26,000 G.M. workers on strike, demands that the auto maker accept broad restrictions on its ability to shrink its work force further and buy more parts from outside vendors. The union has offered to let G.M. sell the two factories in question, but only if the buyer is required to pay the employees the same wages and benefits for three years.
G.M. has accepted such an arrangement for past sales of parts factories, but it has refused this time, while also demanding a variety of other departures from the three-year labor contract that the union reached on Sept. 17 with the Chrysler Corporation.
In a brief interview here tonight, Basil E. Hargrove, the Canadian union's president, said, "Jack Smith doesn't know what's going on here, he ought to get in his car and drive over and talk to me."
Two hours after Mr. Smith spoke this afternoon, another 2,460 auto parts workers here and 2,210 workers elsewhere in Canada joined the walkout. Hundreds of workers toted signs, whistled and shouted in 45-degree weather in front of a car-seat factory here this evening.
Union officials and industry analysts warned that the strike could easily last another two or three weeks, eventually threatening more than 100,000 American workers with temporary layoffs.
"It seems to me like positions are slowly hardening -- it appears to me like this one could be a long one, a month," said Joseph Phillippi, an analyst at Lehman Brothers.
Negotiators for G.M. and the Canadian union have met almost every day since the strike began, but for less than an hour at a time, as each side waits for the other to make the next move. "There remains a lot of hard work and a lot of very tough ground to cover before a settlement can be reached," said D. Stewart Low, a G.M. spokesman.
The strike has had little effect so far on G.M.'s operations in the United States, where many assembly plants rely on parts shipped from Canada. The strike began on Oct. 2 at Canadian assembly plants that produce only a few parts for the United States operations, spreading on Sunday night to a 5,300-employee engine and transmission factory in St. Catharines, Ontario.
Dean W. Munger, G.M. Canada's vice president for personnel and top labor negotiator, has said that the company accumulated extra stocks of some parts in preparation for a strike. Tom Klipstine, a company spokesman, confirmed today that G.M. had leased warehouse space in preparation for the strike and moved finished parts out of factories before picket lines were established.
But Mr. Klipstine cautioned that the quantity of parts in storage was not large, and certainly not enough to meet G.M.'s needs for a month.
On Monday, as a result of the strike, G.M. temporarily laid off 1,050 of 4,000 workers at an engine plant near Buffalo, and 800 of the 6,000 workers at a transmission factory in Ypsilanti, Mich. G.M. has not announced any layoffs since then, but as many as 400 more workers in Ypsilanti may be let go later this week, Mr. Klipstine said.
Wesley R. Brown, an automotive production analyst at CSM Forecasting in Farmington Hills, Mich., was skeptical that G.M. would be able to keep its assembly plants in the United States open for long. "By the last week of October, it would be likely that almost all of the North American operations could be down, could be almost completely down," he said.
In March, G.M. temporarily laid off 176,000 workers when a 17-day strike at two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, forced an almost complete shutdown of North American auto assembly operations and the closing of many G.M. parts factories. The 6,000 outside suppliers of auto parts to G.M. also furloughed a huge number of employees then.
G.M. is the largest corporate employer in the United States and the world's largest industrial company in terms of sales. In addition to state unemployment benefits, laid-off G.M. workers would draw supplemental unemployment benefits of $220 to $330 a week from the company. The combination of benefits is equal to 70 percent of their pay for a 40-hour week -- still a sizable pay cut, since most G.M. workers usually work a lot of overtime as well.
The auto maker's contract with the United Automobile Workers union did not require it to pay supplemental unemployment benefits in March to workers laid off because of the Dayton strike. But G.M. is obligated to pay supplemental benefits to American workers who are laid off because of the Canadian strike, provided that the American workers meet the fairly easy state standards for drawing unemployment benefits.
Parts suppliers, which make everything from seats to trunk carpets, usually do not pay supplemental unemployment benefits, so their workers would suffer a sharper drop in pay.
Analysts have already begun lowering their estimates of G.M.'s fourth-quarter profits to reflect the strike's cost. Ronald A. Glantz, a Dean Witter analyst, forecast the strike would last three weeks and cut after-tax profits by about $450 million, or 60 cents a share.
But G.M. should be able to recoup about two-thirds of the loss by raising production next year, he added. G.M. is already producing its highly profitable sport utility vehicles and full-size pickup trucks as fast as possible, but few of its car factories are running at full capacity.
The Canadian strike expanded this evening to include the 1,300-employee car-seat and door factory here; an 1,160-employee transmission factory also in Windsor; a 450-worker auto-parts distribution plant in Woodstock, Ontario, and a 1,760-employee diesel-locomotive and armored-car factory in London, Ontario.
The car-seat plant here assembles seats for a Cadillac factory across the river in Detroit. Mr. Brown at CSM predicted that the factory would close within a few days. G.M. is trying to sell the car-seat factory and a bumper factory in Oshawa, Ontario.
Mr. Smith said that G.M.'s balance sheet, which holds $13 billion in cash, was strong enough to withstand the strike.
 In interviews tonight and at a strike rally here last weekend, workers said they had prepared for a strike, many building up savings with lots of overtime. But a few workers were nervous. "We have three kids, a house -- if there's a strike, it'll be tough," said Jeff Brown, a 36-year-old seat-belt assembly worker here.
Strike pay for Canadian workers is only a fifth of their regular pay. The Canadian Automobile Workers union says it has enough money in its strike fund for an eight-week walkout, and can raise more through bank loans or by mortgaging its headquarters.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Comments by Fed Governor Send Treasury Prices Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
After waffling through most of the trading session, prices of Treasury securities deteriorated yesterday after comments by Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor.
Speaking from text to a community banking conference in Dallas, Mr. Lindsey said: "While the commitment of the Federal Reserve to a low inflation environment is unwavering, I cannot assure you that all politicians feel the same way. Nor can I assure you that sustaining the fight against inflation will not mean a temporary rise in interest rates at some point in the future." 
 Traders interpreted those remarks as being bearish. Although prices had opened sharply higher in thin trading volume, influenced by overseas buying, they ended on the decline. The 30-year bond fell 10/32, to a price of 99 1/32, sending its yield up to 6.83 percent, from 6.80 percent on Tuesday.
According to some analysts, prices had fallen as a result of the slow distribution of Tuesday's 10-year Treasury note auction, and that prompted overseas traders to buy intermediate maturities at prices that were too inexpensive to pass up.
Wholesale trade data for August, which were released yesterday morning, were within expectations, providing continued evidence of steady inventory growth through the third quarter that is likely to increase third-quarter gross domestic product. The August wholesale trade report showed a nine-tenths of 1 percent decline in sales and a five-tenths of 1 percent increase in inventories. It had little impact because the market is more interested in tomorrow's retail and manufacturing data.
"The highlight of the report," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, "was the five-tenths of 1 percent increase in wholesale inventories, which lends further credence to the concept that inventories are being replenished during the third quarter following the sharp slowdown in accumulation during the first half."
More important for the bond market will be tomorrow's release of the Producer Price Index and retail sales. Mr. Fine said retail sales in September were likely to show an improvement from the lackluster levels of the prior three months, although not to the extent of suggesting a rapid acceleration in consumer spending.
"The P.P.I. will be carefully noted as always, but barring any upside surprise from the market's anticipated two-tenths of 1 percent rise, focus will immediately turn to next Wednesday's more important Consumer Price Index," he said. "Certainly last week's unexpectedly sharp decline in nonfarm payrolls, while a below-trend deviation, helped to alleviate much of the concern about an overheating labor market, and also helped reduce some of the apprehension that typically builds up in front of the price indexes and retail sales. In addition, it gives the Fed more latitude to continue to keep its monetary policy on hold despite the Federal Open Market Committee's bias toward tightening."
In the corporate bond market the AT&T Capital Corporation priced $3.1 billion of global asset-backed securities yesterday through underwriters led by Nomura International and Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The proceeds will be used to help pay for its purchase from the AT&T Corporation by a group of leasing companies and managers. Sale of the unit, formed 11 years ago to finance phone equipment sales, was made as the long-distance company carried out plans to split into three public companies.
Yesterday's sale was divided into five parts and sold through a Capita Equipment Receivable Trust, with the average life of the securities that are backed by equipment loans ranging from 0.46 year to 3.81 years. The securities were priced to yield from minus 4 basis points off the six-month London interbank offered rate to 49 basis points above the 6.125 percent Treasury note due July 2000. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.) Except for a small amount of A-rated subordinated debt, the whole issue is rated triple-A by the major bond houses.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Shunning the Sound Bite

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

 BODY:
Last Sunday night, Bob Dole did not do it. For whatever reason -- lack of passion, strategic miscalculation or oversight in the heat of the moment -- he failed to make much of a case for his proposed 15 percent tax cut in debating President Clinton.
So last night, Jack Kemp did it for him. Facing Vice President Al Gore in a debate televised nationally from St. Petersburg, Fla., the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee put heart and soul -- and a torrent of words -- into an effort to sell the tax cut to the country and to prove that it would foster more rapid growth, much as he had helped earlier to sell the plan to Mr. Dole. 
 Together, Mr. Gore and Mr. Kemp confronted the tax issue head on and laid their cases pro and con before the electorate in some detail. They explored its impact on the environment, on blacks and on the inner cities. Seldom in the image-driven, sound-bite campaigns of recent years has a single topic received such extensive exposure at the height of a Presidential campaign.
"We cannot just run the clock out on the 20th century," Mr. Kemp said, arguing again and again that every time in this century that the United States had cut income taxes, revenues had increased and the economy had grown. A tax cut now, followed in short order by a thoroughgoing rewriting of the Federal tax code, he declared, would "take the country roaring into the 21st century."
He painted a picture of a country overtaxed, overregulated and overworked because the economy was growing far too slowly under Mr. Clinton. The "haves are doing well," he conceded, but he argued that "the have-nots are not."
It was precisely what the Republican leadership, which considers the tax cut the party's best hope for victory, had wanted. Before the debate, Alan Novak, the Pennsylvania party chairman, said that if not Mr. Dole, someone else had to rebut Mr. Clinton's criticisms of the Republican tax program, and added: "That's right up Jack's alley."
But Mr. Gore did not stand idly by while Mr. Kemp defended the tax cut, and after 90 minutes of back-and-forth, he seemed to have held his own. He repeatedly branded the Dole-Kemp program "a risky, $550 billion tax scheme" that would "blow a hole in the deficit" and "knock our economy off track."
When Mr. Kemp said his plan was not "trickle down" economics but as propulsive for the economy as Niagara Falls, Mr. Gore replied that the Republican proposals would "put the economy in a barrel and send it over the falls." He insisted the proposals would mean cuts in Medicare and other social programs.
The Republican nominee brought the greater energy and fervor to the debate, though he sometimes got tangled in his statistics and syntax.
But even if Mr. Kemp proves to have prevailed in the eyes of most of those who watched, he may not have changed many votes. Few people, academic studies have shown, vote on the basis of their views of the Vice Presidential candidates. Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp trail by 10 to 15 percentage points in most polls, with less than four weeks left until Election Day.
Mr. Dole had also been criticized by many in his party for failing to exploit the so-called character issue, and he had berated himself for not pressing it effectively when he confronted President Clinton.
But given a chance at the beginning of the session by the moderator, Jim Lehrer of PBS, to discuss any "ethical differences" between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole, Mr. Kemp spurned it with the comment that it was "beneath Bob Dole to go after anyone personally."
The two men did discuss abortion, including so-called "partial birth abortions," the form of late-term abortion that Congressional Republicans tried to ban in their last session, a subject that was absent from the Presidential debate. Mr. Dole's opposition to abortion is believed to be a big element in his difficulty in attracting support among women. Mr. Kemp conceded that there was no chance of passing a Constitutional amendment outlawing abortion, even though the Republican platform calls for one and suggested that persuasion and discussion were needed.
Nothing that was said appeared likely to change the minds of suburban Republican and independent women with whom Mr. Dole has failed to connect.
A major question now is whether Mr. Dole, who has been taking a harder anti-Clinton line in his radio and television advertising and on the stump in the last few days, will follow through in that vein in the final Presidential debate, which is scheduled for next Wednesday in San Diego. He had promised to do so, but Mr. Kemp's avoidance of personal attacks put that tactic in doubt.
Old friends and old Congressional colleagues, Mr. Gore and Mr. Kemp smiled frequently, joked with each other and never came close to losing their tempers. Mr. Kemp kept his famous prolixity under control, though he could not resist using the term "Judeo-Christian" a lot, and the Vice President, who is noted for a wooden speaking style, managed occasionally to sound fairly relaxed, even if he used the phrase "with all due respect" so often it sounded like a recording.
The Vice President praised Mr. Kemp as an effective voice against "coarseness and incivility" in the United States during his long career.
If, as so widely suggested this week, the confrontation in Florida last night was a preview of the 2000 Presidential campaign, it will be a very different matter from those of the recent past, full of discussions of enterprise zones and hydrocarbons and economic theory and the Greek roots of English words.
Mr. Gore rattled off long lists of what he termed the accomplishments of the Clinton Administration, to which Mr. Kemp replied that it was not nearly enough. The harshest words were Mr. Kemp's, when he accused the Democrats of demagoguery for asserting that the Republicans wanted to cut Medicare benefits.
But he also went after the Administration on foreign policy, another subject largely absent so far. Mr. Clinton, he said, substituted ambiguity for decision-making, and had much less success in Bosnia, Haiti and Mexico than he claimed.

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Credit for Shrinking Deficit

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
The nation's budget deficit sank to a 15-year low of $109 billion in fiscal 1996, two Republican lawmakers said today in taking credit for the drop.
The announcement, pre-empting the Clinton administration's planned release of the figure later this month, came from Senator Pete Domenici of New Mexico and Representative John Kasich of Ohio. 
 The Administration in July projected the deficit at $117 billion and, a month later, the Congressional Budget Office predicted $116 billion.
Lawrence Haas, a spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget, said the Republicans' figure was "quite conceivable," but he attributed the decline to the President's 1993 economic program.

HEADLINE: Retailers Dreaming Of Bright Holiday Season;
The Bet Is on High Consumer Demand and Low Inventory

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Here is all that has to happen for retailers to have their best Christmas in years: No more than an inch of snow can blanket the Northeast in December; the stock market must continue to go gangbusters; stores will have to have whisper-thin stacks of inventory, and shoppers -- well trained to buy stuff only when it is on sale -- must suddenly agree to pay full price just for the fun of it. This with five fewer shopping days between Thanksgiving and Christmas.
All those things, of course, are not likely to fall into place quite so neatly. 
 But retail experts agree that this could still be a decent holiday season, because at least part of that wish list will almost certainly come true. Add in the fact that Presidential election years are traditionally great for retailing no matter who wins, along with high levels of consumer confidence and new video games and apparel styles, and the prospects are even better.
"I think it will be a good Christmas," said Carl Steidtmann, an economist at Management Horizons, a consulting unit of Price Waterhouse L.L.P. "Retailers are set up to be more profitable. Levels of apparel inventory are very low, which puts less pressure on them to promote. There is a change between the balance of supply and demand that is better than we have seen in a long time."
Christmas is always the make-or-break season for retailers, and with the industry mired in tough times, it could well determine which American retailers will live and which will bite the dust. Merry-Go-Round has gone out of business and the Petrie Stores Corporation and the Caldor Corporation and others have filed for bankruptcy in the last year.
Indeed, it is highly unlikely that retailers could fare any worse this Christmas than they did in 1995, which -- barring recessions -- was the worst in a decade. The question is whether retailers can really reach the stellar sales gains of nearly 8 percent enjoyed in 1992, a goal some retail experts say is attainable, while others are keeping their growth estimates closer to a respectable 5 percent.
Some of last year's themes remain. High-end retailers like Saks Fifth Avenue, owned by Saks Holdings Inc., Neiman Marcus, a unit of Harcourt General Inc., and luxury jewelry stores are positioned to rake in the cash from shoppers flush with gains from Wall Street's tireless bull market. Those retailers also have a monopoly on brand-name purses, belts and shoes, which shoppers have once again gone gaga for, just as they did a decade or so ago. "It is going to be much more intense this year in terms of brand awareness," Rose Marie Bravo, president of Saks Fifth Avenue, said. "We are really promoting anything 'lux.' Gucci, Chanel, Prada -- all the signature items."
On the opposite end, discount stores are also looking forward to a good season, as shoppers continue to hunt for bargains at the stores that have survived discounting's mergers and bankruptcy filings.
Merchants in the middle, particularly specialty stores that dot the country's malls, are still struggling. "The middle ground does not seem to be performing too well," Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, said. Mall-based stores -- ranging from the Limited to bath shops like Nature's Elements to record stores like those owned by the Musicland Stores Corporation, which announced earlier this week that it had hired Smith Barney to help it explore strategic alternatives -- have all had a tough few years, and are facing Christmas fearfully.
Toy sellers, bruised last year by the lack of fresh products, are already benefiting from the arrival of Nintendo 64. It went on sale in the United States on Sept. 29, and 350,000 were sold in the first five days. And tie-ins from films like "Space Jam," starring Michael Jordan, and Disney's live-action "101 Dalmatians," are expected to do well.
Sellers of educational toys -- stores with goofy names like Noodle Kidoodle and Zany Brainy -- have carved out only the tiniest piece of the market in recent years. But for the first Christmas ever, they are coming into their own.
"These stores are developing major hits of their own," said Frank Reysen Jr., editor of the trade journal Playthings, citing Beanie Babies and Stomp Rockets as runaway best sellers. Of course, Barbie, in all her incarnations, is flying out of conventional toy stores.
Even housewares shops, which had a mixed year, are looking for a good season. Several analysts call Williams-Sonoma Inc.'s stores hot, especially the Pottery Barn unit, which redesigned many stores this year to feature hip urban furniture at affordable prices.
Retailers will show "varying levels of performance," said Matthew Fassler, a retail analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, "but I am not looking for any disasters."
Shoppers have been pretty much sitting on their wallets since last Christmas. But it is not just an array of new offerings and a bunch of family members who would not take kindly to being forgotten at the holidays that will entice them into stores.
For one thing, pent-up demand for all types of goods seems inevitable, largely because retail spending continues has so far defied all other economic trends. While consumer confidence hit a six-year high in September and housing and car sales continue to be strong, retail spending, or same-store sales, has lagged month after month. When retailers report their results today for stores open at least a year -- known as same-store sales -- the numbers are expected to be mediocre at best.
"It is hard to reconcile soft consumer spending numbers with the broader economic picture," Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, said. "I just don't think the soft numbers can last."
Further, analysts and economists said, a stock market that remains strong in the third quarter and generally robust economic growth will help. "We are going to see stronger spending in the months ahead," Mr. Crandall said. "And if you go to a mall, you will see that the Christmas season started last week."
But just in case shoppers are not as eager as everyone hopes, retailers have taken measures to see that they are not served up a cash register full of coal. In an effort to reduce preseason promotions and after-Christmas sales, most are planning to keep inventory levels low.
"So far retailers have been more cautious with inventory levels in 1996 than they were at this time in '95," said Susan Silverstein, a retail analyst at Gruntal & Company. "Despite the fact that there was some buying resurgence in spring," she said, they did not load up on goods, so they can expect decent profits.
Most retailers insist they will not put their wares on sale before the holidays, but they are headed for the usual showdown against tough-minded shoppers enamored of sale signs. This year, as always, stores will almost certainly lose a few rounds of that game.
For example, toy retailers, still feeling last year's pressure from discounters, are expected to begin sales right after Thanksgiving. Some department stores and other apparel stores, while expected to enjoy renewed consumer interest in fall fashions, will also hit the price gun, retail experts said. "Promotions are going to be rampant," said Mr. Barnard, the consultant. "I have no doubt about it."
And while almost all the experts said there were still far too many stores for too few shoppers, the number of stores that have gone out of business has increased 7 percent for the year, according to Dun & Bradstreet reports, which has eliminated some competition.
Other stores are already on shaky ground. County Seat Inc., a private jeans store based in Dallas, has defaulted on bond interest payments and is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Musicland is also on thin ice, some analysts say, and recently retained an investment bank to help it explore its options.
There are other business fundamentals at work. Catalogue retailers got the cold shoulder from shoppers last season. But they also faced big increases in postage and paper costs, forcing them to limit the number of catalogues they sent, and this took a bite out of profits.
But with paper prices down, sometimes by nearly 40 percent, brace yourself for more catalogues, said Mark Marcon, a retail analyst at Cleary Gull Reiland & McDevitt in Milwaukee. "The expected return per catalogue doesn't have to be as high now," so revenues should rise, he said.
Anna Schryver, a spokeswoman for Lands' End Inc., the homey catalogue merchant in Dodgeville, Wis., said she is looking toward a good season, though she declined to give actual sales predictions. Last year, the company was biting its knuckles and hoping for the best, all while cursing postal rates. Mr. Marcon has increased his fourth-quarter earnings estimate for the company to 83 cents a share, from last year's 77 cents.
What could stand between retailers and shoppers' pocketbooks?
Well, there is the nettlesome issue of personal debt. While a three-year streak of high growth in consumer borrowing has seemed to slow, there is at least the perception that it is out of control, analysts said. Perhaps more troubling, personal bankruptcy filings have risen roughly 25 percent so far this year.
But many economists said the dangers of debt were exaggerated. "We are far enough away from the levels of debt of the late 80's," Mr. Crandall said, that it is hard "to make the case that people are tapped out."
Also, retailers have been lamenting a late Thanksgiving -- it falls on Nov. 28 this year, making the official shopping season five days shorter than last year. While this seems like a reasonable fear on paper, most retailers do not expect people to write off anyone on their shopping list to make up the time. What it might mean is fewer impulse purchases, simply because there is less time and quicker markdowns from retailers.
"The retailer will play a little bit of chicken with the customer to see how high the resistance level is to full price," Ms. Silverstein, the analyst, said. "But with five less shopping days, they can't extend that game as far as they would probably like."
So while many analysts are looking at 1992 for a benchmark for the season, many more said they will be happy to see a modest 3 to 5 percent sales increase, compared with last year. "We can live with 3 percent," Allen I. Questrom, chairman of Federated Department Stores, said. "We have learned over the years to make our projections smaller."
For a stocking stuffer, here are some oddball facts: Golf clothing and accessories are expected to sell splendidly. Cigar smoking, which had seemed to be a flash in the pan, has spawned its own retail boomlet. Humidors, cigars and other related supplies are hot. Mr. Potato Head, the poinsettia of Christmas toys, will now be sold in the form of a back scratcher. It can't be worse than last year's Kermit the Frog perfume.
