SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 2588 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Touring the Canyons of Money and Dreams

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
YOU can get lost in lower Manhattan. The streets are not named after numbers. They disregard the Manhattan grid. They bend, twist and turn back on themselves, creating looming, demented perspectives on a scale Dr. Caligari never dreamed of. On Broad Street, home of the New York Stock Exchange, New York's usual system of street addresses is turned upside down: the numbers mount higher as you proceed south. This escape from logic affords immense delight, an oasis of irregularity within a city that offers little relief from the rigid, rectilinear grip of the civil engineer.
On Sunday, New Yorkers will have a rare opportunity to lose themselves within the inner recesses of a financial citadel. Nine of the area's most impressive buildings will be holding open house. Organized by the Association for Downtown New York, a civic improvement group, the event will enable people to see interiors that are ordinarily screened from public view. Included on the itinerary are such gems as the Red Room at the Bank of New York, a dazzling Art Deco interior of glass mosaic; 55 Wall Street, a classical temple with a Wedgwood dome that Donald J. Trump may turn into a House of Blues, and the International Commercial Bank of China, an exquisitely restored building that once housed the New York Chamber of Commerce. Beyond the chance to glimpse some spectacular spaces, the open house is an opportunity to see this city within the city at a time of momentous transition. 
 Lower Manhattan has long been a favorite weekend destination for urban romantics. The streets, bereft of traders, come into their own as the canyons to which they have often been compared. The whole district takes on the character of a natural wonder, a Grand Canyon of human creation. The strange mix of architectural styles could be an assemblage of natural rock formations. They have been carved out not by wind and water but by history and money, a substance that, in this part of town, is virtually a force of nature.
Visitors who lose themselves in these streets have entered into their ethos. The place itself embodies a condition of lostness, or, rather, a sense of will exerted against the unknown. Even more than the rest of the city, lower Manhattan sits atop a foundation of pure speculation. This was true when the place was called Nieuw Amsterdam, and settlers raised wooden pikes to protect themselves from the overpowering newness of the New World. It remains the case today, as the city calculates how to resist the centrifugal force of a new economic order. Lower Manhattan is now an existential proposition. As recently as 10 years ago, financiers needed Wall Street as urgently as Willie Sutton needed banks, and for the same reason. That's where the money was. This is no longer exactly the case. Global currency now floats around in cyberspace, blips on a screen.
Though the stock market rebounded from the 1987 collapse, the same cannot be said for the financial district. Thousands of jobs have been lost. Many buildings stand vacant, or only partly occupied. Shops have closed. Chase Manhattan Plaza, for years a symbol of the Rockefeller family's commitment to the area's future, is no longer the bank's headquarters, a casualty of Chase's merger with Chemical Bank.
But the area is on the upswing. Buildings too small to accommodate large trading floors are being converted to residential use. Across from the Stock Exchange, the Information Technology Center is attracting refugees from Silicon Alley. A health club now conducts aerobics classes in what was once a grand ground-floor banking hall.

God and Mammon
Sunday's open house, a self-guided tour that may be conducted with the assistance of an excellent booklet produced for the occasion, starts with the Woolworth Building, at 233 Broadway. As a point of departure, the site is geographically and historically apt. Across the street from City Hall Park, the 800-foot tower sits at the border between the civic center and the financial district. And it introduces the major theme that runs through the entire tour: the use of architecture to mask the brutalities of material acquisition within the trappings of religion.
Completed in 1913, the building was designed by Cass Gilbert in the Gothic style, with tracery-encrusted walls, Tudor-arch entrances and a lobby full of gargoyles. The idiom reflected Frank Woolworth's allegiance to Christianity and capitalism, not necessarily in that order.
In its day, it was called "the Cathedral of Commerce," not by Woolworth himself, but by an admiring minister who intended no irony. The building, at its completion the world's tallest, stands as a reminder that the desire to reconcile high and low culture was not a post-modern invention. Here, Woolworth's nickels and dimes were piled up to an edifice that seeks to rival Chartres.

Gargoyles to Greeks
At 195 Broadway, the second stop on the tour, Gothic gargoyles are exchanged for Greek gods. Now known as the Kalikow Building, the edifice was originally designed as the headquarters for AT&T. Though the architectural style differs from that of the Woolworth Building, the message is the same: Making money is an act of faith. Embrace the faith or go to hell.
The lobby is the building's main distinction. An extraordinary hall of columns, the lobby inducts the visitor into a modern version of the Panhellenic procession, an Athenian ritual dedicated to civic prosperity. The religious effect is due not only to the hypnotic rhythm of the columns, but also to the soft light filtered through alabaster in the lobby's chandeliers.
The building's exterior is less memorable, especially since the abduction of "Golden Boy," the gilded allegorical figure of Electricity that stood upon its pinnacle. The statue was removed in the 1980's and shipped uptown to be boxed inside the lobby of the "Chippendale" skyscraper that Philip Johnson designed as AT&T's new headquarters. It was replaced by a gold ball, a sad prosthetic stump.

Gothic Updated
One Wall Street is an anomaly. Typically, Art Deco architects aimed for a streamlined classicism. Here, the intention was to update the Gothic style. Now owned by the Bank of New York, the building was erected in 1931 by Irving Trust, formerly headquartered at the Woolworth Building. In his design for 1 Wall Street, Ralph Walker tried to transfer the Gothic idea into 20th-century terms.
The Red Room, originally the ground-floor reception room, was the work of Hildreth Meiere, an artist who specialized in ecclesiastical commissions. The soaring room, with walls that create the rippling effect of a Cubist painting, is encrusted with brilliant mosaics of red and gold. Ostensibly abstract, the patterns nonetheless convey Gothic aspiration, with golden wing forms that appear to flutter near the ceiling.

The Spirit of Zen
Chase Manhattan Plaza presents perhaps the most exotic religious association of all. There, in a circular pit, Isamu Noguchi sought to recreate the spirit of Zen. Noguchi denied that the design was a Japanese garden, and properly so. Conspicuously outfitted with plumbing that enables water to variously spray, bubble and gurgle over the arrangement of stones, this is clearly as much a modern work as the tall International Style tower that looms above it.
Still, the patterns made by the cobblestone paving, and the natural rocks grouped upon it, were clearly inspired by the famous rock garden at Kyoto's ancient temple of Ryoanji. And it's a great East-West moment to see this image of non-attachment recalled in the midst of the money-changers. What is the sound of one coin clinking? Within the tower itself, designed by Gordon Bunshaft in 1960, a recently renovated lobby gleams beneath a silver leaf ceiling.
One of the world's great skyscrapers is 70 Pine Street. A downtown companion to the Chrysler Building, this is one of the few towers that actually capture the pulse of Jazz Age New York, a period that radically changed the skyline.
The 65-story tower, formerly the home of the Cities Service Company, was built on the eve of the Depression, but there's no hint of hard times in its exuberant vertical thrust. Tiers of curved parapets mount toward the crown like a great blast from a brass orchestra. The crown itself, a cube of glass, is an immense piece of Deco jewelry, a Cartier diamond in the sky.
It is shocking, however, to realize that this building, along with most of those presented on this tour, is not designated a landmark. Indeed, scandalously few buildings in lower Manhattan have been awarded landmark designation. The reason is obvious. The owners of these buildings have the city over a barrel. They don't want the limitations imposed by that status. And the city isn't in a position to turn a deaf ear when companies threaten to relocate to New Jersey.

Barricades Are Up
There are barricades on Wall Street, metal fences policed by security guards who give the best fish-eye in town. Officially, the barricades are there to keep terrorists from attacking the Stock Exchange. In fact, the barricades have been set up not only to prevent terrorists from getting in but also to prevent the Stock Exchange from getting out. There have been rumblings that this nerve center of finance, cramped in its historic Broad Street temple, might have to move, an option too hideous for the city to contemplate.
It's useful to be reminded that the owners of these buildings aren't fooled for one moment by their religious trappings. Still, the barricades don't detract from the riotous sense of fantasy that the buildings themselves embody.
One aim of the open house is to demonstrate architecture's power to turn money into dreams: The blue gas flame that glowed at night from the crown of the Standard Oil Building on lower Broadway. The "moonbeam" technology employed at the Cities Service Building, an experimental technique in which radio waves, transmitted from the tower, were bounced off the moon. The opening festivities at the Woolworth Building, in which President Woodrow Wilson touched a telegraph key in Washington to set the building ablaze with electric light. Even the strange combination of morbidity and pretension that would cause Bankers Trust to place a replica of Mausolus's tomb, the original mausoleum, atop its tower at 14 Wall Street.
To a degree, of course, lower Manhattan's architectural fantasies are deceptions, acts of urban sleight of hand designed to disguise the cruder aspects of profit-taking. But how masterfully entertaining these disguises contrive to be. Inspiring, too; spiritually uplifting almost despite themselves. The profits are made and lost many times over. The fantasies endure.
 
Architectural Gems, and More, to See
 
The lobbies and halls of nine buildings in lower Manhattan, many of which are usually closed to the public, will be open on Sunday from noon to 5 P.M. for self-guided tours, sponsored by the Alliance for Downtown New York. LENGTH: 178 words

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Drop to 5-Week Low

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
First-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 22,000 last week to the lowest level in five weeks, partly because of the return of workers laid off after hurricanes in late summer.
New applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 319,000, down from a revised 341,000 for the week ended Sept. 28, the Labor Department said today. The late September figure was first reported at 340,000. 
 It was the smallest number since claims totaled 317,000 the week ended Aug. 31.
A spokeswoman for the Labor Department attributed much of the decline to workers returning from temporary layoffs caused by the storms.
Many analysts had expected claims to remain unchanged from the previous week, noting signs that job creation had slowed recently.
The four-week moving average of new claims dropped by 2,500, to 332,250, last week from 334,750 a week earlier. It was the lowest since 328,750 in the period ended Sept. 21.
Many analysts prefer to track the less volatile four-week average because it smooths out the spikes in the weekly reports.

HEADLINE: No Bark, No Bites

BYLINE: By Christopher Buckley; Christopher Buckley is the editor of Forbes FYI.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Adm. James Stockdale's startled "Who am I? Why am I here?" was the most memorable moment of the 1992 Vice-Presidential debate. Wednesday night's showdown between Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp produced nothing to match it.
The debate was a model of decorum; within minutes phrases like "with all due respect" and "my friend Al" were flying through the air like cruise mistletoes. The Kemp camp did not try to psych out Mr. Gore by seating the head of Philip Morris in the front row; the Gore people did not recruit Richard Darman, the Reagan Administration's budget director, to glower at his old rival, Mr. Kemp. 
 Fight fans the world over must have thrilled to hear the Vice President, sounding like a St. Albans School prefect, tut-tutting that the expectorating miscreant Roberto Alomar of the Baltimore Orioles should have been "severely disciplined," and then thanking Mr. Kemp for promoting civility.
"Well I thank you, Al," replied Mr. Kemp, "and I mean that very, very sincerely."
Mr. Gore speaks so deliberately you get the feeling he's under the impression that English is your second language. "Here's . . . how . . . we . . . plan . . . to . . . do . . . that." You savvy tuition tax credits?
He can take an inherently dramatic moment -- the night American troops were sent into Haiti -- and make it sound like this: "When that dictator got the news from his spies outside the gate that all these planes were taking off, he said, 'Let's get out of here' . . . I was so proud of our President in the way he handled that, and the result so far is excellent." Bill and Al's Excellent Deployment.
As for the Mexican bailout, I had no idea we'd made $500 million on the deal. We must do this more often.
Mr. Kemp is genuinely driven by the power of ideas, even if they occasionally help to produce deficits of $3 trillion. Mr. Gore is phlegmatic; Mr. Kemp is pneumatic. He gets so excited -- thank goodness someone does -- that his chest heaves and swells to the point where you think one of those creatures from the movie "Alien" is going to pop out, squeak "With all due respect," clamp its tentacles over your face and lecture you comatose about empowerment zones.
The best sound bites? Certainly Mr. Kemp's admonition that gentlemen do not "bomb before breakfast." (As William Kristol, the editor of The Weekly Standard, pointed out afterward, "What does it mean to be a Republican if you can't bomb before breakfast?")
Mr. Gore got off a freeze-dried (just add saliva) bite. "The problem with this version of Niagara Falls," he said, apropos Mr. Kemp's metaphor for unfettered free enterprise, "is that Senator Dole and Mr. Kemp would put the American economy in a barrel and send it over the falls." Not bad, although those who build bridges to the 21st century ought to watch the Niagara Falls jokes.
The debate left little material for video editors to regale us with in 2000, should these two men meet again as Presidential candidates. Foot-in-mouth-wise, the debate was a disappointment. No one talked of "Democrat wars" or compared himself to John F. Kennedy. Even the bloopers were minor-league. Said Mr. Kemp in an all-embracing moment: "African-Americans, Asian-Americans, Latino-Americans, female Americans."
Maybe the video archivists can make a little mischief out of something else. A friend of mine -- a Democrat, as it happens -- said that at one point he distinctly saw a fly buzzing about the Vice President, and reported a brief, delicious moment when Mr. Gore's eyes crossed as they attempted to follow it, with excellent result.

HEADLINE: China's Endangered Democrats

 BODY:
While the Clinton Administration is busy these days repairing relations with China, it cannot ignore Beijing's continuing abuse of citizens who speak out for wider democratic freedom. Yesterday the State Department rightly protested the latest wave of Chinese arrests. American concerns also need to be conveyed personally by top Administration officials.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher will travel to China next month to begin planning for an exchange of Presidential visits expected to take place in 1997 if President Clinton is re-elected. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Christopher should make clear their concern over the abuse of Chinese dissidents. 
 China does not like to hear criticism of its human rights record. But Washington has a responsibility to tell Beijing that China's hopes for economic expansion and political stability are poorly served by its cruel persecution of anyone who publicly challenges the party line.
A high-level party gathering this week launched another campaign to tighten public order and defend Communist values. On Tuesday the authorities picked up Liu Xiaobo, a literary critic, for asking party leaders to honor their promises of free speech and assembly, and a day later sentenced him without trial to three years in a labor camp. Yesterday they notified relatives of Wang Dan, a leader of the 1989 student democracy movement, to prepare for a trial in the next few days. He could face seven years' imprisonment. Mr. Wang has been held without formal charges for 17 months.
Meanwhile Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent advocate of democracy, is now serving the harsh new 14-year sentence imposed on him last year. He had already spent 16 years in prison and secret detention for his peaceful political advocacy. Bao Tong, a high government official in the reform era of the late 1980's, has completed the seven-year prison term he was sentenced to after the Tiananmen Square crackdown, but continues to be held in a restricted government compound.
Washington needs to keep channels of communication open to a major military and economic power like China. But one important use of those channels is to convey how strongly Americans feel about democratic freedoms and the protection of human rights.

HEADLINE: Nobels as a Lagging Indicator

 BODY:
It is gratifying that American scientists have once again dominated the Nobel Prizes for science and economics. Sweden's Royal Academy of Sciences announced that three Americans shared the Nobel Prize in Physics and that two other Americans shared the Chemistry Prize with a British scientist. Another American was named co-winner of the award in economics.
Nobody is naive enough to believe that spawning the world's leading economists will guarantee the world's most robust economy. But the Nobel science prizes are often taken as a measure of a nation's scientific prowess. Even so, they are lagging indicators, honoring pioneering work performed years ago. The physicists David Lee, Douglas Osheroff and Robert Richardson were cited for superfluidity studies done a quarter-century ago. The chemists Robert Curl, Richard Smaller and the Briton Sir Harold Kroto won for their discovery a decade ago of a new form of carbon. 
 The Nobel Prizes are thus a measure of past greatness, not of current or future excellence. These latest awards come at a time when basic research expenditures in America, adjusted for inflation, are actually falling slightly, with worse projected to come. The deficit-reduction efforts endorsed by both major political parties will primarily hit civilian discretionary programs, with a big chunk almost certainly coming from research budgets. Research will be a tempting target because the impact might not be noticeable until, years hence, no Americans grace the Nobel victory stand.

HEADLINE: The Heavy Burden of Low Rates;
Small Japanese Savers Find the Return Barely Worth It

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 10

 BODY:
Gone are the days when Hisashi Ishigaki could spend the fruits of his bank savings on home repairs and new shirts. Now, the interest he earns barely buys a daily cup of tea.
True, Mr. Ishigaki, a 67-year-old retired auto engineer, siphoned off some of his $100,000 nest egg to pay down his mortgage and buy a new car. But these days, rock-bottom interest rates in Japan are barely keeping pace with inflation, and so his savings are quickly evaporating. 
 For decades, ordinary Japanese have been parking their money in the bank and watching it grow, often doubling in 12 years. Today, though, when Americans complain about the 4.5 to 5 percent they get on six-month certificates of deposit, the Japanese are eking out one-quarter of 1 percent, one-eighteenth as much. Put another way, the same Japanese saver who reaped more than $2,500 annually on a $50,000 deposit for most of the 1980's, when interest rates ran above 5 percent, now collects only $125.
"I look at my bank account," Mr. Ishigaki said, "and -- you know, we get interest about twice a year -- and I say, What on earth is this?' You can't say it's just interest, that it's just a small bit of money. We need it to live on. It's a matter of life or death."
The main reason for the cascade in rates is the Government's effort to pump up the faltering economy with cheap money for industry and consumers. The economy -- after stagnating since the speculative bubble burst in the early 90's -- sailed ahead in the first quarter of this year, expanding at a 12.2 percent annual rate, only to shrink in the second quarter to 2.9 percent.
But what is good for the economy can be agony for Japanese savers, whose frustration is mounting. Yoko Ito, 65, manages her family's finances, and used to prefer the banks because they seemed so much safer than stocks. But Mrs. Ito learned a lesson the hard way when her long-term trust fund, invested in stocks, lost half its value in the market plunge of the early 1990's.
That fund is maturing this year, and her broker is pestering her to reinvest it in stocks. She doesn't have the appetite now, but the banks don't look appealing either.
"Until several years ago, we could use the interest to pay our utility bills," Mrs. Ito said. "When I see the small amount of interest every month, I feel so bad that my husband worked all these years to earn precious money. This is miserable."
So far, most people are just watching in disgust as their interest income slides, and there is little indication that a revolt is building like one that took hold among some Americans in the 1970's. Then, when inflation-adjusted interest rates on savings accounts turned negative -- as they did briefly this summer here -- the public outcry ultimately led to the creation of all sorts of alternative savings vehicles like bond and money market funds.
Nothing like that is happening yet in this country, but the low rates threaten to change the saving habits of Japanese like Mrs. Ito, whose frugality has fueled decades of economic growth. Some critics of Government policy fear that today's Japanese supersavers will become tomorrow's American-style spendthrifts. Already, people have been rushing to buy homes to take advantage of cheap mortgages and to beat an expected increase in the consumption tax.
"I'd prefer to spend my money on trips abroad and on cars, rather than putting it in the bank," said Yoshitoshi Arii, a 63-year-old retiree as he withdrew some cash from a bank recently. "I think this is the effect that the Government is hoping for."
But if so, the policy may be backfiring. The latest Government figures show a small decline in household spending, possibly because many Japanese feel impelled to save more to make up for lost interest income and to prepare for rough days ahead. Still, with the economy's weakness, growth in overall savings has slowed somewhat in recent months.
Japanese pension funds have been quietly suffering from the low rates, too, and the result is that many are in trouble, with some logging deficits in their operations. Other institutional investors are fed up, and now some economists worry about instability -- with billions of dollars in capital fleeing overseas in search of higher returns.
The hardest hit, however, are retirees and the poor, who often have few alternatives. Finance Minister Wataru Kubo and other senior officials have expressed sympathy for their plight. And banks have opened special "welfare deposits" that pay 4.15 percent a year, though the amounts are limited to $30,000.
One of those angry pensioners is Masakazu Uenaka, 83, a former steel-company administrator, who wrote a pointed letter to a national newspaper. After retiring nearly three decades ago, Mr. Uenaka and his 77-year-old wife, Ikuyo Uenaka, took part-time jobs. They worked themselves to the bone and built up about $500,000 in savings.
Though their savings allow a comfortable living, they had hoped to live off the interest income and use some of the principal to build a country house for their extended family.
"I had to give up my dream of having a villa in Hakone," Mr. Uenaka said in a recent interview. "All these plans have collapsed."
His wife, determined not to tap into the principal except for emergencies, is depriving herself of extravagances such as renovating the bathrooms. "Also, I can't buy a new suit to wear to the alumnae gatherings," Mrs. Uenaka said. "I've cut down on my visits to the beauty parlor, and I dye my hair at home now."
For many older people, the situation is much worse. Most Japanese employees get retirement bonuses of around $200,000, typically using half to pay off their mortgages and banking the rest for the interest income. In the old days, they could expect $5,000 or more a year. But even at the higher interest rate given for deposits of $100,000 or more, the payoff has shrunk to about $280 after taxes for six-month rollover deposits -- or $23 a month, enough for lunch for two at a noodle shop.
Japan's central bank instituted the present level of easy credit a year ago to stave off a crisis of confidence in the nation's financial system. At the time, thinly capitalized banks were saddled with several hundred billion dollars in bad debt, and one big institution, Daiwa Bank, had just disclosed a $1.1 billion trading loss at its New York office.
Fears of a financial crisis have since receded but the central bank has kept rates low, in part to give the commercial banks time to increase their profit margins and ease their debt problems. But with the economy still sputtering and Japanese companies hesitant to embark on big investment projects at home, the central bank is in a quandary.
If it keeps rates low, and if creeping prices produce negative real interest rates, Japanese people will have a hard time even preserving the value of their savings. But if it raises rates, it might suffocate the precarious economic recovery.
"They want to dismantle the crisis management as soon as possible, and they launched a trial balloon to raise the official discount rate," said Takashi Kiuchi, an economist who heads the LTCB Research Institute in Tokyo, referring to a time in the spring when many economists were predicting that rates would rise. "But that didn't take place."
With the central bank sacrificing the saver, the consensus among economists is that rates will probably not be raised any time soon.
Moreover, with public distrust of the stock market still high six years after the plunge in stock prices, and with virtually no mutual funds available to spread the risk of stock investments, most Japanese savers feel stuck with the banks.
A few emboldened individuals, like Akiko Murakami, a 49-year-old woman who manages her family's household finances, are putting money into higher-yielding foreign bank instruments or name-brand American corporate bonds like those of the Walt Disney Company. Together, these yield-seeking investors -- including institutional investors -- are now pouring the equivalent of billions of dollars into foreign bonds, on the assumption that interest rates will remain much lower here than overseas.
Citibank N.A. has also watched its foreign-denominated deposits soar. Dollar deposits last month, it said, grew 43 percent over those a year before, while its New Zealand dollar deposits exploded by 500 percent in the same period.
These investments involve foreign-exchange risk, such as the danger that the yen will strengthen against the dollar.
"But it's better than keeping it in Japanese banks where the rates are so low that it's the same thing as keeping it at home," Mrs. Murakami said. "I don't keep money at home, in the cabinet, but sometimes I feel like I might as well. For kicks, my friends and I sometimes talk about getting a whole bunch of people together to yank out our money from the banks at the same time.
"If enough people are in on it," she said jokingly, "the banks will be unpleasantly surprised."
Others, like Hiroko Endo, a 50-year-old mother of two, are experimenting -- very tentatively -- with stocks. "We're putting some 'extravagance' money into the stock market," Mrs. Endo said. "But the money we need is in the bank."
Most Japanese are even more cautious about investing in stocks or in foreign markets, and many mistrust brokers. "I'm afraid of investing it," Mr. Ishigaki, the retired engineer, said. "Floating interest rates and all that -- unless you're an expert in the monetary world, it's hard."
For the most part, the Japanese are showing little interest in personal-investing courses or in financial counseling, partly because of their bad memories of the stock market plunge starting in 1990. "People got burned back then and they are no longer in the mood," said Minori Narita, an administrator at the NHK Culture Center, which once attracted scores of housewives and pensioners to its personal-investing classes.
Brokers are trying to change that attitude, and the younger generation may be more amenable. But they face an uphill battle.
"The Japanese people are too afraid," said Hiroyuki Fujimoto, a 34-year-old broker at Nomura Securities. "They need to play around more with their money and be more adventurous."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries' Prices Move Down Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday, the fourth consecutive decline, as concerns about inflation and interest rates grew before today's report on producer prices.
A sharp drop in the number of first-time unemployment claims made some traders question the prevailing market view that the economy is slowing and that interest rates will remain stable. Bond prices had been rising in recent weeks, with buyers encouraged by the Federal Reserve's decision to leave short-term rates unchanged and by last Friday's unemployment report, which showed a surprising decline in the nation's payrolls. 
 But traders yesterday were not willing to increase their bets on longer maturities with producer price and retail sales data for September due out today.
"Traders still have a slightly positive bias, but they are not willing to buy at the high price levels with so much uncertainty about the economy and inflation," said Dave Shabelman, a market analyst with MMS International in San Francisco.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 20/32 , to 9812/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.88 percent, from 6.83 percent on Wednesday.
Overseas selling heading into the New York session contributed to the market's decline yesterday. Concern about a strengthening labor market emerged yesterday following remarks by Laurence H. Meyer, a Federal Reserve governor, who according to a report in Investor's Business Daily said gross domestic product probably had slowed to a pace that would keep the jobless rate from falling further.
Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said Mr. Meyer's remarks worried the market.
"The market has been trading with a weary, almost nervous attitude this week, especially with the less than robust 10-year auction on Tuesday," Mr. Regan said. The yield on the 10-year note has gone from 6.50 percent at auction to a current 6.62 percent.
The market's worries grew after the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that initial claims for unemployment insurance for the week ended Oct. 5 fell by 22,000, more than expected, to a seasonally adjusted 319,000. The decline caused the four-week moving average to slip to 332,250.
Also weighing on the market yesterday was a poorly received auction of one-year bills. Mr. Regan said the auction was on the poor side because of reservations about today's data. "The market had been looking for a rate of 5.33 percent, but 5.34 percent came in," he said.

HEADLINE: In Housing Battle, Faint Hope and a Few Bright Spots

SERIES: BARELY FOUR WALLS: Housing's Hidden Crisis -- Last of six articles

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
Ana Nunez, paying $350 a month for a tiny, illegal room above a pawnshop on the Lower East Side, illustrates the harsh realities of housing for many of the poorest New Yorkers.
But the hope for a better future is embodied in Lula West's new two-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn. 
 Miss West and her teen-age sons, Jemar and Emanuell, live in a warm, pleasant building on what was, not long ago, a burned-out block in one of the city's most devastated neighborhoods, East New York. The walls of her apartment are freshly painted, the floors are hardwood and the kitchen appliances are just a few years old. Her sons' awards and trophies are proudly displayed on shelves in the living room, as are a smattering of books and a small television. Dried flowers perk up the modest furnishings. The rent: $422 a month.
"This is the best apartment I've had in all my life," said Miss West, who is 38 and has lived in East New York for 13 years.
It is not by accident that Miss West's accommodations are so much better than the makeshift and often expensive apartments in attics, basements, old commercial buildings and illegal boardinghouses that many other poor New Yorkers reluctantly call home. Nor did her home result from the efforts of the private sector, which virtually everyone agrees cannot fill the need alone. Government -- in the form of Mayor Edward I. Koch's vast city housing program -- planned and helped pay for the complete rebuilding of Miss West's apartment house at 539 Williams Avenue.
But the program that gave Miss West a decent and inexpensive home was a product of a bygone era: in the last several years, with money and political will in short supply at every level of government -- city, state and Federal -- housing programs that at their peak did not manage to reach all of the poor who needed assistance in New York City have been cut back substantially.
And as they look to the future, many housing advocates and experts agree that this retrenchment will probably lead to more substandard, expensive dwellings in a city already notorious for its high housing costs and cramped accommodations.
"We can expect it to get worse, absolutely," said Ron Shiffman, a member of the City Planning Commission and the director of Pratt Institute's Center for Community and Environmental Development. "While we have reversed the trends of the past and done a lot of building, that was geared primarily toward the existing population, and the population of the city is growing."
Decent, inexpensive housing is in short supply in New York for many reasons. While the city's population is growing, its aging housing stock is not being replenished quickly enough. The income of poor New Yorkers is often simply inadequate to cover the basic cost of maintaining apartments. (A mother on welfare with two children gets $286 a month for rent -- less than the average landlord's monthly cost per apartment.) Rent control and rent stabilization also keep rents low, although their effect on low-income housing is uncertain.
With the city in chronic budget trouble these days, and the Giuliani administration eager to get out of the housing business, very little new construction is on the drawing boards.
"I think we're at a point where we cannot continue that huge investment, not that the need has gone away," said Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, the city's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development.
There is also less money for new rent subsidies for poor and working-poor families, and less money for housing inspectors to clamp down on illegal apartments and unsafe conditions.
But that is not to say that people concerned with low-income housing are bereft of modest hopes. Local nonprofit groups continue to develop some housing. And some experts assert that changes in the city's regulatory system could be made to improve the lives of people living in substandard housing.
New York's low-income housing crunch is significantly different from what most other old, industrial American cities are experiencing, many experts said. Most cities with an aging and significantly dilapidated housing stock, like Chicago, Cleveland, Philadelphia and Baltimore, have also had significant population declines, which has eased the pressure on housing.
But New York City now labors under the unusual burden of an increasing population, due largely to immigration, and an aging housing stock that is not being replenished quickly enough. The two trends force up rents and intensify the competition for livable low-income housing.
 
Roots of a Crisis
Government Retreats From Role as Backer
Since the 1930's, the Federal Government had assumed prime responsibility for helping to house people too poor to pay on their own for a decent place to live. The Government built and maintained housing projects. It also helped finance private developers who built new low-income housing, and it gave rent subsidies to poor people, paying the gap between what they could afford and a reasonable rent in the private housing market.
The private market cannot do it alone, many people say, because the cost of building and operating housing in New York City simply exceeds the ability of many poor people to pay. The city's problem is as much insufficient household income as it is inadequate housing.
The situation, says Louis Winnick, an urban economist who has studied housing in New York for decades, is not complicated.
"I have preached maybe to the point of obsession that there are three reasons why housing is in a crisis in New York City -- cost, cost and cost," Mr. Winnick said. "There is no way that any builder, the most ingenious builder in the world, can build for the poor without subsidies. All the private market can do is a thin band of the population, and that is not going to change. Without public subsidy, there cannot be any prospect for new housing for the poor and even the middle class."
But the Reagan Administration sharply curtailed the Government's role in constructing new apartments for the poor in the early 1980's, and now the Clinton Administration cuts mean that the city is barely giving out any new Federal rent subsidies. And Congress has threatened much deeper cuts.
Landlord representatives say that thousands of apartment building owners in poor neighborhoods depend on the Federal subsidies, called Section 8, to meet expenses.
"If you remove Section 8, there is no doubt in my mind that you would see greater abandonment," said Joseph Strasburg, president of the city's largest landlords' group, the Rent Stabilization Association. "Without that, the entire low-income housing stock is down the tubes."
Some critics note that while the Federal Government is retreating from its traditional commitments to house the poor, it has kept intact far more expensive housing subsidies for the middle class and the wealthy. Deductions of homeowners' mortgage interest and property taxes have remained largely untouched, costing the Government about $94 billion a year, according to recent Congressional estimates. But the major national program for building new housing for the poor -- a Federal tax credit for corporations that invest in low-income housing -- is worth about $2.6 billion a year in forgone revenues.
"You really have to question the national priorities," said Paul S. Grogan, president of the Local Initiative Support Corporation, a nonprofit organization that helps finance community revitalization, particularly with the housing tax credits. "The largest housing program in the nation, the mortgage interest deduction and the deduction for local real estate taxes, is available only to homeowners, and only to homeowners who itemize."
This contrast reflects, among other things, a profound national shift in political power over the last three decades. As the country's population has moved from large cities to suburbs and smaller cities, so has political clout shifted from the big cities to the suburbs and towns.
Still, while the flow of Federal, state and city dollars into low-income housing has slowed substantially, it has not stopped altogether. Many of the dozens of local nonprofit groups that became housing developers and operators over the last decade through New York City's programs remain active. Some still receive city money to create new housing, though on a vastly diminished scale. Others have found specialized sources of money from the state and Federal governments.
The East New York Urban Youth Corps, for instance, is an ambitious neighborhood group in Brooklyn that rebuilt Lula West's apartment house on Williams Avenue. Over the last seven years, the nonprofit group has reconstructed or built from scratch 56 small buildings.
Martin Dunn, Urban Youth Corps's executive director, said the group continued to develop new housing in the last two years by tapping specialized sources, like Federal money for housing the elderly and state money for housing AIDS patients. But Mr. Dunn and many other low-income housing advocates are worried that even those resources may soon dry up.
"It's entirely dependent on whether the public support, the government support, is there," he said. "As a group, we have the capacity to do more. The vacant land, the vacant and substandard housing still exists, and the demand for housing is still there. All we need is access to financing, and this can continue for another 10 years."
 
Patchwork Approach
Hopeful Solutions, On a Small Scale
Some low-income housing experts assert that, even without significant new public investment, some small improvements could be made in the city's regulatory system, which even city officials admit has ceased to function properly.
Bruce J. Gould, a Housing Court judge in Manhattan, has long been a proponent of creating a new administrative tribunal to enforce housing violations. The city does not have nearly enough lawyers to pursue in court all the landlords whose buildings have been cited for violating the housing code, and the Housing Court would not have nearly enough judges if the city did pursue every violator.
But by creating an administrative body to handle violations, "you would have a systematic way of going after everybody," Judge Gould said.
Several tenant lawyers said they doubted a tribunal would accomplish much because it might encourage more landlords to certify falsely that they have fixed code violations.
"This will get people to certify, I guess, but without addressing the underlying problems," Andrew Scherer, a Legal Services lawyer, said.
But Judge Gould disagreed, saying that inspectors could go out and make sure that the repairs had in fact been made.
Other tenant advocates contended that with a relatively small commitment of money, the city could hire more housing inspectors. Since the early 1970's, the number of inspectors has fallen from nearly 700 to fewer than 200.
"They could put their resources into enforcing the law, and a lot of substandard housing could be brought up to code," said Scott Sommer, chairman of the Metropolitan Council on Housing, a tenants-rights group.
Ms. Barrios-Paoli, the city's Housing Commissioner, said she wants to rethink and reorganize the entire housing regulatory system. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declined requests to be interviewed about low-income housing.
Some tenant advocates suggested that in the winter, the city should hire retired housing inspectors to help with the peak load of inspections for problems with heat and hot water. And some said that the city should offer courses to small, inexperienced landlords on basic building maintenance. City housing officials are planning a small experiment soon with such a course.
Still, these are only modest improvements, and their proponents acknowledge that it would take major commitments of government money and political will to truly improve housing for New York's poor. Some housing scholars contend, however, that what is needed is less, not more, government involvement.
Peter D. Salins, a professor of urban planning at Hunter College and a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, said the solution to New York's low-income housing shortage lay right here in the city.
If New York were to eliminate rent control and rent stabilization, which limit rent increases on more than 1.1 million apartments, Mr. Salins said, private developers would have more incentive to build new housing for the middle and upper classes, and in the process would free up older housing for the poor. Those rules expire next year, and although no one expects that they will not be renewed, landlords can be expected to try to relax them. Easing the city's restrictive zoning and unwieldy environmental regulations would also stimulate new market-rate construction, he said.
"The city has poured a fortune into housing," Mr. Salins said. "No city has done as much. We should have the best housing in America, but we don't measure up with other cities. And the question is why? The housing market isn't working. We have stymied the market in a number of ways."
Many other housing experts, however, dismissed the idea. They said the primary problem was the combination of tenants' lack of income and the high cost of developing and operating housing.
Some experts even suggested that things might have to become worse before they got better.
"The public assistance and housing programs that are now being dismantled grew out of social unrest in the 1930's and the 1960's," said Steven Banks, coordinating attorney of the Legal Aid Society's homeless family rights project. "They sprung not just from benevolence but from real fears, from people in the streets."
Indeed, it was the surge in homeless people on the streets of New York in the early- and mid-1980's -- along with the physical devastation of the city's poorest neighborhoods -- that persuaded Mayor Koch and his advisers to offset cuts in Federal housing assistance by committing huge amounts of city money to rebuild abandoned apartment houses and neighborhoods.
Over the last decade, the program begun by Mr. Koch and continued by his successors has produced more than 43,000 new apartments and more than 20,000 new houses on vacant, city-owned land -- more new housing, in fact, than was developed during that time by all other American cities combined.
But the program did not come close to eradicating New York's enduring shortage of low-income housing, which did not surprise the officials who created it.
A study in 1985 estimated that the city needed at least 231,000 new apartments to accommodate all the people living doubled-up with friends and relatives, in homeless shelters or in seriously dilapidated housing. A follow-up study two years later estimated that by the year 2000, New York would need 372,000 more apartments and houses than it would have.
And the economic conditions that helped sustain the city's housing program are now a distant memory.
"It's the same problem that existed when we got into the housing program," Mr. Koch said. "The Federal Government has withdrawn from low-income housing production. It's unrealistic for the city to step in because they can't even afford to keep building schools, and that's an even higher priority."
Still, the beneficiaries of the decisions made 10 years ago are keenly aware of how their lives were changed by government's intervention. Lula West used to live down the block from her current home in East New York, in a small, rundown, roach-infested building. She paid $286 a month, the basic welfare housing allowance, for her old apartment. She pays more now, but she says the new apartment is worth the sacrifice.
"I pay $422 a month, but it's all right," said Miss West, who is legally blind and lives on Federal assistance for the disabled. "Thank God, I made it here."
 
Many Offer to Help
More than 100 people have called to offer help to the tenants whose lives and living conditions have been chronicled this week in The New York Times. The Children's Aid Society has agreed to manage donations or other offers of help. For inquiries or donations, call (212) 949-4935 or write to Philip Coltoff, Executive Director, Children's Aid Society, 105 East 22d Street, New York, 10010.

HEADLINE: Place Your Bets: A New Casino;
Mohegan Sun Will End Foxwoods' Local Monopoly

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: UNCASVILLE, Conn., Oct. 10

 BODY:
Michael Giguere sipped a Coke and looked ill. It was late Wednesday afternoon, and in a few minutes, 20,000 people would be streaming through the doors of Mohegan Sun, a giant new casino that is opening to the public on Saturday.
Mr. Giguere, a 30-year-old Montville resident who until that moment had worked only as a roofer, was about to sweat through his first full shift as a blackjack dealer, a test for him and 5,500 other employees of the new casino. After 10 weeks of training, he was panicking about whether he would spin out the cards smoothly, collect and pay out his bets properly, and avoid spilling the chips. 
 "I'm too nervous to talk," Mr. Giguere said. "Please leave me alone."
Only a year or so ago, the dealers, waitresses and cashiers had been welders, machinists, nurses and engineers, working for companies that were laying people off or closing whole divisions. For them, and this region, the opening of the casino offers a ray of hope, and yet one more sign of how southeastern Connecticut has moved away from the blue-collar manufacturing that was once its hallmark to a very different industry.
With the opening of Mohegan Sun, a casino the size of three and a half football fields in a factory complex that used to make nuclear reactor components, this part of the state now has two of the three largest casinos in the nation.
Only 10 miles away from the new casino, owned by the 1,100-member Mohegan tribe, is Foxwoods Resort Casino on the Mashantucket Pequots' reservation in Ledyard, the world's most profitable casino with more visitors last year, at least 20 million, than the combined populations of New York City, Los Angeles and Chicago.
Mohegan Sun will end the monopoly over the New England gambling market that Foxwoods has enjoyed for several years and may cut into its revenues, estimated to exceed $1 billion this year. But equally important, it is a large step toward turning the region into a gambling and resort mecca rivaling Atlantic City and Las Vegas.
"There is no market like this anywhere in the world," said Sol Kerzner, the South African gambling mogul whom the Mohegans brought in as a partner. Indeed, there are 21.8 million people in a 150-mile radius, 3 million more than in a comparable area around Atlantic City.
The shift toward gambling comes as southeastern Connecticut has searched to find jobs and businesses to spur an economy that had been heavily reliant on the relatively high salaries of military work. With the slashed payrolls of military contractors and the movement of some Navy operations to other parts of the country, this area has lost thousands of jobs.
For instance, Electric Boat, the submarine manufacturer in Groton that once was the region's biggest employer, has seen its work force drop more than 50 percent in the last decade to 10,900 this year, from 24,500 in 1986. It is expected to drop an additional 3,000 to 4,000 in the next two years.
"We need jobs," said Patrick J. Dougherty, Mayor of Montville. "And the casino brings them."
Mr. Dougherty said about one-third of the adults in his town had once worked for the Navy or Pentagon contractors. Now, the bumper-to-bumper traffic between Montville and Electric Boat has thinned. It is common to hear people at church talk about how they just got a "golden handshake" and are planning to move, if only they could sell their home, he said.
The casino, while not providing the same level of pay as military work, is going to help the town, he said. Already, Montville has changed its zoning to allow for large commercial developments. A six-story hotel is on the drawing board, and there is talk of a golf course, he said. Such development is part of the region's new emphasis on tourism. In addition to the two casinos, Six Flags is looking to open an amusement park. The Mystic Aquarium is expanding. The Mystic Seaport, a maritime museum, is continuing as a major attraction, and other developments are expected.
Even those who are not enthusiastic about the changes are resigned to them. "I'm not sure whether its progress, but I don't think there's anything else to be done," said Helen Aldrich, an 80-year-old retired secretary, who is the Montville town historian.
Mr. Kerzner said more than half the employees had never worked in a casino, though Mohegan Sun has recruited heavily from Atlantic City and Las Vegas for many management positions. Also, about 650 employees from Foxwoods have moved to the new casino, G. Michael Brown, Foxwood's chief executive, said.
On Wednesday night, three new dealers sat in the employee cafeteria, waiting for the shift to start. "It feels sort of strange not to be going to work with a helmet on," said Bill Barnard, a welder for 19 years at Pratt & Whitney, the aircraft engine manufacturer. "And I'm going to be associating with people, with customers."
Mr. Barnard, 40, said he was laid off earlier this year and came down to the casino looking for a job on the construction crew driving a dump truck. "I asked, do you need any help?" he recalled. "They said, sure, we're looking for blackjack dealers, if you can pass the test." Although he had never played the game before, he was hired.
Across the table, Jim Aiello, 47, a computer programmer who had been laid off from a water utility, shook his head in disbelief. "We were chosen out of 20,000 who applied," he said. "And the job has benefits."
The third man, who declined to give his name, was less upbeat. He had been laid off from Electric Boat this summer and was not sure that the casino was where he wanted to be. While he had been making $16 an hour at his defense job, about $30 on overtime, here he was making about $8, not including tips.
"People can hype everything up, but it's a bad situation," he said.
For many of the younger generation of employees, the casino was a step up from jobs at convenience stores, fast-food restaurants and odd jobs in the service economy.
"A four-year college degree wouldn't get me anything better," said John Oliver, 27, who said he had done odd jobs for the last few years. "This is my dream job. I love to gamble."
One worker quit her job as a waitress at Friendly's to come here. Another, Jenn Ryan, 23, a croupier, said it had allowed her to escape from 80-hour weeks at minimum wage as the manager of a convenience store and gas station. "This is going to be less hours for the same final take-home pay," she said.
The new casino officially opens to the public on Saturday, but on Tuesday the Mohegans and their partners invited "10,000 of their closest friends and relatives," in the words of one casino official. On Wednesday night, they conducted a "soft opening," holding an invitation-only charity benefit in which the slot machines were "live," but table games used only play money bought from the casino. All proceeds went to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.
The event was not just philanthropic. With Gov. John G. Rowland, state lawmakers and local business leaders sipping free champagne and noshing on shrimp, crab and other free food, the evening was a chance for the Mohegans to show they have arrived and create a buzz. The new casino is being billed in television and print ads as "a legendary" experience and "a casino like you've never imagined," where "the magic of the sun never sets."
It is a striking contrast to its bigger rival, Foxwoods, which is elegant but understated, a sort of well-run suburban mall with lots of amenities and almost 5,000 slot machines. In turn, Mohegan Sun could perhaps be described as New England Native American Glitz, a sort of Disney park casino with a Mohegan theme.
Giant faux animal skins, decorated with hieroglyphs and Mohegan symbols, hang from the rafters. Aluminum pipes, stylized to look like rough hewn logs, adorn the gambling floor. A huge video screen in the Wolf Den, a 300-seat lounge in the center of the complex, shows a video of a wolf, the tribe's icon, running through the woods.
The ceiling is decorated with clouds, which, through sophisticated lighting, appear to be scudding across the sky. A fiberglass cliff and a small forest of artificial pine trees tower over a food court where gamblers can dine on burritos, egg rolls, grinders and cheesecake. There are 19 restaurants, not to mention an elaborate day-care center -- complete with a kid-sized karaoke and two-story indoor playscape where gamblers can leave their children for $6 an hour.
Still, for some the ambiance was secondary.
At 7 P.M. on Wednesday, Anna Capuano, 78, of Stratford, had been sitting in front of a slot machine for two hours and had not had a chance to look around. Her hands were stained black from the tokens she had been dropping into the machine.
She watched the wheels spin on the machine, got three bars, and some coins began pouring out.
"Yup, this place is beautiful," she said.

HEADLINE: Baghdad Journal;
Iraq at Play: Eliza Doolittle Is Now a Belly Dancer

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq

 BODY:
You can tell that the Baghdad rendition of "My Fair Lady" is going to be somewhat different when, five minutes into the musical, a male dancer brandishes a pistol and shoots his lithe female counterpart dead.
Then there is the matter of Eliza Doolittle. Since women who sell flowers are largely nonexistent in Iraq, a local version had to be found. 
 Rewrite transformed her into an accomplished village belly dancer who masters the cha-cha-cha even while smoothing her squawking country vowels. (That was Mom being shot in the beginning, presaging both the dancing talent and untamed character of her daughter.) And the happy ending was also canned.
Baghdad used to bill itself as the living incarnation of "1,001 Nights," a proudly cosmopolitan capital where the entertainment spun on until dawn. But a combination of international sanctions and Draconian laws largely cut off the outside world, dampening the music and laughter. The thriving cabaret theaters are the only remnant of the city's night life.
The Government shuttered all nightclubs years ago to eliminate the spectacle of sanctions profiteers flinging around stacks of cash for a bottle of Scotch while most Iraqis have trouble feeding their families. Satellite dishes, never cheap, were banned outright this year.
Since the population is starved for entertainment, and trade sanctions eliminated the importing of new films, the city's downtown movie palaces have been converted en masse into theaters. The most popular shows are basically nightclub belly dance fare thinly disguised as plays -- the gyrating goes on hold every 15 minutes or so to introduce the barest plot sketches.
"My Fair Lady," or "Sayadati al-Jamila" in Arabic, opened this summer and has been selling out nightly at a rate expected to sustain an 18-month run.
"The educated in an Iraqi audience appreciate a show's foreign origins," said Mahmoud Abu al-Abbas, who adapted the show and stars in the Prof. Henry Higgins role. "But you also have to make the characters look like Iraqis so the ordinary audience will take it."
Despite Western confrontations with Iraq, its citizens show little overt hostility toward things Western. (At the once gleaming, now frayed Hotel Rasheed, the receptionist registering a guest's American passport number spontaneously sought to reassure him about his safety. "Don't worry, the only Americans we hate are George Bush and Bill Clinton," he said. "You are welcome in Baghdad.")
So no one finds it surprising that a work created in the West would be so popular with the cast and the audience.
"As artists, we don't think about the play in that way," said the show's star, Leila Mohammed. "But I don't really think of myself as Eliza either," she said, laughing through an attempt to sing "The Rain in Spain." Like all the music, it was replaced with the undulating drumbeats of southern Iraq.
The reworked version does include puns turning on English words. A sorcerer trying to exorcise evil spirits -- jinn in Arabic -- from one character watches her topple over on stage. "I am not sure if it's a question of jinn or gin," he deadpanned.
Audiences say the cabaret shows are wildly popular because they allow Iraqis to forget the difficulties of living in a once rich country brought low by a six-year-old international blockade imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait.
"It has been a difficult period, so we go out to forget the suffering, to forget the sanctions," said Fajr Sweidan, a 40-year-old food store owner who was taking his wife, sister and two children to the show.
Inevitably, however, sanctions jokes get mixed into the slapstick routines. One denizen of Professor Higgins's study -- full of books and dominated by a painting of Venus de Milo -- complains that the electricity has been out for an hour again. "We only get electricity for an hour," retorts a visitor from the countryside.
The bleakness of life under sanctions, especially a sort of pervasive national depression, is also woven into the dialogue. One character laments that the source of his listlessness cannot quite be diagnosed: "It is not sorrow, it is not pain, it is not anger. I think I am going crazy and I don't know why."
No one is overtly blamed for the problems, and references to domestic and international politics are largely absent. There is a minor dig at the television network run by President Saddam Hussein's older son, Odai, known for broadcasting endless imported South American soap operas and American gang movies. When a character starts singing a trite song, the other character cuts him off by asking, "Did you learn that from Youth Television?"
If it sounds as if the plot meanders from the original, it does. That is why critics accuse the theaters of trying to plaster Western titles on their shows in a quest for respectability where none exists.
"You don't have to copy an English or American film and make it terrible," said Mohamad Shukri Jameel, an Iraqi film maker. "It is a travesty."
"But they are packed," he said of the shows. "Before you could go to a bar or a restaurant, but now it's either illegal or too expensive. Everyone thinks it's better to go to one of these shows for an hour or two. It is all a reaction to the war."
Postwar sentiments also prompted the writers to throw out the happily-ever-after ending. The now lovely pupil, swathed in a pink pantsuit instead of her belly dance spangles, feels so unloved by her soulless professor that she spurns him and swears to return to her village.
"The rest of the shows all have happy endings, but our show is the reality," Mr. Abu al-Abbas said. "There is never a happy ending for Iraqis."

GRAPHIC: Photo: To take time out from its endless troubles, Baghdad enjoys a night life of sorts. A popular cabaret show is "My Fair Lady," in which the Eliza Doolittle character, a belly dancer, spurns Prof. Henry Higgins. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
G.E. Reports 11% Increase In Third-Quarter Earnings

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The General Electric Company announced yesterday that third-quarter earnings increased 11 percent over the period last year.
"It was a truly solid quarter," said Ann M. Schwetje of Smith Barney. Nicholas P. Heymann, a NatWest Securities analyst who is among the most bullish of G.E.'s fans, readily agreed. "It shows everything is A-O.K. and on track there," he said. 
 Indeed it is. G.E., a conglomeration of 12 disparate businesses, has always been well hedged -- a sluggish European market can always be offset by a boom in Asia, while one good sweeps week at NBC can make up for a badly timed entry into on-line information markets. And lately, only G.E.'s smallest businesses, like transportation and information systems, have been hiccupping. Indeed, the company's sales were up more than 15 percent, to $20 billion.
"One of the joys is that our largest divisions, like GE Capital, power systems and NBC, led the record growth," said Bruce Bunch, a G.E. spokesman.
G.E. has been cutting costs across the company. Its manufacturing divisions are chasing service and spare parts contracts, far less capital-intensive businesses than equipment manufacturing. And all its businesses are trying to sell more to existing customers, which is less expensive than trying to woo new ones.
The cost improvements have freed up a staggering amount of cash. So far this year G.E. has generated $5.4 billion in cash, compared with just $2.4 billion in the first nine months of last year. Much of that money has been used to increase dividends and to buy back stock. In fact, the stock buybacks were in part responsible for raising earnings to $1.08 a share. The gain over the third quarter last year was 13 percent a share, exactly what analysts had predicted. Actual earnings were $1.788 billion, up 11 percent over the corresponding quarter last year.
Both the sales and earnings reflect a nonrecurring bonanza from last summer's Olympics, which analysts say tacked $650 million onto NBC's sales numbers and added close to $60 million in profits to the company's coffers. The sluggish economy in Europe, an area that accounts for about a fifth of G.E.'s sales (a quarter, counting exports from the United States), reined in some sales.
Still, the good news far outweighed the bad. G.E.'s major appliances, despite a flat market, saw sales increase about 4 percent, as G.E. continued to grab share away from Whirlpool, Maytag and other makers of washers, dryers and the like.
G.E. plastics and silicones did well, despite soaring chemical costs, primarily because demand was high and no new capacity came on stream.
G.E.'s power systems division, which has had technological problems with some of its newer turbines as well as a flat market from American utilities, got a tremendous boost when Nuovo Pignone, the Italian company it purchased in late 1993, received a $1 billion contract to supply compressors to Gazprom, Russia's huge natural gas company. Power system's sales were up 30 percent and its profits up 35 percent for the quarter.
Even G.E.'s nuclear businesses are enjoying a turnaround, as more utilities hire the company to manage existing nuclear power plants.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall On Worries Over Earnings And Inflation

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks drifted farther away from record territory yesterday amid growing caution about earnings reports and September's inflation data.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.95, to 5,921.67, rebounding from an early 26-point loss, but extending a weeklong slide from record levels. The index breached 6,000 for the first time on Monday. 
 Broader measures also recovered from steeper losses in the morning, but the rebound was cut short by a worsening bond market. For the fourth session, the yield on the 30-year Treasury rose, finishing the day at 6.88 percent, up 5 basis points.
"People are worried that retail sales may be picking up a bit and that maybe the inflation numbers that are coming out will be a little higher than they have been," Robert Streed, senior investment adviser at Northern Trust in Chicago, said.
In their monthly sales reports, the nation's retailers showed mixed results for September. Still, the trend was strong enough to leave analysts upbeat about the Christmas selling season.
In another indication of inflationary pressure, first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 22,000 last week, to 319,000, the lowest level in five weeks.
Although the volatile weekly unemployment tally is given far less attention than the Labor Department's monthly unemployment report, analysts had expected the claims to remain unchanged from the previous week, noting signs that job creation had slowed in recent weeks.
On the New York Stock Exchange, declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by nearly a 13-to-11 margin. Volume totaled 395.4 million shares, down from 408.5 million on Wednesday.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.13 points, to 694.61.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 1.01 points, to 1,236.97, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index fell 0.11 point, to 579.99.
Shares of General Electric fell 7/8, to 92. The company said its third-quarter profits rose 11 percent, lifted by the Summer Olympics broadcast by its NBC television network.
Sears, Roebuck, which reported a 7 percent gain in September sales at stores open at least a year, rose 1/2, to 48 1/4. Shares of the Gap rose 1 1/2, to 28 1/4, in active trading after reporting that same-store sales were essentially flat. The stock had fallen in recent sessions amid fears of an even worse showing.
Shares of Olin, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., jumped 4 3/8, to 88 1/2, after the company said it would spin off its ammunition and aerospace divisions into a new company, Primex Technologies, sell four chemical businesses and buy back as many as 10 million common shares.
Monsanto shares rose 1 1/4, to 41 7/8, in Big Board trading. The company, based in St. Louis, said yesterday that it was considering splitting off its chemical businesses.
In Nasdaq trading, shares of Sunglass Hut International fell 45/16 , to 93/16 , after the company, based in Coral Gables, Fla., warned that earnings for the current quarter could fall below forecasts unless sales for the rest of the period exceed targets. Sunglass Hut blamed a slowdown in mall traffic, cooler weather and a lack of new products. Afterward, several brokerage firms downgraded Sunglass Hut, and one downgraded Oakley, a sunglasses designer that relies on Sunglass Hut as a key sales outlet. Oakley shares, which trade on the New York Stock Exchange, finished the day at 37 1/4, down 7 7/8.

HEADLINE: For Nuclear Power Plant, Bottom Line Is Death Knell

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
For many years, the debate about nuclear energy in America has been framed by concerns about the environment and dominated by complicated discussions of geology and water tables and the disposal of spent fuel rods.
But the decision on Wednesday by Northeast Utilities in Connecticut that it probably will not restart the 28-year-old Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant in Haddam Neck -- currently shut down for safety reasons -- suggests that the environmental arguments are no longer the prime mover. Accountants now call the tune. 
 For the nation's oldest operating full-scale nuclear power plant, the numbers simply do not add up anymore, the company said.
The idea goes to the heart of what utility industry experts say is one of the great emerging themes of the nation's aging archipelago of nuclear plants: drastic change.
The aging plants were built in an environment of utter stability -- with 40-year-licenses, billions of dollars in capital costs and a dense overlay of necessary scientific and government regulation. They have now lived long enough to see just about everything change around them, as the electricity-generating industry has been transformed from stodgy and slow to fast and competitive.
Newer, more efficient power plants and plummeting costs in some parts of the country for fuels like natural gas have lowered costs for non-nuclear power-generation choices. At the same time, deregulation of the utility industry has given more customers choices about which competitor they choose. Being a power-generating company has become a high-risk business in one of the least forgiving environments of all: Wall Street.
"It's a tough, tough industry right now because of competition, and the simple fact is, you can't pass the cost on if the customer has choice," said Paul Patterson, a senior analyst at Furman Selz, the investment firm.
Certainly, Connecticut Yankee's fate is not a death knell for all nuclear power. But the plant had two important factors in its favor: a long-term record as one of the most reliable in the nation, as measured by the infrequency of past shutdowns, and its location in New England, where it had little local competition from cheaper energy sources like hydroelectric power that have battered nuclear plants in the west. That is not a hopeful note for nuclear operators in tougher markets.
In other words, if an aging plant cannot make economic sense in Connecticut, where can it make sense?
"A lot of folks with 10 to 15 years left on their licenses are going to be watching this very carefully," said Karl R. Rabago, the energy program manager for the Environmental Defense Fund.
In economic terms, any uncertainty adds to the risk of an investment, and, utility experts say, for older plants like Connecticut Yankee especially, concerns and uncertainties about safety and age have been compounded in an industry that, like telephone service and health care, is in the middle of a total transformation.
If the company does decide to close the plant formally -- a decision it expects to make in the next several months -- Connecticut Yankee will have to deal with a moving target as costs and prices are deregulated.
Under deregulation, which is proceeding in all three states in the region, utilities that once had territorial monopolies and had their prices set by the government will compete for customers in much the same way telephone companies do.
But the question is, which era's values should hold sway -- those of the old regulated mentality or those of the market? Does the company have to swallow the costs because, under the harsh logic of the market, it made a bad investment? Or should the costs be spread to its customers because the company built the plant in a different time, under rules that were changed when it was too late to go back?
"The old regime was a regulatory compact," said Jamshed K. Madan, a principal at Georgetown Consulting Group, a Connecticut firm that advises mostly state utility regulators. "The utility would provide safe and adequate service at reasonable cost, and on the other side, would get a return that was commensurate with that operation." What that meant, he said, was that a company with higher costs simply built that into the rate structure.
"Competition doesn't work that way," Mr. Madan said. "If you have $10 extra in cost, you might just be the highest cost producer, and you've got to eat it."
To some extent, industry experts say that nuclear energy's economic problems are really the problems of all power generators, who face the fiercest blasts of competition as the utilities are deregulated. They must compete on price or close up shop in the world to come.
Indeed, Connecticut Yankee's second-largest shareholder, New England Electric System, a utility in Westborough, Mass., which owns 15 percent of the plant, announced just last month that it wanted to divest itself of the generation business entirely and to concentrate on delivery. Last month the company also formally requested the economic review that led to Wednesday's report on Yankee's viability.
One of the main topics in the industry is how to compensate companies for the obsolete investments they made in regulated days. Environmental groups, in an unusual alliance with the utilities, have pushed the idea of allowing companies to pass along some of the costs of closing old plants. They argue that it would be fair to the companies, and by being fair would hasten the companies' decisions to shut down the plants that the environmentalists don't like.
So far, only California has created a structure to make those pass-through costs, said Mr. Patterson at Furman Selz, though Massachusetts is close behind. It is expected to follow California's lead, perhaps by the end of this year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Aetna to Trim 4,400 Jobs In Fourth Layoff This Year
Aetna, in one of the largest job cutbacks in the health care and insurance industries, said it would reduce its payroll by 4,400 jobs, or 13 percent of its 33,700 work force.
The decision brought the number of overall layoffs planned by Aetna this year to more than 10,800. About 1,000 jobs will be cut in Connecticut. [Page A1.]

Retail Sales Results Mixed
Retailers posted another month of mixed sales results, adding to accumulating evidence that there are still too many stores decorating the country's landscape. Not many retailers stood out as true winners or losers as they reported their monthly sales. The exception was merchants of luxury goods, which continued to draw shoppers. [D3.]

Designer Will Head Ford Operations
Ford named Jacques A. Nasser, 48, a group president in charge of vehicle development, to head its North American and European automotive operations. [D4.]
 
Stocks Fall on Earnings Worries
Stocks slipped further amid growing caution about earnings reports and September's inflation data. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.95 points, to 5,921.67. [D4.]
 
Treasury prices fell sharply as concerns grew about inflation and interest rates. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.88 percent, from 6.83 percent on Wednesday. [D14.]

Olin to Spin Off Two Divisions
Olin said it planned to spin off and sell some operations and buy back as much as 10 percent of its stock. [D4.]

G.E. Earnings Rise 11 Percent
General Electric posted third-quarter earnings that were 11 percent higher than the performance of the period last year. [D3.]

Internet Deal for Madison Avenue
True North Communications said it would combine its TN Technologies unit, which specializes in interactive marketing communications, with Modem Media in a stock deal worth $29 million. True North also said it planned a public offering of shares in the combined operations. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D2.]

Nuclear Plant Will Remain Closed
Northeast Utilities in Connecticut said that it probably would not restart the 28-year-old Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant because of high costs. [B1.]

Time Warner-Turner Deal Approved
Shareholders of Time Warner and Turner Broadcasting System approved their $7 billion merger. Now, Time Warner faces the more difficult problem of cutting its $17 billion in debt. [D2.]

J. P. Morgan Has Lower Earnings
J. P. Morgan said that its earnings fell 23 percent in the third quarter. [D3.]
 
Loewen Board Rejects Buyout Offer
The Loewen board unanimously dismissed a hostile $3.2 billion offer from Service Corporation International. [D3.]
