HEADLINE: Wealthy Indonesian Businessman Has Strong Ties to Clinton

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH and STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
Last year, when Indonesia's Ambassador here wanted to arrange a rare meeting with President Clinton, he did not rely on the State Department or the White House, but turned to James T. Riady, a 39-year-old Indonesian businessman, for help. The Ambassador said he knew that the President's longtime friendship with Mr. Riady was how Mr. Clinton "came to be familiar with Indonesia."
As a member of a billionaire Indonesian family whose business interests and political influence span the United States and Asia, especially in China, the family's ancestral country, Mr. Riady is adept at using his connections to bring together the political and commercial elite on both continents. Nineteen years ago, Mr. Riady was an intern at an investment bank in Little Rock, Ark., when he met Mr. Clinton and helped set up the family's ties to Arkansas. 
 With Mr. Clinton's election to the Presidency in 1992, the Riadys and their business associates have become more politically active, from soliciting campaign contributions to influencing trade policy and conducting quiet diplomacy.
In the United States and overseas, they have played an important role in helping finance the Democratic Party over the last four years, contributing and raising millions of dollars. In turn, the Riadys' political support helped them place their American representative in an influential trade job in the Clinton Administration, the family's associates say.
The Knight Ridder news service reported that one of the largest contributions to the Democratic Party this year, $425,000, came from Arief Wiriandinata, an Indonesian who lived briefly in Virginia and whose father-in-law was a senior executive who worked for the Riadys.
Last month, in response to queries from The Los Angeles Times, the Democratic Party returned an unlawful $250,000 contribution that had been solicited from a South Korean company by the former American head of the Riady's American business operations, John Huang. Mr. Huang became vice chairman of the party's finance committee after stepping down late last year as a high-ranking trade official at the Commerce Department.
The flood of money from Asian interests has renewed debate over whether laws governing foreign contributions are too weak.
Out of the limelight, Mr. Riady has become a player in Asian-American relations, holding discussions with Mr. Clinton about United States relations with China and Indonesia, American and Asian officials say. The officials also say he has acted as a back-channel between the State Department and President Suharto of Indonesia on East Timor, a former Portuguese colony that Indonesia now controls and where human rights questions have been raised.
In the commercial realm, the Riadys have become business partners with Americans who want to do business in Asia, along the way hooking up with some prominent Arkansans who are close to Mr. Clinton. Among them is C. Joseph Giroir Jr., the former law partner who hired Hillary Rodham Clinton to the Rose Law Firm in Little Rock.
The projects being planned by Mr. Giroir and the Riady family include a $1 billion power plant in China.
Mark Fabiani, an associate White House counsel, said, "The Riadys are longtime supporters of the President." Mr. Fabiani's initial review of records has uncovered only two or three possible meetings between the President and Mr. Riady at the White House, including one in 1995 involving Mr. Giroir, Mr. Huang and Mr. Riady.
The Riady-Arkansas connection is longstanding. Mochtar Riady, the family patriarch, studied banking in China and made the family's initial investments in Arkansas. But it was his son, James, who spent the most time in Arkansas and became close to Mr. Clinton.
In 1977, when he was 20, James Riady went to Little Rock to train at Stephens Inc., a large investment bank. He met Mr. Clinton, then the state's Attorney General, and later returned to help run Worthen Bank, a large Arkansas bank that had been partly owned by the Riadys and the Stephens family.
The lawyer at the Rose Law Firm who represented both the Worthen Bank and Mr. Riady in the 1980's was Webster L. Hubbell, another former law partner of Mrs. Clinton. Mr. Hubbell kept up his connections to the Riadys. When he quit as Associate Attorney General in 1994 to defend himself against charges of bilking his former law partners and clients, Mr. Hubbell traveled to Indonesia. He has testified before the Senate Whitewater committee that he was retained by the Riady family's company, but declined to discuss what he did or how much he was paid.
In his testimony Mr. Hubbell said he worked for a Riady affiliate until he pleaded guilty to two felony counts in late 1994. The affiliate was part of the Lippo Group, a diversified holding company controlled by the Riadys with interests in banks, insurance and real estate.
In the United States, the Riady holdings include a California bank, the Lippo Bank. In April 1994, Federal bank examiners found evidence that the bank violated "laws and/or regulations," Federal records show.
Later that year Federal regulators ordered the bank to impose tighter controls to assure compliance with the anti-money laundering law, the records show. The order was lifted last March. A bank official declined this week to discuss the matter.
Mr. Huang was the Lippo Bank's vice chairman until the summer of 1994, when he joined the Commerce Department as the principal Deputy Assistant Secretary for International Economic Policy. The Riadys have told associates that they were able to help Mr. Huang get his Commerce Department job as a result of the family's political support for Mr. Clinton, according to two Riady associates who asked not to be identified.
In that position, Mr. Huang would have been able to influence a wide array of trade policy issues, though a spokeswoman for the department, Anne Luzzatto, said Mr. Huang primarily involved himself in managerial and administrative matters.
In 1992, James Riady and his wife gave at least $175,000 to the Democratic Party and the Clinton inaugural fund. Election laws allow foreigners to donate to political parties as long as they are legally residing in the United States at the time. Mr. and Mrs. Riady were legal immigrants living in the United States until 1993, according to Federal records. They now live in Jakarta, Indonesia's capital.
Mr. Riady has avoided talking publicly about his ties to Mr. Clinton. As recently as this week, he told a reporter at an Asian business forum in New York that he would not discuss his American political activities or his relationship with the President.
But Mr. Riady has told others that his political support for Mr. Clinton stems from his longstanding friendship and the Democratic Party's greater interest in minority issues, including those of Asian-Americans. In Indonesia, ethnic Chinese were subjected to official as well as social discrimination. In recent years, however, with the opening up of China, the elite Chinese business community, including the Riady family, are pillars of the establishment.
Other Asian and American officials describe Mr. Riady more as a bridge between Indonesia and the United States.
Arifin M. Siregar, the Indonesian Ambassador to the United States, said in an interview last year that Mr. Riady was very useful in setting up the 1995 meeting with Mr. Clinton. Mr. Siregar said Mr. Riady attended the meeting but he declined to discuss what they talked about.
Mr. Fabiani said there was no record of a White House meeting, but he did not want to suggest that the meeting described by Ambassador Siregar did not occur.
The Riadys have also set up meetings between Americans and President Suharto. And James Riady has promoted East Timor's investment opportunities to Americans, taking some Arkansas associates of Mr. Clinton there, according to associates of Mr. Riady.
The State Department has criticized Indonesia's human rights record, but the Administration has angered some labor and human rights groups by not linking the criticism to economic issues. For example, the Administration has maintained tariff preferences for Indonesia despite complaints by human rights groups. At the Asian-Pacific economic summit talks that were held in Jakarta in 1994, however, human rights and East Timor were not high on the agenda.
During that mid-November summit, Mr. Clinton slipped away for a visit with Mr. Riady, a Lippo spokeswoman, Dewi Dharmanan, said at the time. Mr. Fabiani said the President only met the Riadys briefly in Jakarta during a summit-related reception at which they were the hosts. While he was in Jakarta, Mr. Clinton planned to meet with some Arkansans, but the idea was dropped because a White House aide thought it was a bad idea, according to private testimony before the Senate Whitewater committee cited in The Wall Street Journal.

HEADLINE: Both Kemp and Gore Erred in Debate Over Policy on Mexico

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
When the Vice-Presidential debate turned to foreign policy, there was a sharp exchange of views over Mexico, with Jack Kemp accusing the Clinton Administration of causing Mexico's worst economic crisis in half a century, and Vice President Al Gore defending the Administration's actions with boasts that Mexico had already paid back all the money it borrowed.
Both were wrong. 
 Mr. Kemp first broached the subject of the Mexican peso crisis, which has been criticized by Republicans since the early months of 1995, when Washington cobbled together an international rescue package.
In the past, some Republican leaders have accused the Administration of having been caught asleep at the wheel when the peso was devalued in December 1994. The war cry at the time was, "Who Lost Mexico?"
During Wednesday night's debate in St. Petersburg, Fla., Mr. Kemp shifted direction. He blamed the Administration for forcing Mexico to devalue the peso, setting off a chain reaction of panic selling and roaring inflation that crippled the Mexican economy and threatened to spread to other countries.
"We caused the problem in the first place," Mr. Kemp said. "And it cost us $20 billion to $50 billion to bail them out."
In fact, the $50 billion package included only $20 billion from the United States, and the Mexicans have never used all that had been made available to them. The remaining $30 billion in the package was put up by the International Monetary Fund and the central banks of several European nations.
Mr. Gore patiently but persistently tried to give his version of what happened. "No. That's not right," he said the first time. "I fail to understand the basis of the charge that we caused the monetary crisis in Mexico," he said later. "They manage their own monetary policy."
Mexican officials have always said they were forced by rapidly deteriorating economic conditions to abruptly devalue the peso just three weeks after Ernesto Zedillo became President in 1994.
In the months before the devaluation, private economists and United States Treasury officials had grown increasingly worried about Mexico's growing debt and the evaporation of investor confidence in Mexico.
"We had expressed grave concerns about Mexico's inconsistent exchange rate policy and monetary regime in 1994," Lawrence H. Summers, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, said in a telephone interview. "Mexico made its own decision to devalue the peso, and notified us of it after it had been taken."
But Mr. Gore's precise performance grew sloppy when he bragged about how the Mexican rescue had turned from a risky loan to a nicely profitable venture.
"We've ended up making a $500 million profit," the Vice President said. "All of the loans have been paid back."
In fact, the Mexicans have not paid back everything they owe the United States. They had drawn down $12.5 billion of the total of $20 billion that the United States had offered. Under pressure to pay back the loans before the elections, the Mexican Government has moved quickly to repay $9 billion.
Mexico still owes $3.5 billion. The next payment is not due until next summer.
So far, Mexico has paid $1.36 billion in interest on the loans, according to the Treasury Department. The $500 million in profit that Mr. Gore mentioned is calculated to be over and above what the Government would have made if it had used the money set aside for Mexico in other ways. Mexico was charged a premium, about four percentage points higher than other borrowers would have received.
Mexico has risked angering the European nations that contribute to the International Monetary Fund by focusing its repayment efforts almost exclusively on its debt to the United States.
Mexico borrowed about $14.5 billion from the international organization. So far, it has paid back $1 billion.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1280 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
1 Economy, 2 Diagnoses

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
Listening to Jack Kemp and Al Gore debate on Wednesday night, it would be easy to conclude that the two men lived in completely different countries.
Mr. Kemp's America is one in which economic growth is drastically stunted, condemned to inching along at 2.5 percent a year, unless its citizens are no longer grossly overtaxed and its Government drops what he called its "anti-capitalistic mentality." 
 Mr. Gore's America, in contrast, is a capitalist's dream, the job-creating envy of the world, charging ahead while Europe and Japan are languishing in low-growth swamplands. It is bursting with productivity, overflowing with exports produced by the world's most highly trained workers.
Not surprisingly, both worlds have been overdrawn in the heat of the campaign end-game. And though both campaigns insist that only the private sector can spur growth and create jobs, each sees the Government playing a central role in charging the economy. But their paths to that goal are dramatically different.
Mr. Kemp, far more consistently than his running mate, makes the case that the only answer is an across-the-board tax cut that would free entrepreneurs to spend money any way they wish. "We should double the rate of growth, and we should double the size of the American economy," Mr. Kemp said on Wednesday, setting a goal even higher than the one he has usually espoused on the campaign trail. That would mean growth rates of 5 percent a year -- a pace rarely seen in the United States in the past two decades.
Mr. Gore, along with the Administration's economic advisers, talks mantra-like about the wonders of cutting the deficit. Their tax-cut programs are modest and narrow: to assure that every high school student can afford some form of college, for example, or to encourage companies to hire welfare recipients.
It is hardly unusual for candidates to portray the state of the American economy in such starkly different terms; incumbents always seize the best statistics of the day and claim credit for them, and challengers usually talk about missed opportunities for the country to do far better.
But their solutions overlap more than either side would like to admit: both advocate a $500 tax credit per child for working families, and contend that it is possible to balance the budget without cutting into Medicare, Medicaid and entitlement programs, a feat that makes partisans in both camps roll their eyes. At times, with his talk of urban policy and making sure the poor are not left behind, Mr. Kemp sounded like the Democrat, while Mr. Gore's discussion of the benefits of deficit reduction had echoes of pre-1996 Bob Dole.
The problem, many economists say, is that both sides are probably overselling the Government's power to affect the growth of an economy the size of the United States'.
"The truth of it is that there is not a hell of a lot the Government can do," said Charles L. Schultze of the Brookings Institution, who served on President Carter's Council of Economic Advisers. His own analysis is that Mr. Dole's tax-cut plan, if fully paid for with large budget cuts, would increase growth by about a tenth of a percentage point a year -- hardly the stuff of campaign drama. And even a Government commitment to education and training larger than anything the Administration has proposed would have about the same effect, he concludes.
"The bottom line is that if you want get the most bang for the buck in economic growth, cut the budget deficit," Mr. Schultze concluded.
The opposite scenario, commonly discussed on Wall Street these days is that after a five-year expansion, the American economy seems likely to slow down in coming years, no matter what economic course the Government pursues. But that is too impolitic a subject to be mentioned by either campaign. "Not great sound bites there," one of Mr. Clinton's top economic advisers allowed the other day. "Next subject."
While the differences in economic views were particularly vivid in the Kemp-Gore debate on Wednesday night, the contrasts have surfaced only episodically during much of the campaign. Mr. Dole declared several weeks ago that achieving economic growth of roughly 3.5 percent through a 15-percent cut in taxes "is what this campaign is all about," but he did not talk about boosting America's growth rate in his first debate with President Clinton last Sunday. That reinforced the view that while Mr. Kemp is a true believer in the power of tax cuts, Mr. Dole has his doubts. "He reveals his discomfort with his proposal by not sustaining a continued effort to sell the package to the American public," Salomon Brothers warned clients last week.
Conversely, while the Administration has taken a page from Mr. Dole's book in declaring that "the era of big government is over," his campaign has rarely let a week go by without unveiling another small program or targeted tax cut that is termed part of a "concerted growth agenda." In fact, while some of those tax incentives are clearly tied to increasing productivity -- credits for higher education or job retraining -- others seem more akin to election-year gifts. First among those is Mr. Clinton's proposal, first made during the Democratic convention, to end the capital-gains tax on the sale of a home, up to $500,000.
The key to the Clinton Administration's tax cuts is that they do not cost much. That has freed Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore to make the case that the $550 billion tax cut proposed by the Dole campaign -- which they pejoratively term a "tax scheme" -- would "blow a hole in the deficit." And that message, more than any other, seems to have undermined the political effectiveness of the call for a 15 percent tax cut.
"It was a miscalculation," Richard Darman, the veteran of many budget wars during the Reagan and Bush Administrations, said of the 15 percent plan recently. "The public actually cares more about deficit reduction than about tax cuts. This year, the Republican candidates didn't believe those polls. After the election, maybe they will believe it."
But that is only one theory about why the Republican theme that worked so well for Ronald Reagan in 1980 -- cut taxes and the economy will boom -- is not selling so well.
The most compelling theory is that that experience of the Reagan years has undermined the political appeal of big tax cuts.
It was during the Reagan era that the United States ran up the huge budget deficits that still weigh down the economy today. While Democrats and Republicans still argue over which party is responsible for failing to trim the budget to pay for the tax cuts, the experience left millions of voters suspicious of any plan that calls for cutting taxes first and spending later.
Another theory -- one put forward by Republicans like Mr. Darman and Democrats like Daniel Patrick Moynihan -- is that voters no longer feel the bite of ever-increasing taxes the way they did in the 1980's. At that time, the problem was "bracket creep": inflation kept pushing taxpayers into ever-higher tax brackets. But there are fewer brackets now, and little inflation.
Perhaps the biggest hurdle Mr. Kemp's growth argument faces is a more basic one: while America may be growing slowly, its biggest competitors in the world are growing even slower. Growth rates tend to be a hot political issue only when Americans have the sense that their clocks are being cleaned by the competition; Mr. Clinton played that card well in 1992, when the Japanese economy appeared to be thriving at the expense of Silicon Valley and Detroit. Today, both the popular perception and the politics of America's competitive standing have reversed.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
In the Hamptons, Prices Are Soaring, but Not All

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
Some brokers in the Hamptons are cautioning people not to panic. It's not that the market is so bad -- but that it's so good.
"In terms of prices for some properties, we've surpassed even the hot 80's," said Philip Elliott, who manages the East Hampton and Southampton branches of Sotheby's International Realty. "But we don't want people to panic and start raising the prices of their houses; we don't want to give the impression that anybody can sell anything at any price because then they'll wind up not selling at all." 
 The market, he said, is strong, "but it's not tearing away; it's not scary." Furthermore, brokers say there are exceptions: some of the more mundane houses in less desirable locations and some of the post-modern-style houses built in the 1970's and 1980's. Nevertheless, Hamptons brokers report that their sales volumes are up from 30 to 60 percent over a year ago.
"We're experiencing a terrific frenzy," said Melanie Ross, president of Cook Pony Farm Real Estate. "Right now, we have far more buyers than supply in about every price range."
And the sales are not only in prestigious East Hampton and Southampton. In Bridgehampton, the average price of a house soared 77 percent in less than a year, Dayton-Halstead Real Estate in East Hampton said. In Bridgehampton, the average price of 40 house sales was $450,000 in the first quarter; by the middle of the year the average of 32 sales was $800,000.
Average home prices in nearby Wainscott, where properties are traditionally less expensive than in the towns with "hampton" in their name, jumped by 24 percent, from $267,000 to $330,000.
Brokers gave several reasons for the increase, beginning with the country's economy, followed by a great year on Wall Street. Diane Saatchi, president of Dayton-Halstead, also credited the recent repeal of New York State's 10 percent surcharge on the profits on transfers of real estate over $1 million.
The price increases are particularly remarkable in land sales. Mr. Newbold pointed to a 5.3-acre parcel overlooking Sagg Pond in Sagaponack. In June of this year, an investor bought the land for $650,000. This month, he said, it went under contract for $1,395,000.
Or take the case of a 1.3-acre lot on Sagg Pond Court, which is closer to the beach than to Sagg Pond, also in Sagaponack. The lot, in a subdivision of 10 lots, sold in 1994 for $299,000. The lot sold again one year later for $375,000. This year, it sold for $495,000, Ms. Saatchi said.
But Ms. Saatchi -- whose total volume, she said, was up 60 percent -- wanted to be very clear.
While prices have risen "almost across the board in village houses, in antiques and vintage properties that can be fixed up and in brand new homes in the traditional style," she said, there are exceptions: "Seventies and 80's contemporaries are out of fashion," she said, along with properties "that are not well located, where we still have a lot of supply." These are "undistinguished houses on one-acre lots in the woods, where one street looks like another," she said. Ms. Ross agreed. "In the higher price ranges -- over $2 million -- there's hardly anything left, but you can still get a little two- or three-bedroom house in the Springs or Noyak for $150,000," she said. "These are in wooded areas, close to a bay beach, no pool. They're actually quite pleasant, but not desirable for most of our buyers and certainly not to people looking for an address."
For the smaller homes in wooded areas, Ms. Ross said, prices have stabilized -- they are no longer going down and may even be up slightly. For one of the new homes on Parsonage Lane in Sagaponack, south of the highway (on the ocean side of Route 27, the main road through the Hamptons), prices seem to be steadily rising.
In June 1994, Ms. Saatchi said, the highest price for one of these five-bedroom, five-bath houses with pool and garage, built by the same contractor, was $1 million. In May, one of the houses sold for $1.375 million and one is listed for $1.85 million.
The brokers seemed particularly amazed at prices for houses within the village of East Hampton. A house north of the highway in town "just closed on Newtown Lane in September for $600,000 -- a two-bedroom with a guest house -- and one in July for $575,000," Ms. Saatchi said. "Two years ago, I would've fallen over in disbelief if any house there sold for more than $400,000."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Prospect of a British Rate Rise Sends Pound to 11-Month High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The British pound reached an 11-month high against the dollar yesterday and rallied against other currencies on expectations of higher British interest rates.
The dollar finished mostly higher against other currencies, an indirect result of the pound's strength. It also benefited from remarks by senior officials in Japan indicating that interest rates there would remain low -- which depressed the exchange value of the yen. 
 The main theme in currency dealings was the appetite for the pound, which came a day after the British Government reported higher-than-expected inflation data for September, suggesting that the nation's central bank would soon raise rates. Higher rates make a currency more attractive.
Traders also focused on the release earlier this week of minutes of a September meeting between the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, and the central bank governor, Eddie George, that also suggested the possibility of higher British rates in coming months.
The prospect of higher British interest rates, combined with steady or falling rates in continental Europe and Japan and the uncertain prospect for rates in the United States, combined to create heavy demand for the pound.
"Sterling was strengthening against the dollar as it was strengthening against the rest of Europe, and that's a positive sign for sterling," said Michael Malpede, chief currency analyst at the Refco Group, a Chicago-based brokerage firm.
Late in New York yesterday, the pound rose to $1.5750, from $1.5665 on Thursday and the highest level against the dollar since early November 1995. The pound also hit highs for the year against the mark.
The dollar rose to 111.60 yen from 111.15. It ended lower against the German mark, at 1.5307 compared with 1.5382 marks on Thursday.
Some traders said that a rousing speech by Mr. Clarke on Thursday to the Conservative Party conference in Bournemouth, England, also encouraged optimism about the pound, spurring some hope that the Conservatives might win the general election that will be held by May 1997 and retain power. Recent polls continue to show the opposition Labor Party with a big lead, but the Conservatives ended their conference with a strong show of unity.

HEADLINE: Price Report Revives Bonds After a Week of Uncertainty

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
After being pounded this week by investor fears of inflation and higher interest rates, Treasury prices rebounded yesterday in a shortened session.
Buying was encouraged by a report on September producer prices that showed inflation in check and by retail sales data that pointed to moderate growth. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 16/32 , to 9828/32 , in trading that ended at 2 P.M. in New York. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.84 percent, from 6.88 percent on Thursday. The Treasury market will be closed on Monday, in observance of Columbus Day, and will reopen on Tuesday.
Prices rose after the Labor Department reported that its Producer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent, less than expectations of a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent. And the Commerce Department reported that retail sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, but that followed a revised figure for August, which showed a modest decline. In addition, the strength in September sales came largely from cars and light trucks, which are expected to slow.
Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Everen Securities Inc. in Chicago, said the market had declined the four previous sessions largely "on repeated news stories or opinions that P.P.I. and retail data could be worse than the consensus."
"But when they came in at pretty much the consensus, the market experienced a relief trade," he said.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, said: "The fear that consumers would come roaring back in the fourth quarter was not borne out by the retail sales statistics.
"In fact, after incorporating last month's significant revisions, it appeared more like the consumer ended the third quarter with more of a whimoer than a bang."
The market may have also received help from comments yesterday by a Federal Reserve governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey. In an address to the Atlantic Economic Conference in Washington, Mr. Lindsey said real income growth was virtually nonexistent.
His comments confirmed the market's optimism that the Federal Reserve would continue to hold interest rates steady.
Indeed, Mr. Lindsey said the Fed's monetary policy was "about right" in terms of historic levels.
Still, any lingering concerns about inflation and Fed policy may not be enough to drag down the market sharply lower, Mr. Hamilton of Everen Securities said.
"We still feel that international accounts have been the driving force behind the recent run-up in bond prices," he said. "Until we see selling from those international accounts, sharp moves down will probably not occur. As long as the dollar remains on its general upward path it will act as a support in a down market."

HEADLINE: U.S. Benefits Go; Allure to Dominicans Doesn't

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic

 BODY:
The line outside the United States Consulate here begins forming at dawn, and as the police struggle to keep order and vendors hawk lottery tickets it lengthens rapidly with Dominicans who hope to join relatives already living in the United States.
Nearly everyone seems to know that the United States is adopting measures that sharply cut benefits to legal as well as illegal immigrants. But that has not dampened their determination to reach what they see as the land of their dreams. 
 "I've got two good arms and two good legs to work," scoffed Elisa Mojica, a recently wed 22-year-old beautician who is awaiting a visa to join her 24-year-old husband, Amauris, in New Jersey. "I don't want to go there to live on welfare; I want to go there to improve my life."
The lure of a better future will continue to draw immigrants to the United States, Dominicans say, so long as poverty and lack of opportunity here endure. Although some in Congress maintain that immigrants flock to the United States for the benefits that the new measures on welfare and immigration would now deny them, interviews with more than two dozen Dominicans show that most of them dismiss American efforts to discourage immigration as illogical and likely to fail.
In the Absent Dominicans barrio, named in honor of those who sent home the money that built the tidy pastel houses lining the street, Ruben Cueva said he continued to dream of joining his 2 sisters and 10 nieces and nephews in Queens.
"If you've got money, the Dominican Republic is the best country in the world in which to live," said Mr. Cueva, who was recently hired as foreman of a garbage collection team after a long spell without a job. "The rich here, they have no need to go anywhere. But we who are poor, we are eating stones, so these measures are not going to stop anybody from going to New York in search of the green."
Over the last decade, that search has made this Caribbean nation of 7.5 million people the source of more legal immigrants to New York City than any other country, according to the New York City Department of Planning. Of the roughly 40,000 Dominicans who have entered the United States legally each year since 1990, more than 22,000 a year have settled in New York City, with many of the rest establishing themselves elsewhere in the metropolitan area.
But there is also a substantial flow of illegal immigration to the United States, both the Dominican and the United States Governments acknowledge. Statistics compiled here indicate that more than 700,000 people have left the country in the last decade, the bulk of whom are assumed to have settled in cities in the Eastern United States.
In the United States 28 percent of Dominican households classified as post-1980 "new arrivals" have received public assistance at one time or another, ranking them third among immigrant groups. By comparison, 38 percent of new Vietnamese arrivals and 33 percent of immigrants from the former Soviet Union received such assistance. For all households in the United States, the figure is 7.5 percent; in New York City, 13.3 percent of the households are on public assistance.
Many Dominican immigrants, however, gravitate toward factory jobs or end up opening small businesses. The money sent home by Dominicans living abroad is now the largest single source of foreign exchange for this country, amounting to more than $1 billion a year and making the recent American debate about immigration and welfare resonate deeply here.
"My relatives were just down here visiting, and that's all we talked about," said Tomas Vasquez, a 50-year-old cement salesman. "I don't think there is a single family in this country that doesn't have somebody in the United States, so naturally there has been a lot of attention paid to the coverage in the newspapers and on radio and television."
The new welfare law, which was signed into law on Aug. 22, will deny many current legal immigrants food stamps and supplemental Social Security income and denies future immigrants the right to food stamps, public housing, Medicaid and other social services during their first five years of residence. Congress has also approved a restrictive immigration bill that includes provisions requiring minimum income levels for sponsors of immigrants, and President Clinton is expected to sign the measure soon.
Here, few questioned the right of the United States to try to diminish the flow of immigration from poor, developing countries like this one. "Personally, I think these new laws are anti-Latino," said Narciso Frias, a 31-year-old mechanic. "But it's their country, and they should be able to take whatever measures they think are necessary to guarantee their national security."
Yet most of those interviewed here said economic pressures would continue to encourage Dominicans to try to reach the United States, whether legally, through family reunification programs, or illegally, in the flimsy boats called yolas that regularly make the dangerous sea crossing to the west coast of Puerto Rico. From there entry to the American mainland is relatively easy.
"What else would make people risk their lives to board yolas and go to a place where they are not wanted?" asked Juan Pablo Diaz Gonzalez, a 59-year-old store owner from the northern town of Moca who often visits relatives in the United States. "This country has been in a state of economic stagnation for years, so people are desperate and have no other choice."
Billilo Vidal, an unemployed painter and carpenter, counts himself among that group. Last year, he said, he stowed away on a ship carrying a consignment of machinery back to the United States after an industrial fair here, but was discovered and briefly jailed. Nevertheless, he said, he plans to try again as soon as he can afford to do so.
"If I had the money, I'd be out of here in a flash, regardless of whatever measures might be taken in the United States," said Mr. Vidal, 41. "It's not that I want to go, but that I have to go. I've got five kids, and I'm not even able to give them what they need for breakfast. I want to have a house that I own, instead of having to pay rent, and I can only achieve that in the United States, not here."
The concern that Dominican immigrants might be adversely affected by the new welfare and immigration laws extends to the highest levels of Government here. President Leonel Fernandez Reyna, who took office in mid-August, grew up in New York City, where his mother worked as a seamstress, and he attended elementary and high school on the Upper West Side.
In a speech last month, which was later televised in New York on Channel 41, Mr. Fernandez, a 42-year-old lawyer, said he recognized that "many Dominican families residing in the United States that have benefited from welfare and food stamps will begin to experience difficulties once this law is promulgated." But he urged Dominicans living in the United States to feel free to pursue dual citizenship, which was made legal here in 1994, in order to retain whatever benefits they could.
"If you, young mother, or you, elderly gentleman, or you, young student, feel the need to adopt the nationality of the United States in order to confront the vicissitudes of that society stemming from the end of the welfare era, do not feel tormented by this," he said. "Do it with a peaceful conscience, for you will continue being Dominicans, and we will welcome you as such when you set foot on the soil of our republic."
But long before Mr. Fernandez spoke, Fernando Mateo, the 38-year-old owner of a document courier and money transfer company, Mateo Express, had already taken that step. Many other Dominicans are sure to follow suit as a result of the pressure they are feeling, he said, with easily predictable political consequences.
"Indirectly, the Republicans are doing us a favor by encouraging us to empower ourselves by becoming American citizens," Mr. Mateo, who divides his time between New York and Santo Domingo, said at his office here. "If we do that, we will be heard, the way the Cubans are in Miami. Any time they holler, the President goes running to Florida. Then we'll be able to negotiate, and anyone who wants our vote will have to help develop this country, so that less of us take off for the United States."

HEADLINE: Fewer Unwed Mothers

 BODY:
Last year the illegitimacy rate in America dropped for the first time in 20 years. The number of babies born to teen-agers also declined for the fourth year in a row. There may be several factors at work here -- more accurate reporting, for example, and wider use of contraceptives, particularly among teen-agers -- but the new data can only hearten all those who worry about the social, economic and personal consequences of illegitimacy.
The National Center for Health Statistics reports a decline in the rate of births to unmarried women, from 46.9 per 1,000 in 1994 to 44.9 last year -- the first drop since 1978. About half of the decline is attributable to more accurate reporting of out-of-wedlock births to Latino women in California. The rate of births to 15-to-19-year-olds dropped 3 percent in a year, from 58.9 births per 1,000 women in 1994 to 56.9 last year. 
 The Alan Guttmacher Institute says that government-financed contraceptive programs deserve some of the credit. In a new study, the institute concludes that on an average annual basis, these programs prevented about 1.3 million unplanned pregnancies -- two-thirds of them involving unmarried women -- and 29 percent involving teen-agers.
The institute notes further that family planning programs are cost-effective, with every tax dollar spent on contraception saving three dollars in Medicaid costs for pregnancy-related health care. Family planning services also avert more welfare costs.
Federal and state funding for these programs exceeds $700 million, but measured in 1980 dollars, spending has decreased by about 30 percent. Young, poor and single women are most at risk from unplanned pregnancies. They are also the largest consumers of publicly funded family services. Higher funding for these services would be a smart investment.

HEADLINE: Economic Data Help Stocks Regain Part of Week's Loss

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks broke out of a weeklong slump yesterday, helped by economic data pointing to modest growth with stable inflation, sending interest rates lower in the bond market.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 47.71 points, to 5,969.38, cutting its loss for the week to 23.48 and pulling back within 31 points of 6,000. 
 The Dow broke above the 6,000 mark for the first time on Monday and did it again on Tuesday but quickly backed away both days.
Broader measures were higher too, moving back toward Monday's record highs, after several days of profit taking amid jitters about of third-quarter profits.
Bellwether technology shares were among the session's biggest gainers, as signs of improving computer demand were reinforced by Morgan Stanley's upgrade of Intel, the world's leading producer of semiconductors.
Stocks received an early lift from bonds, which ended a four-session losing streak and rallied after the Government reported that inflation at the producer level eased in September while retail sales rebounded from a summer slump.
The Labor Department said the Producer Price Index rose two-tenths of a percent in September; the Commerce Department said retail sales rose seven-tenths of a percent.
The two readings were seen as reinforcing the delicate balance that has helped the markets bounce back so quickly from July's selloff: strong enough economic growth to keep company profits rising but not so strong that prices will soar.
The Federal Reserve has been holding off an increase in its key lending rates, betting that the pace of business activity is slowing enough to contain inflationary pressures.
"Inflation is low; the odds of a Fed interest rate hike are remote at least until after the election, so people are comfortable with stocks," Bob Dickey, managing director of technical analysis at Dain Bosworth in Minneapolis, said.
Higher inflation and interest rates hurt bonds by making their fixed payments less attractive, forcing down prices to improve their yields. Higher rates at the Fed or the bond market hurt stocks by slowing consumer spending.
As bond prices rose yesterday, the yield on the 30-year Treasury -- a determinant of corporate and consumer borrowing costs -- fell to 6.84 percent from 6.88 late on Thursday, but still above last Friday's 6.74.
Advancing issues outnumbered declining stocks by 7 to 4 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 396.1 million shares.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.05 points to 700.66.
The advance in computer-related shares helped lift the Nasdaq market back to record levels. On Monday, the Nasdaq composite index closed at 1,250.87, its first high in four months after trailing the broad market's rebound from July's selloff.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 11.30 points yesterday, to 1,248.27, led by Intel, up 5 1/2, to 105 3/8, and Microsoft, up 3 3/8, to 137 1/8.
I.B.M. was among the Dow's biggest gainers, adding 7 points to the Dow's advance as it rose 2 1/8, to 129 7/8. Compaq rose 2 1/2, to 71 5/8.
"It's still evident to many investors that this is the growth area of the market and that it got sold off too heavily," Mr. Dickey of Dain Bosworth said. "This most attractive growth area is still attracting the money."
Shares of Sabre Group Holdings rose to 31 5/8 from an initial offering of 27 on its first day of trading. The computerized reservation system of American Airlines sold 20.2 million shares for a total of $545 million.
Cascade Communications tumbled 15 1/8, to 71 3/8. The company, a maker of switching products, reported third-quarter earnings that tripled its results from the similar period a year earlier, but it failed to surpass Wall Street's expectations.
Earlier, stocks in Tokyo rose. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 97.33 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,968.16.

HEADLINE: Impact of Canadian Strike Extends Beyond G.M.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Toyota Corollas that are assembled in North America use a part manufactured at a General Motors factory in Canada that is now on strike, showing the increasing vulnerability of auto makers to labor walkouts as they buy more parts from each other.
The General Motors Corporation sent a flat-bed truck with a police escort several times today to a factory in Oshawa, Ontario, to try to remove the die used to stamp seat brackets for the Toyota Motor Corporation cars, said James A. Nimigon, the strike captain at the factory. Mr. Nimigon said that the police had asked him to order the picketers to move aside and let the truck through the factory's north gate, and that he had refused. 
 D. Stewart Low, a G.M. spokesman, confirmed today that the auto maker was trying to remove a stamping die from the Oshawa plant on behalf of an outside customer, which he declined to name in keeping with company policy. Mr. Low said G.M. was telling the union that job preservation as well as profits depended on G.M.'s ability to maintain a reputation as a reliable supplier for other auto makers.
Other people familiar with the situation said that the die was for making Toyota Corolla parts.
Toyota assembles the fast-selling Corolla in Cambridge, Ontario, and in a joint venture with G.M. in Fremont, Calif. Both factories were still operating today.
"We're still open for business and we don't anticipate a problem at this point," said Greigory D. Mordue, a Toyota spokesman in Cambridge. He declined to comment on the company's inventory of the seat brackets, which hold springs inside seats, or the G.M. strike.
Mr. Nimigon said that he did not know if the seat brackets were produced elsewhere in North America, or if brackets for Corollas made in Japan were compatible. But, he added, "We just know they're very desirous of getting the die out." G.M. also wants to remove three containers from the factory, each holding 800 to 1,000 finished brackets, he said.
Michael Leveque, a union strike marshal, said that the union had sought but not received assurances that the die would be brought back to the factory after the strike.
Auto makers are buying more parts from each other and moving rapidly to establish joint ventures for auto parts production, all as a way to reap greater economies of scale. Chrysler and BMW recently announced plans to build an engine factory in Brazil as a joint venture.
Alex Trotman, the chairman and chief executive of Ford Motor, said on Thursday that the engine factory was a model for the industry. He said that a reorganization of Ford's auto parts operations was partly intended to increase sales to other auto makers, and that Ford would even consider joint ventures abroad with G.M.
But maintaining separate factories has insulated auto makers until recently from labor problems at their rivals' operation. When members of the United Automobile Workers union went on strike last March at two G.M. brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, some workers stayed on the job to continue making brakes that Chrysler and several other auto makers desperately needed.
The U.A.W. contracts with G.M. over the years have required workers to continue making parts for other auto makers during strikes. But the more militant Canadian union has not agreed to such a provision and, in any case, the labor contract in Canada has already expired.
The Canadian union's 26,000 G.M. workers are on strike to obtain new restrictions on G.M.'s ability to buy lower-cost parts from outside vendors. G.M. is trying to sell two parts factories in Canada, and the union also wants G.M. to guarantee that workers at these factories will not suffer a cut in wages or benefits.
G.M. has temporarily laid off only 2,000 American workers but is expected to lay off thousands more early next week when it closes a Cadillac factory in Detroit and a small-car plant in Lordstown, Ohio.
Basil E. Hargrove, the Canadian union's president, said in a call with reporters today that while high-level talks would continue in Toronto through the weekend, most of the bargainers had gone to their hometowns to celebrate Canadian Thanksgiving, which is on Monday.
Mr. Hargrove also said that he would not object if the U.A.W. reached a labor contract with G.M. while Canadian workers remained on strike. The U.A.W. and G.M. have already resolved most of their differences, people close to the talks said today.
Some auto analysts have predicted that the current strike in Canada will discourage foreign auto makers from building any more factories there. Mr. Hargrove said in a brief interview on Wednesday night that conservative Government policies, such as making it easier to hire replacement workers, were disrupting communities and making Canada a less attractive place to live and do business.

HEADLINE: Producer Data Show Prices Still in Check

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Moderating prices for food and energy helped keep inflation at the producer level in check last month while consumers spent cautiously at a pace scarcely faster than when the summer began, Government figures showed today.
The Producer Price Index climbed two-tenths of 1 percent in September, according to the Labor Department, a result that comforted the financial markets, which have feared that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates after the election to curb a rise in the prices. 
 "The P.P.I. provides even more evidence that inflation is under control and that the Fed can relax," said William Cheney, chief economist for John Hancock Financial Services in Boston.
This view prevailed even though the "core" rate of inflation, which excludes the often volatile food and energy components, rose three-tenths of 1 percent to match its biggest increase of the year.
Economists noted that the pickup in the core rate was dominated by presumably temporary surges in the price of cars and light trucks and that there was nothing worrisome in the prices of producer goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production.
The data encouraged investors, who drove bond and stock prices higher yesterday. The rise in bonds drove the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for consumer and corporate interest rates -- down to 6.84 percent from 6.88 percent. And the Dow Jones industrial average rose 47.71 points, to 5,969.38.
The markets were heartened even as the Commerce Department's first estimate of retail sales for September showed an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent, which was greater than expected.
But this was also heavily influenced by the automotive sector and seemed large only in comparison with a weak August, which now shows a two-tenths of 1 percent decline instead of a gain of that size, as initially estimated.
"The retailing picture going into the fourth quarter is quite weak," said Susan M. Sterne, president of Economic Analysis Associates, a Greenwich, Conn., firm specializing in consumer behavior. She said nominal sales growth in the third quarter was just six-tenths of 1 percent, the poorest since the final three months of 1991, when the economy was just emerging from its latest recession.
While income growth is "stable," she said, financial stress as reflected in record credit card delinquencies is restraining retail spending, which accounts for one-third of economic activity.
"We are starting to lend less and borrow less," Ms. Sterne declared, implying that the coming holiday shopping season may be no better than lackluster.
Excluding automotive dealers, who enjoyed a 1.7 percent gain, retail sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, not quite making up a five-tenths of 1 percent August decline.
In all, consumers pushed $205.7 billion across retail counters last month, 4.7 percent more, with no adjustment for inflation, than in September 1995. Consumer prices for the 12 months through August rose 2.9 percent.
Merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes posted a sales gain of one-tenth of 1 percent last month while those selling furniture and other home equipment had a sales decline of three-tenths of 1 percent.
In nondurables, up six-tenths of 1 percent over all, food stores registered a 1.2 percent sales gain while lesser increases were posted by gasoline service stations, restaurants and bars, and stores selling general merchandise. Drugstores and apparel stores had modest declines.
The report on producer prices, which does not include imported goods or services, showed sharp deceleration for both food and energy last month, each rising just two-tenths of 1 percent. Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers.
Passenger cars rose 1.2 percent after a small decline and prescription drugs, light trucks, book publishing and women's apparel and capital equipment also turned upward.
Prices for items at the intermediate stage of production, like construction materials, increased three-tenths of 1 percent and a scant one-tenth of 1 percent without food and energy. Durables used in manufacturing, like plywood, climbed six-tenths of 1 percent, reversing August's decline, while such nondurables as chemicals rose two-tenths of 1 percent.
Crude goods dropped 1.5 percent over all last month but rose six-tenths of 1 percent excluding food and energy.
Although Wall Street welcomed today's sets of figures, many analysts remained quite wary of inflation. Nicholas Perna of the Fleet Financial Group, for example, pointed to the relatively long time it has often taken for a tight labor market to generate faster inflation.
He warned, "By the time you see the state trooper with his radar gun, you've already got a ticket."

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Producer Prices" shows index of finished goods prices, from April 1995. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics); "Retail Sales" shows total retail sales, from April 1995. (Source: Commerce Department) (pg. 39)

HEADLINE: U.S. Presses Shaky Belarus to Honor A-Weapons Pact

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The United States, its influence limited, is trying to prevent the former Soviet republic of Belarus from slipping into a dictatorship and reneging on its promise to President Clinton to give up its nuclear missiles by the end of the year.
Ukraine and Kazakhstan, two other former Soviet republics that also inherited modern missiles, have both become nuclear-free, handing over their missiles, as agreed, to the Russian authorities for dismantling. But Belarus has not even begun the process. 
 The Belarussian President, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, has called for street demonstrations by handpicked "people's deputies" on Oct. 19 in an effort to disband Parliament and force through a new constitution in a referendum on Nov. 7, the anniversary of the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution.
The proposed constitution would extend his term until the year 2000, allow him a second seven-year term, let him appoint a majority of the highest court and control a new upper house of Parliament with veto power over the lower house. And despite opposition in Belarus, senior American officials say Mr. Lukashenko could win such a referendum, even without election fraud.
Mr. Lukashenko, a flamboyant, demagogic 41-year-old elected in 1994 to replace the man who brought the country to independence, wants to reunite with Russia and stymie market reform. He ran on an anti-corruption program and the promise to integrate with Russia and restore Soviet-style economic security. He has restored the Soviet-era flag, shut down newspapers and radio stations, fired elected officials, restricted human and civil rights, broken up some opposition demonstrations and banned others, and prevented the Parliament's chairman, Semyon Sharetsky, the country's second-ranking official, from appearing on television.
Belarus, with only a thin and debatable history of sovereignty separate from Moscow, might be considered just another victim of history, a sort of geopolitical joke. But unlike the authoritarian governments of Central Asia, for example, Belarus is a European country with nuclear weapons, bordering what are likely to be the boundaries of an expanding NATO and led by an unpredictable and openly anti-Western leader who is pushing for nearly unlimited power.
In light of the recent developments there, Defense Secretary William J. Perry, who is going to Moscow next week, has canceled plans to stop in Minsk, the Belarus capital, because of serious doubts that Belarus will become non-nuclear by 1997. Such a high-level visit would be seen as support for Mr. Lukashenko and its cancellation as a form of criticism.
The restoration of a Communist dictatorship in Europe would be an embarrassment for the Clinton Administration, which has broadcast its success in helping the former Soviet Union make a transition to a relatively democratic, free-market way of life.
A failure to get Belarus to give up its 18 nuclear missiles, however, would be dangerous, even if they are currently under the control of Russian officers. The SS-25 missiles are Russia's most modern mobile single-warhead missiles.
The Clinton Administration is using what tools it can muster to influence Mr. Lukashenko. The Americans are pressing the Russians hard to get Belarus to live up to its nuclear promises.
"We'd be comfortable with Russia playing a role in this," a senior American official said.
Mr. Lukashenko, for his part, has talked darkly of a Washington-Moscow conspiracy to undermine him. Last April, he and President Boris N. Yeltsin signed a pact of "federation" between Belarus and Russia, but Amrican officials suggest that Mr. Yeltsin was looking more to his own re-election struggle than to real reunification, a notion popular among Russian Communists and ultranationalists. The Russians are also leery of absorbing the sizeable debts of Belarus, which has made little effort to reform its economy or collectivist agriculture.
The United States has also tried to strengthen the democratic opposition to Mr. Lukashenko by providing assistance to non-governmental organizations working there and discouraging large corporations like McDonald's and Ford, who seek advice from the State Department, from making significant investments in Belarus just now. The United States also gave quick political asylum to the leader of the main democratic opposition party, Zenon Poznyak.
Congress, in the 1997 Foreign Assistance Act, has banned all American aid to the Belarus Government.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Pressures Mexico To Halt Tomato Shipments
The Clinton Administration pressured Mexico into agreeing to end the shipment of low-priced tomatoes to the United States, defusing a major political issue in Florida just weeks before the election. 
 The action, which seems likely to raise consumers' costs for tomatoes this winter, was the latest in a series of Administration efforts, under the aegis of Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor, to sidestep trade problems. [Page 1.]
 
Fidelity Funds Hold Cam-Net Issues
Two mutual funds managed by Fidelity Investment are among the biggest investors in a small Canadian company whose chairman, Daryl Buerge, was charged Thursday with conspiracy to commit securities fraud in connection with a Federal sting operation. The Fidelity Convertible Securities fund and the Fidelity Equity-Income fund bought convertible bonds issued by the Cam-Net Communications Network of Vancouver, British Columbia. [38.]
 
Vickrey, Nobel Laureate, Dies
Professor William Vickrey of Columbia University who won the Nobel memorial prize in economics earlier this week -- and was cheered by "the bully pulpit" it offered him -- was found found dead behind the wheel of his car on the Hutchinson River Parkway in Harrison, N.Y., of an apparent cardiac arrest. He was driving to a conference in Cambridge, Mass., after a whirlwind three days of nonstop attention. He was 82. [1.]
 
S.& L. Poster Boy No More
Just a few years ago Charles H. Keating Jr. was the poster boy of the savings and loan crisis, a shady operator accused by the Government of having committed about every crime associated with the debacle. But in a striking turn of events, Mr. Keating had his state criminal conviction overturned earlier this year, then last week was released from prison on bail. Suddenly, Government officials and other experts are having to confront the question of what it means if the supposed arch-villain of the savings and loan crisis is not found guilty. News Analysis. [38.]
 
A New Index for Growth Brands
The Hambrecht & Quist Group, the investment bank in San Francisco, is seeking to carve out a niche for itself with a new index it calls its Branded Consumer Growth index. It tracks 51 companies as diverse as Tiffany & Company, Starbucks, Cannondale, Nike, Boston Beer and Ben & Jerry's. The index has outperformed the S.& P. 500 since its start in 1993. [39.]
 
Time Warner Wins a Round
Time Warner won the first round of a bitter dispute over efforts by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York to promote Rupert Murdoch's new 24-hour news channel. A Federal judge temporarily blocked New York City from showing the channel on a city-run cable station carried by Time Warner. [1.]
 
Stocks Break Out of Slump
After a four-day slump, stocks posted a strong gain, buoyed by economic reports that pointed to low inflation and steady interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 47.71 points, to 5,969.38, for a loss of 23.48 points on the week. The Nasdaq composite gained 11.30 points, to 1,248.27. For the week, the Nasdaq eked out a 0.71 point gain. [41.]
 
Treasury securities' prices also rebounded, sending the yield on the 30-year bond down to 6.84 percent from 6.88 percent on Thursday. The market will be closed Monday in observance of Columbus Day. [41.]
 
An Aggressive Move Into Asia
An aggressive electric power company must go far these days for growth. After acquiring 80 percent of Consolidated Electric Power Asia Ltd. for $2.1 billion, A. W. Dahlberg, chairman of the Southern Company, is looking to cities like Keti Bandar, Pakistan, and Sual, in the Philippines, for profits. [38.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ADVOCACY GROUPS;
Christian Coalition Mailing Prompts Apology to Blacks

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
In a move that has been criticized as lacking racial sensitivity, the Christian Coalition has distributed a sample of an election pamphlet with photographs depicting a fictitious white candidate espousing views favored by the conservative religious organization and another fictional candidate, who is black, opposing them.
Christian Coalition officials, who, in recent months, have sought to improve relations with blacks, said they were embarrassed and chagrined by the sample pamphlets and said they had stopped sending them out last week. 
 Ralph Reed, the group's executive director, said that he had faxed a letter of apology to the head of the branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in Texas, where the sample had been widely distributed.
He added that he had tried, so far without success, to call civil rights leaders such as the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Kweisi Mfume, the national leader of the N.A.A.C.P., to express his regret over the incident.
The pamphlet is a sample of the evangelical group's 1996 voter guide for state and Congressional elections. On the cover is a picture of "John Doe." Under his photograph are positions he champions: support for a balanced budget amendment, backing of vouchers to allow parents to send children to private and religious schools, support for school prayer and opposition to "homosexual adoption of children."
All the positions taken by John Doe are in line with those advocated by the Christian Coalition.
Across the page from Mr. Doe is a picture of a black candidate, "Joe Sample." He supports "abortion on demand," opposes term limits for Congress, supports "taxpayer funding of obscene art" and opposes every position the coalition favors.
"I think it's outrageous," said Wade Henderson, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a coalition of liberal organizations that lobbies on economic and equality issues. "It obviously is intended to send a not-so-subtle message about the coalition's attitude towards black candidates, which I think is troubling."
In a telephone interview, Mr. Reed said that the sample was prepared by a private company and that its distribution had been approved by a low-level employee who had seen only a poor quality fax that was so dark that the race of the candidates could not easily be discerned. He said that none of his group's top officials had seen the pamphlet before it was distributed.
"It was a mistake made by an outside vendor and not by any member of the Christian Coalition staff," Mr. Reed said. "It was wrong. It should not have happened. I was personally offended by the characterization of an African-American candidate in this way. As someone who grew up in the South, I am extremely sensitive to the use of race in this manner. I have zero tolerance for political race-baiting of any kind, no matter how subtle."
The voter guide sample was part of a packet that included a cover letter, an order form so churches could order the guide in bulk and a memorandum from a Washington lawyer assuring ministers that distribution of the pamphlet would not violate Internal Revenue Service regulations.
The letter said the voter guides had been "thoroughly reviewed" to insure they did not violate I.R.S. regulations. The Christian Coalition is being sued by the Federal Election Commission, which has accused the coalition of promoting Republican candidates, including former President George Bush, Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina through the use of its voter guides. As a nonpartisan organization that asserts that its political activity is educational, the Christian group is prohibited from endorsing or working for specific candidates.
The controversy over the sample election guides comes at a time when the Christian Coalition, which was founded by Pat Robertson, the television evangelist, has been trying to reach out to politically conservative blacks.
After a spate of arsons at small black churches in the South, the group raised about $600,000 to help rebuild some of them. At the time, Mr. Reed said he was sorry that too many white evangelicals were on the "sidelines" or "on the wrong side" in the desegregation struggles of the 1950's and 1960's.
Mr. Reed said that his group intended to send out about 500,000 voters guides -- thought none with the offending pictures of ficticious black and white candidates -- to black churches out of a total of 45 million pamhlets that will be sent out before the Nov. 5 election.
Several civil rights leaders said today that the sample voter guide had raised suspicions about Mr. Reed's apology.
"It really calls into question the credibility of the overtures that the Christian Coalition made to the black community after the church burnings," said Hugh Price, president of the National Urban League. "I recall people being skeptical of those overtures and how genuine they were. An incident like this affirms that skepticism."
The pamphlet reminded some political scientists of past campaign advertisements that used racial imagery like the George Bush commercial that featured Willie Horton, a black convict who raped a white woman while free on a prison furlough program, and the 1990 commercial for Senator Helms that showed white hands crumpling a job rejection notice while a narrator spoke of the position going to a woman or a minority.
It is unclear how widely the sample voter guide was distributed. People for the American Way, a liberal organizations that often monitors the activities of the Christian right, said it had received calls from affiliates in Texas and Pennsylvania who has seen copies of the guide.
Mr. Reed said he did not know how many copies had been mailed.

HEADLINE: In Federal Subsidies, South Gets the Short Stick;
End the Union?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's annual report on the fiscal shortchanging of New York and other "frost belt" states is nothing but cant (news article, Oct. 8). As Mr. Moynihan knows, one of the objects of Federal spending programs is to compensate for differences in fiscal capacity among the states, usually measured by per capita income. 
 All of the large "deficit" states in his analysis boast per capita income above the national norm, resulting in higher tax payments. In contrast, most of the "surplus" states record incomes below the national average and thus send less money to Washington on a per capita basis. Each year, the Senator suggests this redistribution of Federal monies is unfair. Does he propose we dissolve the Union?
 
BERNARD L. WEINSTEIN
Denton, Tex., Oct. 8, 1996
 
Chairman, Institute of Applied
Economics, Univ. of North Texas

NEW YORK
 
Economics Nobelist Dies
When William Vickrey won the Nobel Prize on Tuesday, he seemed finally to have a platform from which to make his economic ideas widely known. Television crews descended. Admirers offered to set up meetings with people with the power to put his proposals to work. And then, as suddenly as it had happened, it was over. Professor Vickrey, who was 82, was found dead behind the wheel of his car on the Hutchinson River Parkway in Harrison, N.Y. [Page 1.]
 
Mayor Is Rebuffed in TV War
The Time Warner media conglomerate won the first round of a bitter dispute over Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to promote Rupert Murdoch's new 24-hour news channel yesterday, when a Federal judge temporarily blocked the New York City from showing the channel on a city-run cable station. [1.]
 
Another Police Bill Vetoed
Siding yet again with Mayor Giuliani against the powerful police unions, Governor Pataki vetoed a bill that would have promoted hundreds of sergeants and lieutenants in New York City's Police Department. It was the sixth time in roughly a year that Mr. Pataki vetoed legislation backed by the police unions but opposed by Mr. Giuliani. [25.]
 
Elections Board Under Fire
Long after most major cities have handed over their elections to nonpartisan professionals, the New York City Board of Elections remains a bastion of political appointees. Criticism of the board has been rekindled in the wake of two botched elections this year. [25.]
 
A Candidate's Education
Nearly three years after the Long Island Rail Road massacre that killed her husband, wounded her son and transformed her into a political activist against assault weapons, Carolyn McCarthy says she still has to remind herself to keep her head up in a crowd and be a public person. But four weeks before Election Day, this blunt 52-year-old nurse is the Democratic candidate in one of the nation's most closely watched Congressional races. [25.]
 
Writing Songs That Heal
John Beltzer used to worry about making the pop charts. But these days the songwriter is concerned about other charts, the kind on the hospital beds of sick and dying children. Since January, he has helped to compose and produce 165 songs for hospitalized children. About New York by David Gonzalez. [25.]
 
A Startling Wife-Beating Case
Last February, a Hasidic man was arrested and charged in Rockland County with beating his sleeping wife into unconsciousness with a hammer. Yesterday, the wife testified at her husband's trial that she was able to see him seconds before he beat her. Then, in a revelation that stunned the courtroom, she said that she and her husband had received counseling from John Cardinal O'Connor, the leader of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. [26.]
 
Officer Convicted in Death
Despite his claim that he was not the one to pull the trigger, a Manhattan jury convicted an off-duty police officer in the accidental shooting death of a woman who had been celebrating her 25th birthday in a Washington Heights restaurant. [26.]
 
For 2, Housing Crisis Ends
Two women whose wretched living conditions were described this week in a series of articles in The New York Times about the city's hidden housing crisis will soon reach goals that had eluded them through years of deprivation. [27.]
 
The Tunnel, a nightclub shut down by the authorities in August, reopened last night after reaching a settlement with the Police Department and the State Liquor Authority. [26.]

With his rape trial scheduled to begin on Tuesday, lawyers for Alex Kelly, the Darien man who fled to Europe after being charged with two sexual assaults a decade ago, were negotiating a possible plea bargain last night with prosecutors and a lawyer for one of his accusers. [28.]
