HEADLINE: Employment Workshop for Older Jobless

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN work disappears, depression is likely to take its place. So say those who conduct A.A.R.P. Works, a career-planning workshop for the unemployed. Aimed at helping people older than 50 find new jobs, the program is sponsored by the American Association of Retired Persons.
Since its inception in 1988, A.A.R.P. Works has become an accurate barometer, recording the highs and lows in the Westchester job market, said Claire Watsky, a professional career counselor. 
 "For years, there were only lows," observed Ms. Watsky, who has been the volunteer head of the workshop since it began. "When it came to employment, older people, no matter how well qualified, were viewed as anathema."
Saying that the most recent survey conducted by the association showed that people 55 and older had more than seven times the unemployment rate of those 16 to 54 years old, Ms. Watsky continued: "By now, we can pretty accurately predict the climate of the job market. In June we first noticed a distinct upturn in the hiring of older workers. And I say, 'It's about time.' "
In the last few years, despite the upward surge in employment in the county, Ms. Watsky said: "The 50- and 60-year-olds were the very last group to be hired. It wasn't until after all the available 30- and 40-year-olds were gone that employers finally began to give experienced older workers a chance, since many businesses were short staffed as a result of too much downsizing."
When Dorothy Allen's job with a nonprofit crime victims information and counseling organization was phased out last January, she went to London, she said.
"I felt I really needed a break before beginning a job search," she explained. "I'm over 60. I knew it was going to be tough, but I have to work. I've been supporting myself since my divorce many years ago."
Ms. Allen, who spent 15 years as the assistant director of Legal Awareness of Westchester, a nonprofit clearinghouse for legal information, said she honed her marketable skills as a volunteer.
"I was the ultimate volunteer when I was leading the good suburban life in New Rochelle as a wife and the mother of two daughters," she said. "I was on the library board, on the board of the Girl Scouts, president of the P.T.A., and I learned a lot."
But nothing, she added, prepared her for the current job market.
"For three months, I answered ads, sent out resumes without getting to first base," she said. "Not a single interview resulted from my efforts. Of course, I knew I was doing something wrong, so last spring, when I read an article about the A.A.R.P. workshops, I signed up."
From all reports, Ms. Allen recalled, she expected the other participants to be mired in gloom and doom.
"I kept hearing that the older jobless going into uncharted territory were frightened and fearful," she said. "To my surprise, I found high-caliber movers and shakers, a very confident group. While acknowledging that they had lost their jobs, most of them were able to view their situation positively, as an opportunity to do something different and interesting."
"One of the workshop's counselors opened up my mind to possibilities," Ms. Allen said. "On the practical side, she critiqued my resume and helped me redo it, and she stressed the importance of networking. Tell everyone you know that you are looking for a job was her advice. And it worked. A friend of a friend of mine faxed my new resume to a nonprofit organization that was looking for a project coordinator. On Aug. 1, I started working for Tobacco Free New York on issues that are dear to my heart, such as implementing programs to discourage teen-agers from smoking. I am extremely happy with the way things turned out."
And so, Ms. Watsky said, are others in the workshop group.
"In the eight years we've been running the A.A.R.P. program, this is the most optimistic time for employment of older workers," she said. "Good stories are coming back to us from the participants. For instance, a former nurse has landed a good job in the health field. Several people who relocated to take jobs out of state report that they are making good salaries."
Walter M. Svec, 58, a former banker and a member of the group, did not need a big salary but, he said, "I did need a job to supplement my pension, and I felt too young to retire, especially since my wife is still working."
Mr. Svec, who spent 39 years climbing the career ladder at a major bank, before retiring as a vice president in the commercial credit division, signed up for the A.A.R.P. workshop because, he said, "Having spent my entire working life in one place, I really didn't know how to go about looking for a job."
Mr. Svec said he came away from the course with a better understanding of himself. "I was able to make a self-assessment and define my values," he said. "And on the practical side, I learned interviewing techniques and how to write a good resume."
Two weeks ago, Mr. Svec started working as manager of student accounts in the business department at a college.
"The atmosphere is very pleasant," he said. "I like working with people. And I'm able to put my banking experience to new use."
The next workshop will begin on Oct. 21 and will run through Nov. 21. The fee for the seven sessions is $20. The program will be conducted by trained A.A.R.P. volunteers, including an executive recruiter, a management consultant, a retired guidance counselor and a former businessman. Speakers other than the association's volunteers will also offer advice.
A free information session will be held Wednesday from 10 A.M. to noon at Diversified Information Advisers, 4 Manhattanville Road in Purchase, the site of the workshops.
For more information, Ms. Watsky can be reached at 381-2048.

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
As Serene as a Teahouse in Kyoto

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
IN A ROW OF SEDATE BROWNSTONES ON THE Upper East Side of Manhattan, one stands out. The tall windows, edged in black, look like hanging scrolls. The off-white facade, the dark gray sidewalk and the weeping Japanese pine by the front door merely hint at what lies beyond it. Inside is Kaikodo, one of the city's newest and most elegant art galleries, which opened six months ago in a modernized town house on 64th Street east of Lexington Avenue.
Hung on a wall of the low-ceilinged entryway with a shimmering black slate floor is a Japanese scroll depicting the darkening leaves and misty mountains of autumn. Two steps down, in the library, a room of honey-toned floors and bookshelves, are colorsplashed Song and Ming ceramics and ancient Shang bronzes, each framed in its own cubicle. The 16-foot windows illuminate Kaikodo's main gallery, a soaring space two stories high displaying 14th-century paintings and 16th-century calligraphy. 
 Kaikodo is the brainchild of Howard and Mary Ann Rogers, its owners, who have spent most of the last 20 years living and working as teachers and art dealers in Japan. While the gallery's serene, uncluttered spaces may suggest a Kyoto temple or a teahouse, Mr. Rogers said that its most Japanese aspect was its absence of extraneous detail.
He made his first trip to Japan in 1976 on a Ford Foundation fellowship after graduate school in California. He planned to stay six months but remained to write a book on Chinese paintings, which he completed in 1978. He then started teaching art history at Sophia University in Tokyo and married Mary Ann Perse.
By 1980, the couple had begun collecting Chinese paintings and ceramics. Three years later, to finance their expanding appetites for objects and augment their modest teachers' salaries, they became part-time dealers. Their first piece was a Song jar, which was given them as payment for a translation he had done.
Throughout the 1980's, the couple helped organize exhibitions at several prominent American museums. Mr. Rogers worked on the 1980 catalogue of "Eight Dynasties of Chinese Paintings" that appeared at both the Cleveland Museum of Art and the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., and he was the curator of "Masterworks of Ming and Qing Painting From the Forbidden City," a 1989 traveling exhibition that wound up at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mrs. Rogers catalogued the ceramics from Tokyo's Idemitsu Museum of Arts for a 1988 touring exhibition, "In Pursuit of the Dragon," which was sponsored by the Seattle Art Museum.
Their background in museum work gave them an advantage few dealers enjoy. "When we became dealers, we knew museum curators all over the world," Mr. Rogers said. "But we had known many of them in graduate school at Berkeley or traveling in the late 1960's in Taiwan." Finally, in 1994, Mr. Rogers gave up teaching to become a full-time dealer.
The timing of the couple's setting up shop in New York was fortuitous. "I call it good luck," Mr. Rogers said. They bought the town house during the real estate recession, and, after a year of planning and a year of construction, they opened the gallery just as the Asian art market gained momentum.
Kaikodo is doing a brisk business. At its first exhibition last spring, most of the pieces were sold; in its current show, which ends Oct. 26, more than half were bought. The rarities in this show include a tile from the fifth century emblazoned with a boar's head (priced at $45,000) and an owl-shaped Shang bronze pot ($1 million). The least costly object, at $2,500, is an 18th-century still life. Last month, the staff at Kaikodo doubled in size, with the addition of Carol Conover and Arnold Chang, two Chinese art specialists formerly with Sotheby's.
James J. Lally, a prominent New York dealer in Asian art, said he welcomed the addition of Kaikodo to the Manhattan art scene. "This is a positive development," he said. "It demonstrates again the importance of New York as an Asian art center, at a time when Europe is becoming more difficult because of the new tax laws in the European Economic Community."
Notwithstanding difficulties in foreign markets, the Rogerses continue to operate a gallery in Kamakura, Japan, also called Kaikodo. In comparison with the Manhattan branch, Mr. Rogers said the one in Japan was almost rustic; it is far more crowded with objects and set up to function as a home. (In fact, the couple live there half the year.) Also, business is conducted differently in each place. In Japan, he and his wife take the artworks to clients, especially museums. In New York, most sales take place at the gallery.
Mr. Rogers said he preferred the Western style. Standing in the main gallery surrounded by art treasures, he said, "In Japan, everyone is secretive, and important scrolls are kept rolled up and out of sight."

HEADLINE: ART;
A Journey in Geometric Designs And Photographs That Confound

BYLINE: HELEN A. HARRISON 

 BODY:

A Journey in Geometric Art
 Wisser Library, New York Institute of Technology, Rte. 25A, Old Westbury. Through Oct. 30. 686-7633.
In a survey spanning more than 40 years, Martin Schreiber traces his development as an abstract artist who began as a painter but eventually embraced sculpture as well. In fact, his most recent pieces are amalgams, painted reliefs that combine elements of both forms of expression. 
 The earliest work, a 1952 oil, is an understated homage to de Stijl principles of harmony, not imitative but respectful of its source. Like Mondrian's canvases, its austerity is relieved by evidence of the painter's touch. Later, however, Mr. Schreiber would expunge painterly handwriting, opting instead for an almost mechanistic formalism in which all trace of brushwork is eliminated.
The works of the last 30 years are progressively concerned with color relationships and then symbolic form, as in Mr. Schreiber's 1980's "Comet" series, which owes something to Kandinsky's late geometric phase. His recent reliefs, combining painted and cutout metal elements -- some in the shapes of Hebrew letters -- are an uncomfortable union, lacking the cohesiveness and purity of the earlier, color-based geometries.

Space Sites 1
 Port Washington Public Library, 1 Library Drive, Port Washington. Through Oct 30. 883-4400.
Using photography to reinterpret earlier work, Katinka Mann has transformed shaped canvases into cut and folded wall reliefs that subtly tamper with the evidence before our eyes. Texture, dimension and, above all, spatial relationships are redefined in terms of a new and remarkably effective approach to perception.
Ms. Mann has employed light to color and model the original shapes, making interior spaces glow and exterior planes shimmer with unseen radiance. Her Polaroid and Cibachrome prints are then reshaped to confound notions of depth and surface, negative and positive, recession and protrusion.
In "Grey," for example, a shadowed area is brought forward, physically defying its implicit depth. "Brown With Opening" turns an apparent hole into an advancing shape. In several works, highlighted textures are belied by the prints' smooth, shiny surfaces. Colors that sparkle with the metallic luster of hot-rod enamel are also illusory, evoked by the nuances of reflected light.
 
Joan Harrison: Photographs
 Port Washington Public Library. Through Oct. 30.
Ms. Harrison is showing selections from her "Hybrids" and "Chasing the Light" series, two distinct bodies of work with little in common beyond symbolic content. While "Chasing the Light" is based on still-life setups photographed in black and white, the "Hybrids" combine color Polaroid prints with oil pastel drawings.
In both series, Ms. Harrison deals with identity as a mutable concept. The mask is a recurring motif, suggesting discrepancies between outer appearance and hidden reality. Her most arresting device is the application to dolls' heads of torn sections of portrait photographs, reversing the mask metaphor by using real faces to hide the false ones.
The "Chasing the Light" prints, with their understated theatricality and allusions to Surrealist precedents, are far more engaging than the "Hybrids," in which the drawing often seems a mere mannerism. Only when the subject triumphs, as in "The Lovers" and "Anxiety," does the marriage of media prove to be a happy one.

Unique Differences
 Graphic Eye Gallery, 301 Main Street, Port Washington. Through Oct. 27. 883-9668.
Although the gallery is primarily devoted to prints, neither of the artists in this two-person show is exhibiting them. Clara Steiner's drawings on cloth and mixed-media works are graphic but not printed, while Alice H. Proskauer's collaged canvases go in a different direction altogether. Perhaps that divergence explains the show's title.
Ms. Steiner refers to printed sources in her group of "Bookless Pages" and other works using recycled paper. In "Dot Com" and "Max-Pax-Fax," new information technologies are critiqued as purveyors of raw data, often without context or meaning. A card table cover and bedsheet become more intimate vehicles for communication, allowing domestic associations to suggest human interaction that sometimes connects and sometimes misses the mark.
Words and phrases play a prominent role in Ms. Steiner's work, with puns, admonitions and witty asides reminding us not to take our confusion too seriously. Even her "Angry Jacket," weighed down by decorative trappings and clearly fed up with playing the stereotype of feminine finery, is more an amusing caricature than a militant rebel.
Ms. Proskauer's canvases are arrangements of torn and shredded burlap, built up in elaborate organic shapes that she further models with painted highlights. Occasionally sand is added for extra textural interest, but apart from their tactile qualities the works are curiously vapid. Some artists can wrest extraordinary power and meaning from the basest materials, but Ms. Proskauer fails to transcend cloth and pigment.

HEADLINE: Sam and Elizabeth, Guns and Art in Hartford

BYLINE: By ALBERTA EISEMAN 

 BODY:
THE new exhibition at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford is in part a portrait of Victorian New England in the industrial age, in part a profile of a vibrant, influential couple, Sam and Elizabeth Colt. "Sam and Elizabeth: Legend and Legacy of Colts Empire" tells its multi-faceted story through paintings, sculpture, furnishings, decorative arts, period photographs and manuscripts.
Samuel Colt (1814-1862) was, of course, the firearms inventor and entrepreneur who built an industrial village on the banks of the Connecticut River, changing the face of Hartford and the state. 
 Elizabeth Hart Jarvis Colt (1826-1905) was his high-born, public-spirited wife, who focused on philanthropy and art collecting, creating a private picture gallery in her Hartford mansion and bequeathing it upon her death to the Wadsworth Atheneum -- unusual achievements for a woman of her time.
Their lives were marked by extraordinary financial success and worldwide recognition, but also by tragedy. Samuel Colt died after a mere six years of marriage and of Elizabeth Colt's four children, three died in infancy, the last in his 30's. Mrs. Colt dedicated the rest of her life to building a church, a park, several monuments and a wing of the Wadsworth Atheneum.
"Creating a historical exhibition infused with art was no small challenge," said William Hosley, the Atheneum's curator of American decorative arts who with Karen Blanchfield, the department's assistant curator, organized the show. "It's a great story that has both human drama and beautiful things."
Appropriately enough, the first exhibit is the well-known sculpture of a rampant colt that stood atop the blue, onion-shaped dome of the Colt armory until 1989. Executed in gilt zinc in Germany in 1860, the lively landmark became Colt's trademark and symbol of his firearms industry.
Flanking the rearing horse are two romantic, monumental oil paintings representing the inventor and his wife, the massive gilt frames crowned by the colt. There are also intimate miniature portraits of the couple done in 1856, the year of their wedding. Period quotations and personal effects give visitors a brief overview of both lives, including Samuel's earlier, ill-fated attempt at various enterprises and his great talent for self-promotion.
The section on Coltsville presents, in photographic murals, prints and paintings, the factory village that grew around the still-existing armory. The 200-acre complex included workers' housing, a community center, a farm, a fire engine company and a factory that manufactured wicker furniture.
At the push of a button, museum visitors can tune in to the sounds of armory machinery, then to the brass band formed by factory workers, many of them German immigrants.
The owners of this industrial empire lived in a grandiose mansion known as Armsmear, set on a knoll overlooking the factory village. Built in 1857, the 20-room villa with its four-story tower, conservatory, greenhouses, ponds and landscaped grounds was considered one of the most lavish in the state. Mrs. Colt, a pillar of the Episcopal Church, left the house as a residence for clergy widows and laywomen.
A series of environments recreate Armsmear's library, reception room and observatory with original furnishings. Foremost among the reconstructive spaces is Mrs. Colt's picture gallery, featuring 30 paintings by American and European artists.
Mrs. Colt turned to the painter Frederic Church -- a Hartford neighbor -- for advice on planning the gallery. Church's own brooding landscape, "Vale of St. Thomas, Jamaica" holds center stage, along with Albert Bierstadt's misty canvas "In the Yosemite."
Central to the exhibition is the extensive section devoted to Colt's revolvers. His repeating revolver was patented in 1836, then became "the gun that won the West" and the key to his success.
"It was the perfect climate to make a fortune making guns," said Mr. Hosley. The mid-19th century, with its wars and rebellions in the United States and in Europe, and the new wealth and leisure that popularized target shooting and hunting, meant "Guns, far from being stigmatized, emerged as symbols of progress during that time."
Correspondence and gifts from high-placed admirers of Colt's firearms -- the Czars of Russia, the Sultan of Turkey, leaders of nationalist uprisings in Italy, Hungary and France -- are on display along with jewels, porcelains, fine glass and antique furnishings purchased during the couple's six-month bridal tour of Europe and Mrs. Colt's extensive later travels with her son Caldwell.
One of the most intriguing sections of the show documents Samuel Colt's devotion to the legendary Charter Oak. The centuries-old tree, said to have been the hiding place of Connecticut's Colonial charter when the British wanted to revoke it in 1687, was felled by a storm on Aug. 21, 1856.
"Colt wrapped himself and his enterprise in the mantle of the sacred tree," Mr. Hosley related. "He summoned the company band to play dirges and patriotic hymns at the site of 'aged monarch of the forest.' "
He also purchased much of the wood and had it carved into myriad objects, including an intricately carved, canoe-shaped cradle -- Colt claimed he was a man who could "paddle his own canoe" -- made for Sam Jr., embellished with the heads of eight colts and two rampant colt finials. Another eccentric work is an ornate chair carved for the Mayor of Hartford, bought by Samuel Colt when the common council balked at paying the bill.
"Sam and Elizabeth Colt were individuals driven to action by personal ambition, civic pride and a need for worldly and spiritual rewards," said Mr. Hosley. "Together, they helped transform the culture and economy of a community that, a century later, is grappling with the legacy of industrialization and a history of dependence on arms manufacturing."
"Sam and Elizabeth," at the Wadsworth Atheneum, 600 Main Street, Hartford, until March 9, 1997. Tues.-Sun., 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., $8, discounts for senior citizens and students; children under 6 and museum members free.

HEADLINE: Helping Wineries Grow the Best Grapes

BYLINE: By MERYL SPIEGEL 

 BODY:
AS the Long Island wine harvest rolls into full gear, with the 17 or so wineries pulling their grapes for the 1996 vintage, Alice Wise, a small sturdy woman, is patrolling a two-acre vineyard in Riverhead, picking grapes by hand for her own special cellar, a basement winery the size of a large, walk-in closet.
Ms. Wise is not pressing grapes for a profit nor is she a home wine maker concocting her own blend. She is a viticultural specialist employed by Cornell Cooperative Extension at the Long Island Horticultural Research Laboratory, a 70-acre farm devoted exclusively to the study of vegetables, fruits and flowers grown in the region. 
 She is trying to determine which grape varieties will thrive best on Long Island, given its climate, soil and limited growing season. Her primary mission is to discover which ones can produce at least three tons of high quality grapes an acre.
"We can't have vines that produce one ton an acre," she said. "Even though they may be great in fruit quality, they don't pay the bills."
In France, where a bottle of wine could sell for $150 or $300, yield is not that critical, she added. "However, in the United States, especially on Long Island, taxes are high, labor is high, and there is a certain economic yield that you need to function as a business."
While Ms. Wise spends some time studying grapevine disease and pest management, most of her attention is devoted to pinpointing which varieties will grow best on Long Island. In fact, on a shoestring budget, she is providing the 20-year-old industry -- now believed to be grossing about $15 million a year -- with the only viticultural research specific to the area.
Every important wine region -- upstate New York, California, France -- has large, well-financed research programs because the data regarding one region is not applicable to another, according to Richard Olsen-Harbich, the wine maker at Jamesport Vineyards.
"What a chardonnay does on Long Island is very different than what it does in California or Upstate New York," said Dr. Herodotus Damianos, owner of Pindar Vineyards in Peconic, the largest in the region, and Duck Walk Vineyards in Water Mill, adding that the young industry lacked the resources of a major research institution.
While Cornell Cooperative Extension of Suffolk County pays Ms. Wise's full-time salary, she receives funds each year from the New York State Agricultural Experimental Station in Geneva to cover certain fixed expenses. For the last two years, the annual appropriation was $11,000, down from $15,000 in 1994, according to James Hunter, director of the station.
All funds necessary to support the research vineyard and other grape-related projects -- amounting to $10,000 a year -- must be "pieced together" through grants and corporate work, Ms. Wise said.
Mr. Hunter said in a phone interview that funds for the program were cut, because his budget, amounting to $10 million this year, had been cut $3.5 million over seven years. And since support for agricultural research is "so hard to come by," he said, "the private sector is going to have to help." Its future, he added, will depend on a partnership with private industry, state and Federal governments and universities with agricultural programs.
Mr. Olsen-Harbich of Jamesport Vineyards asserted that a major wine-growing region could not rely on private enterprise for research and development because there was "too much self-interest" at stake. And because the wine industry provides "one of the only viable types of agriculture" that can preserve farm land and promote tourism on the East End, he said there should be more financial support from government agencies.
In fact, the local industry is starting to pitch in. A number of vineyard owners, managers and wine makers have formed the Grape Research Advisory Committee to organize fund-raising events to sustain Ms. Wise's research.
Ursula Masoud, co-owner of Paumanok Vineyards in Aquebogue and a member of the fund-raising committee, said: "We have to keep it going in order to establish a database that everyone can draw from." And since the "state is in a squeeze, we must look for additional sources of funding and industry members have to play a role."
The committee's first event will be on Oct. 25 at Macari Vineyards in Mattituck. Through a $25 admission price and a cash raffle, Ms. Wise is hoping that the event will raise $5,000 to supplement her 1997 budget.
Those who attend will get the chance to taste the first wines produced from the vineyard's harvest last fall. They will include three chardonnays, a merlot, a cabernet sauvignon, a pinot noir and a dornfelder. "These are research wines meant to show members of the industry what different clones and varieties might taste like as wine,"Ms. Wise explained.
As a result of a tasting of dornfelder last April, Joseph Macari, owner of the new Macari Vineyards, said he planned to plant two acres of the German vine next year. If it wasn't for Ms. Wise, Mr. Macari said that neither he nor his new wine maker from Napa would have been exposed to the dark red variety that is "good for blending." An advantage of dornfelder, he added, is that it is an "early red" that ripens before the whites, allowing the grower to start harvesting sooner.
The motivating force behind the vineyard project was a survey of Long Island vintners taken by Ms. Wise in 1991 asking them what kind of grape and wine research they needed. "The majority of respondents said that clone research was what they wanted most," she said.
"Clones are like strains or different types of the same variety," Ms. Wise explained. For instance, she grows 14 clones of chardonnay in her vineyard and sees slight differences between them. "I see variation in how the vines grow, in cluster size and shape, and in how they taste even though they all taste like chardonnay."
Ms. Wise explained that a clone is discovered when a researcher notices that, for instance, one chardonnay vine looks or tastes or is behaving differently from the vine next to it, or the chardonnay in one vineyard is exhibiting a different character from the one in the vineyard next door. The researcher then selects out the clone, tests it and if the vine is, in fact, a different strain, the plant may be released to nurseries, where the new clone is propagated and then sold to grape growers.
Five years ago, Ms. Wise, previously a fruit specialist at the farm, was assigned to head the grape and wine research program in 1991. Within a year, she planted the research vineyard where she is currently growing 33 grape varieties and will produce small lots of wine from 15 this year -- 8 chardonnays, 4 merlots and 3 other reds grown in Europe, dornfelder and lemberger from Germany and gamay from the Burgundy region of France.
Several North Fork vintners interviewed said they had learned about new wine making possibilities through tastings of the research wines and often consulted with Ms. Wise by phone or in the field about pest and disease control. Charles Masoud, co-owner of Paumonok Vineyard and president of the Long Island Wine Council, said that in the past, growers had to test varieties on their own and wait five years for the results.
Now, Long Island vintners can go to the research vineyard and "shop before they buy."
"It's a luxury for us," he said. "It shortens the path in a competitive worldwide wine market and gets you where you want to go faster."
Last year the Wine Council donated $1,000 to Ms. Wise's research, Mr. Masoud said. People in the industry have also contributed wine bottles, corks, yeast, trellis posts and wires, fertilizer and other vineyard supplies.
Since this is just her second year producing wine from the vineyard, Ms. Wise does not expect the impact of her research to take hold for several years. Mainly, it is "investment for the future" and most useful for vintners establishing a new vineyard, expanding or replacing their plantings, or are diversifying their product line, she said.
Among the many grapes not pressed into wine, Ms. Wise is experimenting with growing several varieties not found on Long Island -- such as zinfandel and petit sirah from California and nebiolo, barbera and trebbiano toscano from Italy. If some perform well, she is hoping local vintners may find "niche markets" for them.
"We basically know that we can do chardonnay well, we do a pretty good job with merlot, we know that most years we do a pretty good job with cabernet sauvignon and beyond that it drops off quickly," she said.
However, a few wineries do make riesling, sauvignon blanc and gerwurztraminer, she added. "I think as we mature as an industry, finding market niches and having something that is a little different than your neighbor is going to be important."
Commenting on this year's harvest, she said that although August was "reasonably dry," the cool, rainy weather in July has produced grapes that "are pretty big" and are going to present a challenge.
"We live for warm, dry seasons on Long Island. When you have real ripe, real luscious fruit, it is almost like the wine makes itself," she added.
Varieties that ripen later in the season, such as cabernet sauvignon, are going to be especially "tough" this year because of a lack of sun, Ms. Wise said. "People are going to let it hang and let it hang to get to the point where they feel it is as ripe as it can be."
Ms. Wise developed "a casual interest in wine," she said, while working as waitress in college and later earned a master's degree in pomology (fruit science) from Cornell University. However, she said that training her taste buds to detect the subtleties between grapes came from on-the-job training.
"Part of being in the wine industry is actually going out into the vineyard and tasting the fruit because that is how you gauge the harvest, the appearance, the taste and texture. . When fruit starts to break down, it gets a little more mealy and the seeds get brown inside. It's real important to look and taste and feel these things in your mouth," she said.

HEADLINE: Democrats Hope Candidates Ride Coattails

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
TWO years after a national conservative tide swept Long Island Republicans to an additional seat in Congress, Democrats are encouraged by a more moderate mood among voters that they feel will enable them to recover lost ground on Nov. 5.
With President Clinton holding a wide lead in Nassau and Suffolk Counties over Bob Dole, according to several polls, the Democrats say they expect Mr. Clinton's coattails to improve Congressional candidates' prospects. 
 But political professionals said even if Mr. Dole closed the gap, the chances of victory are excellent for two Democrats, Carolyn McCarthy in the 4th Congressional District and Nora L. Bredes in the 1st. Republicans disagreed.
Also of interest is a spirited, some say nasty, race involving Gary Ackerman, Democrat, against Grant M. Lally, Republican of Oyster Bay, who is mounting a second challenge for the seat.
Ms. Bredes is seeking to recover a seat that Democrats had until two years ago and one that they have held more often than Republicans for 30 years. The incumbent is Michael P. Forbes.
"The furrow has been plowed in that area," the Suffolk Democratic leader, Dominic J. Baranello, said. "We anticipate Bredes is going to win on her own. All our surveys show her doing exceedingly well."
The district, by far the largest geographically on the Island, includes the five East End towns and parts of Brookhaven and Smithtown.
Republicans say they are concerned that expectations of Clinton landslides in New York and nationally will keep Republicans from voting. Political analysts have said the Dole campaign has virtually written off New York. But Republicans said they expected all four Republican incumbents from the Island to withstand challenges and win re-election.
"Our surveys indicate our candidates are in good shape," a spokesman for the Suffolk Republican Party, Alan Eysen, said. "Now it's up to the Republican voters to get out there and vote."
Rick A. Lazio appears to be comfortably ahead of Kenneth J. Herman in the 2d District, on the South Shore. Even some Democrats privately acknowledged that the seat was safe for Mr. Lazio.
In the 3d District, Peter T. King also appears to be leading. His opponent, Dal A. LaMagna, tells voters that his name "rhymes with lasanga" in an effort to build recognition.
In races that appear to be closer, Ms. Bredes and Mrs. McCarthy are trying to defeat freshmen who are closely associated with House Speaker Newt Gingrich. Mrs. McCarthy, a political neophyte and a registered Republican until she switched parties to run against Daniel Frisa, has gained national attention in a crusade to advance gun control. Her husband, Dennis, was slain and her son Kevin was wounded by Colin Ferguson, who fired a handgun on a Long Island Rail Road train three years ago.
In the 1st District, Ms. Bredes, a Suffolk County Legislator who started in politics as an opponent of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, depicts Mr. Forbes as a tool of special interests whose votes have harmed working families.
Mr. Forbes, who defeated George J. Hochbrueckner in 1994, was widely seen as a major beneficiary of the Republican tide that year. He became an eager proponent of Mr. Gingrich's programs, including the Contract With America.
"Now that the poll numbers on Gingrich are so bad," Ms. Bredes said, "Forbes is not promoting his votes for the Contract With America. He is trying to disguise his support for Gingrich. But I don't think people will buy the disguise."
Ms. Bredes has gained backing from national Democrats who view her as crucial to regaining control of the House. "Nora Bredes has a record of service to the community," the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Donald L. Fowler, said at a campaign stop for Ms. Bredes. "Her opponent has a record of service to Newt Gingrich.
"The Republicans had a great opportunity to establish themselves as the controlling political force in this country and they simply blew it. They pursued a political agenda so far to the right involving such extremist measures that they took themselves right out of the middle."
Mr. Forbes said associating Republican candidates with Mr. Gingrich was "right out of the national Democratic playbook."
"Democrats are doing the exact same thing in every district," he added.
Mr. Forbes said many initiatives advanced by Mr. Gingrich had been usurped by Mr. Clinton, who then claimed credit for them. "Have the Democrats now succeeded in making Mr. Gingrich such an icon of evil that everyone is running away from him?" Mr. Forbes asked. "I'm not sure that is relevant in this campaign. If my opponent wants to run against him she should move to Georgia. Nobody is asking me how Newt Gingrich is doing on eastern Long Island."
Mr. Forbes said he had forged close ties to constituents with town meetings and forums on topics like breast cancer, aging and small business. "I am very visible and active in the district," he said. "I never moved to Washington."
"His votes in the 104th Congress," Ms. Bredes said, "have been votes to squash families, take health care away from seniors and cut educational support for children." She said Mr. Forbes had a weak record on environmental issues.
Some environmentalists have attacked Ms. Bredes, saying she ignored problems involving radioactive contamination at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton. Mr. Forbes said at a debate held by the Hampton Bays Civic Association that Ms. Bredes had received campaign contributions from top officials at the laboratory.
A write-in candidate, Lorna Salzman of the Peconic Green Party, said neither candidate had proposed measures "to deal with the vast radioactive contamination." Neither major party, Mrs. Salzman said, is "addressing the overriding political and economic problems of our nation." Those, she said, include "the growing gap between the rich and poor, the concentration of wealth in the hands of a few, the takeover by corporations of our public institutions and media and the growing incursions on our basic freedoms."
Ms. Bredes, a supporter of abortion rights, is backed by several women's groups, including the National Organization for Women.
Mr. Forbes, an abortion opponent who is also on the Right to Life line, said at the debate that Ms. Bredes's supporters were attacking him for being Roman Catholic, adding, "They said I was a tool of my Catholic religion, all because they don't like my pro-life stand."
Ms. Bredes's campaign said Mr. Forbes was trying to create a bogus issue.
Ms. Bredes said she expected to spend more than $250,000 in the race. Mr. Forbes said he would spend $400,000.
In the bizarrely shaped 5th District, which includes parts of Queens, the North Shore in Nassau and Huntington and Smithtown, Mr. Lally is again trying to unseat Mr. Ackerman, the sole Democrat whose district is partly or all on the Island.
In a campaign notable for its savagery, Mr. Lally, a lawyer, consistently refers to his opponent as "Dirty Gary Ackerman." He has called Mr. Ackerman a radical extremist; a corrupt politician; a flag defiler; a promoter of homosexual marriage; an advocate of illicit drug use whose motto is, "Just smoke it"; a receiver of campaign contributions from a union controlled by organized crime, a shameless political buffoon and a clown who did not even live in his district.
Mr. Ackerman, who was cast into the Long Island arena when the district, previously all in Queens, was reapportioned before the 1994 election, has acknowledged that his Queens home is a short distance outside the district. Publicly, he has taken the high road, telling constituents in a letter of his fight to "bring a sense of civility and moderation" to the 104th Congress. But his campaign manager, Alan Gershuny, described Mr. Lally last week as "an ultra-ultra conservative right-wing fanatic," a homophobe and an unashamed liar about Mr. Ackerman's votes and positions.
"Gary Ackerman happens to be a a moderate Democrat," Mr. Gershuny said. "I have never seen anything like the vileness of this man Lally. He is a disgrace and should never hold public office."
Mr. Lally said that he supported Mr. Dole's 15 percent tax cut as a good start and that he backed a version of the flat Federal income tax, cuts in the capital-gains tax and an end to inheritance taxes. Mr. Lally is also a strong supporter of capital punishment. Mr. Ackerman has voted against it. Both support legalized abortion, but Mr. Lally opposes Federal financing for it.
Mr. Ackerman's campaign has said Mr. Lally secretly orchestrated primary challenges to Mr. Ackerman's designations as the Democratic, Liberal and Independence Parties' candidate. "He tried to give us three primaries to make us expend our resources, but we caught his hand in the cookie jar," Mr. Gershuny said. "We threw them off the ballot."
The challenges were disallowed after Mr. Ackerman successfully objected to signatures on the nominating petitions. Mr. Gershuny said Mr. Lally was linked to a deputy Nassau County attorney who was charged this month with falsely notarizing signatures on a petition for a would-be challenger to Mr. Ackerman's Liberal designation.
Mr. Lally denied that, saying he took no part in working with the challengers. "It's more mud from dirty Gary Ackerman," he said.
About 40 percent of the voters are in Queens, where Democrats hold an enrollment edge. On Long Island, 25 percent are in Nassau and 35 in Suffolk.
Even the campaign photographs have been nasty. A photo on Lally literature shows the trademark white carnation Mr. Ackerman that wears on his lapel obscured by a hot dog roll in his hand. The roll, dripping with fixings, appears to be on its way to Mr. Ackerman's half-opened mouth. The portly Mr. Ackerman is bug-eyed in anticipation. Tufts of hair from his balding head sprout raffishly outward over his ears, adding to a clownish appearance.
Mr. Lally, composed, trim, youthful and with a full head of hair, smiles on an accompanying photo, the American flag draped behind him. "We have a real choice for a change," the caption says.
The unflattering photo was taken at a fund-raising event that featured delicatessen food from Queens, Mr. Ackerman's staff said.
Mr. Lally said the 1994 Ackerman campaign used a photo of Mr. Lally in commando garb, a photo that Mr. Lally said was taken at Halloween and later printed in an April Fool's publication at Georgetown University, where Mr. Lally earned a master's in international law.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a recent debate, Nora Bredes, left, a Democrat, faced off against Representative Michael Forbes, a Republican. (Michael Shavel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: GARDEN;
How Seeds Get Around

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
HAVE you ever called the dog in from an afternoon's run in the meadow, only to find its fur matted with burdock? Or have you come in from a morning's weeding and found your trouser legs and shirt a mass of prickles?
These nuisances are nature's way of spreading seed. Seed has been designed with all sorts of hooks, barbs and sticky gels to provide a good hold on free transportation. If you're not careful in disposing of the nuisances, you may find unwanted plants in the garden next year. 
 Possibly the largest seed known belongs to the coconut. It is no small wonder that tropical beaches are festooned with rows of coconut palms. The seed floats where wind and wave take it, and it doesn't take much in the way of sand, rain and sunshine for coconut seeds to germinate.
By contrast, the tiniest seed, almost dustlike, belongs to the orchid family. It is almost impossible to see. Be careful to hold that sneeze when working around this seed.
Perhaps the first lesson about nature's distribution systems is learned in childhood by picking up a ripe dandelion puff and blowing on it. The seeds' small, silky hairs provide feathery parachutes, so a good wind or a good blow can send out for quite some distance.
Another childhood fascination with seeds involves the impatiens clan. No wonder it has acquired the name touch-me-not. The seedpods develop anytime after mid-August, and when touched, even slightly, the pods burst open and shoot out seeds. This is probably why jewel weed (a wild impatiens) seems to sprout everywhere. Animals, people, even a strong wind can jar the pods to spring open.
This seed dispersal method also explains why impatiens plants pop up each year in odd nooks and crannies. Sometimes these seedlings can be dug up carefully and transplanted to other sites for summer display.
Although witch hazels may not be as widespread as impatiens, their seed dispersal system is fascinating. The seed is cannonlike. When it is ripe, the seed capsule splits open and out shoots the hard black seed for quite some distance.
Some seed has a winged propeller. This is especially true for members of the maple family. The shade trees provide great entertainment in the spring, when the seed falls off the tree and comes down like a helicopter to land on the grass, in the flower border or vegetable patch. If the tasty seed is not consumed by birds or squirrels, it germinates and starts to grow, with the result that tiny maple trees sprout just about everywhere. If not pulled up promptly, some of the seedlings can get a deep roothold and soon become stubborn little trees.
Another tree with a propellerlike samara, or winged fruit, is the ash, which releases its clusters in late spring.
Probably one of the most delightful seedpods is the salt shaker type. Just tilt the pod, and out comes the seed. One of the first that comes to mind belongs to columbine. Although technically this plant is a biennial -- that is, it blooms every two years -- its steady supply of seed makes it seem more like a perennial. When the flowers have finished performing, the upright pods form, filling quickly with quantities of seed. When ripe, the pods split apart and the black seeds drop. Those who want to save the seed must watch the plants closely because it may be dispersed by nature before it can be gathered by the gardener.
Poppies have this salt shaker type of seedpod, too. Many a cook knows well the value of poppy seed for muffins and breads. Planting culinary seed would not be practical, however, as it is too aged for good germination.
SINCE so many types of seed are food for nature's creatures, they should be considered ecologically efficient in more than one way. Many birds feast on berries and, having ingested and gotten nutrients from the fruit, pass seed through the digestive tract and on to a germination site.
One of the prime squirrel foods is the tasty ripe red dogwood berry. And what about the squirrel's busy habit of burying acorns for the winter? Those they cannot scent out, find and eat in the winter may well sprout in the spring. The woods are thus blessed with oaks. Chipmunks can be good acorn planters, too, carrying as many as eight at one time.
Sometimes nature's creatures can't wait to feed. Ants don't. As soon as they find some seed, they transport it to their tunnels, often feeding on the aril covering and thus spreading the germination potential around. Bloodroot and cyclamen are two particularly fine plants that are dispersed in this way. It is another phenomenon that helps to explain how plants occur where they were not planted.
Although seed dispersal can sometimes be a nuisance, it is also a fine demonstration of the economical way nature spreads its bounty around.

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 13B; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 793 words

HEADLINE: GARDEN;
How Seeds Get Around

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
HAVE you ever called the dog in from an afternoon's run in the meadow, only to find its fur matted with burdock? Or have you come in from a morning's weeding and found your trouser legs and shirt a mass of prickles?
These nuisances are nature's way of spreading seed. Seed has been designed with all sorts of hooks, barbs and sticky gels to provide a good hold on free transportation. If you're not careful in disposing of the nuisances, you may find unwanted plants in the garden next year. 
 Possibly the largest seed known belongs to the coconut. It is no small wonder that tropical beaches are festooned with rows of coconut palms. The seed floats where wind and wave take it, and it doesn't take much in the way of sand, rain and sunshine for coconut seeds to germinate.
By contrast, the tiniest seed, almost dustlike, belongs to the orchid family. It is almost impossible to see. Be careful to hold that sneeze when working around this seed.
Perhaps the first lesson about nature's distribution systems is learned in childhood by picking up a ripe dandelion puff and blowing on it. The seeds' small, silky hairs provide feathery parachutes, so a good wind or a good blow can send out for quite some distance.
Another childhood fascination with seeds involves the impatiens clan. No wonder it has acquired the name touch-me-not. The seedpods develop anytime after mid-August, and when touched, even slightly, the pods burst open and shoot out seeds. This is probably why jewel weed (a wild impatiens) seems to sprout everywhere. Animals, people, even a strong wind can jar the pods to spring open.
This seed dispersal method also explains why impatiens plants pop up each year in odd nooks and crannies. Sometimes these seedlings can be dug up carefully and transplanted to other sites for summer display.
Although witch hazels may not be as widespread as impatiens, their seed dispersal system is fascinating. The seed is cannonlike. When it is ripe, the seed capsule splits open and out shoots the hard black seed for quite some distance.
Some seed has a winged propeller. This is especially true for members of the maple family. The shade trees provide great entertainment in the spring, when the seed falls off the tree and comes down like a helicopter to land on the grass, in the flower border or vegetable patch. If the tasty seed is not consumed by birds or squirrels, it germinates and starts to grow, with the result that tiny maple trees sprout just about everywhere. If not pulled up promptly, some of the seedlings can get a deep roothold and soon become stubborn little trees.
Another tree with a propellerlike samara, or winged fruit, is the ash, which releases its clusters in late spring.
Probably one of the most delightful seedpods is the salt shaker type. Just tilt the pod, and out comes the seed. One of the first that comes to mind belongs to columbine. Although technically this plant is a biennial -- that is, it blooms every two years -- its steady supply of seed makes it seem more like a perennial. When the flowers have finished performing, the upright pods form, filling quickly with quantities of seed. When ripe, the pods split apart and the black seeds drop. Those who want to save the seed must watch the plants closely because it may be dispersed by nature before it can be gathered by the gardener.
Poppies have this salt shaker type of seedpod, too. Many a cook knows well the value of poppy seed for muffins and breads. Planting culinary seed would not be practical, however, as it is too aged for good germination.
SINCE so many types of seed are food for nature's creatures, they should be considered ecologically efficient in more than one way. Many birds feast on berries and, having ingested and gotten nutrients from the fruit, pass seed through the digestive tract and on to a germination site.
One of the prime squirrel foods is the tasty ripe red dogwood berry. And what about the squirrel's busy habit of burying acorns for the winter? Those they cannot scent out, find and eat in the winter may well sprout in the spring. The woods are thus blessed with oaks. Chipmunks can be good acorn planters, too, carrying as many as eight at one time.
Sometimes nature's creatures can't wait to feed. Ants don't. As soon as they find some seed, they transport it to their tunnels, often feeding on the aril covering and thus spreading the germination potential around. Bloodroot and cyclamen are two particularly fine plants that are dispersed in this way. It is another phenomenon that helps to explain how plants occur where they were not planted.
Although seed dispersal can sometimes be a nuisance, it is also a fine demonstration of the economical way nature spreads its bounty around.

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
Homework's Greatest Hits

 BODY:
For students, past and present: What was the best homework assignment you ever had to do? Or the worst? Why?

Believe It. Or Not.
The best assignment was a paper I did for Western Civilization I, my freshman year in college. The title was "Witch Craze versus Christianity." And we had to do it from an atheist's point of view.
 
IRIS CRUET
Roselle
 
Meeting Plato and Marx
The best? Reading a slender little paperback by George Soule titled "The Ideas of the Great Economists." It was a real rush, a turn-on to all the really interesting views of Plato, Veblen, Marx and the rest. I loved it so much I still have the very yellowed, well-thumbed little book to this day.
 
BOB DONNELLY
Montclair
 
Right Out of History
The best homework assignment I ever had was to watch "The Flintstones" and take notes on what they had that did not exist during the time period. It was probably also the worst, since the list took up nearly two pages!

Before Mars and Venus

Foster's is (A) a brand of motor oil; (B) an imported beer; (C) A home for children. (The girls selected C.)
Does anyone else remember that assignment?

HEADLINE: Eligibility Changes, Widening the Pool Of Potential Jurors

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
AS a lawyer, Neal Allen of Irvington is used to courtrooms. When he was recently summoned to the County Courthouse here for jury duty, however, the experience was disconcerting.
"They're very nice here in Westchester," said Mr. Allen, who had served on a Federal jury in Manhattan two years ago. "They want to make sure everyone knows what's going on. They try to make it very user friendly. But you sit and wait. Most people were picked for a panel by the morning. Forty of us were held over until the afternoon. I got called at 3 P.M. I knew the judge in the case, so when he asked if anyone knew anybody connected with the case I said, Yes, I knew him. The judge told me to 'get out of here.' " 
 Like Mr. Allen, many people who had previously been exempt from jury duty by virtue of their occupation, age or status are finding jury service notices in their mailboxes.
Since Jan. 1, 17 groups that had been entitled to automatic exemptions, including medical doctors, lawyers, members of the clergy, mothers of young children, people older than 70, firefighters and police officers, have become eligible for jury duty. Welfare recipients and people receiving unemployment compensation have also been added to the pool of potential jurors. Nearly 38,000 county residents have received notices since January.
At a recent orientation session for a prospective jurors, a video addressed jurors' concerns and promoted a civics lesson on the importance of jury service. Justice W. Denis Donovan of State Supreme Court described cases he had presided over in which doctors, police officers, priests, nuns, rabbis and lawyers had served as jurors. Justice Donovan said that even he had been called for jury duty a few months ago.
While celebrities like the actor Richard Gere, the Knicks basketball player Charles Oakley and Judith S. Kaye, Chief Judge of the State of New York, have been the center of news attention when they have been called for jury duty, the ordinary juror has felt the effects of reforms the most.
Instead of showing up every day for two weeks or so, jurors now call the courthouse to find out when they will next be needed. They are also required to serve only once every four years instead of once every two years.
But such changes do not mitigate the frustration and resentment many jurors still feel at having their daily lives disrupted.
Patricia Cutaia, a prospective juror waiting in the central selection room, is a social studies teacher at White Plains High School and the mother of a 14-year-old and a 10-year-old.
"The child care does not coincide," she said. "My husband is coming home from work early today to take care of our children. One child is missing an after-school activity today. It's still difficult when you have children. This is a dilemma. We want to be good citizens, and this is exactly what we teach. You need to have people for the jury system to work. But I'm not very happy."
For Beverly Kissel, a full-time mother of three who was called for jury duty last winter but had her service postponed until July when her children were in camp, the experience was sobering.
"I came with my youngest child's birth certificate, but there never was a time to give any reasons why you shouldn't be there," Mrs. Kissel said, expressing disappointment that there was no time for her to present the documents.
"They sent me to a panel, and I wasn't picked. But it was clear that they weren't taking any excuses."
For those who work in the judicial system, the changes are palpable. "I find far fewer people who've had previous jury-selection experience," said Gerald E. Loehr, a personal injury lawyer who practices in Westchester and Rockland Counties and New York City. In recent trials, Mr. Loehr has put a police officer on an auto accident case and a psychiatrist on another panel.
"I find the jurors are more willing to serve," he continued. "The fact that it's more efficient has a positive impact to all the parties in a lawsuit. It's a whole new ballgame."
Westchester's District Attorney, Jeanine Pirro, said: "There's no question that the jury pools are more representative of the society at large. We're getting juries in less time, and as a former judge, I can tell you that saves an enormous amount of time. I personally can't wait to get on a jury, and I look forward to getting called for jury duty."
Although there are no statistics on how many previously exempted jurors now serve, the Commissioner of Jurors, Frances Tursi, said, "Doctors are being selected, and detectives are sitting on cases."
Still, there are some skeptics who think that the much publicized changes are window dressing and that being called for jury duty does not necessarily translate into actually sitting on a jury. A White Plains lawyer, Barry G., who agreed to comment only on condition of anonymity, said: "I was in a jury pool, but when I got into the box, I was knocked out. I guess most lawyers get bounced."
Mr. Allen, the Irvington lawyer, added: "It's very difficult for me to be picked for any jury. It's a waste of time for me. It may be hard for a lawyer who sits on a jury to take off his 'lawyer hat.' There's a legitimate effort to make more people part of the jury process, but now it's too global. There are valid reasons why certain people were exempt in the past. Certain people should be exempt."

HEADLINE: Pealing Bells, Bach to Madonna

BYLINE: By VALERIE CRUICE 

 BODY:
THE tryouts are rigorous: Two months of intensive training, then the first cut, and finally, the selection. Those who make it have to have outstanding hand-eye and foot-eye coordination. They must be aerobically fit and unafraid of heights. And they must read music.
The Yale University Guild of Carilloneurs, which has 25 undergraduate members, last year trained 60 aspiring bell ringers, auditioned 24 and took 7, said Matthew Gubens, a Yale senior and former chairman of the guild. 
 So what's the big deal?
To ring the bells, of course. To play for all the campus to hear. To play Bach, traditional songs of Yale, "The Star-Spangled Banner" and Pearl Jam.
Uh, Pearl Jam? As in heavy metal?
Yes indeed, said Mr. Gubens. A half-hour program might range from Beethoven to the 18th-century carillon composer van den Gheyn to Madonna.
"I like the Simon and Garfunkel," said Alice Ko, a junior on her way to class recently. "It's a bit charming, the contemporary pop."
Earlier this fall, students changed classes to the beat of "The People in Your Neighborhood," a staple from the Sesame Street songbook.
"We can practice for hours on a classic. It's the simple Sesame Street theme song that people remark on," said Mr. Gubens.
The 54-bell Yale Memorial Carillon is housed in the 206-foot Gothic-style Harkness Tower, the centerpiece of Branford College. "For a lot of people, the allure is the tower," said Mr. Gubens. "But as they continue their training, they realize the instrument is an incredible thing to play."
"It's so expressive," he continued. "With seven tons in the lowest bell, you can get such fortissimo -- but there's such a dynamic range -- the smallest bell being about 23 pounds. That's a lot of dynamic capacity."
How the bells are rung adds to the tower's mystique. Do the students of this guild don brown hooded robes, climb more than 100 pie-wedge spiral steps to the belfry and leap up to pull down on their designated ropes in perfect order? No. It's a one-person band, actually.
Two visitors -- one lugging very heavy camera equipment and the other with no excuse whatsoever -- breathlessly followed Mr. Gubens up into Harkness Tower for his half-hour shift beginning at 12:45. The group made it to the fifth story, where the guild has its office. Chatting away and with one eye on the clock, Mr. Gubens went into the files and selected his sheet music for the ring.
A massive console resembling an organ with a long bench sat to one side, a Disney Quasimodo doll dangling above the keyboard. Mr. Gubens breezed past it and headed for yet another spiral staircase. "That's what we practice on," he said, disappearing through the ceiling.
The ascent was eight stories when all was said and done. Coming out of the staircase and into the belfry and daylight, the visitors confronted the bells -- from the enormous, lowest-pitched ones to the highest-pitched ones at the top. Underneath the rows of bronze stood a cabin where the console was housed and that protected it and the carillonneurs from the elements. ("You can see your breath in the winter," Mr. Gubens said.)
Mr. Gubens spread the music out, adjusted the hydraulic bench to his comfort level, and started off with the traditional Westminster Chimes.
Launching into a difficult piece by Ronald Barnes, Mr. Gubens, with clenched fists, stroked, pounded and pressed the batons, each of which is connected by a cable that pulls the clapper to the side of the bell. ("I can't move seven tons," he said.)
At the same time, his sneakered feet worked the batons for the lowest bells. The ethics-politics and economics major, who is preparing for medical school, tore through the runs of sixteenth notes with fists flying, sliding up and down the oak bench. It was an athletic event.
"When you play a wrong note the whole campus hears," he said between pieces.
Next came Purcell's Trumpet Voluntary: most wedding-goers would recognize the the stately Baroque work. Then Mr. Gubens lightened things up with the Sesame Street excerpt. For a touch of Ivy, he played Yale's alma mater, "Bright College Years," followed by the National Anthem. Oh yes, and the hour: One.
"We really are given total latitude over the repertoire," he said, gathering up his music. "We have a vast library in the tower. It's up to the carillonneur. Sometimes we get requests. We even have a web page. We get requests through there -- from across the world."
According to the university, the first 10 bells were installed in 1921, a gift of Mrs. Stephen V. Harkness, who stipulated that they be played four times daily by the university organist. In 1948 the Guild of Yale University Bell Ringers was founded by Elliott Kone ('49), and students have played the carillon ever since. A gift of 44 more bells was made in 1966 by Florence S. Marcy Crofut. All the bells were cast by the English bell foundry John Taylor & Company, which has been in existence since the 15th century.
Guild members ring on Tuesdays and Thursdays at 12:45 P.M., on Monday, Wednesday and Friday and weekends at 12:30 P.M., and every evening at 5. In the summer there is a concert series that features guest carillonneurs. The guild, which offers music for holidays and Yale sports events, will also play for weddings. To raise money for their recent trip to Belgium and the Netherlands to study with master carillonneurs, the guild took requests on Valentine's Day.
"On Halloween we have a special ring at 11 P.M. We cover the tower lights with gels, and we ring the hour 13 times. We play everything from the Funeral March to Caspar the Friendly Ghost," Mr. Gubens said.
During the summer months, while other students were waiting tables on Cape Cod or teaching tennis, Mr. Gubens landed a job as summer carillonneur at St. Martin's Episcopal Church on Lenox Avenue in Harlem. As a senior, he realizes that his ringing days are coming to an end, just like a collegiate athlete's: "That's the sad thing about it. You can't take it with you."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Matthew Gubens, carilloneur, with hands flying, left, in Harkness Tower at Yale: "With seven tons in the lowest bell, you can get such fortissimo," says the senior. (Photographs by Helen Neafsey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Dog Track's Woes Added to a City's

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
WHEN the $30 million Shoreline Star greyhound race track opened in Bridgeport last fall after years of anticipation and amid considerable hyperbole, city and business leaders predicted it would attract large crowds and help spark an economic recovery in the deteriorating city.
But everything seemed to go wrong. Proposals for a nearby casino, as well as slot machines for the state's dog tracks and jai alai frontons, were turned down by the legislature, the crowds never materialized and the betting never set much of a pace. 
 Nearly a year later, even the dogs are scarcer -- the number of kennels at the track has dropped from 19 to fewer than 10. Performances have also been scaled back to five from the original eight, and there is no longer Friday evening racing.
The track has had financial problems ever since it opened, not coming close to the revenue projections of $60 million a year; state projections for the track are now about $14 million annually.
"I don't see how they're even managing to stay open anymore, they take in a lot more revenue from simulcast wagering than from on-track betting and that's a very bad sign," said John Ewaski, associate accountant in the State Division of Special Revenue.
Mr. Ewaski noted that when Shoreline opened last November, on-track wagers averaged $60,207 a performance covering 38 cards and for the month totaled nearly $2.3 million. During August the average had dropped to $41,888, covering 23 performances for a total of $963,435.
The handles -- which have hovered around $40,000 per performance -- are far below the original projections of $100,000 to $150,000.
And during the past few months a series of setbacks at the track has Shoreline employees and state officials predicting that it will close down by the end of the year. Among the setbacks are the following:
* The track's owners, led by the lawyer and entrepreneur A. Robert Zeff, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection several months ago, claiming the track had $33 million in liabilities and $22 million in assets.
* Contractors filed more than $2.2 million in liens against the track.
* The track's general manager, Jim Gartland, and several kennel operators left the operation.
* Layoffs reduced the original 600-worker total to 240.
* And the State Organized Crime Investigative Task Force began an investigation into Mr. Zeff's relationship with the former chairman of the State Gaming Board.
Mr. Muska, vice president for student and external affairs at Western Connecticut State University in Danbury, resigned from the Gaming Board in April after it was disclosed that he had gone to Las Vegas with Mr. Zeff on the same day the state board voted to waive a background check on Mr. Zeff.
Mr. Zeff did not return calls for comment and Mr. Muska declined to comment.
Despite the off-track problems and diminishing crowds, the track's new general manager, Steve Alford, insists Shoreline Star will remain open.
"I compare our situation to a boxer taking all the hits, but still standing and determined to find a way to win the fight," said Mr. Alford, who replaced Mr. Gartland in July. "I still think we're going to turn this around, and by reducing our overhead and getting the creditors off our backs with the bankruptcy, we're starting to see some positive results. We're not that far now from breaking even."
Mr. Alford, who refused to comment about the state investigation into Mr. Zeff's activities, acknowledged that better planning and management during the track's opening last November might have made a difference. Mr. Alford, as director of racing, was second in command to Mr. Gartland when the track opened.
"We know we made some mistakes, probably opening at the worst time of the year and bringing in kennel operators expecting a much bigger return on their investments than was realistic," he said. "But we scaled things down and I think it's starting to pay off."
Gov. John G. Rowland ordered the investigation into Mr. Zeff and Mr. Muska's relationship, and in late June Mr. Zeff was arrested and charged with interfering with an investigation and destroying evidence after attempting to throw bags of audio tapes over a fence at his Westport home. In July, Mr. Zeff was arraigned on the charges and pleaded not guilty.
"The investigation is still ongoing, but we're not at liberty to release any information at this time," said Sgt. Dale Hourigan, a spokesman for the State Police. "All I can say is that it's a very in-depth and complex investigation that is going to take some time to complete."
Despite the problems, some kennel operators are hoping the track can survive. "We're willing to stick it out as long as they are and I hope they can turn things around," said Peter Laporte, owner of Delamack Kennels, which has 270 greyhounds in several places, including Bridgeport.
"Some of the big name kennels from out of state had to bail out because their overhead was too high and they were losing money," said Mr. Laporte. "But we've been operating in Connecticut since 1991 and there's far less of a risk for us."
Some regular bettors at the track said they liked Shoreline, and were hoping for a miracle recovery.
"It's a nice track, but the worst part is getting here, you've got to worry about being robbed, mugged or carjacked," said a patron, Nick DeLucca. The track is in the East End neighborhood, long known as an area of drug trafficking and crime.
Margaret Marzocchi, of Yonkers, said she goes to the track about once a week, but agreed the neighborhood keeps a lot of potential bettors away.
"It's really a shame, this is a nice track and clean building, but there's nobody here and I think it's mostly because of the neighborhood," said Ms. Marzocchi, who has been betting on the dogs for more than 20 years. "But with turnouts like this, I don't see how they can stay open much longer."
Neither do the employees.
"Every day we wonder how much longer this can go on, how much longer they can survive," said Millie Heyden, a 15-year veteran parimutuel clerk, "It's almost as though people are looking forward to getting laid off so they don't have to worry about it anymore."
Ms. Heyden said that on a good afternoon she would take in more than $2,000, but that on this particular day she was barely over $400.
"Morale here is terrible," she said. "People like me remember the days when this place was a fronton, and things were really hopping all the time. It's really kind of sad."
Jack Schwarzkopf, a parimutuel clerk for 20 years, said the State Assembly's failure to approve a casino in Bridgeport earlier this year pretty much sealed the dog track's fate.
"If a casino were right down the road, this place would be booming," said Mr. Schwarzkopf, who also blamed mismanagement, the decaying neighborhood and bad timing of the opening as contributing factors for the track's decline.
"They opened in November, the worst time of year to open a track like this," he said. "And by this November, I think it will be closed . . . at least as a dog track."
Mr. Schwarzkopf and other employees speculated that the building could remain open as a simulcast center, which has done considerably better than the dog track. Dog and horse racing simulcast for bettors are beamed on large screens and televisions around the building.
Some bettors said they expect the dog track to close, but will continue to wager there as long as it stays open.
"If it closes it closes, there's nothing I can do about that," said Leon Saunders, a twice-weekly patron who lives in Bridgeport. "Yeah I'll miss it. I've had some real good days here . . . but as long as it stays open I'll keep coming.
"If I want to bet on the dogs, where else am I going to go?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Bridgeport, the dog track crowds are far thinner than anticipated a year ago. (James Marshall for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 'GIANT';
The Code of the West: Big Sky, Big Money

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I hesitate to argue with an author who understands West Texas ranch life as exquisitely as does Larry McMurtry, but I found myself disagreeing with his recent appraisal of the changes in that life style since James Dean and company brought Ferber's "Giant" to the Texas high country ["Men Swaggered, Women Warred, Oil Flowed," Sept. 29]. 
 Mr. McMurtry is sensitive to the changes in the oil industry, yet he misses the fact that West Texas ranching remains bound to, even possessed by, a land unchanged and unrelenting. The land continues to mock efforts to develop it, to fence it, even to manage it, and the code that governs daily life is surprisingly unchanged from my childhood. Houston and Dallas are a long way east, both geographically and economically, of the Pecos. West of the Pecos, the land remains master, and the economics of staggering mineral-rights leases still exist, as do the politics of possession that most often govern family and race relations.
As a young ranch wife, I often rose at 3:30 in the morning to cook for as many as 23 cowboys and illegal aliens so they could be off to roundup before the sun hit the desert. I now teach at a Midwestern university. Each time I return to West Texas, I am surprised at how the people of that country continue to hold to the heritage of the old West.
John Sayles's recent film "Lone Star" astutely represents the complexity of border politics these 40 years after "Giant." Two more wars, multiculturalism, technological innovations, immigration debates and economic diversification have brought only surface changes. The code of West Texas remains, as always, determined by the vastness of big sky, big ranching operations and big money.
 
BETTY ROBBINS
Norman, Okla.

HEADLINE: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:

AMERICA NEEDS A RAISE
Fighting for Economic Security and Social Justice.
By John J. Sweeney with David Kusnet.
Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.
This short book might have been called "Something's Rotten in the U.S.A." Although he covers familiar territory, John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., makes a powerful case that something is badly awry as he describes how wages are losing the race to inflation and corporations have cavalierly downsized thousands of loyal workers out of their jobs -- all while corporate profits, stock prices and executive pay have soared. His prescription: millions more Americans should join unions, a step he says will give dispirited workers leverage to win higher pay and a real say in running their workplaces. Mr. Sweeney dreams that rebuilding the labor movement will restore a long-lost sense of community in the United States -- the sense of community he felt when as a boy in the Bronx he attended his bus-driver father's union meetings. (It is regrettable there aren't more such autobiographical and introspective touches.) He rightly lambastes unions for neglecting to organize workers, but he inexplicably ignores one of labor's chief problems: corruption. Perhaps that should be expected from what is essentially a tract to rally people to the union banner. Steven Greenhouse
