HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
The Off Season in the Hamptons Is Getting Busy

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
THE four-bedroom, fully furnished period house that Stephen R. Steinberg has rented for $1,200 a month since Sept. 15 in the center of Bridgehampton commands roughly $15,000 a month for the summer season.
While Mr. Steinberg's rent is less than a tenth of what his landlord charges during the summer season, which runs from Memorial Day to Labor Day, there is a catch. By May 1, he and his dog, a Chinese Shar-Pei named Wrigley, will have to find other accommodations or be prepared to stay for the summer at the much higher rate. But he is not worried, Mr. Steinberg said. 
 By then, he will know whether the law practice he opened in Sag Harbor last May after working many years as a litigator for the Manhattan office of the Fulbright & Jaworski law firm, will be successful. If the answer is yes, he expects to buy a house. If not, he will move elsewhere, he said.
The other season in the Hamptons -- generally from mid-September to mid-May -- has just begun, and brokers and owners say they see a growing market for winter rentals.
"The Hamptons, more and more, are becoming a year-round community," said Susan Green, a broker with the Bridgehampton office of the Braverman Newbold Brennan real estate agency, who found Mr. Steinberg his house.
Some people, like Mr. Steinberg, want to sample the off season before making the commitment to buy a house. Others come out to savor the peace and quiet of the winter months. Still others see this as an opportune time to find a relatively inexpensive weekend retreat, one they might not be able to afford during the summer.
Another of Mrs. Green's customers, a commercial loan officer for a Manhattan bank who asked that her name not be used, together with a friend is paying $30,000 for an eight-and-a-half month rental that started Sept. 15.
They come out each weekend to the four-bedroom, three-bath house in Sagaponack. It is one block from the ocean and has an ocean view. It rented last summer for $70,000.
"There are a number of reasons I like to go to the Hamptons in the fall, spring and even winter," said the woman, who lives on Manhattan's Upper East Side. "It's mostly peace of mind because, although summers are beautiful, they are hectic, and the winter season is much more subdued and it's very relaxing."
Rents generally range from $1,000 to $3,000 monthly based on the full winter season, but can go as high as $10,000 monthly, according to brokers.
"The days when an owner was happy to get someone to occupy the house just to keep the heat on and water the plants are over," said Joseph Horstmann, owner of the Main Street Properties real estate agency in East Hampton.
BROKERS usually charge the owners 10 percent of the gross rental. Winter renters must take into account that heating bills could add substantially to the amount they pay.
Nevertheless, the thought of having a cozy country retreat with logs crackling in the fireplace and being able to walk on empty beaches is starting to rival the attractions of the private pool and sunbathing, brokers say.
"I've been in this business 12 years, and when I first started, there were lots of winter rentals, they were very inexpensive, and not many people were interested," said Peter L. Hallock, president of the Allan M. Schneider & Associates real estate agency, whose main office is in East Hampton.
"Now it is the absolute opposite. There are very few rentals available, and people really want to be here. And although prices are creeping up, winter rentals are still our best-kept secret."
Frank E. Newbold, a partner of the Braverman Newbold Brennan agency, whose East Hampton office handles about 40 winter rentals a year, gave as an example a 4,500-square-foot, four-bedroom, five-bath oceanfront contemporary with three fireplaces.
The house is in Bridgehampton and is on the market for $3.2 million. It is available over the winter for a monthly rental of $3,000. The rent for the Memorial-Day-to-Labor-Day summer season is $150,000.
The winter rentals most in demand are houses further inland, Mr. Newbold said. "In the summertime, people want to be on the beach in something open and airy," he said. "In winter, they want to be snug and cozy and prefer to be in a village. And a fireplace is a must."
Among his other listings is a two-bedroom farmhouse in Wainscott overlooking farm fields but within walking distance of the ocean. ("Perfect for sitting by the fireplace, holding hands and watching the sunset," he said.)
The rent -- $20,000 for the summer -- is $1,000 a month over the winter.
Another listing is a 19th-century Victorian in the center of East Hampton with four bedrooms, two bathrooms and a fireplace on an acre of property that is available for $890 a month.
The winter season is often the time when people who had rented for the summer are looking around for something to buy, so they rent for the winter while they search for a property. Or they rent while they wait for their house to be built.
The rental market has been extremely strong overall this year, said Harold F. Shepherd, an East Hampton broker, and this is helping to fuel the winter rental market. "A lot of people who rent over the winter can't really afford the summer prices," he said.
AT one time, Bob Bubka of East Hampton said, he would close up the two-bedroom cottage he owns near the beach in Amagansett over the winter. It rents for $16,000 for the summer. It was rented this winter for $700 a month as soon as he put it on the market, he said.
"What really attracts the winter renter is the solitude, and even though the ocean isn't swimmable, when there is snow on the beach it's magnificent to look at," he said.
Cynthia Barrett, a bond saleswoman, and her husband, John, a writer, own a three-bedroom postmodern house on 2.2 acres in Sagaponack that is available year-round. They want $22,500 for the summer season, and $1,300 monthly over the winter.
A similar house would sell for $350,000 to $400,000, Mrs. Barrett said. "So even if someone wants a year-round house without the headaches of ownership, it becomes quite economical," she added.
Weekly or even monthly rentals, however, are seldom available over the winter. Pipes have to be drained and the house must be properly winterized, said Ernest Schade, owner of Robertson Realty in Sag Harbor. "If all the owner gets is a month's rental, they might as well shut the house down," he said.
Nevertheless, David Pearlberg of Manhattan said he was pursuing his dream of spending the Thanksgiving holidays in the East Hampton-Bridgehampton area. Steve Corwin, a sales associate for Main Street Properties in East Hampton, has been working with him to locate the right property.
"I rent a house over the summer in the Hamptons, but this is the first year that we are thinking of spending the holidays there," said Mr. Pearlberg, who with a partner, Jackie Himelhoch, owns a cafe, Eureka Joe, on lower Fifth Avenue.
Each year, he, his mother and his sister try to come up with an intriguing way to celebrate the holidays, he said.
Last year, they treated themselves to dinner at the Four Seasons restaurant in Manhattan.
"I suggested that this year a house in the Hamptons with a fireplace would be a nice idea," he said. "Something that is cozy and woodsy."
Ideally, the house will have four bedrooms, because friends will join them, and preferably it will have a country setting.
What they are finding is that a week's rent is somewhat more costly than they had thought, with asking prices in the $3,000 range.
"But for people from the city, the idea is so appealing," Mr. Pearlberg said. "Just having new surroundings, and a new way of celebrating the holidays, will be very rejuvenating."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Stephen R. Steinberg and his dog Wrigley at the Bridgehampton home he rents for $1,200 a month. The summer rate is $15,000 a month. (Photographs by Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: October 13, 1996

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2726 words

HEADLINE: The Empty Firetruck

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: PARAMUS

 BODY:
THE aerial ladder swayed under Ron Manke, and he leaned out of the bucket, holding an unwieldy 30-pound power saw and struggling to keep his balance. Arms extended, straining against his harness, he cut a hole in the roof of the building to let the smoke escape. The saw bit into the inch-and-a-quarter decking with a grinding whine, jerking his arms forward.
Afterward, splotched with soot, he said he felt exhilarated, because he had never worked on an aerial ladder before. And no lives had been lost, no property really damaged. It was just a drill in a vacant commercial building, part of Mr. Manke's training to sharpen his skills as a volunteer firefighter. 
 "I learned a lot today," said Mr. Manke, 26, a lieutenant in the volunteer fire department in Upper Saddle River, in northwestern Bergen County. "It's always a good day when you learn something."
Unfortunately for Upper Saddle River, his knowledge will not benefit its fire department. He was learning a lot for the Paramus Volunteer Fire Department, which was conducting the drill and of which he is the newest member.
Mr. Manke, who sells telecommunications equipment for a living, is making the switch because he can no longer afford to live in Upper Saddle River, the upper-middle-income town he grew up in. He is moving to Paramus, where houses are more affordable, and is taking his eight years of firefighting experience with him.
Upper Saddle River is one of dozens of towns that are struggling to keep volunteer fire departments and first-aid squads intact. Though statewide numbers are hard to find, a recent nationwide survey indicated that the number of volunteer firefighters had dropped almost 10 percent since 1983 while emergency calls jumped almost 50 percent. In New Jersey, many fire and ambulance-corps chiefs say they are having trouble finding volunteers, while others are just making do, especially during daytime hours, when many members are at work far from home.
"There isn't a community in the state that isn't short on volunteer personnel," said Edward S. Cohn, a former fire chief in Ramsey who is chairman of a state committee for the recruitment and retention of volunteers. "All the ranks are dwindling."
One day in August, for example, the Upper Saddle River Ambulance Corps got three back-to-back emergency calls but could not field a crew to respond to them. Volunteers from other towns answered the calls as part of a mutual aid agreement.
As the nationwide statistics suggest, the shortage of volunteers has been building for years. But in recent years, the towns that rely on them have been trying inventive ways to attract and retain volunteers, from paying stipends to waiving town recreation fees for firefighters and their families. Like other states, New Jersey has established a toll-free phone number, (800) FIRE LINE, for people to learn about voluntary emergency services and how to become volunteers.
The efforts have had mixed success. "There are different degrees of decline," said Mr. Cohn, who was instrumental in setting up the phone line. "I think there are communities that are in desperate need of help. But are we at a critical stage yet? I hope not."
Ron Manke says he expects to enjoy being part of Paramus's firefighting force (which has had its own recruiting problems in recent years). But he laments having to leave his hometown and the department where his father, Lou, is assistant fire chief and two brothers are volunteer firefighters.
"I regret leaving," Mr. Manke said. "But unfortunately, it's just something I have to do. Upper Saddle River is just so out of my range now."
Larry Rauch, the fire chief in Upper Saddle River, has seen his own son, Scott, leave the fire department for Mahwah's, and he says that losing experienced firefighters cuts away at the nucleus of volunteers on whom departments depend on for stability.
Of Lieutenant Manke, he said, "Paramus is getting a very experienced firefighter."

'Don't Have the Time, Couldn't Stand the Blood'
Volunteer firefighters go back to Colonial days. The role is as American as apple pie; George Washington himself was a volunteer firefighter. There was great competition between fire companies -- even fistfights as they raced each other to fires, writes Paul C. Ditzel, author of "Fire Engines Firefighters" (Crown, 1976). No city had paid fire departments until 1850, and even today, the most firefighters remain volunteers.
First-aid squads have a similar history, though Keith Griffiths, co-publisher of J.E.M.S., the Journal of Emergency Medical Services, points out that in the early days, the ambulances were often provided by mortuaries. Many volunteer ambulance squads modeled themselves after a life-saving crew that organized in Roanoke, Va., in 1928.
Of 1.07 million firefighters nationwide, volunteers number about 808,000, according to the National Fire Protection Association. But the number of volunteers has declined by nearly 77,000 since 1983. In New Jersey, only 39 fire departments, of 800 in the state, are made up of salaried firefighters. The others are manned by some 34,000 volunteers, said George Miller, assistant director of the State Division of Fire Safety.
"We haven't seen the total number dwindling," he said, "but what we're seeing is that people who would have passed on the torch have had to hang on longer because there's no one to pass it on to." Many fire officials around the state say it is hardest to attract and retain volunteers between the ages of 30 and 50.
The state has 450 to 475 first-aid squads, and of 22,000 emergency medical technicians registered in New Jersey, about 15,000 are volunteers. Beverly Barthmaier, president of the New Jersey First Aid Council, says volunteers tend to burn out in three and a half years. "The number of trauma calls they've been on," she said. "They just can't handle it anymore."
Even as membership has declined in some departments and squads, he said, there has been more of a demand on the those remaining: more training requirements, more calls to respond to, more paperwork and administrative demands.
Chuck Smeby, a fire protection engineer for the National Fire Protection Association, says the number of volunteers in the 18-to-25-year-old age group is declining. More ominously, there is a trend in the general population not to volunteer at all.
"Since World War II, the focus of the American public seems to have drifted from 'we' to 'me,' " David M. Beck, an associate editor of J.E.M.S., wrote in 1988. "The would-be volunteer may be too busy working hard and playing hard, as the number of leisure activities grows continuously and people seem comfortable with the notion that if you want something you pay for it."
Officials in New Jersey concur. "People just don't want to do it anymore," said Mayor William W. Bain Jr. of Deptford in Gloucester County, who is a career firefighter in Camden. "Volunteerism in general is at the lowest ebb it's been for years." And Thomas Horner, the former fire chief of Hazlet, Monmouth County, said: "People nowadays who move from the city think you're a paid department. They don't even think of volunteering."
But even those who want to volunteer cannot afford the time to do so. In today's economy, people are working longer and at second jobs. Or both spouses are working, meaning that one can no longer stay home with the children while the other answers fire or ambulance calls.
Training to become an E.M.T. takes 120 hours, plus 48 hours of follow-up training for the necessary recertification every three years. Besides being on call at least 12 hours a week, and 24 hours on one weekend a month, there are meetings and drills. Firefighters must take 120 hours of training and attend regular meetings and training exercises.
Whatever the reasons, Lindsay Graham, captain of the Upper Saddle River Volunteer Ambulance Squad, which is down to 18 members from the 50 it had when she came aboard 20 years ago, says she is frustrated.
"I haven't worked it out yet, why it is that people are not volunteering," she said. "Maybe they don't think about it. Maybe we're not high-profile enough. It's either 'I don't have the time' or 'I couldn't stand the blood.'
"But if they call us, they expect somebody to be there," she went on. "And sometimes, they don't notice who those people helping them are."

Paying the Volunteers, Caring for Their Children
Through the dusky glass doors of the old one-story Bergen Bluestone building, and all the thick smoke, a team of firefighters could be seen crawling, shadowy figures in semi-darkness looking for the source of the fire as part of a drill. And for victims.
James J. Tedesco 3d, the battalion chief, who had kept the wood fire blazing in the fireplace and was acting as a safety officer, was pleased as he watched Mr. Manke and his team in their fire-retardant hoods and air packs, yelling at each other to keep communication, their voices muffled by their face masks.
"It's what you try to get them accustomed to," said Chief Tedesco, a business service manager for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company. "The smoke is one problem that you have to overcome, because you can't see your hands in front of your face.
"The other problem is the heat. It just sucks the energy out of your body, and they have to get used to that. They have to know how close and how deep to get into the fire."
There are four firehouses in Paramus, one at each point of the compass. They house the four engine companies and two ladder companies charged with fighting fires in the 10.5-square-mile borough, the second largest in Bergen County, with its major highways -- Route 17, Route 4 and the Garden State Parkway -- and many malls, including the Garden State Plaza, the Bergen Mall and Paramus Park.
"We have 25,000 people who reside here at night," said Councilman Sam Casiello, the fire commissioner, "but during the day the population rises to 250,000, what with shoppers and office workers."
When the current fire chief, Guy Picone, joined the department 13 years ago, there were 90 members responding to 750 calls. Just a few years ago, however, the number of members had dropped to about 75 while the calls had reached about 900.
In the late 1980's, Paramus instituted a stipend system. It now pays $3,000 a year to members of the fire department and the ambulance corps, which had also been struggling to get new members, Mr. Casiello said. In April, Paramus also began waiving certain fees for emergency service personnel and their families -- the $35 golf-course registration fee, for example. And this year the town started a junior fire program for 16-year-old volunteers, who can become probationary firefighters at 18.
Thanks to incentives like these, the fire department is back up to 125 members -- a healthy number, although the department is allowed 200 by ordinance. They have responded to 900 calls so far this year and expect to reach 1,100 by year's end, he said.
"It's kind of been like a roller coaster," Mr. Picone said, "but we've never been in a desperate situation."
Of the stipend, Brian Niland, the assistant chief (and next in line for chief), said: "It pays your taxes, pretty much. That's the way the guys look at it."
Similarly, Fort Lee, which bristles with high-rise apartments and their pricey views, looks on the $3,600 it pays its firefighters each year as rent money. Without such help, young people could not afford to stay, said the borough's fire chief, Joseph J. Licata, a code enforcement officer in the building department.
"We were losing volunteers," he said. "They were going to different towns because of cheaper rents."
Fort Lee's neighbor Cliffside Park pays a stipend of $150 a month, said Fire Chief Frank Leone, and is one of an increasing number of departments that have hired a small number of career firefighters to augment the mostly volunteer department.
Many departments are also relying on municipal employees to fill gaps on weekdays, when most volunteers are working at their regular jobs. In Paramus, at least 20 borough employees are volunteer firefighters, said Mr. Picone. He himself is a mechanic in the borough garage; Mr. Niland, the assistant chief, is a Paramus police officer.
Waldwick, north of Paramus, pays a $1,500 stipend to police dispatchers with E.M.T. training to respond to ambulance calls when the first aid squad is in a bind.
"When the firebell rings," said Gary Kratz, the borough administrator in Waldwick, "three-fourths of the Department of Public Works respond."
And some communities are hiring paid ambulance squads to cover for the volunteers during the day, said Mr. Leggett of the State Health Department.
Then there are creative remedies. "In some squads they have a squad mom who comes to headquarters to watch the children of those who go out on calls," said Ms. Barthmaier of the State First Aid Council. Upper Saddle River arranged with a nursery to watch children of recruits taking E.M.T. training.

Sons Follow Fathers, Brothers Follow Brothers
But Paramus also continues to get volunteers the way fire departments have always got them. Sons follow their fathers, brothers follow their brothers -- which is why firefighters often refer to their departments as family.
Brian Niland's brother, Dennis, is in the Paramus department, and John Ferguson is a probationary firefighter who will soon follow his brother Tim and become a full-fledged member. Bill Possehl's 29-year old brother, David, has become is a Paramus firefighter. These are just a few.
The other night, Chief Tedesco looked into the smoky store where the drill was still going on, and he asked his assistant, Capt. Dan Conway, how Mr. Tedesco's son, James 4th, who is a week short of 18, was doing.
"Fine," said Captain Conway. "We got him in there with the LT" -- the lieutenant. "He's standing right there by the fire."
As proud as he was, Mr. Tedesco also felt a father's nervousness, knowing that someday his son would be in a real firefighting situation. If he is in the burning building at the same time, he said, he will make sure James 4th comes out all right. "But when I'm stuck outside," he went on, "trusting to somebody else, that's where my faith really has to grow and trust that the people he's with are good firefighters."
Asked why they choose to rush into a burning, smoke-filled building when the natural response is to break the record for the 100-yard dash in getting out of there -- or why they expose themselves to seeing someone lying in a bloody roadway with unspeakable injuries who must get to a hospital -- emergency volunteers all tend to give the same response: they want to give something back to their communities.
The camaraderie of the firehouse or ambulance-corps headquarters, the sense of accomplishment, wanting to prove something to themselves: these are also mentioned, but service to the town is usually their first response.
Before he entered the smoky store during the drill, Mr. Manke said with a smile that he had fulfilled the dreams of childhood. "I like to be on the firetruck with the red lights and sirens," he said.
Mr. Possehl, a 37-year-old plant nursery owner who has been a Paramus firefighter for 19 years and was injured when chemicals blew up in his face as he wetted down a garbage-truck fire, says he enjoys "giving back to the community," and "the brotherhood of the firehouse."
"And there's a certain thrill," he went on. "A certain high from being able to put a fire out. You're scared to death when you're getting involved in a fire. If you're not scared, you're stupid. And when you conquer it, there's a great sense of accomplishment."
Adita Salas, who has seen her share of injured people in her 17 years with the Upper Saddle River Ambulance Corps, said, "Even though you've seen something really horrible, you also know that if you weren't there that day, somebody would have died."
For S. Carol White, after 22 years in the Upper Saddle River Ambulance Squad, there is still the nervousness going in and the adrenaline that blocks out the emotion -- though only until afterward.
But there is the joy too. She had always wanted to be a doctor, she said, and one day, 21 years ago, she helped to deliver Ron Manke's brother, Peter, in the back of the ambulance.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 3; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1610 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Glen Cove, L.I.;
An Ethnically Diverse North Shore City

BYLINE: By CHERYL PLATZMAN WEINSTOCK 

 BODY:
HIS wife has lived all over the world; together, they have lived with their three children on the South Shore of Long Island and, most recently, in Queens.
But after deciding it was time to move back to the suburbs, Marc. S. Bresky and his wife, Aliza, chose Glen Cove, L.I. 
 "It has a wonderful ethnic diversity, which is culturally advantageous for my three children," Mr. Bresky said. "It also has the qualities of the South Shore, like the beaches, and the beautiful qualities of the North Shore, like large trees, large parcels of property, privacy and tranquillity."
Many before him have felt the same way.
One of only two cities on Long Island (the other is Long Beach), the historic peninsula of Glen Cove, with its views of Hempstead Harbor and Long Island Sound, became home to a number of prominent millionaires after the Civil War.
The arrival of such influential men as F. W. Woolworth, the Standard Oil magnate Charles Pratt and J. P. Morgan was hailed as the beginning of the "Gold Coast" era during the 1920's.
The financier's private island, once known, logically enough, as Morgan's Island, is now a waterfront community known as East Island.
Some mansions of the Gold Coast era have survived. Some are still private residences, but others are occupied by the Nassau County Museum, the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture and the Russian Delegation to the United Nations.
Film makers have taken advantage of the grandeur of these homes. "Sabrina" and "Batman Forever" are among the recent movies with scenes shot in Glen Cove.
AT the northern edge of the peninsula, in an area known as "The Landing," immigrant families first settled in the 1860's.. In search of employment and other fresh opportunities, they arrived first from Ireland and then from Poland, Italy and other parts of Europe.
The first jobs for many of the immigrants were at the Duryea Starch Works, one of the largest such businesses in the world, which opened in the 1850's on the south of Glen Cove Creek. Later other factories opened, including ones for tin, leather industrial power belts and chemicals.
Hard-working immigrant groups continue to contribute to the vitality of Glen Cove today, which is still thriving despite changes that have sapped the strength of many small cities.
Glen Cove Creek, once the hub of industrial activity, became polluted. Abandoned industrial complexes line its edge, and the creek area has been designated as a Federal Superfund cleanup site; the city plans to redevelop it and provide waterfront recreation.
In a world where small businesses are challenged daily by megastores, Glen Cove is still home to many smaller shops. Douglas Goldstein, whose father bought the hardware store Charles of Glen Cove in 1958, has maintained the store as a community focal point.
Just beyond the neatly organized aisles of everything from rock salt, fertilizer and mothballs to shelf liner, kitchen trinkets and small gifts is the "nuts and bolts room" where customers can find almost anything they need in old wooden cheese boxes. And if they can't, he stands with them on the same simple, warped wooden floors that his father stood on, and helps.
"We've always been the old-fashioned type of store," Mr. Goldstein said.
Likewise, Mark Udell carries on his grandfather's and father's tradition at London Jewelers on School Street. Though it is across from a new Starbucks coffee house and a multiplex movie theater, Mr. Udell keeps the atmosphere and personal service attuned to its beginnings in 1926, when his grandfather would journey to the estates once a week to wind all the eight-day clocks or tend to the silver.
Thomas R. Suozzi, the city's Mayor, has followed in the political footsteps of his father, Joseph A. Suozzi, who served as Mayor from 1956 to 1960, and his uncle, Vincent A. Suozzi, Mayor in the 1970's and 1980's.
Brenda Weck, who grew up in Glen Cove, left and came back to raise her family, said she returned because of the city's wealth of housing, educational and recreational opportunities. "We know that there are less expensive places to live and places just as pretty," Ms. Weck said. "But the majority of people stay here because of the greater possibilities. We want our children to have the same sense of security we had, and it's not necessarily financial security."
Susan Cornell, another native, recently moved with her husband, Richard, and their four children from an apartment to a Dutch colonial in Glen Cove. "To me this place is still hometown," she said. "My children are the fourth generation here. This is a place you develop roots. It's the kind of town people come up to you and say they can remember you as a baby."
Pascual Blanco, executive director of La Fuerza Unida de Glen Cove Inc., a not-for-profit social service agency, said the city saw an influx of Puerto Rican immigrants in the 1950's when mechanization in some industries cut field jobs.
"We wanted to settle in a place that had opportunity as well as tranquillity," said Mr. Blanco. "Many of us settled here, rather than in Brooklyn. Even though I'm Puerto Rican I've been able to mingle here with everyone and enjoy a sense of community. It doesn't mean that all racial feelings have been overcome. But to a certain degree, many have been exceeded."
Residents say the city's schools have nurtured their endeavors. "I think academically that our students do as well as any students on the North Shore of Long Island," said Frank DeLuca, superintendent of the Glen Cove School District. "Statistically, our schools compare with those of more homogeneous school districts. We send students to the finest schools in the country, from Georgetown to Stanford."
THE average S.A.T. scores were 413 for the verbal section and 461 on the math part, in the middle range when compared to other districts in the county. The reading scores for elementary students are just above the state average.
Among the schools in the district are the Gribbin school, kindergarten through second grade, the Landing elementary school, grades 3 and 4, the Robert F. Finley Middle School, grades 5 through 8, and Glen Cove High School.
Among the private and parochial schools are Friends Academy and St. Patrick's elementary school.
Though 15.4 percent of the city's school-age children are educated at parochial and private schools, 3,050 children attend the district's schools, founded in 1830.
Last year, the high school placed No. 1 in its division -- schools with populations of 900 or less -- in the Nassau County Mock Trial competition and made it to the quarter-final level in the contest.
Of the district's high school graduates last year, 60 percent went on to four-year colleges and 36 percent to two-year colleges or technical schools.
But what makes the district unusual, and appealing to many, is the diversity of ethnic and economic backgrounds of the students.
Michael Kirsch, the principal of an elementary school in Chappaqua, N.Y., who left Glen Cove years ago to start his own family but often comes back to visit his parents, said he has fond childhood memories of growing up here.
"Even though it's a very small city, Glen Cove really mirrors a larger microcosm of society," he said. "The extremes in property values, ethnic groups and religions made me aware that there were all kinds of people. I grew up believing in the melting pot, and its impact was to prepare me to get along with many different kinds of people."
Glen Cove has 18 houses of worship, including African Methodist Episcopal, Roman Catholic, Presbyterian, Episcopal, Lutheran and Greek Orthodox churches and conservative or reform synagogues.
Residents can swim at the city's three public beaches, play golf or tennis for a minimal cost at a number of public parks, or moor boats at several marinas.
Rosemary Semidey, owner of Gold Coast Properties, who is a fifth-generation resident, cited the city's wealth of public amenities as one reason for the stability of the housing market.
"There's so much here that the market is holding quite well in this economy," Ms. Semidey said.
Houses can range from small capes in the mid-$100,000 range to ranches, colonials, manor homes and estates that sell for more than $5 million.
John Wichrowski, a construction worker who paid $320,000 for a three-bedroom home on three-quarters of an acre in Glen Cove last October, believes the city offers house hunters good value for their money.
"I found my buying power here was a whole lot better than anything I could find elsewhere," said Mr. Wichrowski who moved after selling a house in nearby Glen Head. "I got a bigger piece of property, I think I got a lot of house for the money. It's a fantastic place. There's ample parking at the railroad. If my car is laid up, I could manage because of the bus service."
Ms. Semidey said services such as the teaching hospital, North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove, and the city's own police, fire and sanitation departments provide an added level of security.
Antonia Petrash, a staff member at the Glen Cove Library who moved into town more than 25 years ago, said the city's proximity to both urban and suburban recreation made it easy to raise three children there.
"You could go to the Hamptons in the same day, or to Manhattan for a Broadway show," Ms. Petrash said.
Residents of Glen Cove said they don't find much to complain about, except the lack of electrified service on the L.I.R.R.
"I'm going to have to make sacrifices with the commute," Mr. Bresky said. "But I'm sure the quality of life we're going to have here in Glen Cove will be worth it."

FIRST VOTE: Glen Cove is one of 57 small cities in New York State that have never been allowed to vote on their school budget. School taxes are 60 percent of the tax burden in Glen Cove, yet the school board has been historically opposed to residents voting on the budget. After much lobbying by the cities individually and collectively, the residents of small cities in New York State recently won their right to vote on the school budget. Glen Cove residents will cast their first ballots in May.

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 2; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 779 words

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
You Don't Need a Poll Tax To Subvert Voting Rights

BYLINE: By Brett Pulley; Brett Pulley reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Ed Rollins, the infamous campaign manager who caused a stir in 1993 when he said he had paid ministers to keep black voters away from the polls, lives his life these days in fear of setting foot in New Jersey. "When I have to use the Turnpike," he said in a recent interview, "I drive through the state really quickly."
While Mr. Rollins may be keeping his foot on the accelerator, he seems to be leaving some pretty toxic fumes behind. Three years after he made his fallacious claims, and decades after would-be voters were taxed and forced to take literacy exams at the polls, the potential for voter suppression still hangs like a stench over New Jersey. 
 The latest threat to voting rights came in the form of recently released state guidelines that could make it extremely difficult for low-income voters to cast their ballots in November. Under the proposed guidelines, a voter who had moved within a specific county but into a new election district would learn upon arriving at the polls that he or she could not vote without first trekking to the municipal clerk's office to file an affidavit confirming the new address, then back to the polling place.
In response to these new ballot security measures, the Democratic Party of New Jersey sued the state on Oct. 1, charging that the new requirements violated the National Voter Registration Act of 1993, which was, among other things, intended to make it easier for people who move to vote. The lawsuit also charged that the rules violated the Voting Rights Act of 1965, which effectively ended discrimination against minority voters.
Poor urban dwellers would be adversely affected by the rules, the lawsuit argued, because they tended to be the most transient voters and because they also had the toughest time getting transportation to the polls. The additional travel required by the rules would have made it nearly impossible for such people to vote, the lawsuit contended.
"New Jersey has a long and sad history of efforts to interfere with voters at the polls," said Cardell Cooper, Mayor of East Orange and chairman of the national Democratic Party's get-out-the-vote effort in New Jersey this year. "We are taking the steps we need to take to make sure that nobody is improperly denied the right to cast a ballot on Nov. 5."
When a Federal District Court judge indicated that she was likely to rule in favor of the plaintiffs, Governor Whitman quickly stepped in. By late last week the Republican-controlled state government and the Democratic Party had signed an agreement, averting an Election Day travesty of democracy.
The agreement, however, did not come without some difficult, and strange, moments. Just hours after Democratic Party officials and the Secretary of State, Lonna Hooks (the state's chief election official), adopted a revised procedure that would allow relocated residents to vote at their new polling places without a hassle, the state Republican Party and Representative Richard A. Zimmer tried to stop the agreement from going forward. The settlement, Mr. Zimmer and his Republican allies contended, would infringe on the rights of poll challengers who check for voter fraud.
At a time when Republicans across the country say they want to draw more minority voters into their "big tent," why would Republicans in this state put the rights of poll challengers before the rights of voters? And how could Mr. Zimmer, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, advocate a position that threatens voting rights with only weeks to go before Election Day?
Mr. Zimmer said he intervened only because the state Republican Party had asked him to, and he didn't know about the details of the lawsuit. It is also possible that Mr. Zimmer chose to side with his party not only to tow the party line, but also to take a firm stand in opposition to his rival for the Senate, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, who had already joined the Democrats as a plaintiff.
To be sure, both sides were acting in the interests of their respective parties on this issue, but the Republicans' callous disregard for voting rights may signal that their interest in attracting minorities to join their ranks applies only to minority voters of upscale economic status.
Ultimately, all sides reached a compromise, but sadly, our state leaders allowed the guarantee of the 15th Amendment to the Constitution to become mired in partisan politics.
It may have been way back in 1965 when Lyndon B. Johnson proclaimed, "There can no longer be anyone too poor to vote." But if some officials here in New Jersey could have had their way, 1996 might have been deja vu in the Garden State.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2411 words

HEADLINE: A Warming Trend in Winter Homes

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
CHARTREUSE and rusty brown bunches of paper-thin ferns were clustered around the bottoms of beet-red, goldenrod and caramel-colored trees; children peered out the backs of husky station wagons, their setter dogs' heads stuck out side windows, ears flying, as mothers and fathers in plaid flannel shirts threaded their way along the back roads of Vermont and New Hampshire on a green-apple-crisp weekend. For many the goal was merely to explore, to raid the maple-sugar shacks and cider mills and discount-clothing outlets, and then swing the station wagons around and head back to New York City apartments and suburban split-levels -- to taste the countryside in autumn and return to the land of paved driveways and canopied apartment houses.
But for some -- real estate agents say far more than a year ago -- the trip was another type of exploration: a journey to find, or at least to consider, a weekend house, or a place to spend fall and winter vacations. 
 So of course, they went to Vermont, to places like Stowe, with its plethora of ski runs -- where the dream may be a 17-acre building lot with views of Mount Mansfield, or maybe a distinctive Japanese-inspired cottage with a swimming pool. And they drove to New Hampshire, where the leaves are just as lovely but where towns like Peterborough are not as built-up, where instead of downhill skiing, there is cross-country skiing and skating on town ponds -- and where properties are a lot cheaper than they are in Stowe or Woodstock, Vt.
For those whose dream does not encompass the nippy air on the deck of a ski lodge but focuses more on, say, bicycling down the path for a loaf of bread in the south of France, there may be a much shorter distance to drive, but in a different direction: south, to Bucks County, Pa., where 18th- and 19th-century stone cottages by the stream aren't as cheap as they used to be, but then again, one may be able to spend more time in Pennsylvania than in Provence.
Agents who reported last year that prices of vacation home properties had dropped sharply are now saying that the free-fall in prices has come to a halt -- except, perhaps, for condominiums in resort locations, many of which are difficult to sell at any price.
For properties in the middle and lower price ranges -- anything up to $500,000 -- agents throughout the region say that prices have stabilized, which in broker parlance means that they may be relatively low, anywhere from 20 to 40 percent off what they were at the height of the market in the 80's, but that they don't seem to be going down.
Sam Strong, who runs the real estate company that bears his name in Old Lyme, Conn., cited "one little Federal on Joshuatown Road in Lyme." The house, which because of its small size, lack of garage and only two substantial bedrooms has traditionally been used as a second home, sold in June 1993 for $270,000, Mr. Strong said. It sold again, on Aug. 28, for $272,379.
"That about says it all," he said. The house, well situated on a prestigious country road, held its value during the last three years -- but didn't go up. During the height of the 80's, the realtor said, the same house sold in the mid-$300,000's.
At the same time, prices for higher-end properties -- from the Hamptons to Nantucket Island to Northeast Harbor, Me., -- seem to have taken off. Average sale prices in Bridgehampton are up 77 percent over prices a year ago, according to one brokerage firm. And on Nantucket, several houses traded for over $4 million.
For the most superb properties, those with acreage, privacy and a pond or a view in a blue-chip location, prices have risen dramatically, in many cases up to the level of the heyday just before, and just after, the stock market debacle of 1987. "This year, we crashed through the glass ceiling of 1988 prices," said Frank Newbold, a partner of Braverman Newbold Brennan, a Hamptons real estate company. At Dayton/Halstead, another Hamptons brokerage, sales volume is up 60 percent.
"Things have definitely changed," said George C. Balantyne, the vice president of Sotheby's International Realty in charge of the company's listings from Maine to Fairfield County, Conn. "We had gone through a period where people were waiting to see if things had gone as low as they were going to go. No one wanted to be the first to jump into the market -- they figured give it another six months."
A year ago, Mr. Ballantyne reported the largest sale in the Manchester/Dorset, Vt., market had been $400,000. "So far this year, we've had two sales over $1 million there, and they're both second houses," he said last week. "One sold to a man from New Jersey, another to someone from Tennesee." And on Squam Lake in New Hampshire, where the movie "On Golden Pond" was filmed, Mr. Ballantyne said, he knows of two contracts signed for properties over $3 million.
"These are numbers never even imagined for second-home properties in New Hampshire," he said.
NO matter what the price, agents report, prospective vacation buyers want to find a property up a narrow winding road and ideally with a pond or a stream running by their house, or a view of the mountains.
"It's hard to sell a village house to a New Yorker," said Heather Peterson, president of The Petersons, a real estate firm in Peterborough, N.H., started by her grandfather in 1948. "It's also hard to sell them any house, in a way, because they like the whole neighborhood to be consistent.
"Some don't mind buying a stately colonial on a village green," she said, "but only if every house on the green is a stately colonial. And you know, we don't really have neighborhoods like that in Vermont and New Hampshire -- oh, maybe Woodstock, Vt. -- that's the town rescued by the Rockefellers -- but mostly, we have rich people and poor people, and a lot of times, especially in town, they live right next to each other."
Pall Spera, a real estate broker in Stowe, agrees. But even in Stowe, he said, there are certain roads with more cachet, certain million-dollar subdivisions with more land per house, and certain outlying townships where property is worth more than it would be elsewhere. In nearby Morrisville, for instance, a massive green Victorian with turrets and dormers and fish-scale shingles just sold for $170,000 -- a house that would have cost double or triple only a five-minute drive away.
For Mr. Spera, a lawyer who moved to Stowe 27 years ago and opened the real estate company that bears his name, business is booming again after the black days of the early 90's. And although he says that property, on an average, is still 20 percent less expensive than it was in the heady days of the mid-1980's, prices have stabilized over the last four years.
"The ski resort reputation -- and the ski resort buyer -- is still here, but it's almost old news," he said. "You'll also find people who come here just to hunt moose or to discuss nuclear fission at elegant restaurants."
Most of his second-home clientele, from New York City, Washington and Connecticut suburbs like Greenwich and Darien, come looking, he said, "for the perfect Currier & Ives country."
But it's also Currier & Ives with a 90's twist. "Many people want a house that can be managed in their absence, maybe even rented out for them," said Mr. Spera. "We're a service economy: If you want your firewood delivered, your food purchased, your wine decanted and maids to clean up after your weekend, The New York Times and eggs benedict -- you can get it."
The would-be buyers are also looking for a solid investment.
"With the slowdown in the 90's, the second home slowed down," Mr. Spera said. "The buyers became much more ambivalent about buying -- after all, they really didn't have to buy. They started asking: 'Is there any real reason for me to be here?' "
Condominiums in the ski resorts of Vermont, often selling for as much as $200,000 in the heyday, apparently didn't meet the test.
"There came a point where condos were not stable," Mr. Spera said, "where pricing was amorphous, not predictable; they became almost impossible to fairly value."
Canadians, many from Quebec, had always provided a backup, a cushion for the condo buyer -- you could also find one to sell to. But then, according to Mr. Spera, they became more like Americans, reluctant to invest in real estate with no land attached. The market values of Vermont condominiums fell, occasionally to half their purchase price in the 80's.
NOW, Mr. Spera contends, condominium prices have stabilized -- but remain about a third less than when they were first built, and many can be hard to sell even at such prices.
"Now when people are looking for value, they like to see a house and some land, a 'Little House on the Prairie,' " he said. "You don't have to be Donald Trump to figure that out."
So would a millionaire developer like a purist's paradise, a 262-acre property with only one house -- a 1780 weather-beaten clapboard cape with eight fireplaces and a wood stove -- and a magnificent barn, all up a gravel road with a spectacular view of the Vermont hills?
The house, owned by an antiques collector, is in Nelson, N.H., a posh lakeside community in the southern part of the state near Dublin, and is priced at $465,000. The owner has already turned down several lower offers, according to the broker.
For those who find the price a little unmanageable -- despite the extensive acreage -- one possibility is the 1960's house on the slope of Rose Mountain in Greenfield, N.H., tactfully described as a "lodge," on 40.1 acres, for sale for $79,900.
Although the house has acreage and an absolutely breathtaking view of Mount Monadnock, along with the requisite walk-in stone fireplace, there are a few things missing. Like a foundation. (The house is built on concrete piers.) And an indoor toilet. (There is, however, an outhouse with a view.)
Nevertheless, this property also offers something that most do not: a "sweat house."
"The owner built it; it's like the Indian-male bonding place," said Ms. Peterson. "I think he's a bit of an Outward Bound kind of guy."
The house was on the market for about a month, she explained, but then the owner decided to rent it out for the winter. "He wanted to do some adventure play thing and wanted to make sure it was taken care of," she said. The rental hurt a possible sale, she explained: "We had some hiker types interested but they would've wanted to buy it right away -- not wait until spring."
In winter, it is impossible to drive right up to the house; residents must park their car in what is known as "the winter parking lot," and a utility vehicle might be useful even to make it this far -- a sturdy Volvo had a bit of a pull.
Such problems do not loom large down in Bucks County, where gravel roads are also prized, but where the winters are milder. There, the grass seemed a little more manicured, and an antique house and stone barn on the Delaware River, an estate called Burgess Lea, is for sale for $3.95 million.
Perhaps the fastest-growing segment of the Bucks County market is relocation -- men and women transferred to the big companies nearby: Merck, Bristol-Myers and Johnson & Johnson, according to Linda Krick-Danese, director of sales for Kurfiss Real Estate in New Hope. New construction, especially in the upper price reaches -- the high $400's and low $500's -- is moving steadily.
IN general, property sales are off about 15 to 20 percent from the dizzying heights of 1986 and 1987, said Ms. Krick, who added that when it comes to second-home sales, it is impossible to judge, to guess at an average.
"Second homes are very eccentric around here, each house is different," she said. With what she calls "country properties," versus "executive colonials in a subdivision near the interstate," each one has its own price -- and audience.
"Country properties have a very specific audience," she said, "and it isn't the same audience as for the others."
Second-home buyers in Bucks County want "full-thickness stone walls, stone horse barns -- even though they don't have horses, people like to have dependencies. Then they want privacy and protection from the road; they'll pay another $150,000 or $200,000 for the same house in a rural setting.
"And they love water," she added. "The Delaware River is hard to find, but a pond or a stream. . . . " Solebury Township is perhaps the most prestigious place, but Upper Makefield and, farther north, Tinicum Township also have some wonderful places, the agent said.
In Tinicum, Ridge Cottage is priced at $795,000 and is one of those rambling, multilevel white-stuccoed stone farmhouses that come right out of an English shelter magazine; in fact, it has sheep grazing in the meadow and Staffordshire platters hanging on one of the exposed beams in the family room. It is described in its brochure as having "Irish country charm."
Ridge Cottage is owned by John and Cecilia Collins, who originally came from Staten Island and bought the house, with its guest house across the gravel road and 20 acres, about 12 years ago. Now Mrs. Collins spends the week in Tinicum, while her husband, a lawyer, spends part of the week practicing law in Staten Island.
"He comes here Tuesdays, Thursdays and weekends," said Mrs. Collins. Because Tinicum is about 15 minutes north of New Hope, it takes him only about an hour and a half to drive to his office, she said. Mrs. Collins and her husband -- she was once an antique dealer with shops in both Frenchtown and Lambertville (both in nearby New Jersey) -- are packing up and moving to Ireland.
New Hope is different from Stowe and Peterborough -- and more like Nantucket or Stonington, Conn. -- because there are buyers who actually like to be in the center of town, a charming, bustling village with lots of antique shops and antique houses. For them, a large clapboard house with an elaborate secret brick-terraced garden off the side behind a high wood plank fence just went on the market. Complete with a quarter acre of land, spacious for an in-town house, the property is for sale at $279,000.
Its current owner, Thomas Sperling, is moving out of town, and he said he was sad to be selling the house, which he renovated, with its deep taupe wood trim, its reproduction of an antique stove in the kitchen and its tall handsome Victorian rooms -- and of course, its luscious garden and brick-patterned patio.
"You do get attached," he said quietly.

HEADLINE: HOUSING;
What to Do When the House Is Too Big and the Budget Not Big Enough

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
Patricia T. Gritman has spent most of her life in Ridgewood, a picturesque Bergen County village of broad streets, venerable old trees and Victorian houses. She learned to swim in the sandy-bottomed municipal pool and later sent her two children to the high school she attended.
"Even the principal was the same when they got there," said Mrs. Gritman, 54. "My town is such a phenomenal thing." 
 But the children are grown now, her husband, Richard, is retired, and she is soon to join him. And, she fears, without a change in zoning they may not be able to enjoy the leisure life in the community of their memories.
"We can't afford it," she said. "Our income will be reduced while our taxes will keep getting higher. I want to stay. My friends, my activities, my wonderful downtown is here."
"And," she added, "there are plenty of others like me."
It is a concern in many communities across the state, particularly those that aged gracefully without the help of strip malls, tract homes and factories belching steam -- places where strict building codes and high taxes keep the land steeped in history and gingerbread trim, but also force some long-time residents to relocate once they retire, divorce or become too ill to remain in their homes.
With all usable land occupied and zoning inhospitable to apartment buildings and condominiums, towns like Ridgewood have been left with a quandary: how to preserve the sense of community that made the town what it is.
"We're essentially talking about the economic viability of a city," said Susan E. Naruk, president of the Ridgewood Savings Bank and one of those in Ridgewood now fretting about its future.
"There is no question that Ridgewood can survive with a transient population that's just attracted to its lovely housing stock," she said. "But continuity is no small thing to these kinds of towns. People with a history in a place tend to be more committed to it. They join the volunteer fire department and support the local theater. They are what gives a town it's quality and stability."
Following the lead of other Bergen towns and several other affluent communities in New Jersey and southern Connecticut, Ridgewood is now considering a change in its zoning rules that would allow a small apartment to exist within some of its large old houses.
Called accessory housing, it is a way for the community to alter its housing stock without changing the feel or the look of the town. Under the proposed ordinance, which community leaders said would likely go before the Village Council sometime in mid-1997, no changes would be allowed to the facade of a house, which would have to remain owner-occupied, and additional parking would have to be accommodated discreetly on the property, not at the curb.
The ordinance borrows generously from one passed in Greenwich, Conn., 14 years ago. Like Ridgewood, Greenwich contains many houses built in the early part of the century. And in recent years, it, too, found its population in decline, as longtime residents grew old and housing prices rose beyond the reach of young families.
Since Greenwich adopted its ordinance, 165 homes -- roughly 1 percent of those meeting the criteria -- have been approved for conversion. There have been few complaints from neighbors who had worried that accessory housing might decrease their property values or peace of mind, said Diane W. Fox, the city planner.
"People have found that there is no visible change to the neighborhood," she said. "The apartments are small, unseen, and health codes regulate the number of people who can live in them."
Hundreds of communities across the country have passed similar ordinances in recent years, according to the American Planning Association. These include six of the eight towns in Fairfield County (which includes Greenwich), where a state law requires towns to set aside 10 percent of their stock to affordable housing, as well as much of Bergen County.
"This can be a win-win situation for these communities," said William G. Dressel Jr., the executive director of The State League of Municipalities, a lobbying group for all but four of New Jersey's 567 municipalities.
"The existing housing stock is what they've got to work with, largely a lot of big old Victorian houses," he said. "While these addressed the needs a century ago, we've moved on. A decision has to be made as to what the needs are now."
Housing advocates in Ridgewood are setting up seminars, distributing information and offering explanatory videotapes to help gain support for accessory housing.
Hope Dingley, the chairwoman of the Ridgewood Housing Task Force, said she is hopeful the measure will be adopted, noting that few young families can afford what at its cheapest and smallest is a $200,000 fixer-upper, and that few of the elderly can afford the taxes on the large old homes where many were born.
Despite a sense of growing support for the measure, a battle for passage might still take place. Arthur Wrubel, vice-chairman of the Planning Board envisions a very narrow interpretation of any new zoning code.
"My father-in-law is living alone in a Manhattan apartment," he said. "He shouldn't be there. He should be here with me." But, he said, allowing others, like young singles, into Ridgewood might be a tougher sell.
"That's opening the door a little wider than I want," he said. "I mean, it opens the door to the rest of the world. I think it's got to be for the family's that are here. We don't want a rooming house."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Using a Mortgage In a Bridal Registry

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
SENSING that many newlyweds would rather have help buying a home than home appliances, the Government is moving ahead with a program that lets couples open bridal registries at lenders approved by the Federal Housing Administration.
The Bridal Registry Accounts, established earlier this month, allow friends and family members to put cash wedding presents into a bank account. The money will earn interest and eventually go toward the down payment on a home bought with an F.H.A. mortgage. 
 "This new initiative will provide a great way for a young couple to save for their first home together," said Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
But no wedding, it seems, comes off without a hitch. The F.H.A. limits the size of the mortgages it underwrites to $157,000 in the nation's most expensive markets, like New York and San Francisco; the limit is as low as $78,600 in other areas. Most of its business will probably be in the South, Midwest and parts of the West. Indeed, of the 33 lenders in the program, none are based in New York, New Jersey or New England. (A few, however, may have branches in those states.)
F.H.A. loans also have down-payment requirements as low as 3 percent, which may sound great to newlyweds who don't receive enough in cash gifts to make a 10 or 20 percent down payment. Down payments of less than 20 percent, though, generally require private mortgage insurance, which can add $30 to $50 a month to mortgage payments.
"I would tell a young couple, or an old couple, for that matter, that it is ludicrous to spend the kind of extra money you have to spend to buy a home using private mortgage insurance," said Marc Eisenson, publisher of the Pocket Change Investor, a financial newsletter in Elizaville, N.Y. "You are better off renting and saving up the 20 percent down payment."
Then there are the interest rates on the savings. The rates, to be set by the banks, will probably be only about 3 percent in most cases. Financial planners advise that couples not keep the money in the registry accounts if they plan to wait more than a few months to buy their home.
"Shop around -- even a six-month C.D. would pay more than these accounts," Mr. Eisenson said. "And more important, if the couple has a lot of credit card debt, then it would definitely make more sense for them to use the money they have received to pay off debt charging them maybe 17 percent interest than it would to keep it in a savings account."
The idea for the H.U.D. program came from the Universal Lending Corporation in Denver, which had asked the department for guidelines for its own registry earlier this year. Universal makes all types of mortgages, not just F.H.A. loans.
Another lender, BankAmerica Mortgage in Uniondale, L.I., has been offering a program similar to Universal's since March 1992, but only to residents of New Jersey, New York, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Delaware.
Gift-givers should know that none of the programs require couples to use the money in the accounts for a down payment on a house. They can withdraw the money whenever they want and use it for whatever they want.
The bride and groom should also know that if they decide to buy a home with the money, they are under no obligation to apply for a mortgage with the lender offering the registry or the designated banks holding the registry accounts.
BankAmerica offers $100 off closing costs for those who do. It's part of the marketing gimmick, to be sure. Romantics, however, can consider it a wedding present.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Pay Bills Early? Now It Can Pay

BYLINE: By MARTHA NOLAN McKENZIE 

 BODY:
GE Capital made waves recently when it announced that people who pay off their bills completely each month would have to start paying an annual fee for the GE Rewards Mastercard.
The rationale is simple: Card holders who do not carry a balance just do not generate as much profit. Card issuers have long pointed to this when explaining why they offer sweeteners to people who revolve some debt month after month, though GE Capital is the first major card issuer to penalize those who do not. 
 So it comes as quite a surprise to find a bank that is taking the opposite stance. Key Bank U.S.A., based in Cleveland, last week began offering a credit card that rewards people for being fiscally prudent. Customers who make big payments on their bills each month will pay a lower interest rate than those who pay only the minimum.
The Key Bank program has won accolades from consumer advocates, who have criticized the new GE policy and similar disincentives for people to dig out of debt. "I have nothing but praise for the Key Bank card," said Ruth Susswein, director of Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer group in Salem, Va. "It is working to assist consumers and rewarding them for paying off their debt."
The Key card, called Key Smart, assesses its top interest rate, 16.9 percent, for a card holder who makes the minimum payment -- 2 percent of his balance. If the customer pays 3 percent of his debt, the rate falls to 14.5 percent, and if he pays 5 percent, his interest rate will fall to just 10 percent.
So what's in it for Key Bank? Steve Hucal, director of credit card services at the bank, says response has been strong and the card is attracting a desirable group of card holders. A mailing for the card resulted a response rate of 3 to 4 percent, three times the industry average, helping to reduce Key Bank's cost of acquiring new customers. Based on a test of the card since April, 90 percent of its users will carry a balance, compared with an industry average of about 70 percent, Mr. Hucal said. Furthermore, the balances are 20 percent higher than average, he said.
The secret to the card's early success may be that it encourages consumers to make substantial payments but not to shed their debt entirely.
Robert McKinley, president of RAM Research, a credit card research company in Frederick, Va., says it's easy to see why companies don't want card holders to pay the entire bill each month. Those who do would have to charge $45,000 a year to create as much revenue for a bank as those who carrying $2,000 balances, he estimated.
The big card issuers -- 10 companies control half of the market -- have been increasingly intent on improving their bottom lines. As the competitive pressures built in the early 90's, card issuers added rebates and other attractions in the hope of encouraging people to charge more, increase their balances and generate more interest income. Cards with such frills typically carry rates four to five percentage points higher than those on plain cards.
Consumers soon realized they could get the rewards, whether frequent-flier miles, points toward a car purchase or a cash rebate, and avoid the high interest rates by paying the balance each month.
Now card companies are encouraging card holders to carry balances. For existing card holders who don't carry a balance, GE Capital said last month that it would begin charging a $25 annual fee on its Rewards Mastercard, which provides a cash rebate of 1 to 2 percent of the amount charged.
Citibank now charges 15.65 percent for card holders who carry a balance of up to $2,500, and lowers the rate to 13.65 percent for those with bigger balances. Chase Manhattan, Household International and Fleet Financial Group have adopted similar rate structures to reward people who carry debt.
"The GE and Citibank strategy is probably going to win out over the nice-guy strategy" of Key Bank, Mr. McKinley predicted.
But there may be another benefit for Key Bank. People who pay only the minimum generate considerable interest revenue for the card issuer, but they are also more likely to fall behind on payments. People who make bigger payments each month, Key officials suggest, will be better credit risks.

HEADLINE: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;
When Your C.D. Is in Francs or Pounds

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN 

 BODY:

Q. I want to diversify my portfolio by investing in foreign currency. Will any United States bank sell me a certificate of deposit in Australian dollars?
 
B. LACEY
Manhattan
 
A. I asked this question at my own local bank. "Foreign C.D.'s?" an assistant vice president replied politely. "No, definitely not here. Have you checked the import section of Tower Records or HMV?" 
 His humor wasn't unjustified. Because American banks have computers that are typically programmed to operate only in American dollars, "most don't want the hassle" of offering investments in other currencies, said Hanspeter Walder, head of private banking at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
But some American banks decide otherwise. Two that I found are Citibank (800 755-5654), which has a $25,000 minimum for such investments, and Mark Twain Bank of St. Louis (800 926-4922), a pioneer in the field, with a $10,000 minimum.
And though their minimums are often lofty, the American branches of European institutions like Swiss Bank (212 574-3000) and Deutsche Bank (212 474-8000) often offer foreign C.D.'s, as well as foreign bonds and money-market funds. Switching among many different currencies is no big deal for them; in Europe, they do it all the time.
The globalizing economy, however, may lead American bankers and others to rethink their reluctance to get into the foreign C.D. swim. "In 10 years," said Ira Weiss, a vice president at Merrill Lynch, "everyone will have multicurrency capability. They'll have to."
These currency investments may not be the next Macarena, but there are some signs of growth -- like Merrill Lynch's recently announced pilot program in which investors, for a $50,000 minimum, can buy C.D.'s in six major currencies.
Mr. Weiss also predicts that demand for foreign C.D.'s will rise sharply if there is another greenback tumble like the one in early 1995. The dollar is now 38 percent above its postwar low of 80.63 yen, reached on April 18, 1995.
Some foreign C.D.'s carry penalties for early withdrawal, while others, like Citibank's, do not allow removal before the maturity date. Like domestic C.D.'s, the foreign ones generally pay higher rates of interest for larger amounts. But the basic interest rate varies by currency.
Citibank offers foreign C.D.'s in maturities of 1, 2, 3, 6, 9 and 12 months. It also has money-market accounts in the same currencies in which it sells C.D.'s. The countries are Australia, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, New Zealand and Switzerland; it also offers C.D.'s based on the new European Currency Unit.
Mark Twain has a broader menu, offering C.D.'s in any tradable currency in the world. There's no need to lose sleep anymore wondering how to get the Thai baht or Czech koruna into your account. Mark Twain can even get Russian T-bills denominated in rubles. (The untradable currencies, according to Neil J. George Jr., Mark Twain's chief economist, include the Hungarian forint, Chinese yuan, Vietnamese dong, Cambodian riel and Indian rupee.)
Mark Twain's $10,000 minimum applies to six common currencies; for less popular ones, the minimum is $20,000.
But, Edmund Hillary notwithstanding, just because an investment is there doesn't mean a person should buy it. Mr. Weiss stresses that foreign C.D.'s are not at all like the safe domestic variety. If the dollar strengthens or if your C.D.'s currency weakens, the movement may erase much or all of your interest earnings; you may even end up with a loss. Though they share the C.D. name with dollar-based C.D.'s, then, they are far riskier.
And currency fluctuations are very unpredictable -- even for professionals like George Soros, the billionaire financier. That's why banks try to deter smaller, unsophisticated investors with high minimums, and recommend that affluent investors put only a small part of their portfolios into the investments.
Still, foreign C.D.'s can provide diversification to a portfolio. They can also serve as a hedge against a falling dollar, or as a speculative play. And as long as American interest rates remain low, some foreign C.D.'s can give you more bang for the buck. Investors who were savvy enough to buy 30-day New Zealand certificates, for example, are now enjoying payments at an annual interest rate of 8.75 percent.
To make money on a foreign C.D., select a currency in the same way you'd choose a stock, Mr. George suggests. For instance, many people are now bullish on Ireland, and while some of them may buy stock in Waterford Wedgewood and other Irish companies, others may purchase Irish C.D.'s on the assumption that the country's growth will be reflected in the Irish pound.
"It's a calculated risk," Mr. George cautioned, "and one can lose."
Just look at the Mexican peso, which went from 3.5 to the dollar just before its devaluation in December 1994 to about 7.6 to the dollar today.
All in all, it's comforting to know that in these times of automatic teller machines, a few bankers are still working hard to better serve their clients. It reminds me of a form letter sent to Groucho Marx by his friendly Beverly Hills banker, ending with the traditional "If I can be of any service to you, do not hesitate to call on me."
Back came a note from Groucho: "Dear Sir: The best thing you can do to be of service to me is to steal some money from the account of one of your richer clients and credit it to mine."

HEADLINE: BENEFITS

 BODY:

'Woodlands Ball'
SATURDAY -- The Prospect Park Alliance will hold a dinner and dance under a tent near the Prospect Park Carousel (Flatbush Avenue and Empire Boulevard entrance). HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Taking a Shine to Rust-Oleum

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
THE economy, as usual, is a sphinx. Job growth is weak and that calms inflation fears, but wages are up and that raises such worries. For some investors, these mixed signals are a call to start hunting for all-weather stocks.
One such prospect is RPM Inc., a holding company in Medina, Ohio. Founded in 1947 under the banner of Republic Powdered Metals, the company initially made a liquid aluminum coating for industrial roofing. Now it does much more, producing 100 coatings, sealants and specialty chemicals for industry, as well as for the hobby and do-it-yourself markets. The company peddles brand-name goods like Day-Glo fluorescent paints and Rust-Oleum, the rust preventive that many homeowners swear by.
RPM's hallmark, though, is steady and consistent growth: it has posted 22 consecutive years of dividend increases, in good economic times as well as in bad. One big reason: Sales of RPM's products rise in a prosperous economy, and they are cushioned in tough times when the do-it-yourself market picks up.
"Historically, this stock does quite well within a late cycle-early recession time frame," said Jerry R. Herman, who follows midsize growth companies at Everen Securities in Cleveland. "In 1990, for example, it was up 22 percent, 15 percent in 1991 and 32 percent in 1992."
Such historical performance, however, does not necessarily mean the stock is now a buy. But, for several reasons, bullish investors say it is. Pointing to RPM's recent hard times, as well as to stepped-up management incentives and its overseas expansion plans, they see RPM stock as underpriced.
RPM, which has $1.13 billion in annual revenue, has clearly hit a rough patch in recent years. Even for a company that can prosper in good and bad times, it has been hurt by the recent slowdown in consumer spending. Last winter's weather was so severe that there was a cutback in the use of maintenance products in general. And the Day-Glo brand took a washing in the last few years, as RPM's competitors were far quicker to jump into alternative markets for fluorescent dyes when neon-colored clothing declined in popularity.
RPM's earnings were hurt by these developments, rising only 10 percent, and 6 percent on a per-share basis, in the fiscal year ended May 31. In the previous decade, average earnings rose 17 percent annuallyand per-share earnings rose 12 percent.
Not surprisingly, with all this disappointment, RPM stock has languished, trading in the range of $15 to $17 over the last year and a half. At Friday's closing price of $16.875, the stock was selling at just 17.2 times earnings while the companies on the S.& P. 500 had an average multiple of 20.3. Moreover, RPM often trades at up to a 15 percent premium to the Standard & Poor's 500, analysts say. At that premium, RPM would be selling at $22.90 a share.
Some analysts see several reasons that this premium might return. Karen Lane Gilsenan, a stock analyst at Merrill Lynch, likes RPM's new management incentive plan, announced in June, which will give entire management groups -- not just a few individuals -- the chance to receive bonuses that are 25 percent bigger than before. "That's a pretty attractive carrot to performance," she said.
Then come the ambitious overseas acquisition plans of RPM, which has long been an active buyer of domestic businesses. "Right now, 17 percent of our direct sales are outside of the United States," said Thomas C. Sullivan, RPM's chief executive. "I'd like to increase that to 25 percent over the next five years."
The market potential is certainly there. "If you look at all of the markets that RPM competes in, you're looking at a $100 billion market," Mr. Herman said.
Moreover, Mr. Herman says he thinks RPM has a leg up on foreign acquisitions. "To many sellers of business," he said, "RPM is a buyer of choice because the company has demonstrated a willingness to pretty much leave an acquired operation alone, while supplying them with capital and other forms of infrastructure."
But RPM is new to international work, which is full of uncertainties even for veteran global players. Although no one company competes against the whole product line of this diversified enterprise, RPM faces many big rivals for selected goods. "They have competitors in every single market," said Mr. Herman, including names like Du Pont, 3M and Sherwin Williams.
Harry Millis, a managing director at Fundamental Research in Cleveland, says he thinks RPM is a good value but he cautions that its growing size means it must evolve. Acquisitions used to fuel two-thirds of its earnings, but as the company grows they will probably supply just one-third. Mr. Millis also foresees a more modest annual increase in earnings -- RPM's earnings are due out next week -- than the 15 percent that Mr. Sullivan forecast for 1997.
Nevertheless, RPM's advocates point to the strict cost-control plan that was instituted last fall, and the pent-up demand from last winter for RPM products like the Bondo line of automotive repair aids. And who knows? The Day-Glo paints are beginning to regain some of their former sales glory by finding new lives -- as tracers for use in farming and in fighting fires like those that have recently battered the western United States.
