HEADLINE: Hollywood Dusts Off Its Claim To Glamour

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12

 BODY:
For years now, the fanny-pack-toting innocents who ventured a few steps from Mann's Chinese Theater on their tour have stumbled upon the discovery that in a close-up, Hollywood -- the place, the decaying chunk of northwestern Los Angeles -- has little in common with the booming industry of the same name.
As they followed the Walk of Fame trail of stars on the sidewalks east along Hollywood Boulevard, past the occasional boarded-up shop and the peculiarly loitering young men with beepers or women in stilettos, many shared the reaction of Marlene Keith, a mother of five from the Cape Cod town of Dennisport, Mass. What she had expected, she said, was "glamorous and glitzy." What she had found was "shoddy and seedy." 
 "And a little scary," she added.
But these days, city officials and local merchants say, that image is changing. The turnaround of Hollywood -- its face lift, injections of capital and image-polishing -- has begun.
"Hollywood probably is the most valuable trademark in the world," said Gary Mendoza, the Deputy Mayor of Los Angeles. "Times Square has a level of international cachet that may not rival Hollywood's, and if Times Square can go through the renovation it's gone through, there's no reason in the world why we can't do the same."
Of course, Hollywood has gone through even harder times than 42d Street, what with earthquakes helping to literally bring down landmarks like the Brown Derby, the lingerie looting of Frederick's of Hollywood during the 1992 riots and recent sinkhole problems on Hollywood Boulevard brought on by subway construction. And it has not yet attracted the mega-investments that the Walt Disney Company and others are putting into Times Square.
But boosters point nonetheless to new ground for optimism and the increasingly recognized development potential of a mecca for more than nine million tourists a year.
City officials count at least $100 million in public and private money on its way into the district for 69 new developments and 36 renovations and expansions of museums, theaters, retail stores, restaurants and other projects. This coming week, they added, the American Film Institute will hold its film festival at Hollywood Boulevard's theaters for the first time, and the first meeting will be held for developers who may want to bid on a multimillion-dollar complex around the Hollywood subway portal that is to open in 1998.
As in the transformation of Times Square, 41 owners in Hollywood have banded together to create a small Business Improvement District, which will collect $600,000 a year from members to pay for a private security force and other improvements starting in December. The California Highway Patrol began deploying officers last month along the boulevard to crack down on the young people who traditionally cruise in their cars on weekends. The city is offering special loans and tax breaks to developers in Hollywood, and Richard Riordan, Los Angeles's business-friendly Mayor, has declared the area an economic priority.
Plans are also in the works to better exploit Hollywood's identity as the childhood home of the movies.
The new, 33,000-square-foot Hollywood Entertainment Museum, a few steps from Mann's, opened full time this week, offering visitors a stroll around the Starship Enterprise bridge and the bar used in "Cheers," among other attractions. The shuttered Max Factor makeup museum is scheduled to become a Hollywood history museum, and the Chamber of Commerce plans to post nearly 50 explanatory signs on the district's buildings -- noting, for example, that Clark Gable and Carole Lombard hid away at the Roosevelt Hotel and that gossipmonger Louella Parsons broadcast from the Hollywood Hotel.
Fueling the overall Hollywood revitalization are projects to renovate landmark theaters. The Egyptian Theater, built by Sid Grauman before he built the Chinese, is expected to reopen within two years as a showcase for American Cinematheque's classic movies. The ornate El Capitan, the Art Deco masterpiece that becomes the nation's top-grossing cinema when it holds premieres of Disney movies, has already been made over at a cost of $5 million, and more millions are going into refurbishing its upstairs office space.
And the entertainment business itself is growing in Hollywood, officials say. Most big studios -- except Paramount -- moved out years ago, but there is so much small-scale production and other entertainment work in Hollywood that there is a shortage of work space, said Julie Kleinick, former president of the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce.
"Contrary to popular belief, entertainment people want to be here, but they want a clean and safe environment," she said.
It was in the 1920's that the studios of Hollywood had their heyday. Though the area itself was always somewhat seedy, it started to go seriously downhill in the 1960's, struck by urban blight.
John F. Drap, a resident and retired Army sergeant now volunteering at the Entertainment Museum, said that in the early 80's, Hollywood "was a pit."
"I would not walk down Hollywood Boulevard after sundown because it was just a really bad place," he said. "It had gone down as far as it could go -- but now it's a great story of the revival of the inner city. It's just like Cleveland."
The real-life Hollywood experience can still be unpleasant, as witness the recent travails of Daryl Kamin, a tourist from Wisconsin who said he had been threateningly accosted twice by locals as he tried to videotape the sidewalk stars on the Walk of Fame.
"I'm still a little queasy," he said. "The day was soured for me. The atmosphere is thick with thuggery."
But a stroll down the Walk of Fame these days also entails encounters with dozens of uniformed people, from a security force in Smoky the Bear hats paid for by the city and the subway authority to a crew of cleaners wearing yellow "Hollywood Beautification Team" T-shirts. New palm trees tower across from the Chinese Theater, and the enterprising owners of Grand Central Coffee have even dared put tables out on the street -- though solidly chained.
Hollywood has been ripe for this kind of revival for years, said Leron Gubler, executive director of the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce, but it was held back by the recession, which has been slow to lift in California, along with endless bickering among local business people. The failure of several planned mega-projects also held things up, he said.
But now, Mr. Gubler and city officials said, the Hollywood turn-around is taking on momentum because everyone stopped waiting for one Disney-like savior and went ahead with a collection of smaller projects.
"There's always been a lot of interest but there's been nothing for people to hang on to, to invest in," Mr. Gubler said. "That has changed."

HEADLINE: MAIN STREET, JAPAN: Heading to the Polls;
Family and Friendship Guide Japanese Voting

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: OMIYA, Japan, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Waiting for customers to buy his octopus dumplings, Yukihiro Hatta puffed on a cigarette and explained that elections never make a tad of difference, but that he always votes.
"I'm really not interested in politics," said Mr. Hatta, a grizzled 63-year-old snack peddler whose white smock was lightly stained. A cheerful man whose warm face is full of laugh lines, Mr. Hatta is interested in friendships, however, and as he sees it that is the true rationale for voting. 
 "I'll vote," he said enthusiastically, relishing the chance to do his buddies a favor. "I always vote. I vote for the people my friends tell me to vote for."
As Japan gears up for a national election on Oct. 20, in small towns like Omiya people like Mr. Hatta are preparing to vote for reasons that have little to do with the candidates' policies or personalities.
At bottom, politics here are not political. Rather, electoral politics in places like Omiya rests on much deeper concepts of Japanese behavior that long predate ballots or democracy: notions of group identity, of hereditary entitlement, and especially of "giri," the sense of owing someone a debt or obligation.
Japanese politicians often inherit their seats in Parliament from their fathers or grandfathers, forming a modern aristocracy like the feudal lords of 150 years ago. Then, as happens in the United States as well, the politicians help towns like Omiya by allocating funds for roads or bridges, and the commoners pay fealty in the form of votes -- their own and those of people connected to them with bonds of giri.
Here in Omiya (pronounced OH-me-yuh), a sprawling town of 5,700 surrounded by mist-shrouded hills on the Kii Peninsula, 200 miles southwest of Tokyo, people are preparing for the election by delicately testing the links of giri that are the arteries and veins of small-town Japan.
"I hear that in the cities, people vote on the basis of policies, or on the basis of the person running," said Yoshiaki Okuyama, 44, a post office worker in Omiya. "But in local areas, it's not the policy or the person who counts, but the request from a friend or neighbor. A friend might tell me, 'I'm supporting so-and-so, and if you're not supporting someone, could you vote for him, too?' Then, if I owed my friend a favor, I'd support his candidate."
 
The Process
When Duty Calls, Votes Are Cast
People feel they owe giri to their bosses, and so in Omiya it seems natural to vote as the companies suggest. Not all firms endorse a candidate, but many do -- especially construction companies, which depend on pork-barrel projects.
"When there's a candidate who my company tells me to please support, then I'll vote for that candidate," said Yoshiharu Deguchi, a burly 39-year-old employee of a construction company, as he played with his young son in the living room of their home. "After all, I don't have any other candidate whom I'm supporting, and my thoughts are generally the same as my company's."
Mr. Deguchi then tells his parents and his wife, Michiko Deguchi, for whom he is voting, and they normally vote for the same candidate. "I listen to my husband," Mrs. Deguchi said, "because he works outside and knows a lot about the world."
Workers in unions get their directions not from their bosses but from their union leadership. It is not just that they believe the union is looking after their best interests -- the main reason why American union members tend to vote for candidates backed by organized labor. Another reason is loyalty to the union.
"I'll vote as the union tells me, which means for the Social Democrats in the proportional representation ballot," said Yoshimi Nishi, a 49-year-old post office employee, as he stood in a doorway during an evening drizzle. "If the headquarters orders people lower down to do something, well, this is an organization. We should obey orders."
 
The Arena
In Small Towns, Pork Barrel Rules
"I ask my family members -- my wife and my daughter -- to vote in the same way I do, because this is a decision that my job partners have reached," he said. "When my daughter can make independent decisions, she can vote on her own. But until then I'll ask her to vote my way."
When will his daughter be able to make independent decisions? Mr. Nishi thought about that for a moment. When she is married, he decided; then she is free to vote as her husband tells her.
One of the busiest people in Omiya these days is Teigo Okuyama, a 68-year-old rice farmer who laughs often, revealing a mouthful of gold interspersed with gaps. Mr. Okuyama is putting up a fence to keep wild boar out of his rice paddy, but these days he is also busy as the local representative for one of the parliamentary candidates.
Mr. Okuyama's giri to the candidate, Takao Fujinami, goes back two decades, to a time Omiya needed a tunnel.
"They had built a small road nearby, but it was rather dangerous," Mr. Okuyama recalled, as he sipped green tea in a friend's home. "When we crossed the road with our cultivators, there was a risk of an accident. So we wanted a tunnel to go under the road for our farm equipment."
Mr. Okuyama and other farmers asked Mr. Fujinami, who was in Parliament from the area, and the tunnel was promptly built.
Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill's famous axiom about America, "All politics is local," is even more true of Japan, particularly the small towns. In the cities, giri and pork-barrel politics are less important, but in the countryside they are just about all there is on election day.
Americans may bemoan the lack of issues in modern campaigns, but a visit to Omiya during election season leaves one thinking that by comparison Americans are policy wonks. The people of Omiya are more likely than Americans to vote, and the tone of political debate is far more civil than in America, but there is almost no attention here to issues.
"I'm not really knowledgeable about politics," Mr. Okuyama said as he deflected questions about Mr. Fujinami's policies. The only issue for him, beyond discharging his debt to Mr. Fujinami, is whether a member of Parliament can divert budget money for local projects.
"Then people will be very happy," Mr. Okuyama said, beaming. "National policies are too huge, and they don't really touch people."
One person after another in Omiya made the same point. There is little sense here that anything good or bad might come out of an election.
Economic policy is seen as largely the domain of Government bureaucrats rather than politicians, and while some voters complained about the governing parties' plans to raise the sales tax, they said that they doubted the opposition would keep its promise to cancel the increase.
When a half-dozen people in their 20's and 30's gathered in a room in the Omiya Town Hall the other night, staying after an English class to meet a reporter, it was striking how apathetic they were about politics. They mostly expressed no interest in the election and said that it would make no difference who became Prime Minister.
Of course, that may be not just apathy but also shrewd observation. Politicians are rarely agents of change in Japan, and the real decisions are typically made by bureaucrats in government ministries. Even then, the decision-making process tends to be based less on leadership than on consensus.
 
The Legacies
Where High Office Can Be Inherited
Many districts in Japan are very competitive, but in a deeply conservative area like Omiya it is almost a foregone conclusion that the Liberal Democratic candidate -- Mr. Fujinami -- will win. Indeed, this year Mr. Fujinami's only opponent is a Communist Party candidate who stands virtually no chance of winning.
Voters will get a second ballot when they go to the polls, to vote for a party so additional seats in Parliament can be assigned on the basis of proportional representation.
Given that Mr. Fujinami is considered a shoo-in, that ballot for the party is the one that really matters this year.
Mr. Fujinami's father was not a member of Parliament -- although he was a local politician -- but it is becoming increasingly common for people to inherit their seats in Parliament.
People in Omiya are watching this year as the politician with the biggest local machine, Hajime Tamura, tries to have his nephew elected as his successor. "If I didn't have that relationship, I probably wouldn't be running for office," the younger Mr. Tamura said.
"People say that to run for office you need the three 'ban,' " Mr. Tamura said earnestly. These are the "ji-ban," the party machine or network; the "kan-ban," or brand name, such as the surname of a retiring politician, and the "ka-ban," or moneybags.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE FIRST LADY;
On the Trail, She's First Mom And Wife

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 10

 BODY:
For a few fleeting minutes here today, it seemed as if the Hillary Rodham Clinton of old were back.
"Health care is just too expensive for the vast majority of American families to be able to afford on their own," she said in a commanding voice, revisiting the issue that brought her so much political grief and helped force her out of the spotlight. 
 But the setting was not a meeting hall or ballroom in Washington; it was here at a center for the elderly. Her listeners were not lawmakers or hospital executives pondering national policy; they were retirees thrilled by their brush with political celebrity.
And the intentions she touted were were those of her husband, whom she invoked with affection.
"Tomorrow is our 21st wedding anniversary," Mrs. Clinton told the crowd here, saying she was going to surprise her husband with a copy of a poem to the Clintons that someone in the audience had read aloud. "Nobody tell him about it!"
In a week that began with the first Presidential debate, and ushered in the home stretch to Nov. 5, Mrs. Clinton remained on the fringes of the race, avoiding overly partisan comments and presenting herself as a respectful wife, a devoted mother.
With Mr. Clinton far ahead in the polls and questions about Whitewater still dogging her, Mrs. Clinton seemed to be taking no chances.
She traveled to four different states in three days -- Michigan, Pennsylvania, Illinois and Wisconsin, which are pivotal battlegrounds in a Presidential election.
But for every conventional rally, she visited two or three schools. For every political appeal, she offered half a dozen expressions of her concerns as a mother for America's future. And her appearances were marked by a minimum of fuss. Reporters were not allowed to travel with her, which all but guaranteed local but not national coverage and that she would be chronicled with less skepticism.
Moreover, she visited Democratic strongholds like inner cities, union halls and liberal university towns, where loyalists greeted Mrs. Clinton with unfettered applause.
When she is not talking policy, she is taking a page from so many First Ladies before her, coming across as a national guidance counselor beckoning Americans -- and children in particular -- toward civic virtue.
Defining the importance of the election for hundreds of students in a high school auditorium in Madison, Wis., on Wednesday afternoon, Mrs. Clinton struck a favorite theme and tone. "If each of you individually is successful, that is good, that is important," she said.
But, she added, "it is not enough for individuals to be economically and educationally secure if they care nothing about the larger community responsibilities that are always a part of life, if they don't respect people who have different backgrounds or different points of view."
Time and again, she drew attention to her status as a parent with a child still at home and still in school, implicitly underlining a difference between herself and Elizabeth Dole, who does not have children.
"As the parent of a child who will go off to college next year, I particularly like my husband's proposal that we allow every family to deduct up to $10,000 a year for education expenses," she said in Madison.
That assertion of herself as an average American, rent by the same frustrations and riveted by the same dreams as everybody else, was a motif in all her remarks. In the past, when she said "we", she often meant her husband and herself. This week, it meant the American people, and any talk of programs and policies was attributed solely to "the President" or "my husband."
"We have a President who understands clearly that one of the great conflicts we face is between time and money," she told several thousand Democrats at the rally in Chicago on Tuesday. "We don't have enough of either in lots of cases, do we?"
Just about everyone who turned up to see Mrs. Clinton said they noticed that she had undergone a makeover, but reacted differently to it.. George Yanchuk, who stood on a street corner in Wilkes-Barre to watch her motorcade, applauded the change.
"A lot of people were getting fed up with the way she kept poking into the President's business," said Mr. Yanchuk, 67, a retired carpenter. But while he said he found Mrs. Clinton's current incarnation more attractive, he said he did not believe it would last past Election Day.
Others were saddened by Mrs. Clinton's relative reticence, because they said the negative approval ratings that precipitated it were the product of an archaic national resistance to outspoken women.
"People just can't handle a strong woman," said Tricia Allen, 24, a school psychologist in Chicago who attended the rally there. "I think she's absolutely wonderful. I would vote for her, if she was running."
Clinton-Gore campaign strategists said Mrs. Clinton was not deliberately shrinking from a high-profile role. They said her schedule was as busy as it was four years ago and that she had been appearing with Democratic candidates for Congress because it was felt that her support would help them.
Some political scholars argued that Mrs. Clinton's changed manner might have to do with incumbency. "She's the First Lady now," said Carl Sferrazza Anthony, a historian who has written several biographies of First Ladies. "I think that puts her in a different position from the 1992 campaign, where she was advocating and promising. Now she's reflecting and hoping."
But the focal points of those reflections and hopes were mostly noncontentious: education (she cherished it), drug abuse (she deplored it) and interracial harmony (she embraced it). And her tone of voice was compassionate, nurturing.
A fairly typical event was her appearance on Tuesday at a Y.W.C.A. in downtown Detroit, where she instructed 60 schoolchildren, sitting cross-legged in front of her, about how to avoid violent confrontation.
One child chimed in that his school had a "problem-solving area" to which sparring children retreated before any punches could get thrown.
"What a good idea!" Mrs. Clinton said. "I think we should have one of those in every grown-up place -- you know, in every business, in every Congress."

HEADLINE: Lobbying at Murdoch Gala Ignited New York Cable Clash

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The party under the tent on 48th Street in Manhattan was festive, but the host, Rupert Murdoch, was also a little bit angry. There he was, ballyhooing the debut of his 24-hour cable news channel, while the very viewers he most needed to establish this $165 million expansion of his media empire had almost no way to see it.
Time Warner had repeatedly refused to carry the channel, Fox News Channel, on its cable systems in New York City, preventing it from attaining a presence in the nation's communications center. So Mr. Murdoch and his lieutenants used the gathering on the night of Oct. 1 to make some discreet pleas for help to three prominent Republicans who had come to toast him: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Gov. George E. Pataki and Dennis C. Vacco, the State Attorney General. 
 "By the time of the party, it was pretty clear that we wanted any assistance that we could get," recalled Roger Ailes, a former Republican political consultant who is now chairman of the new channel. "I said, 'Hey, how are you doing? We need your support.' "
The three officials responded the next day by pressing a strenuous campaign on behalf of Mr. Murdoch, one that has injected government into a fierce clash between two corporate leviathans and that has raised questions about whether politicians are playing favorites with media companies.
It has also touched off complaints from some other media conglomerates.
Mr. Murdoch has not spoken publicly about the battle since it began, and his aides referred questions to Mr. Ailes, who vigorously defended Mr. Murdoch's lobbying. Mr. Ailes said Mr. Murdoch had acted after Time Warner, last month, suddenly backed out of a crucial deal to put the channel on its cable systems. Both men have accused Time Warner of violating anti-trust laws in an attempt to shield CNN, which it recently acquired, from competition.
Time Warner, which transmits to every borough but the Bronx, has 1.1 million customers. The other major cable operator in the city, Cablevision Systems, has 450,000 customers in the Bronx and Brooklyn. It has agreed to carry the Murdoch channel, though it has not yet found space for it.
Executives at Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation had begun turning to city and state officials for help even before the Oct. 1 party, but the effort did not appear to pick up steam until afterward.
The next day, the Giuliani administration sent a letter to Time Warner requesting permission to transmit Mr. Murdoch's channel on one of the five city-run cable stations, a proposal that the company eventually contested in court. On Friday night, a judge granted Time Warner a temporary restraining order barring the city from going forward with the plan.
The judge, Denise Cote of Federal District Court, said she believed that the administration had improperly tried to place Mr. Murdoch's channel and another commercial channel, Bloomberg Television News, on the city's noncommercial cable stations.
Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that he had not decided whether to appeal the restraining order, which is in effect until a hearing on Oct. 23. He criticized Judge Cote, saying that his aides had not had an adequate chance to rebut Time Warner's charges.
"In fairness, she should have given us the opportunity to put our side on the record before her," Mr. Giuliani said after marching in the Queens Columbus Day Parade.
On the same day that Mr. Giuliani's aides were sending the letter to Time Warner, Mr. Pataki was calling the company's chairman, Gerald M. Levin, urging him to reconsider his rejection of the channel. The Governor told Mr. Levin that Mr. Murdoch had personally asked him at the party to intercede, the Governor later said.
Mr. Vacco had his own conversation at the party with Arthur M. Siskind, the general counsel for Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation, people there said. Mr. Siskind told Mr. Vacco that the state should pursue an antitrust investigation against Time Warner for not agreeing to transmit the channel, and soon after, Mr. Vacco began one, subpoenaing documents from the company.
"Our concern was voiced to the officials who were there," Mr. Siskind said, declining to comment further.
At about the same time, the most powerful Republican in the state, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, also called Mr. Levin, trying to persuade him to reach an accommodation with Mr. Murdoch, people involved in the dispute said.
Big companies often seek help from politicians over business disputes. But Time Warner executives assert that the swiftness of the moves by the four Republicans is not a testament to the merits of Mr. Murdoch's case, but rather to his standing as a well-known conservative who can deploy his media outlets, particularly The New York Post and WNYW (Channel 5), to aid or damage officials.
"This is the most frightening exercise of political power that I have seen in my entire career, and I have been in politics and government for 40 years," said Richard Aurelio, president of Time Warner's local cable subsidiary.
"This is strictly an effort to endear themselves to somebody who has not only endorsed them in the past but continually supports them with biased coverage," he said.
In court papers, Mr. Aurelio said that Mr. Giuliani's aides tried to bully him into undertaking a scheme that would have put the Fox channel on in violation of Federal law. Yesterday, Mr. Giuliani called that contention false.
All four Republicans vehemently disagree with Time Warner's charges. They say Mr. Murdoch's politics are irrelevant and emphasize that they are helping a businessman who contributes to the city's economy and is being victimized by Time Warner. They say that if the channel, which is based in Manhattan, is not available in much of the city, then it might not be successful, threatening jobs.
"My concern is 1,400 jobs in New York City and damn it, I am going to fight for those jobs," Mr. Giuliani said last week, referring to the number of new jobs that Mr. Murdoch has promised to create through the Fox News Channel and other ventures. The channel already has 600 workers in the city.
Raymond B. Harding, the leader of the Liberal Party and one of the Mayor's closest political advisers, also insisted that the administration was not seeking any political favors from Mr. Murdoch, but he did not deny that the actions could work to the Mayor's advantage.
"Sometimes when you do the right thing, it may also turn out to be good politically," Mr. Harding said.
On Friday, Richard D. Parsons, the president of Time Warner Inc., resigned as an economic adviser to Mr. Giuliani over the dispute. Mr. Parsons said the Mayor was being "politically expedient" by trying to help Mr. Murdoch.
Mr. Pataki, who benefited from a $100,000 contribution that Mr. Murdoch's company gave to the Republican state party for his election in 1994, said there was nothing inappropriate about helping him.
"The day the Governor can't speak out on any issue is a very sad day," Mr. Pataki said. "Fox is a tremendous addition to the range of news coverage that people around the world are going to be able to see. And it's just wrong that they cannot see it in New York."
Mr. D'Amato and Mr. Vacco declined to comment. Chris Staszak, a spokesman for Mr. D'Amato, said, "The Senator hopes the situation is resolved for the benefit of all the people." Christopher McKenna, a spokesman for Mr. Vacco, said there was nothing unusual about the Attorney General talking to Mr. Siskind.
"That is standard operating procedure for any law enforcement body," Mr. McKenna said.
Aides to the four Republicans, speaking on condition of anonymity, did acknowledge that there was another factor, separate from the lure of any endorsements they might continue to receive from the editorial pages of The New York Post. They said the officials resented what they saw as a liberal bias in the news media, so by helping Mr. Murdoch, they were protecting what they believed was the only media conglomerate with a conservative voice.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, noted that the Governor thought that it was curious that there had not been a greater outcry from journalists about what he charged was censorship by Time Warner.
"If the shoe were on the other foot, he was wondering if there would be the same type of reaction," Ms. Mucha said.
Mr. Ailes said that within the last two weeks, he had spoken with Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Pataki, but he said his political ties to the two men had nothing to do with his ability to get them on the telephone. Mr. Ailes was a leading adviser to Mr. Giuliani when he ran unsuccessfully for Mayor in 1989.
Mr. Ailes played down the importance of the conversations that the News Corporation executives had had with the three Republicans at the party, calling them brief and informal. And he said that if Democrats had been in control of City Hall and the Statehouse, he would have made the same requests.
As Time Warner and Mr. Murdoch continue to skirmish, other media conglomerates have been watching with annoyance, saying that they are upset about Mr. Giuliani's involvement. Some have noted that they, too, have not got their programming on the Time Warner system because of lack of space, and have pointed out that they account for more jobs in the city than Mr. Murdoch.
"We believe that it's a dangerous precedent for the city to become involved in content decisions of this kind," said Philippe P. Dauman, a deputy chairman at Viacom, which has its headquarters and 8,500 employees in the city.
Instead of putting on Fox, Time Warner chose to transmit another 24-hour news channel, MSNBC, a joint venture of NBC and Microsoft. At NBC, some executives questioned whether had the situation been reversed Mr. Giuliani would have been an advocate for NBC.
The Mayor has made "an enormously significant, potentially frightening and unprecedented set of actions by a government official," said Richard Cotton, an executive vice president of NBC.
Speaking yesterday at the parade, the Mayor dismissed such talk.
"Disagree with me, fine, say you have a different philosophy," he said. "But don't start demeaning me with the cheap kinds of things that are being done here because people are involved in business rivalries."

HEADLINE: Imperiled Species In Jamaica Bay: The Eel Men;
Industrial Pollution Helps To Crowd Out a Way of Life

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
On the southern shore near Hook Creek, a crane noisily scooped up rocks with its claw, rumbling back and forth at an asphalt plant spewing thick smoke. To the east, scores of gleaming white spherical fuel tanks waited for trucks to deliver their contents to Texaco and Amoco stations.
Westward, beyond Kennedy International Airport's control towers and the jets landing every few minutes, beyond the A train shuttling between the Queens mainland and the Rockaway Peninsula, across the vast salt marshes and waters of Jamaica Bay, the World Trade Center's twin towers rose into the morning sky, the only hint of Manhattan's existence. 
 In the shadow of a barge beside the asphalt plant, a father and son in a small fishing skiff pulled up a cage from the bottom of Jamaica Bay: a dozen eels squirmed inside the trap. Wrapping his massive fingers around a three-foot silver eel, the father kissed its mouth.
"That's your future here, sonny boy!" Larry Seaman cried with relish, holding up the eel to Larry Jr.
Long after most people have forgotten that New York is surrounded by water, the source of many men's livelihoods in another time, the city immortalized by Herman Melville boils down to this -- the Seamans of Queens, two of the last city residents the census lists as "commercial fishermen."
Within a few years, the Seaman family will move to Virginia, where it has already bought land off Chesapeake Bay. There, the Seamans expect to pursue a calling that is vanishing in New York because of industrialization, pollution and stricter environmental regulations.
For now, though, two generations of Seamans live on a sliver of land on the southeastern edge of Kennedy Airport, a stone's throw from a runway. Squeezed in by Rockaway Boulevard and a shopping strip on one side and Hook Creek on the other, this nameless hamlet of two-story shingled houses is officially part of, but a mile away from the rest of, Rosedale. It is possibly the remotest outpost of the nation's largest urban empire, with the Queens county line abruptly looping southward to add the neighborhood's 17 houses to its territory.
Because the city will not have title to the neighborhood's streets until year's end, the private streets still lack a sewage system. They flood during heavy rains and the houses drain untreated waste into Hook Creek.
More than a generation ago, half a dozen families fished commercially out of boats docked in their backyards. Nowadays, only two of the families still fish, the Seamans and, up the block, the Kirchners -- five fishermen in all. The Kirchners also trap the muskrats favored by recent Russian and Chinese immigrants, and they chop wood to heat their house.
"It's like the land that time forgot," said Bob Seaman, 50, Mr. Seaman's brother. "You expect dinosaurs to be crawling around here."
The Seamans say a combination of factors is pushing them to extinction, most recently a $100 million storm sewer being built in neighboring Brookville Park. The underground pipes, intended to relieve flooding in southeast Queens, will release storm water into nearby Thurston Basin by the year 2001. Government officials say the project will cause no ecological damage, although the fishermen and some environmentalists believe it will pollute the bay.
For the Seamans, the airport, the State Department of Environmental Conservation and the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge have such authority over their lives that the fishermen's powerlessness is captured in a village adage: "Next to God is the Port Authority." Regulations forbid them from erecting bulwarks, using rope with lead or venturing into corners of the bay the fishermen know like their living rooms.
"They teach them in college," said Larry Seaman, 53. "They come out here and try to change our way of life. This net's too big -- this and that."
Hook Creek was at half tide and a neighbor's dog was baying at the rising sun as the Seamans prepared recently for a day of trapping eel.
Mr. Seaman's daughter, Kim Zatto, 30, came down a wooden plank connecting their backyard to a pier. A regular customer had called for eel. How much should they charge him? she asked her father, who answered: $4 a pound.
The son raised an eel tank from the creek, picking out a few dead ones and throwing them into the water so that rats would not come scavenging during low tide. Atop the roof of the house across the creek, a sea gull, alert to the morning drill, gazed down at the floating carcasses.
After Bob Seaman's boat drifted by downstream, the father and son followed in their 24-foot skiff.
The brothers steered their boats through the creek, alongside Rockaway Boulevard and a Pizza Hut. They passed by Thurston Basin and headed toward the shore of Inwood, L.I., stopping awhile near the asphalt plant and fuel tanks. Then the captains gathered speed toward the open water, through Grass Hassock Channel, the waves breaking behind them like diamonds under the clear sky.
 
Silence Broken Only by Concorde
Near Silver Hole Marsh, the father and son searched for the ropes attached to their traps as the sun warmed their coats and boats, the silence broken only at 8:15 A.M. by a Concorde taking off.
The eel men use the intersection of two distant structures to mark the spots where they left their traps. But the smog clung to Manhattan because of the windless sky, and one of their reference points, the Empire State Building, remained hidden.
In Norton Basin, not far from Edgemere's towering housing projects, they found some traps near a sunken, stripped car -- full of writhing silver and green eels. After freeing them into a tank in his boat, the father placed fresh bait, half a crab, into the trap and threw it back into the water. Eels enter the trap, the size of two milk crates, through a small hole.
At the height of the season, around November, the father and son set 200 traps throughout Jamaica Bay. Eels reach their fattest then, as they prepare to hibernate from December to April by burrowing at the bottom of the bay.
Freshwater eels were always popular with Italian immigrants, and recently demand has risen because of Chinese newcomers, Bob Seaman said. But the eel supply has fallen over the years, he added, and the eel men are lucky if they make half of the $300 or $400 weekly profits they cleared three decades ago.
Bob and Larry Seaman learned eel trapping from their father, who drove a Mobil truck for 27 years and supplemented his income as a part-time eel man. Back then, it seemed every boy who grew up around the bay knew how to catch eel.
It was perhaps natural that Larry Sr., as the oldest son, became an eel man. But for Bob, the eel was his last chance. After serving a tour as a sergeant in Vietnam from 1968 to 1971, he came back suffering from nightmares and, two dozen job rejections later, found himself unemployable.
"That's why I went back on the water again," he said, discarding a cigarette that hissed in the waves.
 
A First Date Taken To Jamaica Bay
By then, Larry Sr. was already married. On their first date in the early 1960's, he had taken Lois Sterzenbach out into Jamaica Bay -- he pointed vaguely toward Jo Cos Marsh, looking a little embarrassed in front of his son and brother. "We didn't have cars when we were young," he offered by way of explanation, "so we took our boats."
The couple bought a house -- paying $4,000 "in hard-earned eel money," Mr. Seaman said -- in North Woodmere, L.I., just east of the hamlet. Their community was made up of about 20 houses on a handful of islets, linked to the mainland by footbridges and surrounded by marshes where the inhabitants fished and hunted pheasant and rabbit.
"It was all family," said Doris Sterzenbach, Mr. Seaman's mother-in-law, who lived on Queens Avenue in North Woodmere from 1945 to 1965. Her daughter and son-in-law lived down the road.
Some maps still list Queens Avenue and the other streets in that neighborhood, but plans to extend the Nassau Expressway, never realized, got all the residents evicted.
"My aunt, Violet Myers, used to live here," Mr. Seaman said, stepping off his skiff onto a pile of rotting wood on an islet with overgrown weed, near blackened pylons forlornly standing by themselves in the water with no pier to support.
"Over there, they built a golf course so that the rich people can bat balls around," said Mr. Seaman, who still has disturbing dreams, three decades later, about losing his house.
The Seamans found their way to the hamlet, where they now live in three adjoining houses and own a bait-and-tackle shop.
The hamlet was a tight community of fishermen. The head of the other surviving fishing family, Karl Kirchner Jr., 62, remembered that the villagers used to gather at the neighborhood restaurant and bar, Bertrum's, where they watched Jackie Gleason and Sid Caesar on the first local television. Now Bertrum's is an International House of Pancakes catering to the Five Towns.
Mr. Kirchner and his son, Karl 3d, fish for crabs during the summer and eels in the fall.
"It's a father-and-son thing passed down," the son said.
The other fishermen moved or died, leaving many dilapidated houses and bringing new residents who were startled to find commercial fishermen as neighbors in New York City. The traffic on Rockaway Boulevard is sometimes so dense that it is almost impossible for the villagers to merge into it. Twice last year, when Bob Seaman tried doing so at rush hour, motorists threatened him, once with a machete and once with a gun.
Larry Seaman talks constantly of Virginia, where his wife just got her real estate agent's license and where she waits for her husband to move for good. He plans to, in a few years, once they finish paying for their property off Chesapeake Bay. His brother, Bob, expects to follow shortly. His daughter will wait until her husband, a city sanitation worker, retires with a pension.
His son, Larry Jr., 21, said he would also go south but a couple of years after his father so he can "tie up some loose ends here." Unlike his Uncle Bob, who has not been to Manhattan in more than a decade, he enjoys the urban landscape, particularly the area around St. Marks Place in the East Village.
"I've always told him I won't stop him from pursuing his dreams," the father said. "If you want to be a fireman or a cop, go ahead. Don't ever think, when you're 35, that I held you back."
But only fishing was on the son's mind as they returned home in their skiff, carrying 50 pounds of eel.
"We've been together since I was 16," the son said. "We're a cohesive unit. He'll feel lost without me, and I'll feel lost without him.
"This isn't the most glamorous job, but it's something that I can feel proud about. I like the big city, but I also like quiet. If something gets me apart, I go on the water and I feel at peace. That's my one salvation in life."

HEADLINE: A Leader of '89 China Protest Held on Subversion Charges

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Wang Dan, among the most prominent student leaders of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989, has been charged with conspiracy to overthrow the Government, a capital crime.
The activities for which Mr. Wang, 27, was charged included publishing anti-Government articles abroad, raising money to support needy dissidents and accepting a scholarship from the University of California. 
 Prosecutors disclosed the charges on Friday to Mr. Wang's parents, who were summoned to a Beijing court a day after they had been told to hire a lawyer to defend him.
Mr. Wang has spent the last 17 months in detention at a secret police center, where he was not allowed visits from his family. He served four years in prison for his leadership role in the 1989 demonstrations, which ended in a bloody military crackdown.
Legal experts say the filing of the charges makes his conviction virtually certain, and although the death penalty is seldom applied in political cases, Mr. Wang can expect to be sentenced to at least 10 years in prison.
The decision by leaders of China's Communist Party to bring capital charges against Mr. Wang, the most recognizable icon of the Tiananmen era, appears certain to draw a new round of international condemnation against China.
For the Clinton Administration, the prospect that the youthful Mr. Wang could receive a new and lengthy prison term presents a difficult foreign policy challenge. Earlier this year, Mr. Clinton privately signaled Beijing that if re-elected, he would like to bring to a permanent end the campaign of sanctions and trade pressure that Washington has used to win improvements in human rights conditions here.
To go forward with this plan, Mr. Clinton urged Beijing to show compassion to those who had been harassed or locked up for expressing political views.
Now, in the midst of a Presidential campaign in which his foreign policy is under assault, Mr. Clinton will be under greater pressure to explain how his position toward Beijing has garnered any results and how the United States can influence the deteriorating conditions under which many intellectuals and political dissidents live in China.
Most of the political prisoners on whose behalf Mr. Clinton has interceded with Chinese leaders are now back in prison or in permanent exile.
Tonight, Mr. Wang's mother, Wang Lingyun, said the family had not been notified of a trial date, but under standard procedures, it should begin within a few weeks. "We have not seen him in the 17 months since he was taken away, and we have never known where he is being held," Mrs. Wang said.
Only a year ago, China brought charges against the country's most famous political dissident, Wei Jingsheng, and sentenced him to a 14-year prison term. Mr. Wei helped launch China's "democracy wall" movement in 1978 and drew a 14-year prison term for his trenchant rebukes of Chinese leaders who had promised to establish democratic rule after the death of Mao in 1976.
With these two cases, President Jiang Zemin and the six other members of the Communist Party's ruling Politburo have reaffirmed their determination to silence all dissenting voices and to scorch the pathway of dissent.
The cases have emerged in a season of harsh crackdown on all forms of dissent as the Communists begin preparations for the return of Hong Kong next year and a major party congress that is most likely to cement President Jiang's pre-eminent role as the successor to Deng Xiaoping, the ailing paramount leader of China who turned 92 in August.
But beyond the season of insecurity, President Jiang, now in his seventh year as leader of the party, has demonstrated an increasing intolerance for dissent and for the kind of creeping freedoms that marked the 1980's in the arts, film and the press.
Earlier this week, Liu Xiaobo, a literary critic and dissident, was arrested and sentenced without trial to three years at hard labor for co-signing a biting criticism of President Jiang. His co-author, another veteran dissident, Wang Xizhe, is missing and presumed to be in detention also.
When reports began circulating in Beijing this week that Mr. Wang was to be charged and tried, the Clinton Administration called on Beijing to free prisoners "languishing and suffering in Chinese jails solely because of their political views." The State Department spokesman said the Administration was "seriously concerned" about Mr. Wang's health and the conditions of his detention.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher is to come to Beijing next month for talks with top Chinese leaders, the first time he has ventured back here since March 1994, when he clashed with Chinese leaders over their human rights record.
Days after Mr. Christopher's visit, Mr. Clinton is to attend a summit meeting of Asian and Pacific leaders in Manila with the Chinese President.
Though the indictment against Mr. Wang has not been made public, a New York-based human rights organization, Human Rights in China, issued a statement containing a summary of the charges.
Mr. Wang is accused of publishing critical articles in overseas newspapers and magazines in the three years since he was released from jail.
One of Mr. Wang's overseas articles appeared in The New York Times months after he emerged from prison in 1993. He was also accused of taking part in home-study courses organized by the University of California and for accepting a scholarship to finance his study, part of the authorities' case that he was conspiring with foreigners against China.
Also included are Mr. Wang's efforts with others to raise money to ease the lives of dissidents who have been thrown out of jobs, denied diplomas or rendered unemployable by heavy surveillance.
Finally, Mr. Wang is accused of accepting donations and economic aid from overseas organizations.
