SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 6131 words

HEADLINE: Special Tax Breaks Enrich Savings Of Many in the Ranks of Management

SERIES: RUSHING AWAY FROM TAXES: Executives Who Earn Now, Pay Later -- First of two articles

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Even as the Presidential candidates debate sweeping tax breaks, American businesses have beaten them to the punch. Companies large and small have been signing up executives and other top employees for a generous tax break not available to other Americans. Hundreds of thousands of people have become eligible, most in the last few years, at more than 24,000 businesses.
The deal is simple: Rather than take all their pay, and pay taxes on it, executives let the company hold on to some. The company invests the money, and the executives do not pay taxes on any of it until they take the money years later. 
 It sounds like the I.R.A. or 401(k) savings plans used by tens of millions of Americans. Except this deal excludes the rank and file and has special benefits: there are no Government limits on how much can be put away, and many top executives have put away millions. A lot of companies guarantee them high interest rates on the money and throw in a matching contribution.
Just like that, the executive is able to build a much bigger nest egg than people who have to pay taxes immediately, taking greater advantage of the magical compounding power that makes all these plans so attractive.
Take John F. Welch Jr., chief executive at the General Electric Company. By deferring taxes on $1 million last year, he stands to have $263,000 more within five years than he otherwise would have had.
This executive privilege is known as deferred compensation. Once rarely used, it has soared in popularity in recent years -- an unintended consequence of Government moves to raise tax rates for high-income Americans, clamp down on executive pay and limit the benefits that executives can receive from regular company pensions. And it is spreading quickly, even as half the private work force has no retirement benefits and many companies have been trimming pension benefits for rank-and-file workers. Indeed, its growth represents a threat to a prime tenet of the nation's retirement policies: that companies offer benefits as fairly and to as many workers as possible.
Consider these facts:
*The amount of deferred compensation can be staggering. In 1994-95 alone, the chairman of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, J. F. McDonnell, deferred $2.5 million in pay, and Michael H. Jordan of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation deferred $1.8 million. John L. Clendenin of the BellSouth Corporation has close to $10 million in his deferral accounts.
*There is no ceiling on how much money can be sheltered. One executive alone, Roberto C. Goizueta, the chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company, has accumulated $936.4 million, most of it in company stock that will not be taxed until after he retires.
*No longer are just a chosen few capitalizing on this tax break. A growing number of large companies, including Merrill Lynch, I.B.M. and Tenneco, have recently expanded their plans to include hundreds or thousands of prized employees. Other companies have included middle managers and salespeople making as little as $55,000. Even nonprofit organizations as diverse as Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan and the Boy Scouts of America Greater New York Councils are signing up.
*Owners of small businesses like Ollies Station restaurant in Tulsa, Okla., are now setting up deferral plans, allowing them to save for retirement without including their workers, who by law would have to be part of any pension or 401(k) plan.
*In most cases, because the money remains in the business's coffers, the company and its shareholders pay taxes on it instead of the executive, and therefore effectively subsidize the tax breaks.
*The Government's rationale for allowing special deferred-compensation plans for executives is that they typically do not cost the Treasury. But a lot of companies, following the advice of an army of consultants, are reducing their own tax bites by buying life insurance policies on the executives. Under Government rules for insurance, this allows the deferred money to grow for years without being taxed. An analysis for The New York Times by Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, shows that the Government would typically lose half of the taxes it would have collected. About 300 of the 1,000 largest public companies are now using life insurance to finance their deferred compensation, according to one survey.
*All this is happening with no attention from the Government. Top officials at both the Treasury and the Labor Department said they were not aware that there was much growth in the deferral plans or in the use of life insurance to underwrite them.
*The Government has no idea how many billions of dollars are being deferred, or how much this might cost. In most cases, it requires companies to write a letter informing the Labor Department that deferred compensation is being offered. Many companies never bother to file anything with the Labor Department. And its list is riddled with inaccuracies. For example, it does not include Exxon, Ford and Wal-Mart -- though they all offer deferred compensation.
*Companies are not required to disclose to their shareholders how much their top executives are deferring, even though Federal rules require disclosure of almost every other element of executive compensation. A review of the public filings of more than 300 companies shows that only a few disclose how much of an executive's pay is deferred. Critics say deferrals can amount to a stealth pay raise that should be reported to shareholders.
*In theory, the money promised to executives can be lost if a company runs into financial trouble. But in many cases where a company has gone bankrupt, top executives ended up getting their deferred money even as less powerful managers and rank-and-file workers lost some of their savings.
Deferred compensation is perfectly legal and always has been. Like awards of stock and supplemental pensions, it is one of a growing number of techniques that companies use to attract, reward and retain executives. Still, its growth troubles some people familiar with the arrangements, who say such plans are widening the gap between the American manager and the American worker. Deene Goodlaw, a San Francisco lawyer who teaches pension law at the University of California at Berkeley, has prepared hundreds of deferred-compensation plans. And she says that some companies are paying for these plans partly by cutting retirement benefits for the rank and file.
Ms. Goodlaw said she quit the tax department of a prestigious law firm after she was directed to prepare a lavish deferred-compensation plan for one company's executives on the same day she was told to draft a plan that let it cut most of its low-paid workers out of its pension plan.
"That is where they are getting the money to pay for what the executives get in their deferred compensation," Ms. Goodlaw said. "If you quote me on this I'll probably never get another job drafting deferral agreements. But that's the truth, what is going on is wrong. It's immoral."
Of course, many companies are not slashing benefits for their rank and file. But experts say that exclusive benefits like deferred compensation are a significant departure from the way things used to be. In 1980, executives at large companies derived 90 percent of their retirement benefits from regular company pension plans -- the ones offered to most employees -- according to corporate consultants. But today, only 30 percent comes from the company plan; the rest comes from deferred compensation and supplemental pensions.
"You sever that linkage between executives and the rank and file, and you are going to have a problem," said Jack Vanderhei, research director of the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a nonprofit group. He said that any executive whose company was failing to place enough money in its pension plan would "start to worry if he's expecting to get most of his benefits from it." But if most of his benefits came from other plans, he said, then the executive might think, "What do I care?"
Executives say the Government created these problems by imposing regulations that have made it impossible for companies to offer pension plans and 401(k)'s that can satisfy their highest-paid employees, leaving companies with no choice but to expand the deferral plans. And the Government's attempt to rein in multimillion-dollar executive salaries encouraged companies like General Electric, McDonnell Douglas and Westinghouse to shift from cash compensation to a much greater reliance on deferrals, which are exempt from the new limits.
Deferred compensation is off-limits for the vast majority of workers. Federal law allows employers to include only "a select group of management or highly compensated employees" in deferral plans meant to provide retirement savings. That generally means less than 3 to 5 percent of the work force. The reason is that such plans do not have the safeguards required for pensions and savings plans for the rank and file. Unlike the funds for pensions and 401(k)'s, deferred money is subject to claims by a company's creditors if a company fails. Also, the deferral plans are not backed by the Government's pension insurance fund.
But to judge by the numbers, that risk has not frightened many business leaders.
 
Why Delay Pays
A Business Response To Government Limits
Since the Government created the income tax in 1913, wealthy Americans have always found ways to avoid or delay paying taxes. Deferring income can be as simple as a real estate broker shifting the collection of a fee from one year into the next.
Many companies began letting executives defer pay as the highest tax rate surged from 7 percent to 94 percent during World War II. But even though the top rate stayed at 70 percent or higher through 1981, the deferral programs at most companies remained limited, and they were mainly used by a handful of executives nearing retirement.
One reason was that in the 1950's and 1960's, most large companies had basic pension plans that offered adequate benefits to both executives and the rank and file. But in 1974, Congress passed the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, which included measures to expand and protect the retirement money of regular workers.
That law set the first limits on how much executives could draw from basic company pension plans. And it said that if they wanted to save more, they would have to use other vehicles that did not have the same safeguards. These were mainly the special deferred-compensation plans and supplemental pensions.
But deferral plans did not take off until Congress made more changes. This happened even as the top tax rate was being slashed, to 50 percent in 1982 and then to a low of 28 percent from 1988 through 1990.
Two big changes involved I.R.A. and 401(k) accounts. Shortly after the Government introduced Americans to the impressive compounding power of tax-deferred savings, Federal officials became alarmed by how much revenue the Treasury was losing.
The Government allows individuals and companies to deduct immediately their contributions to I.R.A.'s, 401(k)'s and company pension plans that include the rank and file, but the workers do not have to pay taxes on that money until they receive it many years later. This gap between the tax deduction and the tax collection has long been one of the single biggest tax breaks, now costing about $70 billion a year.
So in 1986, Congress eliminated some of the generous deductions. It ruled that most employees covered by other pension plans could no longer deduct their contributions to an I.R.A. (a maximum of $2,000 a worker a year, plus $250 for a nonworking spouse). It also slashed the cap on an individual's annual contribution to a 401(k) plan from $30,000 to $7,000. (Inflation adjustments have since lifted that to $9,500.)
Then, in 1988 and in 1993, Congress again tightened limits on what executives could get from regular pension plans. Before these changes, the pension benefits paid to top managers could be based on no more than $200,000 to $250,000 of annual salary. But Congress cut this to $150,000.
Congressional leaders said they were trying to be fair, by aiming the cuts at people who could afford to save without help. Their main motivation, however, was not to adjust the nation's retirement policies but rather to increase tax revenue by billions of dollars and lower the Federal budget deficit.
For executives, the new limits felt like "a multiple nuclear warhead attack" on their retirement security, said Bill C. Wilson, of the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche.
There was one other fusillade. President George Bush signed a bill in 1991 lifting the top tax rate to 31 percent, from 28 percent. President Clinton raised it further in 1993, to 36 percent on all taxable income over $140,000 for married couples, and to 39.6 percent on any portion over $250,000.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton and Congress took a swipe at sharp increases in executive pay -- a trend that had been angering many people as pay soared even for the chief executives of companies that were laying off thousands of people. New measures banned companies from deducting basic salary and bonuses that exceeded $1 million for any one executive.
But there were exemptions. Companies that tied an executive's compensation to his performance did not have to adhere to the $1 million cap. A company could also defer pay above $1 million and still take a deduction on its taxes once the executive took the money. So now the rush for alternatives was on.
 
An Irresistible Deal
Tax Advantages And Secrecy, Too
Among the evidence that deferred compensation is spreading are surveys of the 1,000 largest public companies by Compensation Resource Group Inc. They found that 74 percent offered such programs for at least their top executives in 1995, up from 62 percent in 1994. The consulting firm expects that number to rise to more than 80 percent in a survey being conducted now.
In a new poll of executives by The New York Times and CBS News, 52 percent of top executives at large companies had been offered deferred compensation. And 85 percent of that group had signed up for it.
Many large companies let executives defer as much as half their salary and all of their bonus. A growing number of plans also allow executives to save for short periods, rather than just for retirement. They can take the deferred money in as little as two or three years with no penalty, while I.R.A.'s and 401(k)'s require a 10 percent penalty on withdrawals before age 59 1/2. That is a big advantage in saving for a child's education or a car, a boat or a house.
Deferring pay could reap larger benefits -- at the Treasury's expense -- if Congress lowers income tax rates as Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, has proposed in calling for a 15 percent cut.
Deferred-compensation plans provide one other benefit for many executives: published tallies of how much executives make almost never disclose how much of that pay is being deferred. Few companies will disclose anything about executive pay they are not required to, and none of the chief executives mentioned in this article would discuss their deferrals. So it is impossible to make a comprehensive list of who deferred what.
Deferred compensation "is at times used to hide the true income of executives," said Eugene Steuerle, a former Treasury official.
"I've been reading proxy statements for 20 years," added Stephen Selbst, a New York lawyer, "and I have trouble finding information about deferred compensation."
But a review of corporate filings and numerous interviews provide a sense of how lucrative the programs have become. Many deferral plans pay 8 to 12 percent interest and some go higher. BellSouth has paid interest rates from 8 to 22 percent on deferrals since the mid-1980's.
General Electric promised Mr. Welch, one of America's most successful chief executives, an interest rate of 14 percent when he deferred $1 million of his $2 million base salary last year. It also gave him a $35,000 matching contribution, the same 3.5 percent rate that the company gives other employees on their 401(k) savings.
At 14 percent, his money will nearly double within five years, to $1.88 million. After taxes, he will have $1.07 million.
If Mr. Welch had not deferred, he would have paid Federal and state taxes last year on the $1 million. So he would have been left with $571,680. Even if he could receive 14 percent interest in a safe investment, within five years he would end up with $810,000 -- $263,000 less than with the deferral.
Time Warner Inc. offers Gerald M. Levin, the chief executive, and other top officers this perquisite: a portion of what the company saves through tax deductions when the executives get the money. Over the last three years, Mr. Levin has deferred at least $1.05 million. If that were to grow to $4 million by the time it was paid out, Time Warner would give Mr. Levin not only that amount but also an extra $1 million under the formula involving the tax deduction.
Some who defer, like Mr. Clendenin and Mr. Levin, are mainly bolstering their savings for retirement. But others, like Mr. Welch, Mr. McDonnell of McDonnell Douglas and Mr. Jordan of Westinghouse, have an added motivation: They are helping their companies hold on to tax deductions on their pay in excess of $1 million.
Norm LaFlamme, General Electric's manager of executive compensation, and officials at McDonnell Douglas and Westinghouse all said their companies encouraged the executives to make the deferrals. Under the 1993 law that capped salary deductions at $1 million a year, the companies would have lost any chance to claim the deductions if they had paid out more than that. But by deferring the rest of the money, the companies can preserve the deductions for later.
For the companies, which pay taxes on their profits at rates of up to 35 percent, the deductions are valuable, saving them up to $350,000 on $1 million in salary.
Mr. LaFlamme said General Electric had also given 3,000 other executives a chance to defer money in recent years and that the company used high interest rates as a "hook" to keep executives from leaving. If Mr. Welch or any of the others were to quit within five years of a deferral, the interest rate would drop to 3 percent.
Mr. LaFlamme said the aim was a "win-win for the employer and the executive." But he also said that "we don't like to manage our executive-compensation programs based on tax law."
Other companies are using the deferral programs to link their executives' pay more closely with their performance. Over the last two years, for example, the Ford Motor Company has deferred $5.4 million in bonuses for Alex Trotman, its chief executive. The amount will rise or fall with the value of Ford's common stock, and he will be paid in Ford shares when he retires.
In a new twist, companies like Chrysler and American Home Products plan to allow executives to defer gains when they exercise options to buy their company's stock at discount prices. Normally, executives owe income taxes on any gains from exercising stock options. But the new method allows them to transfer the gains into deferral accounts and delay the taxes.
Some companies also pick up the cost of insurance that eliminates the risk of deferred compensation. Last year, the CSX Corporation, a giant transportation company, spent $421,000 to reimburse its chief executive, John W. Snow, for insurance that guarantees his deferred compensation if the company is taken over.
 
Trickle Down
Expanding Ranks Of the Chosen Few
Who else can qualify for deferred compensation? The answer is like some ancient riddle. It depends on whom you ask.
Most large companies are expanding their programs to include lower-ranking executives and, in many cases, middle managers and top salespeople. Federal law states only that a select group of managers or highly paid employees is eligible. And the Government has never defined that rule more precisely. So the dividing line is blurry, and each company is setting its own cutoff point.
Compensation Resource Group found that 32 percent of the 1,000 largest companies set the eligibility line at salaries of $150,000 or higher and 24 percent set it at $100,000 or higher. But 19 percent of the companies included people making $80,000, and at least 16 percent dropped that to $66,000 or lower.
A quarter of the companies have expanded their investment choices to allow employees to peg their return to that of mutual funds. Merrill Lynch has extended deferral to 3,000 managers and brokers earning $200,000 a year or more. They can choose from investment options that mirror the returns in 30 stock and bond funds.
Last year, I.B.M. began allowing 1,350 executives earning $150,000 or more to defer up to 12 percent of their salaries and all of their bonuses. They can choose among five funds. Edward R. K. Prohl, I.B.M.'s director of executive compensation, said 75 percent to 80 percent had signed up. And the Dow Chemical Company lets 1,200 executives and plant managers defer.
The New York Times Company, in its "Executive Tax Saver" plan, allows the 307 employees who receive stock options, mostly managers, to defer all of their bonus and up to one-third of their salary.
But other companies are venturing farther down the ranks. At Lockheed Martin, the aerospace company, about 2,500 managers earning more than $80,000 can defer bonus money. The Campbell Soup Company created a salary-deferral program this year for managers making $70,000 and up. And on occasion, the Walgreen Company has given managers making as low as $55,000 a chance to defer up to 10 percent of that year's pay.
Still, at companies like Dow Chemical and Lockheed Martin, only half of those eligible have signed up. Participation dropped at lower salaries because many employees cannot afford to save more.
Younger managers are hesitant to tie up their money for long periods. So about half the plans at large companies now allow short-term deferrals, typically three to seven years. This makes it easier to save for something big, like college or a house.
At Imperial Bancorp in Inglewood, Calif., the senior vice president for human resources, J. Richard Barkley, is saving through his deferral account to help meet some of the $22,000 or so in annual college expenses for his daughter.
Mr. Barkley said one advantage of the deferral program was that his company contributed a match of 10 percent to 50 percent, depending on how the company performed. Each account also earns interest, now 7 percent.
Given such advantages, Mr. Barkley said Imperial had found that the deferral plans were "an excellent hiring tool."
Alan Lebowitz, a Labor Department official, said the department had not received complaints about deferred compensation. So, he said, the idea of setting a "bright line" to rule people in or out "has never risen to a very high level of priority for us."
But tensions over the changing balance in benefits are becoming apparent at some companies, like the Kmart Corporation. Last year, the retailer, which has had big losses, decided to freeze the benefits that 180,000 workers could receive from its Government-guaranteed pension plan and set up a profit-sharing arrangement, where employees share in the company's risks.
In bringing in a new chief executive, however, Kmart handed out millions of dollars in deferred stock grants and left its supplemental pension benefits for executives intact.
The company also has a 401(k), and it said it wanted to use the profit-sharing plan to spur workers to help revive its fortunes.
But Lewis Hubble, a warehouseman in Illinois who received only $475 in profit-sharing this year, said that among the workers at Kmart, "There are a lot of harsh feelings."
 
Washington's Loss
Use of Insurance Costs the Treasury
As the deferral plans extend to more people, many companies are looking for ways to lower costs and make participants feel more comfortable that the money will be there when they retire. A growing number are turning to life insurance as a way to do both.
But while saving money for the companies, this technique is passing on some of the costs to the Government. It also is undercutting some of the revenue gains that Congress expected when it limited pension and 401(k) benefits for high-income workers.
This is because the companies are combining their deferral programs with one of the oldest, and most controversial, tax breaks on the books: the tax-free buildup of investment gains in life insurance policies.
"If the new interest in deferred compensation is leading employers to use life-insurance-based savings vehicles, then there are almost certainly going to be losses to the Treasury over time," said Joel Slemrod, a tax economist at the University of Michigan.
The original reason for this tax break was simple. It was meant to help families cope with the death of a breadwinner. Congress has also long allowed companies to take out insurance policies on executives out of concern that they could face major costs in replacing anyone who died.
But over the years, some companies expanded this concept and took out insurance policies covering tens or even thousands of employees to finance a variety of activities, including employee benefits. And now many companies -- from Southern California Edison, a utility company, to Avery Dennison, which makes office labels and stickers -- are using this approach in their deferral or supplemental-pension programs.
Compensation Resource Group found that 30 percent of the 1,000 largest companies use life insurance to underwrite pay deferrals. And most of the plans for small businesses are essentially life insurance policies.
Here is how it often works: A company takes out the policies on its employees, paying the premiums and naming itself the beneficiary. The company can peg the policy's investment returns to fixed interest rates or to mutual funds.
Once the employee is ready to take his deferred money, the company can pay him by borrowing from the policy or cashing it in. But some large companies prefer to pay the deferred amounts out of their own coffers and hold on to the insurance policies until the employee dies.
Then the company can take advantage of one final break: It collects the death benefit without owing any taxes.
The analysis by Coopers & Lybrand shows what can happen. If a manager started at age 45 and deferred $15,000 a year for 20 years at 7 percent interest, the company would owe him $658,000.
If the company had let the money grow tax-deferred through life insurance, the Government would not have received $119,212 in taxes on the gains until the payout, reducing their value by half. And if the company held the policy until the executive died at 78, it would collect a $2.3 million death benefit tax-free.
Congress voted this year to phase out some large tax deductions when companies borrow money from the policies. But Senate and House staff members said lawmakers had not examined the basic use of life insurance policies to finance deferred-compensation plans and supplemental pensions.
Corporate officials say they think such use will continue to expand.
"There really is no tax-advantaged way to provide these benefits except with company-owned life insurance," said LaMont Keen, the chief financial officer at Idaho Power and Light.
But Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a taxpayer-advocacy group, said this was "a particularly egregious example of life insurance being abused to accumulate money without being taxed."
Others worry about the message that a large tax break for an exclusive group can send. "One of the problems with these kinds of tax gimmicks," said Jeffery L. Yablon, a lawyer at Shaw, Pittman, Potts & Trowbridge in Washington, "is that they erode people's trust, turning them into cynics about the tax system and the Government in general."
 
Spreading Way Beyond the Giants of Corporate America
Across the country, financial planners, insurance agents and mutualfund companies are promoting deferred compensation to one group that had made little use of it before: small-business owners.
From Ollies Station Restaurant in Tulsa, Okla., to Bubba's Produce in New Orleans, thousands of small-business owners are creating plans to defer compensation for themselves or a few prized employees.
The owners say the plans give them a measure of security in a part of the economy where it can be hard to build much of a cushion. But many also are embracing pay deferrals as an easy solution to a ticklish problem -- how to save for their own retirements without having to set aside money for the rest of their workers.
"Is it the best mechanism? I don't know," said John Gray, the owner of Ollies Station, who created a deferral plan for himself and his wife, Lin, last year. Their restaurant has about 20 employees, who have no retirement benefits. "In a small company, you can't afford to set up a pension plan because then you have to do it for everyone," Mr. Gray said.
No law requires employers to provide a retirement program, and only about 15 percent of companies with fewer than 100 workers offer them, Labor Department figures show.
If a company does set up a pension, 401(k) or profit-sharing plan, it has to adhere to Federal rules that require it to include most workers. But because the law limits deferred-compensation plans to select groups of the best-paid employees, business owners can leave the rank and file out of those plans.
As the plans spread, critics fear that many small businesses -- the types of companies that create the most new jobs -- will become less likely ever to offer savings plans to their rank-and-file workers. "This is a very significant policy concern," said Karen Ferguson, the director of the Pension Rights Center, a worker-advocacy group in Washington.
Indeed, the lack of savings plans at small businesses is by far the largest gap in the nation's retirement system. Just two months ago, President Clinton signed a law creating a new type of simplified savings plan intended to make it cheaper and easier for small businesses to offer benefits.
But even that new plan requires employers to include any workers who want to participate. And some business consultants say the Government's effort could be undercut by the deferral plans.
For instance, Leonard Masonry Inc. in St. Louis created a deferred-pay program last summer for six top employees, leaving out a handful of others who have no retirement plan. Under the deferral program, the company plans to pay each of the six workers $25,000 a year for 10 years after they retire. "When you get good help, you want to do what you can for them," said Donald Leonard, a co-owner.
Other businesses are also using deferred-compensation plans to create "golden handcuffs." The Commercial Bank of San Francisco, which has 48 employees, set up a plan for just one of them, its chief credit officer, to encourage him to stay.
The Mansfield Hardware and Supply Company, an industrial wholesaler in Mansfield, Ohio, did the same thing for its sales manager, Craig Copeland, one of nine employees. Mr. Copeland, who is 40 and has two children, said he wanted to save more than he could through his I.R.A. "They came to me and offered it," Mr. Copeland said of the deferral program. "I didn't ask."
Nonprofit organizations are also setting up deferral plans. Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City uses one to pay bonuses to 58 managers. The Boy Scouts of America Greater New York Councils is using its plan to enhance the retirement benefits of its executive scout.
At heart, most of the deferral plans at small businesses and non-profit groups are simply life insurance policies. The businesses or groups take out the policies on the lives of top employees. Like large companies, they can choose whether to invest the premiums at fixed interest rates or in mutual funds, and they can let the investment grow without being taxed. They can also borrow against the policies or cash them in at any point.
Over the last two years, some of the biggest stock brokerage firms, mutual funds and life insurance companies have begun promoting simple deferral packages tailored to small businesses. Merrill Lynch, which sells its plans through its stockbrokers, said the demand had been so great that it had not had to advertise. Among small companies, "there's been an explosion," said David A. Kossak, a financial planner in Tulsa who helped the Grays create the plan for their restaurant.
Still, other financial experts question whether the deferral plans make sense at many small companies, where the life insurance premiums can eat up a lot of cash. Ollies Restaurant is paying a total of $1,000 a month in premiums on policies for the Grays, and the money is invested in mutual funds. But Mr. Gray seems satisfied. "So far, it's worked like a dream," he said.
 
Putting Aside $936 Million While Making Coke Thrive
To investors, Roberto C. Goizueta, the chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company, is a hero. A thousand dollars invested in the company when Mr. Goizueta took over, with dividends reinvested, is now worth $52,000.
Mr. Goizueta, born in Cuba and educated at Yale, is also a hero to other chief executives. That's not only because he streamlined the soft-drink giant to sharply increase sales, profits and its stock price, but also because he exemplifies how it is possible to be paid exceptionally well for producing exceptional results. Since 1979, when he first appeared in the company's proxy statements, Mr. Goizueta's compensation -- salary, bonuses and grants of stock -- has totaled more than $1 billion, a remarkable figure even by today's stratospheric standards of executive pay. And that's without counting stock options.
What is also remarkable is how little Mr. Goizueta has paid in taxes on that compensation. Only about 5 percent has gone for Federal income and payroll taxes. By contrast, a typical middle-class family with two children and a $50,000 income paid 17 percent of its income in such taxes, according to the Tax Foundation, a private research group.
How did Mr. Goizueta do it? After all, his pay package, while unusually large, is similar to many of the sophisticated executive-compensation plans popular today.
Most Americans are paid a simple salary or wage, which is taxed immediately. Mr. Goizueta negotiated to take most of his pay in Coca-Cola stock, which carries significant tax advantages.
The company has given Mr. Goizueta 11.2 million shares on the condition that he not sell them -- or borrow against them -- before he retires. If he quits, he forfeits the shares, although the board has the power to lift that restriction.
These restrictions do not affect Mr. Goizueta's power to vote these shares or to collect the dividends, which are taxable; last year the dividends totaled more than $4.9 million. (He also owns another 4.5 million shares outright, the company says.)
So long as the restrictions remain, Mr. Goizueta does not face taxes on the shares, worth $559 million at Friday's closing price of $49.75 per share.
On the first 5.2 million shares he received, Mr. Goizueta arranged for Coke to pay him enough to cover the Federal and state taxes he will owe on those shares when the restrictions lapse. At today's prices, this cash payment amounts to $116 million.
After paying taxes on that cash and the stock itself, Mr. Goizueta will be left with $208 million. Had he paid taxes on the stock when it was given to him, and then sold the stock when he retires, he would not have fared as well. After taxes, he would have been left with $190 million.
For a Coke shareholder, finding any mention of Mr. Goizueta's stock grants requires a careful reading of the company's proxy statement. In the 22-page statement Coca-Cola sent to its shareholders on March 6, 1992, for instance, the tables describing pay make no mention of them. The only indication is in a thick paragraph of legalistic text: "Mr. Goizueta received one million shares from the 1989 Restricted Stock Award Plan which does not provide for reimbursement from taxes."
Add six million additional restricted shares and two cash payments based on the price of Coke stock, and his tax-deferred fortune grows to $936 million.
And that's not even counting Mr. Goizueta's 401(k), two other deferral accounts and a pension worth $3 million a year.
The following reporters for The New York Times participated in the preparation of these articles: Steve Lohr, Peter Passell and Melody Peterson.

The amount of compensation on which taxes are deferred sometimes reaches seven figures. Most companies disclose nothing about such compensation. Here is a sampling of executives with significant salary and bonus deferrals that have been disclosed.
 
DOING THE MATH: MR. WELCH'S MILLION
John F. Welch Jr., chairman and chief executive of General Electric, illustrates how deferring pay helps savings accumulate much faster. Mr. Welch deferred $1 million of his salary during 1995; the company added a 3.5 percent matching contribution and promised him 14 percent interest on his account through 1999. The chart shows Mr. Welch's balance at the end of each year for the money he deferred, and what the balance would be had he taken the same $1 million as taxable pay in 1995 and invested the net amount after taxes at the same 14 percent interest rate, forgoing the tax deferral and the matching contribution.
 
JOHN L. CLENDENIN
BellSouth
Has close to $10 million in deferred-compensation account. Last year alone, the company credited him with interest on his balance at the market rate of about 8.6 percent, as well as $415,700 on top of that.
 
JOHN R. STAFFORD
American Home Products
Required by company to defer the portion of his $1.185 million salary that was above $1 million and thus not tax deductible. Also deferred not just half of his $1.185 million bonus, as required by the company, but the rest as well.
 
ALEX TROTMAN
Ford Motor
Required by company to defer $5.4 million of 1994-95 bonuses of $9 million. Value of payout will depend on price of Ford's stock when he retires.
 
MICHAEL H. JORDAN
Westinghouse Electric
Deferred $1.8 million in bonuses in 1994-95 that earns interest at a rate equal to the 10-year U.S. Treasury note rate. But if the same amount invested in Westinghouse common shares produces a higher return, he can convert the investment to that stock. (pg. 36)
 
"ONE MAN'S FORTUNE: ROBERTO C. GOIZUETA"
 Just how handsomely the Coca-Cola Company has paid its chairman is very hard to discern from the company's published reports, and it would certainly be impossible from his tax returns.
 That is because, as generous as his taxable salary and bonuses have been over the years, they pale beside his tax-deferred equity compensation: grants of restricted shares, stock-like "performance units" and "incentive units" that have appreciated hugely since Mr. Goizueta was awarded them. Plus, the company will reimburse Mr. Goizueta for the taxes he will eventually owe on some of the grants, increasing their value to him by nearly half again.
 (On top of all this, Mr. Goizeuta has been given thousands of stock options over the years. He has made $54.5 million since 1979 redeeming some of them; at the end of 1995 he held others now worth $66.7 million before taxes.)

"DEFERRED COMPENSATION: I.B.M. AS A CASE STUDY"
I.B.M.'s deferred compensation plans are typical of those at the largest companies. Executives and managers may delay paying taxes on pay, bonuses and stock awards far beyond the $9,500 a year that ordinary workers may now save through the company 401(k) plan. Many companies camouflage details of deferred-compensation arrangements in their public documents, and decline to provide more data. I.B.M.'s disclosures are clearer and more detailed than most. (Source: Company reports)(pg. 37)
 
"WHO DEFERS: EVERYBODY'S DOING IT"
No longer are just a chosen few capitalizing on deferred compensation. Businesses large and small are setting up their own deferral plans, sometimes just for the owners and sometimes for top employees. Nonprofit organizations are also signing up. (pg. 37)

HEADLINE: Housing Crisis Imperils Quality of Life for All;
Not Criminal Behavior

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I would like to express my appreciation for your Oct. 9 front-page article on the young immigrant family from Mexico. As an attorney representing Mexican immigrants, I have been greatly disappointed by the lack of understanding as to why undocumented Mexican immigrants come to the United States. For many, it is as if immigrants are seeking a life of crime because they enter the country illegally. 
 Your article is a reminder that this is a choice driven by the desire to improve one's economic circumstances, made with great sacrifice and often resulting in isolation from one's family, culture and basic support system. It is not criminal behavior.
 
LINDA FRIEDMAN RAMIREZ
Portland, Ore., Oct. 10, 1996

HEADLINE: Housing Crisis Imperils Quality of Life for All;
What Is the Real Crisis?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was struck by how much your "Housing's Hidden Crisis" series (Oct. 6-11) was not about housing. In fact, the last article noted that New York City's housing crunch was unique among older American cities because of the "unusual burden of an increasing population, due largely to immigration." 
 The many anecdotes reported to describe housing conditions, as often as not, featured illegal immigrants. Their housing was almost incidental to their stories of lives on the economic and legal fringe. Notably, much of the "housing" itself was on the legal fringe -- illegal rooming houses, illegal conversions of single-family homes, illegal uses of apartment building basements and alleyways.
Paradoxically, if the people profiled could afford decent housing, they would still be stuck. Legitimate property owners wouldn't rent to them. How could you check credit histories for people with no bank accounts, Social Security numbers or, in some cases, even a believable record of their names?
"Housing's Hidden Crisis" is actually about what some call the underclass. It is about the underground economy (and jobs in the aboveground economy), and it is about legal status in American society. Looking at housing solutions is putting the cart before the horse.
 
RUBIN PIKUS
Forest Hills, Queens, Oct. 11, 1996
 
The writer is a property manager.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 42; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1387 words

HEADLINE: THE RACE FOR CONGRESS: New Jersey's 12th District;
Two Relative Unknowns Try to Make a Name

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: SOUTH BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 9

 BODY:
These are strange days in central New Jersey, where sightings of political giants, movie stars and anyone else who might stir up interest in the 12th District Congressional race are suddenly common.
Former Vice President Dan Quayle surfaced at a deli here the other day, showering praise on the Republican candidate, Mike Pappas. The Democrat, David M. Del Vecchio, is expecting visits from William Baldwin, the actor, and Jim Brady, the former press secretary to President Ronald Reagan, who was shot in the 1981 assassination attempt and now champions gun control. 
 The candidates -- who are fighting for the seat that Representative Richard A. Zimmer, a Republican from Delaware Township, gave up to run for the United States Senate -- are hardly prominent figures on the state's political scene. And the district, smack in the middle of New Jersey and suburban to the core, almost always votes Republican. So why all the fuss?
Democratic Party officials are drooling over the 12th District seat because for the first time in years, they believe the opponent is vulnerable. A victory in the 12th, which is one of New Jersey's largest and wealthiest districts, would help balance the state's Congressional delegation, which now has eight Republicans and five Democrats. The reason the Democrats have any cause for hope is that Mr. Pappas, a Somerset County freeholder, is a conservative Republican in what has long been a moderate Republican district.
And the Democrats take every opportunity to tell voters something else about Mr. Pappas: that he is adamantly opposed to abortion.
"The bottom line is that if most voters know something about both candidates on Election Day, I think Del Vecchio wins," said B. Thomas Byrne Jr., chairman of the Democratic State Committee. "He is more in line with the district's values."
The Republicans say they will have no problem holding onto Mr. Zimmer's seat. Mr. Pappas has played down the abortion issue, choosing to focus on fiscal reform. He has promised to fight tax increases and says he wants to shift responsibility from the Federal Government to states and towns.
"Fiscal matters are what the people of this district care about most," said Paul Pisano, a spokesman for Mr. Pappas's campaign. "That's what unites Republicans, and that's what Mike has focused on since the day he announced."
But both candidates have a major hurdle to overcome: they are not well known outside their home counties, but are running in a district that stretches from the Delaware River to the Jersey Shore, including all of Hunterdon County and parts of Somerset, Mercer, Middlesex and Monmouth counties.
Because the district covers so much ground, advertising is especially difficult. To reach every voter, the candidates would need to advertise in both the New York City and Philadelphia television markets, something neither can afford. So both are focusing on radio spots, mailings and as many campaign appearances as they can squeeze in.
Before this year, Mr. Del Vecchio, 39, was virtually unknown outside Hunterdon County, where he has been the Mayor of Lambertville since 1991. He was an aide to former Gov. Jim Florio, and he is on leave from a job in the State Treasury. Mr. Pappas, 35, a partner in a family-run insurance business, has held public offices since 1982. He became the Mayor of Franklin, Somerset County, at 22, and he has spent 12 years as a county freeholder.
A poll commissioned by the Del Vecchio campaign put the candidates in a dead heat as of late September, but found that nearly half the voters were still undecided. A poll conducted for the Pappas campaign in late August gave the Republican a 12-percentage-point lead. No independent polling has been done in the district.
Democrats like to point out that although the district is considered a Republican bedrock, the majority of its 342,485 registered voters are independents. Although George Bush was the favorite here in the 1992 Presidential election, President Clinton trailed by only 3 percentage points. And this year, Mr. Clinton is leading in local polls.
Several dozen interviews with residents of the 12th District in the last week suggested that the low profile of both candidates is indeed their biggest obstacle. When asked their opinions of Mr. Del Vecchio and Mr. Pappas, many said they knew nothing about the race. Others said the Senate race between Mr. Zimmer and his Democratic opponent, Representative Robert G. Torricelli of Englewood, has overshadowed the Congressional campaigns so much that they did not even know who the candidates were.
"Zimmer and Torricelli are outdoing them, there's no question," said Don Stancavish, who owns a variety store called the One Stop Shoppe in Flemington, Hunterdon County. "Those guys are going nuts, and as far as I'm concerned, they're stealing the spotlight."
Down the road in Branchburg, Somerset County, Gale Voigt stood behind the counter in the Bagel smith, a sandwich shop she has owned for 10 years, and said she did not plan to vote. She knew that Mr. Del Vecchio was the Mayor of Lambertville, but beyond that, she said, she had not followed the race.
"I wouldn't vote for Zimmer, either," said Mrs. Voigt, who is trying to sell her shop and move out of state. "As a small-business person, not one of our Congressmen over the last 10 years has helped me at all."
Mrs. Voigt, who said that taxes and government regulations were forcing her out of business, was pleased to learn that Mr. Pappas wants to reduce the size of government. But when she heard the candidate was against abortion, she winced. "That would be a minus point for me," she said.
Such words are music to the ears of Mr. Del Vecchio, who takes every chance he can get to showcase Mr. Pappas's views on abortion and gun control. (Mr. Pappas has said he would support a repeal of the Federal ban on assault weapons.) During a debate in Flemington last Tuesday, Mr. Del Vecchio brought up abortion several times, even though no question addressed the issue.
"It's important for people to know that I am the mainstream candidate and he is the extreme candidate," Mr. Del Vecchio said later.
But Mr. Pappas has said repeatedly that he is not a "single-issue candidate." Although he remains firmly opposed to abortion, he said, his main goal is to shape up the economy.
"The central issues I have worked on in the three years I've spent preparing for this campaign are economic," he said in an interview. "My opponent has spoken about these things peripherally, but he has made some of the more hot-button social issues some of the first things out of his mouth."
Mr. Pappas has often pointed out that Mr. Del Vecchio used to work for Governor Florio, who fell out of favor when he raised taxes by $2.8 billion. But Mr. Del Vecchio says that taxes in Lambertville have dropped since he was elected Mayor, and that he would work to cut Federal taxes without touching the budgets for Medicare, education and the environment. He wants to cut the capital gains tax, and he supports the death penalty.
"The old labels don't mean anything anymore," Mr. Del Vecchio said in an interview. "The Republicans can't stereotype us into a little box anymore."
Still, Mr. Del Vecchio's centrist approach might lose him some traditional Democratic support. Gertrude Dubrovsky of Princeton said she would not vote for Mr. Pappas because of his support for abortion rights. But she said she would not vote for Mr. Del Vecchio, either, because he was not liberal enough.
"Del Vecchio is not enough of an old-style Democrat for me," Mrs. Dubrovsky said. "We've got to stop this drifting of Democratic candidates toward the right."
Others say that Mr. Del Vecchio's brand of conservatism is not enough for them. Norma Bee of Jamesburg, Middlesex County, said she would support Mr. Pappas even though she favored abortion rights.
"The abortion thing does bother me," Mrs. Bee said, adding that she might write to Mr. Pappas to express her concern. "But I like his aura and I like his ideas about taxes and government. I'm hoping it will turn out to be a non-issue."
 A picture caption with the article misidentified a school visited by the Democratic candidate, David M. Del Vecchio. It is the Desmares Elementary School, not the Desmares Elli School.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 14, 1996, Monday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the congressional race in New Jersey's 12th District misstated a voter's reason for opposing the Republican candidate, Mike Pappas. The voter, Gertrude Dubrovsky, said she would not vote for Mr. Pappas because he opposes abortion (as the article stated elsewhere), not because he supports abortion rights.

HEADLINE: Growing Red Tide Imperils Shellfishing Along Texas Gulf Coast

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEADRIFT, Tex., Oct. 11

 BODY:
An outbreak of red tide that has already killed more than 1.5 million fish and that scientists thought was dissipating last week, is instead expanding and threatening the fishing and tourism industries along two-thirds of the Texas Gulf Coast.
In disclosing the red-tide expansion this week, state health officials extended a harvesting ban on shellfish to include all bays from Galveston Island south to the Mexican border at Brownsville, which covers nearly 300 miles of coast. 
 State health officials predicted that the oyster season, scheduled to open Nov. 1, would also be canceled, though no announcement of that has been made. For dozens of tiny fishing communities along the Texas coast like Seadrift, a village of about 200 homes and house trailers nestled around ramshackle fishing docks, the events could be devastating.
"This may be the one that finally just runs us right out of the business," said Jerry Amason, 60, a weathered fisherman who has plucked an uncertain living from the nearby oyster beds of San Antonio Bay for more 30 years. "If it's not floods, it's hurricanes. If it's not droughts, it's oil spills. If it's not oil spills, it's the damned red tide."
Red tides result from a growth spurt, or bloom, of single-cell algae that add a reddish tint to seawater and bear a neurotoxin that paralyzes a fish's ability to breathe. Oysters and other filter-feeding mollusks collect the toxins in concentrations that can be harmful to humans, state officials said, and that was why the ban on shellfish was imposed. There is no ban yet on shrimp or fin fish, state officials said.
Red tides, described as "wildly unpredictable" events by research scientists, usually last from 1 to 18 months. A red tide along this coast in 1986 continued for 4 months and killed an estimated 22 million fish.
"Water and temperature conditions are nearly ideal," Dr. Dean Stockwell, a marine biologist at the University of Texas Marine Science Institute in Port Aransas, said of the current bloom. "There are plenty of nutrients in the water, and it has everything it needs now to grow. I would say this particular red tide is probably going to be with us for a while."
Thus far, the coastal ecological systems most affected by the red tide include the large bays of Corpus Christi, Aransas, Nueces, San Antonio and Matagorda and the smaller bays of Hynes and Espiritu Santo. But signs of the red tide were reported in nearly every estuarial system from Galveston south to the Rio Grande.
On Wednesday, large numbers of dead fish could be seen floating in the Port Aransas Ship Channel. Earlier in the week, researchers counted 12,000 dead bull redfish, a highly prized game fish, on the gulf beaches of Matagorda Island.
"We're getting dozens of calls daily from tourists or sports fishermen reporting or inquiring about red tide-related events," said Dave Busan, director of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department's spills and kills division. "Fishermen have reported fish swimming crazily, sidewise or upside down, and a lot of bait fish dying at the surface."
Airborne particles of the tide can cause eye irritation or difficulty in breathing for people with respiratory problems, Mr. Busan said. He said his office had received complaints of such symptoms from tourists on gulf beaches at Port Isabel, on the southern end of Padre Island.
In 1994, more than 4.4 million pounds of oysters were harvested from Texas waters, according to the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department's coastal fisheries division, with a total economic impact on the state of almost $24 million.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 17, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about an outbreak of red tide in Texas referred imprecisely to the extent of the shellfish harvesting ban imposed by the state. It extends from Galveston Island south to the Mexican border at Brownsville, but it does not include the Galveston Bay ecosystem.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
In a Debate, It's Themes, Not Facts

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TO the untrained ear, the debate last Sunday night between President Clinton and Bob Dole and the one Wednesday night between Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp must have sounded like people reciting gibberish.
What they kept saying was so clearly repeated by rote (10 1/2 million new jobs, risky $500 billion tax cut scheme, cut taxes 15 percent across the board, balance the budget, Family and Medical Leave Act) that it was difficult to sort out their actual intentions. 
 But the fact is, if you disregard all the memorized statistics and carefully rehearsed one-liners, you can get a sense of the differences between the candidates and the parties. This much seems clear:
If they get elected, Bob Dole and Jack Kemp can be expected to do their damndest to get Government out of people's hair. "We're going to give them a tax cut," Mr. Dole said, "so they can spend more time with their children, maybe even take a vacation. That's what America's all about." Bill Clinton and Al Gore, if elected, would stress the ways the Government can improve people's lives. "How can we help people," Mr. Clinton said, "to get their retirements when they work for small businesses, to be able to afford health insurance, to be able to educate their children? That's what I focus on."
Of course, Mr. Dole might not be able to pull off his plan to cut taxes and balance the budget. To do so, he would have to accomplish a seemingly impossible task: reducing the Government's nonmilitary operating costs, which include everything from the F.B.I. to hurricane tracking to air traffic control, by about one-third.
And as a lame-duck President, Bill Clinton might not stick to the peanuts he tossed out in the debate, like giving parents time off without pay to attend school functions, and instead push big new social programs.
But Mr. Gore's litany of "protecting Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment," and Mr. Kemp's mantra of "lower tax rates across the board on working and saving and investing" draw as good a distinction as this campaign has provided about where the two camps differ and where the debate may resume in four years. For all the candidates' efforts to cast themselves in the center of the American ideological orbit, they represent the essential views that have dominated their parties for most of the century. Like every Democratic President since Woodrow Wilson, Mr. Clinton favors an activist Government. Like every Republican since William Howard Taft, Mr. Dole wants to rein the Government in.
That having been said, it is impossible to watch the debates -- including, undoubtedly, the final face-off this Wednesday -- without trying to figure out who has got the facts straight.
Consider, for example, the Democrats' claim that Republicans would ruthlessly cut spending for Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled. And then consider the Republicans' rebuttal that their plan would actually increase spending on Medicare, merely slowing its rate of growth slightly, while Democrats would allow the program to go broke.
Somebody must be stretching the truth, right? Wrong. The truth about Medicare, and much else in the debates, is more subjective than straightforward.
Here are the facts about Medicare: In the fiscal year that ended last month, the Government spent $195 billion on the program. The cost has been rising by about 10 percent a year, much faster than private health-care costs. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that if the program is not changed, it will cost $329 billion in 2002, the year when President Clinton and Mr. Dole have promised to have a balanced budget. Put another way, the amount the Government spends per beneficiary would rise to about $8,400 in 2002 from $4,800 now.
Moreover, Government actuaries reported last summer that the trust fund that covers hospital costs under Medicare would run out of money by 2001.
The Republican plan is to hold down spending so that in 2002, the cost will be $244 billion and the cost per beneficiary $6,700. That would stave off bankruptcy, the actuaries figure, until 2007. Republicans say that taking spending from $195 billion to $244 billion is an increase.
Democrats respond that if, as the budget office calculates, it would cost an average of $8,400 to give retirees the medical services they receive now and if Republicans lower that to $6,700, the result is a cut.

 
 
Different Dollars
 The Democrats draw this analogy: In 1987, before the end of the cold war, the military budget was $282 billion. It was the same in 1994. But no one would say the military budget wasn't cut. With inflation, the same money bought less in 1994. The number of troops, for instance, declined to 1.6 billion from 2.2 million, and the number of Navy fighting ships fell to 387 from 568.
In the same vein, a case can be made for both the Republican contention that the Clinton tax increase in 1993 was the biggest in history and the counter by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore that the Democratic budget actually cut taxes for 15 million working families.
The Clinton legislation in 1993 raised taxes by $241 billion over five years. In 1982, a bill sponsored by Mr. Dole and signed by President Ronald Reagan raised taxes by $215 billion. But in 1993 dollars, the 1982 tax increase was worth $286 billion.
So in actual dollars, the 1993 measure was the largest tax increase in American history. But adjusted for inflation, it was smaller than the one in 1982.
The 15 million families who in the Clinton-Gore version got a tax cut were those who benefited from a 1993 increase in the earned-income tax credit. This is a program that reduces the taxes of low-income workers and gives cash payments to those who earn too little to take advantage of a tax reductions. Republicans consider this a welfare subsidy, not a tax break.
In the final analysis, establishing the truth in these debates is a futile exercise. It is too much like proving a religious doctrine. The best bet is to ignore the precise charges and countercharges and look for the themes.
 Under the budget approved by the Republican Congress in 1995 and vetoed by President Clinton, the Government would have spent $289 billion in 2002, or $7,118 per beneficiary.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 20, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the Presidential debates used outdated figures data for Medicare. The most current estimates based on figures provided by the Congressional Budget Office follow:
In the 1996 fiscal year, the Government spent $195 billion on Medicare, an average of $5,200 for each beneficiary. With no changes in the law, the Government will spend $328.5 billion in 2002, or $8,091 per beneficiary.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Renovations;
When It Isn't Time to Build, It's Time to Upgrade

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE oddly truncated building between Madison and Park Avenues and 24th and 25th Street has been given a $300 million new lease on life. The Depression-era building, which was never built to its full planned height because of the economic slump of the time, has been stripped down to the frame and exterior walls and rebuilt with upgraded elevators, electrical and mechanical systems and a cleaned limestone facade.
The building, which is owned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and will soon be the home of the investment firm CS First Boston, is the largest renovation project in the city but by no means the only one. 
 Although the city's market for office space has improved since the dog days of the early 1990's, rental rates have not increased enough to justify new construction. Instead, many buildings are changing hands, with new owners investing in them to attract tenants from less-favored structures. "Renovations are a precursor to new construction," said Michael T. Cohen, president of the Williams Real Estate Company. "You can't build for rentals of less than $55 a square foot and we are not there yet. But you can renovate and get $45 a foot in the right locations."
A good example, he said, is 245 Park Avenue, the east-side blockfront between 46th and 47th Streets, where the lobby recently received a $10 million upgrade. "That is a top-of-the-market property in one of the best locations in the city," Mr. Cohen said. "People are willing now to take the risk of putting capital into properties because they are confident of getting a return on the investment."
There is some question about whether cosmetic improvements like a new lobby or renovated elevator cabs will be more attractive to prospective tenants than behind-the-scenes improvements like updated electrical and communications services.
Some say both have to be considered. "Old buildings have to compete with new ones, so you have to think about esthetics and infrastructure, depending on who your tenants are," said Joseph A. Costabile, who is a property management specialist with Cushman & Wakefield.
"You need extra cooling to take care of all the machines that are used in offices today and you need more electrical power," he said. "We used to put in four or five watts per square foot, but now it is a minimum of six watts a foot and if you are doing a trading floor, it is 12 watts a foot."
When the company renovated 100 Wall Street for clients in the financial industry, it added a generator and a fuel tank to provide emergency power in case of a blackout. "The people in the financial business do not want to go down," Mr. Costabile said. "This way we can provide at least minimum ventilation, lighting and elevator service."
BUILDING managers also know that they need to meet building codes regarding fire safety and access for people with handicaps. "To meet the fire safety code," Mr. Costabile said, "you have to be able to communicate using voice and code and to meet the Americans with Disabilities Act, you generally have to modify the toilet areas for handicapped access."
Some renovations can lead to cost savings. One leading candidate is cooling. Many older buildings have cooling systems with only two switch settings: on and off. That was fine when almost everybody worked from 9 to 5.
But now work days have lengthened and more companies operate around the clock, so the system cannot simply be turned off in the evening. But keeping a whole building system operating for just a few floors that need the service increases operating costs.
"You have a spectrum of alternatives you have to analyze," said Mitchell Rudin, an executive managing director at the Edward S. Gordon Company. "You have to decide what is needed to maintain a building's competitive position. One possibility is to convert constant-volume air-conditioning to variable-flow to achieve some economies."
Robert S. Shapiro, executive managing director of Grubb & Ellis, New York, said: "People are paying more attention to making it possible for their tenants to work more effectively, not like in the 1980's when everybody was focusing on gold door handles and elaborate moldings. If one building has a dual communications system and another does not, as a broker I would be foolish not to point that out to my clients."
Renovation has apparently become more popular as the real estate market has improved, but for some the test is a willingness to invest in properties when times are bad. "You differentiate yourself in the bad times by continuing to invest," said Anthony Malkin, the president of W&M Properties, which is completing a five-year, $67 million renovation of the Empire State Building.
"By continuing your programs while things are bad, you let the brokers and tenants know that you are there for the long term." Mr. Malkin said. "You make money in real estate after you have survived your first down cycle."
Many buildings need improvement simply because of their age; nearly 70 percent of office buildings in Midtown Manhattan were built before 1969, according to a report by LaSalle Partners. And some owners were unable or unwilling to invest while rental rates were falling and vacancy rates rising.
"A lot of property went back to institutions," Mr. Rudin said. In many cases their approach was to drive down operating costs of a building, lease as much space as possible and offer it for sale, without doing much else, he said.
But new owners have an incentive and a market opportunity to improve properties that have not seen much in the way of investment capital for years. "A lot of buildings are changing hands and new owners are coming in with a strategy of driving them from B status to A-minus or A," Mr. Rudin said. Although the figures vary from location to location and building to building, A space usually commands higher rentals than B space, Mr. Rudin said.
A good example is 540 Madison Avenue at 55th Street, which, he said, has "languished" on the market despite a good location, layout and views. "With the right program, that building could be an A+," he said. Mr. Rudin, whose company is the leasing agent for the building, said the Macklowe Organization, which recently purchased the property, has plans for a major renovation.
Mr. Shapiro said that in the Grand Central area -- from 32d Street to 50th Street and from the Avenue of the Americas to the East River -- some 730,000 square feet of office space was absorbed from the market so far this year, while there was 40,000 square feet more of "B" space on the market than there was in January.
"The 'A' space took it all," he said. "The message is simple: if you do not upgrade, you are going out of business."
RENOVATION may be as much needed as a defensive strategy for holding on to existing tenants as an offensive one to attract new ones, said James E. Meiskin, president of Plymouth Partners, a brokerage firm. "There has been a flight to quality over the past five years," he said. "So building owners who do not spend the capital to remodel risk losing their tenant base."
He said there had been a steady flow of tenants from "B" buildings to "A" properties and that there was no indication the trend was about to change. Besides, with only one building under construction -- the Durst project in Times Square -- renovation is the only game in town.
"The reason we are seeing renovation, is that it makes sense," Mr. Meiskin said. "There is so little new product on the market."
He said rents had only inched up recently, but that concession packages were shrinking and that significant rises might come soon, particularly in the best buildings. "It is becoming an owner's market," he said. Landlords willing to spend $70 a square foot to adapt space for tenants a few years ago, are down to the $25-a-foot-range now, he said.
Not every building is a candidate for high technology or eye-grabbing renovation. Some buildings are filled with small tenants who value a reasonable rent more than a marble-splashed lobby or fiber-optic communications.
"If a building has a niche on the low end of the rent scale, and is filled with small service tenants," then it probably does not justify much in the way of renovation, Mr. Rudin said.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 27, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 13 about upgrading office buildings misidentified the organization responsible for renovating the Empire State Building. It is the Empire State Building Corporation, not W&M Properties.
