HEADLINE: Running Against Hillary

BYLINE: By Elisabeth Bumiller; Elisabeth Bumiller is a reporter for the Metro section of The New York Times.

 BODY:
"ELIZABETH DOLE SALUTES WORKING WOMEN," SAYS THE BANNER AT an insufferably humid picnic in Bowling Green, Ky., where the star attraction, in a long-sleeved silk blouse buttoned high up her neck, is massaging the crowd. "You know something?" Mrs. Dole says, seemingly delighted, drawing out the vowels in her creamy North Carolina drawl. "I'm just so glad to be in Kentucky, where I don't need an interpreter!" It's a line she uses all over the South, and as usual it gets a big, friendly laugh.
"Bob Dole's vision speaks directly to what women in this country want," she begins, her wireless mike clipped to her blouse. She has come out from behind the podium and, as she did at the Republican convention, is beginning to stroll toward the crowd. She is excellent theater, speaking without notes, and the 500 people, mostly women, seem riveted to their blankets and lawn chairs. 
 At 60, Elizabeth Dole is still a beautiful woman, thinner than she was a decade ago, with smooth skin flushed prettily in the heat. Up close you can see she has freckles. She is wearing stockings and three-inch pumps with her slim, confining black skirt, as if a Washington career woman air-dropped into the land of baseball caps and beer T-shirts should be impervious to the climate.
She tells the crowd that her husband is surrounded by women "whose careers he has boosted" and that as Senate majority leader he had female staff members who handled "health care, environmental issues, foreign policy and taxes." Her tone is comfortable and sunny. "I think that's a pretty good record, don't you?"
This is the campaign of Bob Dole's other running mate. She is, of course, his popular wife -- feminist in hiding, two-time Cabinet member, former White House official, president of the American Red Cross, the take-charge Southern blossom who had the network anchors in awe after her dazzling if saccharine Oprah-style "Why I love Bob" speech at the Republican convention. While Hillary Clinton campaigns gingerly as the committed mother and wife, Elizabeth Dole has become a partisan star of her own wholly separate campaign -- her husband's biggest asset in America's medium-size television markets. Since the convention, when the strapped Dole finally got $62 million in Federal matching funds, his wife has acquired her own staff of 30, a travel budget of $1.5 million and a leased 14-seat Challenger 600 jet.
"This is the first full-time on-the-road operation for a First Lady candidate," says Bob Davis, Mrs. Dole's senior adviser, and he's probably right. Even Mrs. Clinton was on the road only three or four days a week in 1992, and did not travel full time until the final month of the campaign. She did not have her own 12-person advance team to set up events, as Mrs. Dole does, and aides say she rarely answered questions on foreign policy, as Mrs. Dole has on Iraq.
For three days in September I squeezed onto Mrs. Dole's plane, assigned to a seat near a perfectionist known for her lovely old world manners and her rock-candy-hard armor. To a large extent I observed that persona: a copious underliner of briefing books, a scrupulously prepared speech giver, an immaculate executive with a shoe-coordinated, ladylike handbag in public and a masculine, no-nonsense attache case that she takes out in private.
But I also saw glimpses of a sense of humor underneath the bright Republican power suits. One day on the plane, when everyone thought Mrs. Dole had dozed off for a nap, Bob Davis began holding forth about the differences in the landing style of the Delta shuttle and Mrs. Dole's much-spiffier jet. Suddenly, Mrs. Dole opened her eyes across the aisle and said, slyly, "Did you ask Bob when he flew his last flight?" Davis, a corporate lawyer, squirmed as his boss moved in. "Very authoritative," Elizabeth Dole said with a wicked smile. "Very macho."
Not once on the plane did I hear the name Hillary Clinton. But then I didn't have to. Elizabeth Dole will never say so outright, but she is running this fall against the First Lady, presenting herself as the spouse with the 30-year Washington career, a woman who will be too busy at her own office to meddle in the West Wing. At each stop, Mrs. Dole pointedly tells her audience that she will be the first First Lady to work outside the White House, and that she will return to her job at the Red Cross -- managing a $1.8 billion annual budget and 32,000 employees -- whether or not her husband wins in November. In interviews she is even more to the point. "I wouldn't have taken on one-seventh of the gross domestic product," she says, referring to Mrs. Clinton's failed effort to overhaul the nation's health-care system. "You're not elected, you're not confirmed by the Senate and you've got one of the most volatile, high-visibility issues."
Oddly, the wife who was supposed to help bring a new look to a moribund campaign, and to attract female voters, is rarely in the national press, although she did ride a motorcycle with Jay Leno on the "Tonight" show last month. This is partly because there is little room for reporters on her plane, but also because her husband's advisers are running a traditional campaign, in which Elizabeth Dole, as the chief "surrogate," is used everywhere he is not, especially in the smaller markets. Dole's advisers also seem wary of using her so aggressively as to prompt comparisons to Mrs. Clinton. Above all, they believe she should not overshadow the candidate. "We have never had her out breaking new ground on policy," says Scott Reed, Dole's campaign manager. "She never would."
But Elizabeth Dole will still be remembered for redefining the role of the political spouse. "More elections are going to be partnerships in the future," says the G.O.P. pollster Frank Luntz, who does not work for Dole. Luntz credits Mrs. Dole's Republican convention walk-and-talk for swaying more undecided voters toward her husband than his own acceptance speech. Clinton aides assert that the biggest surge in opinion polls for Bob Dole occurred the night Mrs. Dole spoke, not the night the candidate did, a claim the Dole campaign dismisses as propaganda. But Mrs. Dole is better liked by voters than either her husband or his real running mate, Jack Kemp -- 39 percent rated her favorably in the latest New York Times-CBS News poll, compared with 29 percent for her husband and 33 percent for Kemp.
Admittedly, Mrs. Dole is not nearly as well known as either, and people have rarely voted for a Presidential candidate because of his wife: Barbara Bush had a 72 percent favorable rating just after her husband was defeated in 1992. But Elizabeth Dole may be different. "This is the first time a First Lady candidate actually has political appeal of her own," Luntz says. "She tells Bob Dole stories better than Bob Dole. She could actually encourage people to take a second, third or fourth look at him. And that's exactly what he needs right now."
In many ways, Elizabeth Dole represents both the last gasp of the traditional First Lady, the ultimate helpmate ratcheted up to running mate, and a bridge -- to use the campaign metaphor -- to a day when America will have a woman in the White House. "I really believe this country's ready for a woman President," Mrs. Dole says in her office at Dole headquarters in Washington. "It'll probably happen through a woman running for Vice President, rather than someone just jumping in and running for President. Although that could happen too. I think we'll see it fairly soon."
She is asked the question everywhere: Will she herself ever run? She adamantly says no, as etiquette now demands, but in the past has left the door open, saying as recently as January that "if, at some point," she had the option to run for public office, "I've always said it could be something that I would consider doing." There was speculation that Bush would make her his running mate in 1988, and there were jokes this year about a Dole-Dole campaign. "If I weren't the candidate, she might be on the ticket," her husband says, as he has said before.
One thing is certain: At least one Dole has a political future beyond the 1996 election, and at this point it may not necessarily be the candidate.
 ELIZABETH DOLE'S ASSIGNMENT IN THIS ELECTION IS TO get women to vote for her husband. He cannot possibly win without them, but swaying them is a gargantuan task. Elizabeth Dole has been aware of the gender gap since the early 1980's when she was a Reagan White House official, and knows better than most that the gap is now a chasm. The latest New York Times-CBS News poll shows that women prefer Clinton over Dole, 57 to 32 percent. Men prefer Clinton, too, but by a smaller margin, 44 to 42 percent.
Here in Kentucky, Mrs. Dole is working hard. "Sometimes I feel that we don't express as well as we should the values which really drive our policy decisions," she says, going into an explanation of why her husband's proposed tax cut is what these working women need. "One earner is just earning enough to pay the taxes that the Government requires. The other earner is earning the funds to keep the family going. That's not right." Mrs. Dole tells them her husband wants to cut "excessive Federal regulations" for women who own businesses -- "Women are employing more people than all of the Fortune 500 corporations put together, isn't that incredible?" She briefly deplores crime and increased drug use in America, then segues toward a finish. "I want to visit for a moment on the safety net as I conclude," she says. She offers a Republican version of last year's Medicare fight, attacks the White House for offering no alternative "except $22 million in ads designed to scare our senior citizens" and neglects to mention that her husband voted against Medicare in 1965.
She winds up with a drum roll: "Ladies and gentlemen, we need your help, we need your votes. . . . This is a defining moment in the history of this country. . . . You have a man of character who exemplifies the best in America."
Her reviews are excellent and consistent.
"Very classy lady," says Diana Duncan, 39, a hairdresser who calls Hillary Clinton "a little hard core."
"She's just more of a lady," says Bess Shanks, 76, a retiree who says Mrs. Clinton is "more of a false, put-on thing."
I hear much the same sentiment everywhere we go, even though Elizabeth Dole's stump speech -- she has several versions, all memorized, which she mixes and matches to suit the crowd -- is similar to the partisan, unladylike speech her husband makes. But something happens when attacks on the President are made with a girlish smile in a North Carolina lilt. Elizabeth Dole makes it all sound so, well, fun. At every stop she likes to take out a doll-size wooden rocking chair, the Clinton rocker, as she calls it. "It does not rock front to back," she says, grinning, holding the rocker in her hand. "It rocks left, right, left." And it does too. The crowd never fails to roar.
Two days later in Memphis, I ask Regina McKinney, a 38-year-old foster mother of two children and a registered independent, to compare Hillary Clinton and Elizabeth Dole. McKinney is watching Mrs. Dole tour St. Jude's Hospital, where McKinney works as an administrative assistant. She says that she is leaning toward voting for Dole and that Mrs. Dole "just seems more family-oriented to me." I point out that Mrs. Clinton is the one with the child, 16-year-old Chelsea, and that Mrs. Dole is childless. "I know," McKinney says. "But you don't have to have a child to be family-oriented. Where is Chelsea the rest of the year? She's with nannies. I just don't see Hillary Clinton in the kitchen, staying up until midnight making cupcakes for the P.T.A. even though you have to work."
How has this happened? Friends of the First Lady insist that she would have been strung up on the White House lawn if she had publicly finished her husband's sentences, as Mrs. Dole did in July on "Larry King Live." For one thing, Mrs. Dole avoids several crucial things that voters, especially conservatives, don't like about Hillary Clinton. She does not lecture people about higher responsibilities. She does not talk about government as a force for good. And if Elizabeth Dole is seen as artificial and programmed, she does not project the far more irritating quality -- sanctimony -- that Hillary Clinton's enemies ascribe to her. Then, too, Elizabeth Dole has been under far less scrutiny than Hillary Clinton. There have been questions raised about Mrs. Dole's investments, but no counterpart to Al D'Amato, New York's Republican Senator, to start up Congressional hearings.
"Somehow Elizabeth Dole is able to convey that more traditional role," says Jean Baker Miller, a psychiatrist who is an authority on sex roles and the director of education at the Stone Center at Wellesley College. "She's able to appear as if she's not rocking any boats."
Feminists argue that Mrs. Dole is in fact not rocking any boats at all and that this is the nature of her appeal. They say that in campaigning for a man who has a legislative legacy on guns, abortion and tobacco that is abhorrent to many women, she is supporting the male-dominated household and the comfortable status quo.
Mrs. Dole says she fully supports her husband's criticism of the Family and Medical Leave Act, popular among women, which was passed in 1993 to allow up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for the care of a baby or for a family medical emergency. "The problem is, it's a mandate, a one size fits all," Mrs. Dole tells me in her office. "It makes more sense to me to have the opportunity for employer and employees to determine what's in the best interest of that set of employees. It may be that they need health care, pensions, other things."
I realize I am now talking to a former Labor Secretary, not a political wife, who at this moment seems headed for a 15-minute overview of flex time and mandates. To interview Elizabeth Dole is to interrupt her (she has not spent three decades in the Washington bureaucracy for nothing), so I break in to ask if she thinks it was a good idea politically for her husband to attack the act.
Mrs. Dole is puzzled. "I don't know what speech it was," she says. "I'm going full steam. There's no way I'm going to know everything he's saying in every speech." Dole in fact unexpectedly complained about the act in a forum outside Pittsburgh on Sept. 7, astonishing and frustrating his aides and setting off some news ripples.
 "I think we're making too much of it, honestly," she says.
SEPT. 3, KNOXVILLE, TENN.: ELIZABETH DOLE'S PLANE IS FLYING smoothly over the Tennessee River, heading west in the pink-tinged sky toward Memphis. The cabin is cozy. Mrs. Dole gives up on her briefing book and picks up a newspaper, reading a front-page article about the Dole campaign's Labor Day kickoff in St. Louis the day before. (She was on the podium with her husband, but made no remarks. Afterward the Doles took off in opposite directions across America -- Mrs. Dole east to Kentucky, Dole west to Utah. This was Monday. They would see each other again on Sunday.)
"Would you like something to drink?" asks Jeff Ramsay, a 20-year-old Colgate University student -- mercilessly called "cabin boy" by the four Secret Service agents on board -- who is the steward and baggage handler for Mrs. Dole and her staff. The plane is a civilized corporate retreat: soft gray-leather seats, hand towels in the bathroom. Yesterday, Ramsay served boxed chicken-salad sandwiches, tomorrow he'll serve Memphis barbecue, and always first to Mrs. Dole. His initial day on the job he found himself listing toward her with an overflowing bowl of soup, terrified it would spill in her lap, and indeed the rest of the staff also seems intimidated by the boss. When a driver of the staff van gets separated from Mrs. Dole's six-car motorcade en route to her Memphis hotel, there is so much consternation among her aides about the slip-up that it's as if the President himself has got lost. Mary Ellen Tomlin, Mrs. Dole's traveling budget director, who writes checks for the lighting, sound and balloons at each event, cheerfully tells me that Elizabeth Dole is a very important woman and that things need to be done right.
Staff members have a group dinner with their boss about once a week, but most nights Mrs. Dole exercises on a treadmill in her hotel, orders in alone and talks to Bob -- if they can find each other. "Last week we had trouble," Dole says, talking in Washington. He says they compare notes: " 'Did you have good crowds? Were they enthusiastic? What are people saying?' You know, this sort of general stuff." They also communicate by fax. In Memphis, after Mrs. Dole answers questions from local reporters about Saddam Hussein (her husband, she says, "wants to free those Kurds who are prisoners now"), I ask if she has spoken to her husband about Iraq. "We haven't had time to have a real conversation on that," she says simply. "So I'm just going off his press release."
She seems sequestered in her separate world, cut off from the daily political crises of the Dole campaign. Flying into Florida, I was struck that she couldn't remember who carried the state in 1992, Clinton or Bush. (Bush. This year, Dole could be the first Republican to lose the state since Jimmy Carter beat Gerald Ford in 1976.) "Dole would have known it county by county," says one of her husband's former advisers, and when I catch up with the candidate one recent Sunday in Washington, he does.
"I think Clinton would probably win Dade County," he says, talking about 1992. "But what happened, I think Broward County was where the problem was." It is a gorgeous September Sunday, and the Doles are in Washington, Elizabeth Dole in meetings in her 10th-floor office at the campaign headquarters just behind Union Station, Bob Dole a few floors above her on the roof, where he is soaking up the afternoon sun in a lawn chair.
The point here is that while Dole is a political junkie -- "It's like knowing somebody's batting average," he says of the Florida statistics -- no one would ever confuse his wife with one. Dole's managers say Elizabeth Dole is her husband's closest adviser, but unlike Hillary Clinton, who operated as a political strategist for her husband in 1992, Elizabeth Dole's role in her husband's campaign is more of an enforcer, an editor and a coach. This is hardly to call her traditional. Senator John McCain, a Republican from Arizona and a close friend of the Doles, remembers watching Elizabeth Dole prepare her husband for the primary debate in South Carolina earlier this year. "She wasn't talking down to him, but it was very straightforward," he says. "She was saying: 'Bob, you've got to smile and relax. You don't want to fight back at these guys. You're above them.' It was very obvious she was giving advice as a political partner. It was not like a wife. It was like a peer discussion."
John Buckley, Dole's communications director, says that Mrs. Dole felt that the section on defense in her husband's acceptance speech was "too dense" and so made "minor editing changes." She also insisted that the campaign hire a speech coach for her husband this spring and made sure that Dole's anti-crime address in Colorado in May included language that treated crime as a women's issue. She is not in on the staff meetings, but Scott Reed, Dole's campaign manager, says he talks to her every few days.
Downstairs, I ask her what she has in common with Hillary Clinton. "Educational background," she says, and pauses. "That's about it." She laughs. "Philosophically we're like night and day. We really have different views on the issues. And she is a true liberal. And I'm a mainstream conservative."
In fact, they have far more in common than Elizabeth Dole likes to admit. Both were raised as Methodists in affluent families -- Elizabeth Dole as the daughter of a flower wholesaler in Salisbury, N.C. -- both are Ivy League lawyers, both made enormous professional compromises for their husbands' political ambitions, both have fought feminist battles. But it is Elizabeth Dole, born 11 years earlier, who has been at the frontier: Duke University's May Queen but also Leader of the Year for the men's and women's campuses. One of 24 women in a class of 550 at Harvard Law School, where on her first day in the fall of 1962 a male student told her: "Don't you realize that there are men who would give their right arm to be in this law school? Men who would use their legal education?"
Then it was on to three decades in Washington, from the White House Office of Consumer Affairs, to a spot on the Federal Trade Commission in 1973, through two Cabinet appointments and then to overseeing the Red Cross. (In 1981, at the age of 45, Mrs. Dole found a pastor, joined a prayer group and underwent what she calls a spiritual reawakening. "It was just a feeling that there's something missing here," she says, adding that it had nothing to do with not having children. Mrs. Dole now spends 30 minutes each day with the Bible or in prayer -- which she calls her devotional time -- and is a favorite of the religious conservatives who do not trust her husband but whom he needs to win the election.)
I ask Mrs. Dole if she had learned any lessons from watching Mrs. Clinton. There are none, apparently. "I don't think she set a precedent," she says. "I don't think each First Lady coming after her has to do what she has done. I wouldn't. Because I'll run the Red Cross." She dismisses critics who see a conflict of interest.
Not that she will spend all her time at the office. Elizabeth Dole tells her audiences that she will somehow find time to take on a traditional First Lady project: increasing charitable giving in America, an idea she says she has been thinking about for nearly a decade. "I was ready to do it full time before Bush asked me to go with the Cabinet as Secretary of Labor," she says. "I'd already met with a lot of people. It's a massive job, you've got to organize the humanitarian groups, but, being at Red Cross, that will not be so hard to do."
ELIZABETH DOLE HAS BEEN CAMPAIGNING FULL TIME FOR her husband for nearly a year now. I ask if she worries about what will happen if she goes back to work and has an unemployed husband at home. Bob Dole has said, after all, that if he loses he'll walk the dog.
"Oh, that's absolutely a joke," she says, as if it needs to be pointed out. "With that energy level, he'll be doing 10 different things." She adds that "also, it may mean a little more time to be together. We might be able to do a little bit of traveling -- that would be wonderful when it's not all oriented toward getting those trade agreements with China while he's doing his thing." She is referring to a joint trip they took to Beijing, she as Secretary of Transportation, he as Senator. "We had two staffs, the Senate staff and my transportation staff," she says. "And it was unbelievable that trip. Not much time for sightseeing or just enjoying a good meal somewhere."
If Bob Dole loses next month, it will be the third and last time that this 73-year-old man has run for President. But his wife is 60, and the question is now: Will this most disciplined and driven woman try to drive herself up to the ultimate prize? If Dole's campaign ends in repudiation, will she be willing to face a race of her own? In the past, Elizabeth Dole was approached to run for governor of North Carolina or a Senate seat. Either one could have positioned her for the Vice Presidency.
It is impossible at this point to know what she would stand for as a candidate on her own. Although Elizabeth Dole has served five Presidents, she has never held political office or sponsored legislation. Once a supporter of the Equal Rights Amendment, she angered feminists by promoting Ronald Reagan's alternatives when she worked in his White House. And yet as recently as 1984, Elizabeth Dole dropped by Ms. magazine to pay her respects, and startled the editors when she told them -- as they remember it -- that their publication had been an inspiration to her. Michael Pertschuk, former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, remembers Elizabeth Dole as "the most consistently liberal vote of all of the commissioners that I worked with."
When I ask Mrs. Dole about her personal views on abortion, she hastily replies, "I'm where he is -- I'm pro-life." I press for more. "I think on the specifics, you know, I'm going to let the candidate carry it," she says, then changes the subject. Here, as throughout the campaign, she has remained the dutiful and dependable surrogate, never staking out her own positions, always taking what her husband says and pitching it to her audiences.
Whatever she does want, Elizabeth Dole will surely have a line of Republican political consultants at her door when this election is over. And next time, they will tell her, she won't have to run against Hillary Clinton.

HEADLINE: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION

BYLINE: By ROBERT SKLAR 

 BODY:

THE UFA STORY
A History of Germany's Greatest Film Company, 1918-1945.
By Klaus Kreimeier.
Hill & Wang, $35.
UFA (for Universum-Film AG) was Europe's largest and most famous film company. Founded by the German military during World War I to make propaganda films, it triumphed artistically as a private company while struggling economically during the Weimar era, then fell under Nazi control after 1933. Its directors and stars offered the only serious challenge to Hollywood's world supremacy in the 1920's, while the visionary designs and subtle camerawork of its films surpassed anything American movies had to offer. From its enormous Berlin stages came such classics as "The Last Laugh" (1924), "Metropolis" (1926) and "The Blue Angel" (1930). Klaus Kreimeier's history of UFA is as much about German society and politics as it is about cinema. Serious but lively, and marked by vivid judgments, "The UFA Story" (smoothly translated from the German by Robert and Rita Kimber) challenges what Mr. Kreimeier, a German journalist, describes as a prevailing historical viewpoint that UFA was a reactionary, nationalistic, militaristic monopoly dedicated to manipulating public opinion. Among its film makers, he says, were artists who were sincerely trying to form a new culture of perception and who should not be blamed for the betrayal of their hopes and the Nazi liquidation of the company's past. Hollywood began raiding UFA's talent in the 1920's, when Ernst Lubitsch became the first key figure to depart. After the Nazis seized power, the exodus became a rescue mission. Billy Wilder and Fritz Lang are but two names from among scores of film artists who fled Germany and brought their talents to American movies. UFA's legacy appears in retrospect at least as meaningful to the United States as to Germany. It's hard to imagine the shape of American cinema without the contribution of UFA's exiles. Robert Sklar

HEADLINE: The Saints of Servitude

BYLINE: By Patricia Williams; Patricia Williams is a professor of law at Columbia University.

 BODY:
There's a lot in the press these days about "the lessons of hard work."
I'm thinking of the pictures of those women sweating rivers as they tote those bales on the newly equal-opportunity chain gangs in Arizona. No romantic dew of perspiration upon their sopping brows; they atone for their sins in a way that all of the viewing public can enjoy. 
 Elsewhere, welfare recipients are channeled into workfare programs insuring that the poor never sit around twiddling the thumbs of their otherwise idle hands -- surely the prelude to reproductive devilment. Make work, not babies, is the message to those on welfare -- and indeed make-work is the best the poor can expect from this most wealthy nation's most recent welfare package.
Meanwhile, children in gutted inner cities are told that all they have to do to improve themselves is to work hard, just stop complaining -- and a smile now and then wouldn't hurt -- and then try harder, harder, harder.
Now, I'm a fan of work as much as the next person, but I do wonder what lessons are being imparted. In New York City, the poor -- many of whom are the descendants of hard-working slaves, or the grandchildren of hard-working sharecroppers, or the children of coal miners, dirt farmers and sweatshop laborers -- are to be uplifted from their purportedly lazy ways through the rehabilitative effort of cleaning the subways. Subways in which some of them are living. Their instructors will be unionized workers who have spent decades organizing to improve their own lot, yet whose livelihoods are threatened by workfare's nonunionized, below-minimum-wage pools of labor.
The use of work as "lesson" in an economy that offers the least skilled few options is quite troubling. Is it significant, I wonder, that the rush to embrace the least attractive norms of the Industrial Revolution is occurring at a moment when Americans are working harder and harder and harder and harder? Deep resentments are developing toward those who are not busy every single moment of the day. The resentment is deepest, perhaps, among baby boomers who grew up thinking of themselves as the leisure class yet whom Charles Reich has aptly renamed "the anxious class" -- overworked, overwrought, so overwhelmed by debt that even real prisoners in real prisons seem like they're enjoying a vacation just because they have time to sit down and have dinner together.
While much publicity has focused on teaching the poor "discipline" and exposing them to "real work," much of this labor bears little relation either to saving taxpayer dollars or to the lessons of any labor market. The Governor of Alabama, for example, ordered prisoners' vegetable gardens to be plowed under and then imported rock for chain gangs to crush -- even in the absence of any need for crushed rock.
Alabama's chain gangs were recently abandoned in the face of pending lawsuits, but the theme of display labor has played on in the several states where chain gangs persist. I begin to wonder if there is not some theatrical stake in the phenomenon of a public excited by stereotyped and overwhelmingly fictional images of luxurious prisons and indolent welfare recipients, lounging about watching cable TV. I grow concerned about a thirst for hard labor.
Not long ago, there were news reports abut Oseola McCarty, a woman who had "taken in wash" for more than 75 years and who, having no family, had saved some $150,000 from wages that never exceeded a few dollars a week. At the age of 87, desiring to put her affairs in order, she donated the money to the University of Southern Mississippi for a scholarship fund for black students.
The media made much of the marvel of a poor black woman of sufficient sacrificial thrift to amass a small fortune -- and then to hand it on to others. "There was nothing I wanted for myself," she was quoted as saying time and again, patiently, to reporters who seemed awestruck and slightly appalled by the simplicity of her life and by her humility. "I just wanted to do nice . . . something for the children to get an education. Because I didn't get mine, but I want them to have theirs."
Many hailed Ms. McCarty's story with a kind of nostalgia for the good old days when blacks valued a real work ethic, eschewed having babies and didn't go to white people for a handout. Jeff Jacoby, a newspaper columnist, wrote: "No one ever notified her that she was one of life's losers, unable to survive without help from Big Brother. It never occurred to her that she was fit only to receive, not to give; to be assisted, never to assist. For that matter, it never occurred to her that she had a claim on the taxpayers for the money she hadn't earned. Or that washing clothes was a 'dead-end' job. Or that society owed her anything except respect, and the freedom to make herself useful."
It's a doozy, this phrase: "the freedom to make herself useful." This oddly expressed "freedom" of servitude is, I suppose, a twisted reference to the notion that underlies the common law concept of employment-at-will and much historical resistance to organized labor. The premise is a simple -- dare I say simplistic -- one. The employer hires a worker. The employer can fire the worker at any time. The worker can quit at any time. Employment at will.
But assume that there comes a moment when there is little movement of wealth, when mobility is considerably more limited than this ideal economic model.
Assume that poisonous work environments and Dickensian labor conditions exist in a world of free trade zones, of manufacturing islands whose operations can shift almost overnight from North Carolina to Mexico, Thailand or the Philippines.Assume further that the problem of labor is overlaid with unparalleled migrations from rural to urban locations, immigration across national boundaries and the general suspension of civil rights laws.
With all these complications in mind, I'll turn to Oseola McCarty, whose genuinely heroic story is so overlaid with easy finger-shaking bromides about self-discipline. It is probably worth asking just a few questions.
Do we really want to romanticize a system of indentured servitude that left the vast majority of black women in Miss McCarty's generation actually envying those who did laundry because it was a better job than most? And before making generalizations about what Miss McCarty may have "not earned" in benefits from the Government, isn't it worth asking what she ought to have earned in the private sector, given the great likelihood that she was grossly underpaid? Forgive my naivete, but are there really people in the world who believe that it never occurred to Oseola McCarty that washing clothes was a dead-end job?
Why the rush to declare 75 years of washing other people's dirty drawers a blessing? As though never getting "mine" were the answer to every one else's prayers?
We are faced today with a challenge not to forget the insights of those who worked to create the occupational protections that many of us take for granted and that many more struggle to retain. Perhaps if we listened closely to the voices of so many who slaved their lives away, we might find not only the tenaciously held faith that there was, at the end of the line, a heaven for them but also a vision of a future that would be different for us all, the children of their inconceivably generous aspirations.

HEADLINE: Aloha to the GTE Party Line

BYLINE: By MARLENE WERNER 

DATELINE: KA'U DISTRICT, Hawaii, Oct. 8

 BODY:
When Barry Neal, a consulting meteorologist specializing in the Hawaiian Islands' air quality, decided he wanted to move a few years ago, he knew what he wanted: a home away from busy Oahu, in rural Ka'u, and the chance to telecommute to work.
Finding the home was not hard, but telecommuting was impossible. When he tried to send his air-quality data, the calls were interrupted. 
 No one had told him he was moving into one of the few remaining areas of the United States served only by party lines. He couldn't use the Internet, his fax or his answering machine without neighbors picking up the phone.
"I wondered why in the 1990's we were stuck with party lines," he said. "It was a constant aggravation."
Mr. Neal's frustration soon became outrage, when his telephone company, GTE Hawaiian Telephone, said he had no choice. And his outrage, and that of other clients, led to a five-year battle that recently culminated in an order by the Hawaii Public Utilities Commission that GTE Hawaiian Tel turn over its networks to Telalaska, a small competitor from Alaska.
GTE Hawaiian Tel is fighting the order in court. The commission has already fined it $225,000 for noncompliance, and is adding an additional $15,000 a day as long as the utility refuses to go along. The utility is paying the fines, pending a final judicial resolution.
GTE's troubles with the state go back at least to 1991, when the Public Utilities Commission decided to investigate the charges that rural phone service was inadequate. Mr. Neal, financed by nickels and dimes from dissatisfied neighbors, presented evidence of inadequate service throughout Hawaiian Ocean View Estates and surrounding areas, known collectively as the Ka'u District -- the southernmost tip of the United States.
GTE argued that the area involved, with its 2,400 customers spread out over 400 square miles of lava fields, abandoned sugar cane fields, desert and black and green beaches was so remote that improving service was not worth the cost of new switching equipment and replacing existing lines.
Alan Okinaka, the Hawaii Island manager of GTE, said, "We must economically justify upgrading service, so we wait until density increases in remote rural areas."
The standard telephone monthly fee for the big island of Hawaii, where Ka'u is situated, is $15 for residential customers and $31 for business customers, whether they have private or party lines.
After almost three years of investigations and hearings, the commission agreed with the disgruntled customers and in 1994 ordered GTE to install private lines in the area within three years.
The total cost of that project, according to GTE's estimates, would be $20 million, or as high as $10,000 a subscriber in the most inaccessible area. The utility offered five-year payment plans that averaged $35 a month, but would have cost the most remote subscribers as much as $166 a month in an additional surcharge.
Half the total cost, under the utility's plan, would be paid by the subscribers involved. The other half would be taken from a surcharge that all GTE customers on the big island would pay.
Very few people signed up.
The commission then held hearings on whether an alternative phone provider should be licensed. It heard from Mr. Neal and from others and decided to allow competitors to bid to serve Ka'u. Telalaska's new subsidiary, Telhawaii, GTE and two other companies bid; the commission selected Telhawaii, which promised to install private lines, freeze rates for at least three years and reimburse all surcharges that had been paid to GTE by Ka'u customers.
"We serve areas in Alaska so remote it makes Mr. Neal's area look urban," said Dan Gordon, vice president and general manager of Telhawaii. His company furnishes some of the most remote areas in North America with state-of-the art digital switching technology and computer-compatible service and offers private lines exclusively.
Telalaska has customers above the Arctic Circle, on Little Diomede Island just two miles from Russia and in Dutch Harbor at the very end of the Aleutian Islands. Of all the areas that Telalaska serves, only one can be reached by car; all others are accessible only by plane or boat.
In addition, "we will qualify for funds from the Universal Service Fund for upgrading rural phone service," Mr. Gordon explained, referring to a national set-aside fund, to which all long-distance carriers contribute. The fund is intended to assure adequate rural phone service across the country. This money is not available to GTE since it is predominantly an urban service provider.
On July 15, the commission ordered GTE to sell its physical assets in Ka'u to Telhawaii and to turn over business records and technical information within 30 days. GTE decided to pay the fine "under protest," contending it should not take effect while it has an appeal pending before the State Supreme Court.
GTE says in court filings that the commission does not have the authority to make it sell its facilities in Ka'u and that ordering an "involuntary transfer" of GTE's private assets violates constitutional guarantees.
"It doesn't matter if it involves only 2,500 subscribers," said Kevin Payne, vice president of external affairs for GTE, "if the order is not lawful and it violates our company's constitutional right."
Mr. Neal believes GTE is not so concerned with keeping its Ka'u subscribers as it is fearful of the precedent this decision could set for phone service in other GTE service areas.
"GTE is doing everything they can to block this," said Mr. Neal, who has since joined the board of Telhawaii. "With all the money they are spending on attorneys, they could have rebuilt the Ka'u District several times."

HEADLINE: Rats and Squalor, at $800 a Month

 BODY:
New Yorkers are understandably appalled at the squalid and dangerous conditions exposed last week in "Barely Four Walls," The Times's series on the scarcity of livable housing for poor families. The series documents case after case of children growing up in dilapidated, rat-infested buildings that violate nearly every applicable housing code. Meanwhile, the city's housing authorities stand helplessly by, hamstrung by a shortage of inspectors and a housing law that exempts even the worst landlords from serious punishment.
The conditions rival those uncovered in the 1890's by the crusading photographer Jacob Riis, whose book "How the Other Half Lives" awakened the country to the grim realities of tenement life. Like their predecessors in Riis's time, today's new immigrants often live without toilets and several to a room in illegal apartments carved out of basements and gangways. In addition to the obvious health hazard, this steerage-style housing contributes to family breakups, poor performance in school and delinquency by adolescents who choose the streets over the cramped hovels they call home. 
 One of the most horrific cases in the series was that of a Bronx woman named Janet Carcano. Her family of six lives in an apartment whose rotting walls and floors grant easy access to legions of rats. Ms. Carcano stays up at night to beat them away from the sleeping children. Not long ago, her infant grandson was bitten in his crib. Still, the building's owner collects $800 a month for Ms. Carcano's "home," most of it from a Federal subsidy.
New York City's Housing Commissioner, Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, says the city has less power over law-breaking landlords than it does over drivers who double park. Motorists can be fined without court proceedings; their licenses can be suspended if they decline to pay. Landlords cannot be forced to repair buildings or pay fines without first appearing in housing court. The proceedings are slow, the penalties light.
There are too few housing inspectors with too little authority. Over the last six years the number of housing inspectors has been cut in half, leaving fewer than 200 to inspect the city's 140,000 apartment buildings. There is now a backlog of more than three million violations to be cleared. Like previous housing commissioners, Ms. Barrios-Paoli suggests that the State Legislature create an administrative tribunal to enforce housing violations. The idea is opposed both by landlords and tenant groups and has gotten nowhere in Albany. This is one area where Mayor Rudolph Giuliani might profitably apply political energy.
But the dearth of housing for the poor is mainly an economic problem. Poor New Yorkers earn too little money to cover the cost of decent housing. Sometimes buildings deteriorate because landlords cannot raise enough revenue to maintain them. Rent control and rent stabilization laws keep rents low, discouraging residential building of all kinds.
Mayor Edward Koch increased the supply of housing for the poor with a $4 billion initiative in which the city and not-for-profit groups combined to produce 50,000 apartments and houses. The Koch plan rebuilt the blighted South Bronx and parts of several other neighborhoods as well. But as the city's fiscal condition worsened, the money for the program dwindled. Not-for-profit groups continue to reclaim blighted buildings all over the city. But their principal tool is now the Federal tax credit for corporations that invest in low-income housing. That program can produce only 2,000 units a year in New York City, far short of what is needed.
The Mayor cannot alter economic reality. But he can do something to revitalize enforcement. He can also rally the private sector and intensify efforts to get city-owned properties into the hands of not-for-profits that specialize in housing for the poor. In short, Mr. Giuliani could do a great deal of good by making low-income housing a priority in an administration that has thus far ignored it.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Rangers' Slow Start Brings Talk of Changes

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

DATELINE: RYE, N.Y., Oct. 13

 BODY:
For the first time in his three seasons as coach of the Rangers, the job status of Colin Campbell is a valid topic of doubt, debate and discussion. His team, with its marquee names and its high payroll, is off to an alarming start of 0-3-2 following Saturday's 5-2 defeat in Montreal.
Counting last season, when they finished 0-5 on the regular schedule and went 5-6 in the playoffs, the Rangers have won only 5 of their last 21 games since April 7. 
 Campbell said he wasn't the target of Neil Smith's rage Saturday when the president and general manager entered the coach's locker room with a loud, profane tirade that was punctuated by several slams of a door.
Smith was merely venting, Campbell said. They remain friends and mutual supporters.
"He slams a lot of doors," Campbell said of Smith. "Nothing between he and I. We're in this together."
And it's not that the captain, Mark Messier, was hinting about Campbell when he warned today that "the dark side" of professional hockey is that "when you're not winning, jobs are on the line."
When asked for clarification, Messier said he was speaking of players' jobs and not that of the coach.
But the coach, as is his way, was blunt and candid when the subject came up today at Playland Ice Casino after a long session of work on what was supposed to be an off day.
Following a brisk practice and serious one-on-one conversations with several players, Campbell held a long news conference that began with him, eyes down, rubbing both hands up and down a weary face.
"You can shout and stamp your feet," Campbell said when asked what he could do to motivate the team. "Some people would like to see that." He said he and his assistants considered benching players and working them to exhaustion in practice and juggling the lines again and again.
"Is it going to work?" Campbell asked. "Anything I do has to be real. It can't be an act. I'm not going to fool these guys by coming in and breaking a TV.
"The responsibility falls on the coach to win games. I've been around long enough to know if coaches don't win, you get changed."
Among the unemployed coaches now available are Pat Burns and Jacques Demers. Burns, working in broadcasting in Montreal, was dismissed by the Toronto Maple Leafs last season. Demers, dismissed last season by the Canadiens, works for them as a pro scout.
But it would be unlikely for Smith to move with haste in this area. His loyalty to Campbell goes back to their days in Detroit, when Smith was the chief scout and Campbell an assistant coach.
And many of the problems with the current team are beyond Campbell's control. Because of the World Cup tournament that ended Sept. 14, the Rangers never played together as a team in nine exhibition games and practiced for only a week as a full group before the regular season.
With 20 games in the first 40 nights, they have little time for the long practices needed to adjust to Wayne Gretzky, the free agent acquisition whose many creative skills still seem to baffle some teammates.
As he left the locker room today, Gretzky paused to discuss the emotional state of the Rangers and the teams that beat or tie them.
"Hatred is a strong word," Gretzky said, "but teams don't like us and want to knock us off. We have to get that same meanness. I'm not panicking. That's the good news. Obviously, we're disappointed. Maybe even embarrassed. We've hit rock bottom. We've got to win tomorrow."
That would be Monday's game with Calgary, the first of three this week at Madison Square Garden. Mario Lemieux's Pittsburgh Penguins visit on Wednesday. Then it's Mike Keenan's St. Louis Blues on Friday.
Messier, who also offered his thoughts, said the Rangers "have made enough mistakes for half a year in the first five games."
Some are caused because the team, he said, is "caught in between playing a real forecheck system and pulling back a little." A speedy, forceful attacker, Messier has long favored the forecheck approach.
Although Gretzky isn't as fast or powerful as Messier, he, too, is a gambler on the attack, creating scoring chances with risk and imagination. But most of their teammates don't seem in sync. The stars, the coach and everyone else around the team is groping for an explanation, wondering if things will get worse before they get better, and what changes might be coming.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Privatization Program Is Canceled by Mexico
Abandoning a central pillar of its economic modernization program, the Mexican Government canceled its prolonged, troubled effort to sell portions of the state-owned petrochemical industry to private investors.
The scheduled privatization of 61 plants had prompted months of protests from oil workers and even many businessmen; the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party formally announced its opposition last month. Still, President Ernesto Zedillo had pledged repeatedly during his 23-month administration to go ahead with the selloff. [Page D2.]
 
Executive-Plan Bankruptcy Shield
Special tax-deferred savings and supplemental pension plans for corporate executives get favorable treatment under the law, in part because the money is supposedly at risk if the company gets into financial trouble. But even when companies file for bankruptcy, such plans often survive while the retirement funds of rank-and-file workers remain in jeopardy. [A1.]
 
Wooing Internet Gamers
No one has yet made a fortune marrying multiplayer games to the Internet. "But over time there will be," an analyst says. Businesses trying to profit from Internet gaming must meet player expectations while overcoming the restrictions of slow modems and other technological obstacles. [D5.]
 
A More Competitive Medium
A coalition of 38 computer makers and software publishers led by Netscape Communications plans to announce a new audio and video data standard today that will permit companies using the Internet to compete more directly with traditional radio and television broadcasters. [D4.]
 
Aloha to a Party Line
When GTE Hawaiian Telephone told its customers in a rural section of Hawaii that they could only use party lines, their outrage led to a five-year battle that recently culminated in an order by the state's public utilities commission requiring GTE to turn over its networks to a small competitor. [D5.]
 
In Ireland, the British Are Coming
The Irish Times, the most prestigious and influential newspaper in Ireland, is advancing, as its circulation sets new highs and its ability to sway and infuriate politicians increases. But as fast as it grows, the Irish editions of British papers are growing faster. [D7.]
 
Europe Rate Gauge for Finland
Finland, the newest member of the European Union, has taken another decisive step westward, linking its currency to the European exchange rate mechanism and possibly qualifying for participation in the forthcoming single currency. [D2.]
 
Hollywood's Weekend Wars
Every Friday night, only hours after a new film has opened across the country, the faxes pile up in the offices of nervous studio executives and producers detailing the box-office grosses of the movie. Judgments are set by Sunday. A studio film, opening nationally, that takes in at least $10 million at the box office is considered successful. Any highly promoted film that doesn't is a disappointment. Bernard Weinraub: Entertainment. [D7.]

Cable Access as Urban Resource
 
Like many disputes that mix politics and commerce, the showdown between Time Warner and the Giuliani administration is ultimately about control of a precious resource: in this case, cable TV access. Just how precious can be measured by the other media companies wading into the dispute in hopes of turning the furor to their advantage. News analysis. [B3.]

HEADLINE: Petite Martinique Journal;
No Thanks! And You Can Tell It to the Marines

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PETITE MARTINIQUE, Grenada Oct. 10

 BODY:
The jetty that links this isolated Caribbean island to the outside world is a simple wooden structure in obvious need of repair. So when the United States offered to send a detachment of marines here to build a base for the Grenada Coast Guard and to repair the local school and clinic, residents might have been expected to welcome the proposal.
Instead, the dockside site chosen for the project, which is intended to strengthen drug interdiction efforts in the Caribbean, is now festooned with graffiti demanding "No Base." And when Prime Minister Keith Mitchell traveled here recently in an attempt to convince this island's 800 residents that the base, whose construction costs would be entirely covered by the United States, would enhance Grenada's national security and spur economic growth, he was greeted with boos, placards and children chanting anti-base slogans. 
 "One hundred foreign soldiers here for even a short time would completely change our life style," said Michael Caesar, Grenada's former delegate to the United Nations and a native of this island, as he stood at the jetty watching the twice-weekly mail boat take on cargo. "Our little island is less than three square miles, so a facility like this can only be detrimental to the entire island community."
Accustomed as they are to going it alone, many here also seem convinced that the proposed base is part of an American effort to gain a permanent foothold in a place where even the authority of Grenada's central Government has always been minimal.
"It's a Trojan horse, and we don't want it here," said Martin Clement, who makes his living selling ice and gasoline to local fishermen and visiting yachtsmen.
Although the monetary value of the project is small, about $250,000, in strategic terms, something much larger is at stake. American officials describe the "satellite base" here, still scheduled to be built next spring despite the local protests, as the first of a series throughout the Caribbean, with similar American-built installations contemplated for local coast guard operations in Barbuda, Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and Tobago by the end of the century.
"This caught all of us off guard," one American official conceded. "Everyone viewed this as a positive development, as a gift. And no one realized there would be any opposition."
But as people here are quick to point out, any mention of an American military presence in the nation of Grenada, an island group with 120,000 people, involves sensibilities found nowhere else in the English-speaking Caribbean. In October 1983, the United States, alarmed at signs of Cuban influence, invaded this former British colony after a power struggle between two left-wing factions led to the assassination of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop.
"Certain things trigger memories, and talking about Americans and a military base has reopened those memories," said Ivelaw Griffith, an expert on Caribbean security issues who teaches at Florida International University in Miami. "That is why the Grenadian Government should have paved the way with communication and seen as its special mission to tell the people what this is all about and allay their fears."
In reality, however, people here grumble that they were not consulted about the location of the base, which as currently planned would take away their only cricket ground and children's playground and would abut their only school. They would much prefer, they say, to see the base moved to the nearby island of Carriacou, which is much larger and has idle land owned by the Government, or to any of several uninhabited islets in the area.
"The first we ever knew about this was when some American soldiers showed up and started measuring the wharf and playing field and planting stakes," complained Matthew Blair, owner of a grocery store that fronts on the site chosen for the base. "We had no idea what was going on until we went up and asked them."
In an interview in the capital, St. George's, Prime Minister Mitchell said that objections to an infringement of national sovereignty are being "used as a smokescreen" by what he described as "elements profiting from illegality and drug activities." This island, he suggested, is a hotbed of smugglers who see the base as a threat to their livelihood.
"If you benefit from wrongdoing, you don't want to see legal institutions established," Mr. Mitchell said. "You will use all sorts of innuendo and catchy phrases to get people on your side so that you can continue to do what you have been doing all along."
Local people acknowledge that many here are engaged in what they delicately call "barter trade," sailing up to the French territory of Martinique to swap fish for beer, wine and cognac, which they then sell to passing yachtsmen and to the American residents of condominiums in nearby St. Vincent. But they deny any involvement in drug trafficking and say that any other business dealings they might undertake are simply none of Washington's concern.
"If the Americans are coming in for a domestic problem, as opposed to an international matter like drug trafficking, then we have even more right to oppose this base," argued Mr. Caesar, the former United Nations delegate. "For the U.S. to interfere in the internal affairs of Grenada and Grenada's domestic problems is wrong."
But Prime Minister Mitchell said that the American offer to build the base is not only welcome, but is also essential, and that he would be derelict in his duty if he did not accept it. With only two vessels, fewer than 40 men and a tiny budget, he said, Grenada's Coast Guard cannot by itself protect the country's coastline from the encroachments of drug traffickers.
"Since we don't have the resources to build the facility ourselves, I will take help from any and all of our friends," he said. "In fact, I only wish we could have gotten other bases built, so that we can protect the people as a whole and the integrity of our country."

LENGTH: 726 words

HEADLINE: Essay;
'Flat-Out Wrong'

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Asked directly about a charge made in this column that President Clinton had been personally involved in the solicitation of an illegal $250,000 campaign contribution, press secretary Michael McCurry replied, "That's flat-out wrong."
Flat-out, rooted in the auto-racing metaphor of pressing an accelerator flat against the car floor, has come to mean "totally committed." What the President's spokesman meant was flat -- "plain, stark, unadorned." 
 Now to the wrong, Clintonese for "mistaken," but connoting moral condemnation. Let's examine the facts:
1. We know that Democratic finance vice chairman John Huang, "the $4 million man" from Indonesia's Lippo banking empire controlled by the Riady family, this spring asked South Korea's Cheong Am Company for money to re-elect Clinton.
2. We know that a Cheong Am executive -- a foreign national working for a foreign corporation that just set up a U.S. subsidiary -- insisted on first meeting Clinton in person.
3. We know that in April, Lippo's Mr. Huang arranged for Cheong Am's James Lee to shake hands and chat with Clinton at a fund-raiser.
4. We know that subsequent to that meeting, substantial money passed: a Cheong Am check for $250,000 was paid to the Democratic account designated by Huang.
5. We know -- as the Democratic Finance Committee chairman admitted to me -- that the contribution solicited by Lippo's Huang, using the President himself as the closer, broke our law forbidding foreign funding.
6. But only when The Los Angeles Times questioned this illegal transaction did the Clintonites return the money. If not caught red-handed, Democratic admen would be using that hot-soft money to help saturate California's TV market today.
How, then, can my demonstrably accurate charge be called "flat-out wrong," or even "flat wrong"?
The Clinton way: total denial. Yesterday Vice President Al Gore inserted his office into what should be the purview of the election crimes branch of the Justice Department by declaring the Asian influence-peddling scandal nonexistent: "there have been absolutely no violations of any law."
Gore went even further to distance the Democratic ticket from its spreading foreign-money ethics mess, insisting to NBC "there is nothing that has been done that's wrong."
If that were true, why did the Democrats give the tainted money back?
Why did an Indonesian gardener with a green card, related to a Lippo partner, pass along $425,000 and then race home, avoiding inquiries?
And about John Huang -- in 1992 a Clinton Asian fund-raiser, in 1993 the recipient of a million-dollar payment from Lippo on the eve of being appointed by Clinton to a sensitive foreign economic post, and in 1996 wringing more campaign money out of Asian executives through fronts here -- why is he hiding from reporters?
I think wrongdoing is why. Because the Gore blanket denial is palpably untenable, a new story is being spun in the Clinton White House: You see, um, John Huang has no way of knowing the source or purpose of all this Asian money. As for Clinton, who publicly hailed Huang's "aggressive" efforts, he closes on contributions by shaking hands with strangers all the time -- how is a busy President to know clean from dirty money? Another Filegate-like "honest bureaucratic snafu."
But this time, an unforeseeable break has gone against Clinton's Asian connection. The Nobel committee just awarded this year's Peace Prize to two of the leaders of the movement to stop Indonesia's near-genocidal oppression of East Timor, territory it invaded two decades ago.
This fresh media focus on Indonesia should trigger a hard look into advice the Riadys gave Clinton about U.S. trade pressure on labor abuses in East Timor -- and into how Clintonites, despite human-rights lip service, delivered for their donors at the expense of millions of Asian dissidents.
No wonder Mr. McCurry refused to answer a query from here 10 days ago about the Indonesian millionaire James Riady's dealings with Clinton in the Oval Office and in Jakarta. The White House pretends that these Lippo meetings, one as recently as a month ago, were mere "drop-bys."
Do you believe that? A Clinton policy payback for the longtime Riady campaign largess would not only be evidence of corruption but would be, as the press secretary likes to say, "flat-out wrong."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: INDIANA;
A Tight Race For Governor In the Midwest

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 12

 BODY:
Mayor Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis, who is running for governor, won Bryan P. Norman's vote here at the West Side Nut Club Fall Festival, a weeklong carnival in the far southwest of the state that attracts visitors from all over the region.
"I was kind of on the fence," Mr. Norman said today as he waited in line with his wife and two children to ride a roller coaster. But Mr. Norman, an independent, said he was impressed with the Mayor, a Republican, after meeting him at the festival. "He has done a nice job outsourcing things in Indianapolis," Mr. Norman said. 
 Although Mr. Goldsmith has won a national reputation as an advocate for putting city services out for competitive bid, he needs all the friends he can get this fall in Indiana.
In what may be the tightest governor's race in the nation, Mr. Goldsmith is neck and neck with Lieut. Gov. Frank O'Bannon, a Democrat, to replace Gov. Evan Bayh, a popular Democrat who is barred from seeking re-election to a third term.
The most recent poll, taken last week, showed 45 percent of voters favoring Mr. O'Bannon and 44 percent preferring Mr. Goldsmith. The poll, taken by the Indiana University Public Opinion Laboratory for WISH-TV, a CBS affiliate, had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.6 percentage points.
"It is going to be close," said Brian S. Vargus, the director of the polling center, which is the statewide survey research arm of Indiana University.
Peter J. Stein, assistant editor of The Cook Political Report, a nonpartisan newsletter, said the only other neck-and-neck governor's race is in West Virginia. "Of all the gubernatorial races," Mr. Stein said, "Indiana is going to probably be the closest."
While Mr. Goldsmith is a rising star in the Republican Party and is a more dynamic speaker than Mr. O'Bannon, the Mayor has an uphill fight here in part because the healthy economy has left even Republicans voters here more content with the Democrats now running the state.
Carol S. Cusic, who watched her two children take aim at a target shooting game here at the festival, said she had not yet decided whom to vote for next month. "I keep going back and forth," she said. "Normally, I do vote Republican, but I like the way things have been going."
Mr. O'Bannon, 66, has also been greatly helped in the last month by none other than Mr. Goldsmith, 49. Almost everything that could go wrong in a campaign has recently gone wrong for the Mayor.
In just one week in mid-September, Mr. Goldsmith began running negative ads that backfired when the popular Lieutenant Governer cried foul, then Mr. Goldsmith told newspapers that he would be doing better if Bob Dole were a more popular candidate, and the police chief of Indianapolis resigned after a brawl by drunken off-duty policemen.
"It would have been hard to configure as many absolute bad things happening in such a short period of time," Mr. Goldsmith said.
Last Monday, Mr. Goldsmith faced Mr. O'Bannon in their first debate in the campaign. Mr. Goldsmith focused on policy matters while Mr. O'Bannon read parts of his opening and closing statements and fumbled with some numbers he recited.
Recalling President Clinton's lines about building a bridge to the 21st century, Mr. Goldsmith insisted that "Indiana needs to be better prepared for the 21st century." Mr. O'Bannon portrayed himself as the candidate to trust. He repeatedly criticized Mr. Goldsmith's efforts to put government services out to bid as risky.
The outcome for the Presidential race in Indiana also seems to be a tossup. Hoosier voters still prefer Mr. Dole to Mr. Clinton, but only by 44 percent to 42 percent, according to the Indiana University poll. With a margin of error of plus or minus 3.6 percentage points, Mr. Vargus called the race "a statistical tie."

HEADLINE: Mechanic of Japan's Machine Politics Stalls a Bit

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 13

 BODY:
This should be Ichiro Ozawa's big moment, a chance to begin packing his bags for the move into the Prime Minister's residence.
Mr. Ozawa, the burly 54-year-old opposition leader who is a legendary mechanic of Japan's political machines, was first elected to Parliament at 27 and has spent half his life building to the general elections that will be held on Sunday. But these days Mr. Ozawa is facing the distasteful task of explaining poll results that make Bob Dole's look positively inspiring. 
 More broadly, Mr. Ozawa's difficulties underscore the weakness of opposition politics in Japan. A two-party system seems as far away in Japan as ever.
The Liberal Democratic Party dominated Japan for most of its postwar history, and it remains by far the biggest party in the country. The Liberal Democrats are widely expected to win the largest number of seats in the coming elections, although probably not a majority that would enable them to form a Government without a coalition partner.
These days there is great dissatisfaction with the Liberal Democrats, but the opposition is fractured into several parties and more factions.
One recent survey found that only 13 percent of voters plan to support Mr. Ozawa's New Frontier Party, although many are still undecided. So Mr. Ozawa is being forced to contemplate not only the possibility of power but also the prospect of losing and giving up his job as head of the New Frontier Party.
"We are not thinking about any such eventuality," Mr. Ozawa said in a television interview program. "But I have to take the responsibility should the party fail to gain power."
To be sure, Mr. Ozawa is regarded as a wizard of a strategist, and some experts say he might conceivably end up Prime Minister as part of a coalition. But it is at least as likely that his party will collapse after the election, with some defecting to the Liberal Democrats and others joining various other parties.
Mr. Ozawa's plummeting fortunes have disappointed many Americans, who see him as a reformer who would turn Japan on its head -- opening up the country in ways that would facilitate trade and generally please the United States. In a book, in speeches and in interviews, Mr. Ozawa has called in unusually specific language for major changes in Japanese politics, economics, administration and even education.
"We may require not just reform, but revolution," Mr. Ozawa said in an interview earlier this year. He went on to emphasize the need to change the education system, along with company entrance examinations, "indeed, the whole system of employment."
But one of the problems with the New Frontier Party is Mr. Ozawa himself: while Americans have seen him as a fresh force for change, to many Japanese he epitomizes the old machine politics they are trying to put behind them. Even when he makes points that resonate with the public, people criticize him as an opportunist.
"The New Frontier Party has utterly failed to deliver," said John F. Neuffer, a specialist on Japanese politics at the Mitsui Marine Research Institute in Tokyo. One result, Mr. Neuffer noted, is that disgruntled voters may now be inclined to support a brand-new group, the Democratic Party, which insists that it is the real supporter of far-reaching reform.
Some sympathetic experts say that one problem is that Mr. Ozawa is a strong leader, and that Japan is uncomfortable with strong leaders. Certainly, Mr. Ozawa's dictatorial style has alienated many members of Parliament within his own party.
Mr. Ozawa and the New Frontier Party were also criticized this spring for a number of political missteps. Many voters agreed with the New Frontier's opposition to a bailout of financial institutions this spring, but the party lost points for bickering and seeming to engage in old-style machine politics.
Now Mr. Ozawa seems to be trying to recover political ground by turning to a classic American-style approach: a promise to cut taxes. He is pledging to cut income taxes and local taxes by half, abolish a property tax and delay an increase in the sales tax.
The income tax proposal has been met by such skepticism so far that it has triggered little serious discussion. The proposed delay of the sales tax is a common topic -- and very popular -- but it is unclear whether it can energize Mr. Ozawa's campaign in the final days.

HEADLINE: 25-Year Low In a Measure Of Well-Being

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
The nation's social well-being has fallen to its lowest point in almost 25 years, and children and young people are suffering the most, according to an index developed by researchers at Fordham University.
Of the six problems concerning Americans younger than 18, four -- child abuse, teen-age suicide, drug abuse and the high school dropout rate -- worsened in 1994, the most recent year covered by the index. 
 It was the first year that four issues involving children and teen-agers have fallen in the index in a single year. A fifth, children in poverty, improved slightly but remained at its fifth-worst level since 1971.
"The decline in the social health of children and youth tells us something about the future shape of our society," said Marc L. Miringoff, director of the Institute for Innovation in Social Policy at the Fordham Graduate Center in Tarrytown, N.Y. "It's a warning sign."
Mr. Miringoff said there was a widespread pessimism among youth today, as well as more isolation and less sense of community. "The teen suicide rate is 95 percent higher than it was in 1970," he said.
He added that the report, "The 1996 Index of Social Health," does not make suggestions for solving these problems, nor does it call for more or less Government involvement. "My job is just to give the data," he said.
The report looks at Federal Government statistics on 16 social problems, comparing each annual measure with the year in which it was at its best level. It then derives an index figure on a scale of 0 to 100, with 100 the best score. The score for 1994 was 37.5.
The report was first produced in 1985 with statistics dating back to 1970. The nation's best year, as measured in the report, was 1973, when the index stood at 77.5. Before 1994, its worst year was 1991, when the index was 38.1. In 1993, the index was 38.8, down from 41.2 in 1992.
Other concerns that worsened in 1994 were food stamp coverage and the gap between rich and poor, which have fallen in the index at a faster rate in the 1990's than any other problems.
Other issues that improved during the year were infant mortality, unemployment, average weekly earnings, homicides and poverty among those 65 or older, things that have improved more than any other problems in the last 25 years.
The category of alcohol-related traffic fatalities has improved more than any other in the 1990's, but it remained about the same in 1994 as it was in 1993, as did health insurance coverage, health costs for those over 65 and access to affordable housing.

HEADLINE: Closing the Book on a Saloon for 'Drinkers With Writing Problems'

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
In more than a quarter-century behind the bar at the Lion's Head, Paul Schiffman forced more than a few drinkers out onto daybreak's doorstep at the close of a long and sorry night. "We call them the lingerers," he said, a mixture of pity and affection in his old seaman's voice. "The hangers-on, the lonely people who have nowhere to go and no one to go home to, who don't want to leave."
But Mr. Schiffman did not work the last shift on Saturday night, and as 6 A.M. approached, he had become something of a lingerer himself. Still perched atop a stool at the end of the bar more than two hours after last call, the wrenching reluctance to raise the parting glass was his as much as anyone's. 
 The Lion's Head, the history-soaked writers' saloon where a generation of New York's newshounds, novelists, poets and playwrights quenched their thirst for spirits and companionship with politicians, actors and anyone else who happened to stop by, closed yesterday morning. It was 38 years old and for the last 30 years had made its home at 59 Christopher Street in the West Village.
The cause was financial collapse, brought on by increasing rent and dwindling profits, the bar's owner, Michael Reardon, said.
On Saturday night, however, there were scant signs of the financial distress. A teeming crowd filled the bar and its adjacent dining room and spilled into the street as the regulars, current and former, came to pay their last respects.
A miniature coffin with a guest book attached lay on a table at the back of the barroom. Posted on the wall nearby was a roster of the regulars who died before the bar did.
The growing crowd pressed together in a smoky haze under the legendary wall adorned with the framed jackets of books written by the bar's patrons. By 2 A.M., the place was sold out of beer. "If we were going out of business every week, we wouldn't have to close," said Peter C. Doherty, one of three bartenders who were filling glasses as fast as they could.
But only a small core of regulars remained from the old days, and while a small group of younger patrons from the West Village had come to regard the Lion's Head as their favorite neighborhood pub, there was not enough business to pay nearly $10,000 a month in rent, Mr. Reardon said.
The financial difficulties had been going on for a while when Mr. Reardon, a former bartender, took over about three years ago. When Mr. Reardon found out he had lung cancer, things got even worse. His health rebounded ("I don't have my drinking legs back yet, but we're working on it.") but business did not.
"There's just not enough money to pay the rent," he said Saturday night outside the bar. A panhandler came up the block and Mr. Reardon gestured at homeless people across the street in Sheridan Square and trash on the ground. "That's not conducive to tourists stopping, looking at your menu and saying, 'Let's go in for dinner,' " he said. "The rent didn't reflect this. The rent kept going up."
Much of the old bar's furnishings are being auctioned off. The treasures -- the book jackets and the wood-carved lion's head over the bar -- will be put in storage, Mr. Reardon said, in hopes he can reopen in a new location within a year. He said he had been buying extra lottery tickets.
But there was general agreement among patrons on Saturday night that the Lion's Head they knew was never coming back.
Above all, they said, it was a place of friendship, where richly textured conversations lasted into the small hours and where disputes were often settled by pulling a baseball encyclopedia from a shelf behind the bar. They remembered the Clancy Brothers coming in to sing and a woman once asking, "Is this the place where writers with drinking problems go?" only to be told it was a place for drinkers with writing problems.
"Where are we going to go?" Diane Ouding, a writer, said. "I found this place when I'd been in town for three days, in 1966. It was a huge part of my life. This is the end of an era. This is the end of a generation."
Kristin White, a science writer, said many people she thought had died turned up at the bar's finale. "It was a nexus of people who lived by the word," she said, lamenting bygone days. "Engineers, mathematicians, physicists, if you brought them here, they just didn't get it."
The Lion's Head opened at Hudson and Perry Streets in 1958 and was moved to Christopher Street in 1966 by Wes Joice, a former police officer. Mr. Joice was there on Saturday. So was James P. Willse, the editor of The Star-Ledger in Newark and former editor of The Daily News, who admitted that he had not been to the bar in years.
"That's probably part of the problem," he said. "People like me haven't been here lately. The world changed a little bit around the place."
But Pete Hamill, the newspaperman and author who was once one of the bar's most famous regulars, was noticeably absent. Mr. Hamill, who quit drinking 23 years ago, said he was haunted by conflicting emotions.
"Like any good saloon it was a way to deal with the peculiar kind of loneliness that comes in cities when you are in the middle of seven or eight million people and you don't know who to talk to on Friday nights," he said.
But he also said he had lost many friends over the years. "One of the problems I had with going down last night, aside from the fact that I had to work, was that there's too many ghosts in the place," he said. "I always thought of those book jackets as looking like our Vietnam Wall."
