HEADLINE: Smuggled Aliens Now Cross Mohawk Land

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

DATELINE: CORNWALL, Ontario, Oct. 9

 BODY:
The Mohawk Indian reservation along the St. Lawrence River here has long been called Smugglers' Alley, an easy path to sneaking contraband into or out of the United States.
In the 19th century, that meant the occasional cow going whichever way prices were higher. During Prohibition, the contraband was an endless stream of liquor to the United States, and in recent years, it has been huge quantities of untaxed cigarettes heading north. 
 Now, a new form of contraband is being smuggled: people. Hundreds of illegal immigrants are using the Mohawk territory as a pathway to their American dreams. This new traffic became starkly apparent on the pitch-black night of Oct. 2, when a makeshift smugglers' boat overturned, killing a Pakistani woman and, it is believed, a man whose body has not been found, as well as endangering nine other would-be immigrants from the Indian subcontinent.
These victims represent the tip of the iceberg. In the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, the United States Border Patrol says more than 300 illegal aliens were caught after apparently passing through the Mohawk territory, up from 130 in the previous year and 72 the year before that. And the patrol admits it is lucky if it is catching 1 of 10.
"You can about bet they've been smuggled," said Ed Duda, assistant chief of the Border Patrol's office in Swanton, Vt., which polices 261 miles of the border.
These desperate seekers, from Koreans to Poles to Jamaicans who had found it relatively easy to get visas into Canada, pay $500 to $3,000 apiece for the boat ride of less than 10 minutes from Cornwall Island, part of the Indian territory in Canada, to Indian territory on the American mainland, border officials say.
Most are bound for New York City. Some have arrangements to be picked up by limousines sent from New York by those who arranged their passage. Others wander off on their own to buses or planes. Some try to hitchhike. Some try to walk until they dissolve into America.
All face immediate deportation or, for anyone who claims refugee status, a long wait in a detention center while his or her claim is considered. Smugglers, who are seldom caught, can be fined $25,000 per alien. The Immigration and Naturalization Service estimates that 15,000 people illegally enter the United States along the largely unpoliced, 3,500-mile border with Canada each year, compared with more than a million along the 2,000-mile border with Mexico. In the area overseen by Mr. Duda's section of the Border Patrol, the number of illegal aliens captured annually has hovered around 2,000.
"People not from the area cannot fathom the uniqueness of the situation we're up against," Mr. Duda said. Concerned Border Patrol officials have in recent years installed seismic, infrared and other sensors and cameras along the American side of the reservation and have shared information with the Canadian authorities about people and other forms of smuggling. The Canadian authorities have seized guns and drugs they say have moved north through the reservation.
 
Complex Territory Helps Smugglers
The Mohawk land, called the Akwesasne Reserve in Canada and the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation in the United States, are conducive to smuggling in part because of their geographic complexity: many islands, big and small, as well as a large swath of mainland on the American side. The fact that they are under the jurisdiction of so many governments -- the United States, Canada, New York State, Ontario and Quebec -- means that often no one is truly responsible. The situation is further complicated by the Indian contention -- largely realized -- that they rule themselves. Moreover, the Indians' demand for even clearer sovereignty, sometimes delivered with gunfire, has often encouraged outside governments to leave the reservation to itself.
In recent years, there has been armed confrontation against the Canadian Government at a nearby Mohawk location over a golf course which threatened to encroach on an ancient burial ground. The Akwesasne Reserve has also seen a civil war, at times involving armed confrontation, over casino gambling.
Signs on the reserve proclaim the area off-limits to the F.B.I., the New York State Police, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the provincial police and all revenue authorities. Huge banners depicting khaki-clad warriors wielding automatic weapons reinforce the point.
People smuggling is still a small-scale phenomenon next to the illegal importation of untaxed cigarettes a few years ago. The police say that under this scheme, Canadian cigarettes were shipped to American wholesalers who were not required to pay taxes levied by the Canadian Federal and provincial governments. Indians would then buy the cigarettes from the wholesalers and smuggle them into Canada, where they sold for half the official price of $40 (United States) a carton.
Until Canada drastically cut taxes in 1994, more than $1 billion a year worth of cigarettes was being smuggled, according to the Canadian revenue authorities.
 
Tax Cuts End A Tobacco Trade
Those smuggling cigarettes -- and usually alcohol as well -- became rich fast. Big new homes went up and stretch limousines became a common sight in area towns. But with the tax cuts on cigarettes, some limousine owners can no longer afford even oil changes. A sign posted on the bulletin board of the Bear Den, a reservation restaurant, now advertises a six-door Cadillac limousine for $6,500 or the best offer.
Equally relevant is that a tradition of illegal border business has been firmly established. "The most damaging aspect of life on Akwesasne is that it was turned into a relatively unpoliced area that became a haven for other activities besides cigarette smuggling," said a report by the MacKenzie Institute, a Canadian research organization.
The police and others thus suggest that the smugglers have moved from tobacco to people to shore up their flagging incomes. "Necessity is the mother of invention," said Donald Johnson, a former provincial prosecutor and lawyer for the boat operator charged with manslaughter in the Pakistani woman's drowning. "It does seem logical that something like that would happen."
 
Nighttime Journey Turns Tragic
 Mr. Johnson said he would not comment on the case because prosecutors had not provided him a specific description of the charges and the evidence.
The new importance of Smugglers' Alley as a conduit for humans became dramatically -- and tragically -- apparent on the night of Oct. 2. Eleven people from Pakistan and India were crowded in a homemade, 16-foot-long, flat-bottomed boat powered by a 20-horsepower motor. A storm came up, rain pelted down and the inky waters of the river roiled menacingly. The boat began to take on water.
Passengers screamed for the operator to go back to shore, and when he attempted to turn back, even more water poured into the boat, witnesses on board told the police. People sat with icy water up to their chests. About 15 minutes after being called by Indians who had heard the screams from their homes on the shore, rescuers arrived.
The rescuers, members of the Mohawk fire department, found seven people in the boat. Six were members of a family from Lahore, Pakistan. These included Tariq Chaudri and his wife, Zahida, along with their three children: Faraz, 8; Semal, 7, and Ahmed, 3. The other family member was the wife's mother, Naseem Taj, 51. Ms. Taj died in a local hospital. The police said her death appeared to have been caused by ingestion of water and hypothermia.
The boat's operator, Arthur Joseph Yops, 30, was found the next day near his home on the reservation at St. Regis Island, Quebec. He was charged with manslaughter by the Ontario authorities. A bail hearing has been postponed until Oct. 29. There are no American charges because the boat never left Canadian waters.
Rescuers recovered three other men from the boat. A fourth was presumed drowned after several days of searching. There is, however, speculation among Montreal's Pakistani residents that the missing man was the organizer of the expedition, and that he went over to the American side first by himself.
The passengers are in police custody at unidentified locations in Canada, except one who had an immigration hearing in Ottawa on Oct. 7.
The police suggested that this man, Masood Khan, 34, was the only passenger who had not been granted some sort of official permission to be in Canada. The family, for example, was said by the immigration authorities to have lived in Montreal for 11 months as landed immigrants. Such status or simple visitors' visas are easier to obtain for Canada than for the United States. As a result, American and Canadian border officials say it is typical for immigrants to enter Canada legally, and then be smuggled across the border.
At his immigration hearing, Mr. Khan said he had not applied for such status, but he asked for admission as a political refugee. He said he paid a smuggler from New Delhi $3,700 to be hidden in a cargo boat that sailed from Goa, India, to somewhere near Toronto. He said he fled India because of dangers from his involvement with separatists in his home state of Kashmir, leaving a wife and two children behind.
To be allowed to stay in Canada, Mr. Khan, who had been in the country less than a week when he tried to cross the border, must prove he had "a well-founded fear of persecution." The process usually takes a year.
 
Manslaughter Case Reignites Debate
The tragedy has reignited debate in this industrial city of 47,000 over the issue of smuggling. Since cigarette smuggling stopped pouring money into the local economy, more people appear to have joined Mayor Ron Martelle in actively opposing smuggling in general.
Until the Oct. 2 incident, "people considered smuggling a victimless crime," Mr. Martelle said. "If I could use a lower word than scum to describe these individuals, I would."
The Mohawk police have insisted that they are also eager to stop human smuggling. "The access here is so easy," said Sgt. Roger Mitchell of the Akwesasne Mohawk Police. "If we had more assistance, maybe we could do something about it."
But other Mohawks feel the resentment over smuggling activities represents another manifestation of racism. They say fewer than 10 percent of the 10,000 Mohawks were ever involved in any kind of smuggling, and that far fewer smuggle people.
"Generally, the community is against smuggling," said Diane McDonald, editor of The Indian Times, a reservation weekly. "It's a negative activity that promotes an unfavorable image of the Mohawk territory."
But others maintain that Indians are not bound by customs laws, because they were here before there was a country. "The border is just an inconvenience," said Cynthia Smoke, owner and editor of The People's Voice, another Mohawk weekly. "We think they put it there to make our life difficult."
This argument is being pressed by Michael Mitchell, who in 1988, in his capacity as grand chief of the Mohawk Council of Akwesasne, deliberately violated what he calls "the imaginary international border" by taking a truck of American goods across the Canadian border without formally declaring it.
The case is now being heard by Canada's Supreme Court. At issue is whether England in the Jay Treaty of 1794 gave the Mohawks perpetual border-crossing rights, a position Canada denies.
The chief says he does not want to ignore the border to engage in any illegal activity. But others see no such distinction. Robert Skidders, who owns a luncheonette selling Native American food, contended that charging a fellow Mohawk, Mr. Yops, in the death of Ms. Taj is blaming the wrong person. "The poor guy running the boat is just being told what to do," he said. "But they want to hang him because he's native."
Meanwhile, people from all over the world find themselves at a pizza parlor in Massena, N.Y., about seven miles from the reservation. They stop there because it is where the long-distance buses stop. Some sit all night on the cold ground waiting to buy a $63.96 ticket for the 9 A.M. Trailways bus to New York City.
"It's been going on and going on and going on and going on," said Matt Hurlbut, the owner of the pizza parlor. "Finally, people are beginning to take notice because somebody had to die."

HEADLINE: Pennant Elates Yankee Fans in an Almost Spiritual Fashion

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The bus carrying the triumphant Yankees arrived at Yankee Stadium shortly after midnight, greeted by more than 4,000 fans celebrating their arrival and camping out to buy World Series tickets. An exuberant Wade Boggs jumped off the bus, dropped his bags and ran to the crowd dispensing high-fives.
The city's celebration began hours before, on the corner of West 160th Street and Broadway even before the final, sweet throw disappeared into Tino Martinez's glove and landed the Yankees their first spot in the World Series in 15 years. 
 "Yankees! Series! Yankees! Series!" chanted more than 50 men who jostled on the sidewalk around a dusty 11-inch television that someone inside Comedor Economico Restaurant in Washington Heights had mercifully placed in the window above the hero rolls.
"I can't hear the game but I can see it, and that's enough," said Rafael Belgrove, a 48-year-old house painter and former minor-league second baseman who remembers that his son was born in 1977 only because that was the next-to-last time his team, baseball's most storied franchise, won a World Series.
He had waited patiently, loyally, through the lean years, Mr. Belgrove said, and now he was really going to enjoy a fat one.
"You don't even understand," Mr. Belgrove said, as he offered beer-can toasts to the crowd of die-hard Yankees fans, most of them Dominican immigrants. "This is not just baseball to me. This is good for my soul!"
It was the kind of almost spiritual rejoicing, born of agonizing anticipation, that erupted on countless other street corners, in sports bars and in living rooms around the city last night as the team headed to the World Series by taking the American League championship from the Baltimore Orioles, 4 games to 1.
And even with lingering memories -- of the heart-wrenching weeks in August when a 12-game lead all but disappeared, of the nail-biting come-from-behind rallies, of a game snatched from defeat by an unwitting seventh grader -- the fans swore that they had never doubted.
Even the city's First Fan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a man not usually given to gushing, gushed. "This is absolutely wonderful," said Mr. Giuliani, who stopped by Mickey Mantle's Restaurant on Central Park South to catch the end of the game. "The Yankees are a team that proves anyone can overcome their problems. They didn't quit."
In Times Square early this morning, a crowd of about 150 fans gathered outside the Official All-Star Cafe, where the Yankees had scheduled a post-game celebration. The manager, Joe Torre, and the Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson were the first to show up, at 12:25 A.M. About 20 minutes later the players began to arrive; among the first were catcher Jim Leyritz and shortstop Derek Jeter, who shared a limousine.
The celebrations took even louder forms in other neighborhoods. Just seconds after the pennant was clinched, green, red and white fireworks burst into the night sky on the corner of Smith and Union streets in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. Motorists honked their horns in solidarity, disrupting the calm of the usually quiet neighborhood of brownstones.
Frank Giuffre stood across the street from the fireworks, basking in the glow. "It's sort of a nostalgia from when I was younger," he said. "When I was 11, it was the last time they won a pennant, 15 years ago. That's a long time to be waiting."
World Series tickets, will go on sale today at 9 A.M. at the stadium's advance ticket windows and by phone through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-1212.
There will be a limit of four tickets per person for any one game, the Yankees announced. Tickets at the stadium can be purchased with cash only, while credit cards will be permitted through Ticketmaster. Tickets cost $70 for box seats, $45 for reserved seats and $25 for bleachers. Games 1 and 2 will be played on Saturday and Sunday nights. If necessary, Game 6 will be played Oct. 26 and Game 7 on Oct. 27.

HEADLINE: Ignorant Investors Can Build Capitalism Too

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The economist James Grant takes a dim view of United States monetary attempts to mitigate the effect of herd behavior on capital market efficiency (Op-Ed, Oct. 9). His view is justified since government policy, essentially by definition, is incapable of causing market prices and intrinsic values of assets to converge. 
 However, rather than finding the impact of uninformed traders' activities on market prices distasteful, he ought to point out the opportunities that informed investors are afforded by such activity when they short the economy and force assets to be valued fairly.
 
ANDREW LAWSON
Austin, Tex., Oct. 10, 1996

HEADLINE: In Popular Tongues, Spanish Stays Numero Uno;
Russian Opportunities

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Oct. 9 article on shifts in foreign language study at the college level emphasizes the drop in Russian. It is paradoxical that during that same period, job opportunities for undergraduates who combine Russian with another marketable skill have been increasing and are unlikely to decrease soon. 
 Colleges that refrain from immediately gutting programs but ask that these programs adapt to changes in Russia will find the current low numbers rising again. Like the Russian economy, Russian studies is a very good long-term investment, and one that colleges would be foolish to drop for a short-term financial gain.
 
KATHLEEN PARTHE
Rochester, N.Y., Oct. 9, 1996
 
Director, Russian Studies
University of Rochester

HEADLINE: The Riches of Cable

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Like many disputes that mix politics and commerce, the battle raging between the Giuliani administration and Time Warner is ultimately over control of a precious resource. In this case, it is a relatively new and utterly man-made one: access to cable television distribution.
Just how precious that access is at the moment can be measured by the number of media companies that have waded into -- and complicated -- a situation that began as a simple fight between one cable distributor, Time Warner, and Rupert Murdoch's Fox News Channel. In the last week, Cablevision Systems Corporation, Bloomberg Information Television and Nick at Nite's TV Land cable network have jumped into the fray. 
 In Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign to force Time Warner to allow Fox a home on New York City's cable system, each company sees a chance to increase its own access and control.
Bloomberg and TV Land see the dispute as a way finally to gain a slot in the package of 75 channels that Time Warner transmits to 1.1 million subscribers in Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island. (Currently, Bloomberg leases what little access it has from other channels; TV Land has no local distribution.)
And Cablevision Systems, itself a distribution network with 450,000 subscribers in the Bronx and Brooklyn, sees the struggle as an opening to regain the five channels it, like Time Warner, was contractually required to turn over to the city for Crosswalks, its public service programming.
"This is like the newsstand wars of the turn of the century, when publishers threw each other's papers off the newsstand," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center.
The basic problem -- wiring and analog signals that make it physically impossible for a cable to carry more than 75 channels -- will disappear as new technology is installed. Innovations that will allow 150 channels and more are tantalizingly near -- so near, in fact, that cable services already outnumber the available channels.
So the debate over who gets a channel can quickly become heated. Frictions that had been building recently as Time Warner repeatedly turned down Fox's requests for a channel exploded last week, when the distributor got a restraining order to stop the city from carrying Fox on one of its five Time Warner channels.
Mayor Giuliani said yesterday he was weighing whether to appeal the restraining order.
Cablevision also turned down Fox's requests, and the city's. But last week, instead of a legal fight, it offered the city a new deal.
In a letter last Thursday, Cablevision proposed that city simply return all five of its public-affairs channels. Cablevision would then survey subscribers about what they would like to see in place of the city's mix of educational and public-affairs programming.
If viewers voted for the Fox channel, Cablevision would carry the Fox channel; if they preferred TV Land, the company would carry TV Land. James L. Dolan, the president of Cablevision, who wrote the letter to Mr. Giuliani, said that a meeting with city officials had been scheduled for this week.
"We think the Mayor astutely recognizes that the city's channels are being underused," he said. "In this election year, we want to give viewers the opportunity to vote for what they want."
What would happen if the city agreed to give back its cable channels, as Cablevision proposed? Several cable executives said news channels like CNN and CNBC tend to rank low in surveys of viewers. The most popular channels tend to be ESPN 2, the History Channel, and movie channels like TNT.
Mr. Dolan said that any channel would almost certainly draw more viewers than Crosswalks. But he said his company would not necessarily make more money, because it would have to pay fees to those channels to carry them.
Still, Mr. Dolan acknowledged that Cablevision would benefit because its subscribers would presumably be more satisfied with their cable service. "We like people to use our product," he said.
Michael Bloomberg, the chairman of Bloomberg, also wants viewers to see his fledgling news service. But like Fox, the Bloomberg company had been refused a channel by both Cablevision and Time Warner, and its programs were appearing irregularly on leased-access cable channels and on USA Network, for two hours in the early morning every day except Sunday.
When Mr. Bloomberg returned from a trip to Singapore on Thursday, he heard about Mr. Giuliani's efforts on behalf of Mr. Murdoch.
Mr. Bloomberg placed a call to Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Planning and Development, from the taxi that was carrying him into Manhattan.
"It's perfectly appropriate for the Mayor to push Fox," Mr. Bloomberg said. "I just think it wasn't right for him to push one New York-based news channel over another New York-based news channel."
Mr. Giuliani agreed, and the service was sent out on one of the city's Cablevision channels as well as one of its Time Warner channels.
That same night, Cablevision blocked the distribution of Bloomberg. Time Warner pulled the plug on Friday after it obtained the court order.
Mr. Bloomberg said that his company made no money from its brief run, but that the exposure helped to increase public awareness of the Bloomberg company, which also owns radio stations and a business-news wire service.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
The Bean Show Must Go On

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: WEST CAPE MAY

 BODY:
Nothing, it seems, can dampen the spirits of what organizers call the nation's only lima bean festival -- not even the sudden collapse of the local bean economy. Earlier this year, Hanover Foods, longtime buyer of nearly all of Cape May County's Ford Hook lima beans, announced that it would take its business elsewhere, forcing farmers to stop growing the beans. But though the beans in the soup and the bean-toss were store-bought, organizers of the West Cape May Lima Bean Festival reported that Saturday's jamboree was the biggest ever, drawing more than 7,000 bean lovers. 
 And a farmer, Les Rea, who converted 500 acres to soybeans, corn and pumpkins this year, said yesterday that his two remaining acres of lima beans were selling as fast as his fieldhands could pick them.
 ANDY NEWMAN

HEADLINE: The New Isolationist?

BYLINE: By William Kristol and Robert Kagan; William Kristol is the editor of The Weekly Standard. Robert Kagan is a contributing editor.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Republicans love to re member 1980 the only time this century they beat a Democratic president. Bob Dole and Jack Kemp have been trying to reprise that campaign with their tax cut plan and their assault on liberalism.
Now we hear echoes of the 1980 campaign in foreign policy as well. But Mr. Dole sounds more like Jimmy Carter than Ronald Reagan. Back then, the Democrats believed they could paint Mr. Reagan as a trigger-happy cowboy who couldn't be trusted to keep America out of war. Their strategy failed when the American people decided they needed a President willing to lead the world. 
 The parties have now reversed roles. In last week's debates, Mr. Dole accused President Clinton of haphazardly deploying troops abroad. Mr. Dole expressed concern about lost jobs in California because of cuts in military spending, but neither he nor Mr. Kemp made the case for ballistic missile defense.
Neither man challenged the Administration for reacting too meekly to Saddam Hussein's attack on the Kurds. Instead, Mr. Kemp called the bombing of Iraq "precipitous" and said the President should have tried "diplomacy first." When Mr. Dole chastised the President for inadequate consultation with the United Nations, he gave Mr. Clinton a golden chance to sound Reaganesque: "Sometimes," Mr. Clinton declared, "the United States has to act alone . . . we cannot let other countries have a veto on our foreign policy."
When Mr. Kemp blamed the Administration for Mexico's financial crisis, Mr. Gore warned Republicans not to "blame America first."
Bill Clinton as Ronald Reagan. Al Gore as Jeane Kirkpatrick. What's going on? The Republican Party has lost its way. The party is so bereft of a compelling vision for American foreign policy that its candidates don't know how to attack the President's record.
It should not be that hard. Bob Dole is not another Jimmy Carter; he has always been a genuine internationalist. Last year, he supported sending troops to Bosnia, bucking many party members wishes.
In contrast, Mr. Clinton evaded the draft; his relationship with the military has been problematic; and his occasional unsteadiness at the helm has invited challenges from the Saddam Hussein and Radovan Karadzic. Republicans should be able to depict battle-tested Bob Dole as more trustworthy than the President especially when it comes to defending American interests and principles abroad.
That's why Mr. Dole's campaign is unfortunate. Ultimately, a governing Republican Party must stand for strong and assertive world leadership. And if Republicans lean toward isolationism, the next four years under President Clinton could prove dangerous. America is about to take on new obligations with the expansion of NATO into Eastern Europe. We will have to keep our troops in Bosnia well into next year. We will have to continue confronting the dangers posed by Iraq and Iran. We will have to keep a careful watch on China and Russia.
President Clinton may or may not be up to these challenges, but with a Republican opposition singing choruses of "Come home, America," and "Don't bomb before breakfast," the odds of successfully fulfilling our essential role in the world will diminish.
There's one more debate to go. Mr. Dole should read the transcript of the Reagan-Carter showdown of 1980. He will find Mr. Reagan affirming that "we cannot shirk our responsibility as the leader of the free world, because we are the only one who can do it." Then Mr. Dole should go out and win one for the Gipper.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Let Private Sector Help Solve Housing Crunch

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am amazed that your six-part series on low-income housing ("Housing's Hidden Crisis," Oct. 6-11) never focused on the strengths of New York's housing market, the important role played by poor immigrants in revitalizing the city or the significant role the private sector plays in providing low-income housing. 
 It is still possible to shoot photographs reminiscent of the days of the photojournalist and social reformer Jacob A. Riis, and as the president of the Rent Stabilization Association, the largest trade group representing rental property owners, I deplore any situation in which owners fail to maintain housing standards or abuse tenant rights.
But the deplorable housing conditions and associated public health emergencies disclosed by Riis in the 1890's do not compare to conditions today.
Most New York renters now enjoy safe, sanitary and comfortable accommodations, with just over 1 percent of apartments considered to be dilapidated.
And decent housing is available at reasonable rates, with half the apartments in the city renting for less than $560 a month and more than a third of all apartments for less than $400 a month.
Most of this low-rent housing is provided by private owners, mostly mom-and-pop operators who own fewer than 20 apartments each.
The private sector can play a larger role in providing low-income housing if government would only allow it to do so.
For example, about a third of the cost of operating apartment buildings results from real estate taxes and water and sewer charges, which could be reduced to make housing more affordable. And single-room occupancy buildings, which have been virtually eliminated by government rules, could serve to house many of the individuals featured in your series.
Instead of imposing more regulations, the city and the state need to review and overhaul the constellation of housing, zoning and building rules, the most burdensome in the nation. A good place to start is by eliminating rent control and rent stabilization laws when they come up for renewal next year.
As an Oct. 6 article in your Real Estate section noted, as soon as Massachusetts eliminated rent controls, new housing began to be produced in Cambridge for the first time in 25 years.
 
JOSEPH STRASBURG
New York, Oct. 11, 1996

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 6; Science Desk 

LENGTH: 2355 words

HEADLINE: Earth's Dominant Life Form Is Also Its Smallest: the Microbe

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
DEEP in the heart of the Amazon jungle is a famous gold field known as Serra Pelada that lies far from the usual regions where the rare metal is mined. Discovered in the early 1980's, the find prompted many thousands of poor Brazilians to rush into the wilderness and, often digging by hand or with crude tools, to extract more than 100 tons of the precious metal. The episode is often referred to as history's biggest gold rush.
Surprisingly, scientists who later studied the site concluded that the rich lode was produced not by the accepted mechanisms of ore formation but by swarms of microbes that over millions of years concentrated the gold from jungle soils and rivers and rocks. 
 "There's lots of evidence that microbes played a critical role," Dr. William A. Fyfe, a leading environmental geochemist, based at the University of Western Ontario in London, Ontario, said in an interview. "You find fossil bacteria and organic compounds all over the place."
Today Serra Pelada is seen as an example of a revolution that is quietly sweeping the earth sciences.
In hundreds and perhaps thousands of cases, scientists are discovering that microbes dwelling up to miles deep in the planetary crust are responsible for creating and arranging the rocks, seas, oils, soils, gases, metals and minerals that make up the earth's surface.
The implication -- considered likely but so far unproved -- is that this hidden biosphere of trillions of microbes and their ancestors has played a dominant role, perhaps the dominant role, in forming the planetary skin over the ages. Put irreverently, it is the rise of the shower scum.
"We're still at the very beginning" stages of understanding how microbes shaped the planet, said Dr. Henry L. Ehrlich, a biologist at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., who is the author of "Geomicrobiology," a college text published by Marcel Dekker in Manhattan.
This new view of how the earth's surface was shaped, which stresses the importance of subtle biological processes over the more overt ones of chemistry and physics, is supported by a growing body of evidence and is shaking up the traditional disciplines of geology and microbiology. The hottest earth sciences today are exotic hybrids of the two, with names like geomicrobiology, microbial geology and environmental geochemistry.
Hundreds of scientists in these fields are producing a wave of new findings and clues about how microbes do things like generating fossil fuels, catalyzing geochemical reactions and concentrating valuable metals like iron and gold.
"It's becoming a flood," Dr. Fyfe of the University of Western Ontario said of the recent discoveries. "The main conclusion is that if you don't understand the biosphere, you don't understand our environment."
As an example of the field's growth, Dr. Fyfe said that two decades ago scientists knew of 30 or 40 compounds and minerals that were made or amassed by microbes, often as excreta or body parts, much as humans concentrate calcium to make teeth and bones. "Today the number is hundreds," he said. "Every time we look harder, we find more."
Dr. Grant F. Ferris, a microbiologist at the University of Toronto, said swarms of tiny microbes had proved to be adept at forming "an enormous variety of minerals -- carbonates, phosphates, oxides, sulfides and silicates as well as silver and gold."
Dr. Debra S. Stakes, a geochemist at the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute in Moss Landing, Calif., said the microbial revolution was often hard for physical scientists to accept and fathom because it undercut so many old beliefs and tenets.
"This is a huge challenge for geochemists," she said. "What it says is that most geological processes at their more fundamental stages could be biologically mediated, which challenges our models for inorganic thermodynamics, for driving reactions."
Dr. Stakes added, "It undermines our capability to predict what minerals should precipitate under what conditions because biological mediation changes the conditions."
On the positive side, the microbial revolution is seen as giving scientists not only new insights into the workings of the earth's environment, both today and in the past, but powerful agents of influence as well.
For instance, studies are under way to see whether carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels could be pumped underground into rocky formations where microbes would turn it into carbonates, which occur naturally and widely as limestone. And microbes injected into wells might clean up polluted water and stimulate the production of natural gas. Mining with microbes is also under study, including the tapping of gold ores normally too dilute for recovery.
Another use attracting wide interest is studying the earth's microbial ecology as a tool for understanding faraway places like Mars, which was recently in the headlines with a report by scientists that the planet may have once harbored primitive microbes. Insights into terrestrial microbes and their effects, scientists say, can only aid Martian explorations that seek to find extraterrestrial life or evidence of its workings long ago.
"To read the fossil record more intelligently on Mars, you have to understand it here," Dr. Fyfe said.
In general, scientists say, the microbial revolution is a key to understanding the universe and the earth's place in it.
"It's a hot field," said Richard J. Leveille, a graduate student studying with Dr. Fyfe. "The discovery of microorganisms in the earth's crust is very recent. Their influence has been overlooked."
Although individual microbes are largely invisible to the eye, in general they are the oldest, most numerous and most diverse forms of life on the planet. Some of their habitats and effects are obvious, like microbial rusts that speed the weathering of rocks and microbial slimes that form mineral precipitates around ponds.
But in the last decade or so scientists around the globe have discovered that microbes thrive in an even wider range of habitats. In essence, scientists are discovering them wherever there is water at temperatures from about 20 degrees to 250 degrees Fahrenheit, including the icy poles, the deep sea, hot springs, volcanic fissures and, most recently, deep underground, in some cases miles down.
Experts say the enormous range of microbial life was often overlooked in the past because the tiny creatures -- so small that up to millions can inhabit a drop of water -- are easy to miss and hard to investigate, especially when found deep in the earth's rocky pores and cracks.
Much of the recent discovery of deep microbes has been done by governments exploring the practicality of storing nuclear wastes underground and trying to understand what effects microbes could have on metallic waste canisters and their contents. So far, the world depth record for the finding of microbes appears to be 2.6 miles, where diverse colonies thrived at a temperature of 230 degrees Fahrenheit.
So great is the aggregate bulk of these microbial organisms throughout the earth's crust that over the billions of years of geologic time, their cumulative biological mass is now seen as probably exceeding that of the planet as a whole -- all 6 sextillion, 588 quintillion tons of it.
"It could be several times the mass of the earth," Dr. Fyfe said, cautioning that such estimates were extremely crude given the current state of microbial knowledge.
A gripping example of microbial handiwork is Serra Pelada, which Dr. Fyfe and his colleagues have carefully investigated, concluding that the rich lode was produced by microbes. Among the bits of evidence, he said, were not only fossil bacteria and organic compounds in the field but careful demonstrations in the laboratory of how microbes can concentrate gold.
Such work was pioneered by Dr. Terence J. Beveridge of the University of Guelph, in Ontario, one of Dr. Fyfe's former students. Working with microscopes and chemical enrichments in a laboratory, he found that microbes easily crystallized a variety of metals on their cellular surfaces in pure form, including iron, magnesium, copper, sodium, potassium, manganese, zinc, calcium and gold.
"Tiny crystals of pure gold," Dr. Fyfe emphasized. "So we know they do these things." Photomicrographs published in The Journal of Bacteriology by Dr. Beveridge show microbes encircled by dense, growing crystals of gold.
The range of natural deposits tied to gold-microbe interplay is on the rise, said Dr. Gordon Southam, a geomicrobiologist at Northern Arizona University in Flagstaff, Ariz. His research links the life factor to gold placers, deposits found around the globe that are traditionally seen as formed by weathering and the separation of rocks of differing densities in places like swift-running rivers.
But his studies of placer nodules suggest that the process of gold concentration is catalyzed by microscopic miners. "The transformation is organic," he said. "It's mediated by microbes."
Scientists say that this generic process, which is known as biomineralization, can be passive or active. In the former case, the cell walls of microbes simply bind dissolved minerals, speeding precipitation and often completely encrusting cells.
Dr. Ehrlich of Rensselaer Polytechnic noted that such crystallization, once started biologically, can often continue on its own. "It can act as a seed or a nucleus for crystal formation," he said, much as salt crystallizes out of sea water.
In the active case, a microbe's metabolism prompts the making of minerals inside or outside its cellular walls, often by something as simple as excretions that change the acidity of surrounding solutions. For instance, blue-green bacteria living in naturally alkaline waters produce even higher alkalinity, precipitating carbonate minerals like calcite, the basic ingredient of limestone, chalk and marble.
Microbes can also seek out metals and chemically process them to release energy for their growth, often concentrating the metals in the process, for instance, diverse oxides of iron and manganese.
In many cases, scientists say, the physiological role of the metals, minerals and compounds processed by microbes is poorly understood and represents a research frontier.
In addition, the ties between the living and the nonliving realms are often fuzzy and represent areas of intense study.
"There are times when the biological connections are obvious, as with the great sedimentary carbonate or phosphate deposits," said Dr. Fyfe. These include the White Cliffs of Dover in the former case and an important ingredient of fertilizers in the latter case.
"But in other cases the connections are more tenuous," he added, "as with uranium in phosphate deposits or molybdenum in coal."
Beyond minerals, scientists are studying realms like microbial influence in the formation of gases. An example of such work appears in the Sept. 12 issue of the journal Nature.
Scientists from the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor and the Chevron Petroleum Technology Company in La Habra, Calif., studied a big natural gas field in Michigan that was thought to have been made as the earth's heat cooked rich organic remains in a bed of shale about 370 million years old. Shale is a fine-grained rock made of ancient silt and clay.
But it turned out that the gas was actively produced by billions of microbes, as revealed in part by high concentrations in industrial gas wells of carbon-13, a kind of microbial excreta and a sign of active life. Carbon at the earth's surface occurs in a variety of isotopes, or forms, including carbon-13 and carbon-12, which most plants and animals prefer.
The finding is "economically important and unexpected," said Anna M. Martini, an author of the Nature paper at the University of Michigan, adding that it pointed to new sources of natural gas globally.
Another area of microbial studies centers on fossils. In an article in the September issue of Geology, published by the Geological Society of America, British and French scientists suggest that microbes are responsible for the preservation of ancient soft tissues, their powers of mineralizing turning them into rock.
Microbes found in the earth's crust, while studied mainly to elucidate their hidden natural roles, are also increasingly being put to work on a host of projects. The Newmont Mining Corporation of Denver is studying whether microbial miners can eat the sulfur and iron out of gold ore, releasing the gold from its mineral bonds and making it easier to leach out.
And Dr. Fyfe of the University of Western Ontario is working closely with the Chinese to investigate the possibility of pumping microbes and carbon dioxide from the burning of coal into China's exhausted oil fields, forming mineral precipitates.
"We've had numerous discussions," he said. "They're very interested because they know they have a problem" with rising releases of carbon dioxide from burning coal, which many scientists believe is helping trap heat in the earth's atmosphere.
In preparation for Mars explorations, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is studying earth microbes and their mineralogical effects as possible models for Martian ones. The studies are taking place at Mono Lake in California, a highly alkaline body of water whose floor is covered with hot volcanic vents and microbial communities. It is considered an alien environment much like what existed on early Mars.
Dr. Stakes of the Monterey Bay institute and her colleagues at NASA, Stanford University and the Naval Postgraduate School explored the lake last year with a robot and plan to do so again next year.
Reflecting on the recent explosion of microbe studies, Dr. Stakes said the belated understanding of the wide influence of the tiny organisms was a lesson in scientific modesty.
"These processes have gone on for billions of years and we just didn't know about them," she said. "And there are probably other processes -- the earth's primary regulating processes -- that we haven't discovered yet. It's pretty amazing and humbling."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips as Finland Acts To Join European Rate Plan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the German mark yesterday, after Finland agreed to join the European Exchange Rate Mechanism, enhancing the prospect of a unified European currency.
In other trading, the British pound continued the run-up it began on Friday, gaining against the dollar on expectations of higher interest rates in Britain. The dollar rose slightly against the Japanese yen. 
 Trading in the United States was light because banks were closed for Columbus Day. But Finland's decision stirred some buying of European currencies, traders said. The Finnish action was seen as enhancing the possibility that Italy and Sweden might also join the E.R.M. Officials in both countries have been debating such a move.
"It puts a little pressure on the Swedish Government, and probably on the Italians as well" to join the European Union, said Roger Chapin, foreign exchange manager at Bank One in Columbus, Ohio.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5289 marks from 1.5307 late Friday. The dollar eased to 111.55 yen from 111.60 yen.
The British pound rose to $1.5785 yesterday from $1.5750. The pound touched an 11-month high against the dollar and a yearly high against the yen on Friday, after higher-than-expected September inflation data suggested that the Bank of England would soon raise rates.
Yesterday, the pound received an additional boost after the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, said he was not concerned about the strength of the pound. "We allow the markets to judge the value of sterling," Mr. Clarke said, according to Bloomberg Business News. The pound has risen 9 percent against the mark so far this year.
In Japan, the dollar was mired in a trading range as traders lost hope that the Japanese Government would soon take the unpopular step of lowering interest rates further. Lower rates are unpopular in Japan, where many have money tied up in low-yielding savings.
John Beerling, chief dealer at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said that "Japan is in a position where they have no choice but to try and depreciate their currency from here," which would be bullish for the dollar versus the yen.
"They have lowered interest rates as far as they can be lowered, and there is nothing else left to stimulate their economy," he added. "They've been in a recession for quite some time now that hasn't responded to easings."
On Friday, the dollar rose against the yen after Japan's Economic Planning Agency said in a monthly report that the economic recovery was gradual and that interest rates should remain low. The Bank of Japan's key discount rate has been at a record low of half of 1 percent for more than a year.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Some junk bond issues are outperforming many stocks.

BYLINE: By Robert Hurtado 

 BODY:
EVEN with the horde of low-rated companies rushing to sell debt, some junk bond issues may offer investors better value and more promising returns than stocks, according to some Wall Street professionals who follow the securities.
Investing in high-yield debt instruments, however, requires a practiced eye to assay whether the issuer will be capable of meeting the terms of the indenture, or legal contract between the borrowing company and the bondholders. The woeful experiences of the late 1980's, when many junk bond issuers filed for bankruptcy and countless investors paid dearly to learn why some bonds do not win investment grade ratings, should temper investors' enthusiasm for the higher yields that some of these bonds offer. 
 Nevertheless, the junk bond market may provide an investment opportunity, if certain guidelines are followed. Joseph Battipaglia, chief investment strategist of Gruntal & Company, suggests checking for these critical signposts:
*Assess whether the issuer's cash flow is sufficient to meet the bond's interest payment schedule.
*Scrutinize the call provisions to insure that the current price is sufficiently below that at which the issuer can redeem the bond prior to maturity.
*Gauge the total return -- the interest rate to maturity and, where applicable, the discount price of the bond.
"Applying these guidelines to high-yield investing can produce an enhanced return on investment while reducing risk," Mr. Battipaglia said. "And because many of these junk bonds trade at a discount to the underlying assets, there exists a tangible opportunity to purchase more investment value as compared to many stocks, whose prices remain relatively high."
In addition, Mr. Battipaglia pointed out, the junk bond market is currently averaging a yield of about 9.55 percent, a 300-basis-point, or three percentage points, spread over Treasury securities with a comparable maturity and 700 basis points, or seven percentage points, above the inflation rate.
Among the junk bond issues meeting Mr. Battipaglia standards are those offered by the Calenergy Company, the Revlon Worldwide Corporation and West Point Stevens Inc.
Calenergy, formerly the California Energy Company, was founded in 1971 and is a growing electric power company and the world's largest independent producer of geothermal power.
Mr. Battipaglia said about 35 percent of revenues and 58 percent of operating income were expected to come after 1997 from its Asian ventures, much of which are still under construction. He said he liked Calenergy's 9.875 percent senior notes due 2003, which are priced at 103 to yield 9.26 percent. The note are callable beginning June 20, 2000, at a price of 104.94.
The zero-coupon bond is also recommended. It converts to senior discount notes due 2004, and pays an interest rate of 10.25 percent starting Jan. 15, 1997. Callable as of Jan. 15, 1999, at a price of 105.125, the issue last traded on Friday for 103 for a yield of 9.66 percent. Both the senior and zero coupon are rated Ba-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BB by Standard & Poor's.
The Revlon holding company and its consumer products operating unit have four separate junk bond issues that Mr. Battipaglia terms "attractive" investments, Reviewing the operating company, he finds Revlon competing for market shares against larger international rivals, including Procter & Gamble, L'Oreal and Avon. Although highly leveraged, Revlon is "throwing off sufficient cash to manage debt," he said.
One of the debt issues he likes is Revlon's $260 million of 9.375 percent senior notes due 2001, currently trading at a price of 102 to yield 8.82 percent, and callable in 1998. The issue is rated B-2 by Moody's and B by S.& P.
West Point Stevens, a leading maker of bed and textile products, is benefiting from capital investments that have enabled it to become the industry's lowest-cost producer. In addition, its customers include large, high-volume merchandisers, like Wal-Mart, Kmart, J. C. Penney, Sears and Target, with the top seven accounts representing 43 percent of its $1.6 billion in 1995 sales.
Mr. Battipaglia recommends the company's 9.375 percent senior subordinated debentures due 2005, currently priced at 101.50 to yield 9.13 percent. Callable after Dec. 15, 1998, the debentures are rated B-2 by Moody's and B+ by S.& P.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE GOVERNORS;
North Carolina Incumbent Finds Recipe for Success

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBEMARLE, N.C.

 BODY:
He is a Democratic Governor from the South. Sensing shifts in the electorate, particularly after Republicans took control of the House in 1994, he has moved purposefully to the right. He now embraces tax cuts, time limits for welfare recipients and more prison time for violent felons, along with increased spending on education. He has alienated a few liberals, but they have nowhere else to go. And the polls show he is cruising toward re-election on Nov. 5.
Comparisons to Bill Clinton are anything but coincidental. Just as the President seems to have found a recipe for Democratic success on the national level, so is Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina demonstrating that Southern Democrats may yet be saved from extinction. 
 Despite serving for 12 years as a Democratic Governor in an increasingly Republican state, and despite being one of only three Democratic governors in the 11 states of the Old Confederacy, Mr. Hunt is one of the nation's most popular governors.
A poll of North Carolinians taken in July by a group of news organizations found that 86 percent held a favorable view of his performance, 87 percent admired his moral values and 91 percent liked his personality.
In Mr. Hunt's quest for a fourth term (he served from 1977 to 1985 and again from 1993 to the present), he held a mid-September lead of 26 percentage points over his Republican rival, State Representative Robin Hayes, according to a poll taken by Mason-Dixon Political/Media Research. The silver-haired Governor, who is 59, says this is his final race for elective office.
Mr. Hunt's political formula mixes conservative stands on welfare, taxes and crime with heavy government backing for children's programs, an avoidance of divisive social issues, a defiant stand against Mr. Clinton's call for strict regulation of tobacco, and an infectious, cheerleading style.
Mr. Hunt rejects the notion that his ideology has changed markedly since his first two terms, when he was considered slightly left of center.
He said, for example, that his decision to propose the largest tax cut in the state's history in late 1994 -- a $343 million reduction in personal and corporate income taxes -- was inspired not by that year's Republican takeover of the state House of Representatives, but by the state's economic prosperity. This year he has proposed additional cuts in the corporate income tax and the sales tax on food.
"Democrats ought to be willing to give people their money back when you have enough and can still do the things you need to do," he said in an interview while campaigning in the central part of the state.
But Mr. Hunt also suggests that his experiences as a corporate lawyer from 1985 to 1992 and his loss to Jesse Helms in their 1984 Senate race helped make him a more pragmatic politician.
"I may be more conservative, but the real issue is what are we doing?" he said. "And I think we're doing what needs to be done in North Carolina, what our people want us to do. I'm focusing on how you make things work. That doesn't necessarily fit the ideological test that a lot of people like to apply."
A number of governmental analysts in North Carolina say Mr. Hunt has moved astutely with the times.
"Like Bill Clinton, he's going where the voters are, or where he perceives them to be," said Thad L. Beyle, a political scientist at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
David Flaherty Sr., Mr. Hunt's Republican opponent in his first gubernatorial election, said he found Mr. Hunt to be more conservative and less partisan than in their 1976 campaign. A former chairman of the state Republican Party, Mr. Flaherty declined to say whether he would vote for Mr. Hunt this year, but said he would not campaign against him.
"When a man is doing all the things you expect and want of a Republican, how do you oppose him?" Mr. Flaherty asked.
Mr. Hayes has criticized the Governor for shifting positions, for failing to raise the state's low rankings in areas like teacher pay and scores on Scholastic Assessment Tests, and for presiding over increases in juvenile crime and teen-age drug use. But even Mr. Hayes's operatives find themselves complimenting Mr. Hunt's abilities, albeit left-handedly.
"He is a better politician than Bill Clinton," said Andrew Duke, a spokesman for the Hayes campaign, "and Bill Clinton's probably one of the best in terms of being able to find the middle and squeeze through it."
The Governor's campaign events highlight his new agenda. He began one recent day by opening a new prison near Vanceboro -- the number of state prison beds has increased to 28,111 from 18,925 since 1993 -- and then toured a middle school in Shallotte to emphasize school safety measures.
Last week, he helped open a job training center in Greensboro by ripping up a ceremonial welfare check. (His Work First initiative places a two-year limit on cash benefits and requires welfare recipients to get a job or job training within 12 weeks.)
From Greensboro, he traveled to Albemarle, where he visited a child care center financed by his $58 million Smart Start program, which seeks to provide education, health and nutrition services for low-income children in their first five years. A longtime authority on education, Mr. Hunt believes that government's inattention to children's early years has left them "destined to fail."
Even the Smart Start program, while Democratic in its instincts, is Republican in its structure. Like this year's Federal welfare law, it is essentially a block grant program that allows counties to spend money in a wide variety of ways to achieve its health and educational goals. Here in Stanly County, for example, county administrators have chosen to give subsidies to new parents so that mothers can stay home from work during a baby's first year.
"Not everybody would think that's the right thing to do," Mr. Hunt said. "The point is that they thought it was, and they're finding out it works."
On many social issues, the Governor seems more of a traditional Democrat. He supports abortion rights and affirmative action, for instance, but maintains that North Carolinians spend little time thinking about such matters.
Chris J. Fitzsimon, executive director of the Common Sense Foundation, a left-leaning policy group in Raleigh, said many liberals were disappointed that Mr. Hunt had cozied up to business rather than using his political capital to move the state in a more progressive direction.
But any alienation felt by the left is unlikely to have much political impact. "He's turned some people off," said State Representative H. M. (Mickey) Michaux Jr., a Durham Democrat, "but he hasn't turned them off enough to go for the other person."

HEADLINE: Powerful Bull Market Sends Dow To Its First Closing Above 6,000

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Continuing one of the most powerful market advances in history, the Dow Jones industrial average rose past 6,000 yesterday, closing up 40.62 points at 6,010.
The Dow, by far the most widely watched gauge of the market, has risen 154 percent in the just over six years since the current run began after prices bottomed on Oct. 11, 1990, during the 1990-91 recession. 
 The move owes much of its strength to increasing purchases of stocks, directly and through mutual funds, by individual investors concerned about having enough money for retirement.
And it reflects the prolonged economic cycle. The relatively slow growth of the cycle has been criticized by Bob Dole in the Presidential campaign, but it has gone over very well on Wall Street.
"We call it the Silly Putty cycle," said Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs. "It is stretched out because things are developing more slowly." As a result, she said, neither inflation nor recession has appeared to be a significant threat, and stock prices have continued to advance. She noted that corporate profits had risen substantially over the six years.
During that entire stretch, the Dow has never suffered a 10 percent decline. Not in the history of the Dow, which dates back 100 years, has the average moved up so much without such a drop. Nor has a bull market ever lasted so many years without such a setback.
The rising confidence has helped make doubles in the Dow come much more quickly than they used to. It took the market more than 16 years to double from 500 to 1,000, and then took more than 14 years to make it to 2,000. But the double to 4,000 took just over eight years. And the 6,000 mark was reached only five and a half years after the index first hit 3,000.
The final lift above 6,000 came on Columbus Day, a holiday for many, including the bond market. Volume was light by current stock market standards, but trading on the New York Stock Exchange still exceeded 300 million shares, a figure that would have seemed very high only a few years ago. That in itself is a measure of how vigorous the stock market has become.
The advance was widespread, with the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index and the Nasdaq composite index also setting records. But airline stocks were weak, in part because of rising oil prices, leading the Dow Jones transportation average to slip 17.84, to 2,058.05. Among the 30 stocks in the Dow industrials, the one that contributed most to yesterday's rise was Texaco, which rose 3 5/8, to 101 3/4.
Although major indexes are at records, the recent advance has been more selective than the rise earlier this year, before a downdraft in June and July scared some investors and led to a brief period of withdrawals from stock mutual funds.
"The market now is being pulled up by large-capitalization growth stocks," said David Shulman, the chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers. Most of the gain in the Nasdaq index has come from large companies like Intel, which traded at a record high yesterday, closing at 107 5/8, up 2 1/4. It gained several points in after-hours trading, as a result of strong earnings. On the other hand, Netscape, the leading Internet company, rose 3 7/8, to 44 7/8, but is trading for about half what if fetched last December.
The Russell 1,000 index, which includes the 1,000 largest companies in the country, ranked by the value of their stock, rose 1.65, to 375.02 yesterday, and is 3.5 percent above the peak it had set before the summer slip. But the Russell 2,000 index, which includes the next 2,000 stocks, is still 4.3 percent below its spring high, despite rising 1.11, to 349.
Since the last recession ended, in March 1991, traders have occasionally worried about excessive growth, which could ignite inflation, but those fears have always abated. The most recent concern led to widespread speculation that the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee would raise interest rates last month. But it did not, and since then there have been enough indications of weak growth that many no longer expect an increase after the election.
At the same time, the minority on Wall Street who fear an imminent recession -- and with that a plunge in corporate profits -- have gained few converts. The term "Goldilocks economy," neither too strong nor too weak, was coined in scorn by bearish analysts a few years ago, but seems to describe both how the economy has turned out, and how many investors expect it to continue.
The combination of strong financial markets and less-than-vigorous economic growth is not limited to the United States. "On the margin, the global economy is weakening," Ms. Cohen of Goldman, Sachs said. But British stocks hit a record yesterday, and German stocks are only a bit below the peak they reached last week.
The rise in American corporate profits in recent years has meant that the market does not appear to be exceptionally overvalued, when measured as a multiple of current profits, although it is near the upper end of historic ranges. For the moment, there is general confidence that profits will continue to grow for the rest of this year and into 1997.
Mr. Shulman of Salomon Brothers, who forecasts the Dow will get to 6,200 and the S.& P. 500 gauge to 720, up from yesterday's close of 703.54, cautioned that at that level it would be at about 18 times this year's profit levels. He said that the market peaked at 18 to 19 times profits in 1968, 1972 and 1987.
By some other valuation measures, stock prices long ago grew excessive. The dividend yield on the S.& P. 500 -- the income an investor would earn by buying all 500 stocks in the index if they did not go up or down in price over the next year -- is now 2.1 percent, a record low. By contrast, in 1987 the yield bottomed at 2.6 percent, which was then the lowest ever.
But such valuation measures have largely been discounted, with explanations that they no longer apply in an era in which companies can use excess money to buy back stocks, and by a widespread belief that the stock market is the only place to make long-term investments. Mutual funds saw record amounts of cash put into stock funds early this year, and while they have slowed a bit, they remain very high by historical standards.

HEADLINE: Moscow Sends Homeless To Faraway Hometowns

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Behind the iron gate, in a squat red-brick building with barred windows, Viktor Ryazanov sits imprisoned in Social Rehabilitation Center No. 2.
He is allowed to shower once every 10 days. At night, his toilet is a chipped ceramic pot shared with nine other men. For nearly a month, he has been locked in a dingy cell. And soon Mr. Ryazanov, a 47-year-old Russian laborer, will be deported from this city against his will. 
 He is not a criminal. He is a homeless man.
In a measure condemned by human rights advocates and applauded by local citizens, this city has begun to deport thousands of homeless people, rousting them from railway stations and vegetable markets, detaining them for up to 30 days without charge and loading them onto trains to distant villages where they grew up or were last registered as permanent residents.
President Boris N. Yeltsin and Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov have described the deportations as a potent weapon in the war on crime. But none of the 6,000 people deported so far have been charged with any wrongdoing, the police acknowledge.
Rather, the measure seems intended to clear the streets of poor Russians and immigrants from the former Soviet republics who have flooded the capital in a desperate, often futile, search for jobs and housing.
"We don't want our city to look like the streets of New York or the shantytowns of Latin America," Aleksandr V. Zolin, one of the Mayor's legal advisers, said in an interview.
"We're not saying there should be an iron curtain separating Moscow from the rest of the country, but we don't need homeless vagrants or beggars here," he said.
The police in Moscow estimate that 20,000 people, one-fifth the number in New York City, are homeless in this city of eight million. In Moscow, with hardly any shelters, most live on the streets. The debate over how to deal with them reflects Russia's struggle to cope with a social ill that has spread since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991.
The new, post-Communist Russian Constitution guarantees the right to freedom of movement and forbids detention without charge for more than 48 hours. And in the city's new policy, some rights advocates say they hear echoes of old Soviet decrees, which tried to close the capital to virtually all but the most politically connected newcomers.
"As a whole this contradicts our Constitution and our law," Vladimir A. Kartashkin, chairman of Mr. Yeltsin's Commission on Human Rights, said of the new policy. "This is a very serious issue."
Mr. Kartashkin said his commission would study the matter and present its findings to Mr. Yeltsin in a few months.
Undeterred by such criticism, city officials readily acknowledge that they are trying to close the city to the poor. "If people can afford to live here, they are welcome," Mr. Zolin said. "If they cannot, they should stay where they are. In our view, there is no freedom without financial means."
Mayor Luzhkov outlined the city's deportation policy seven weeks ago, after a decree from President Yeltsin gave city officials broad power to detain and deport the homeless.
The deportations, which have cost the city about $4.5 million so far, help ease the strain on its already overwhelmed transportation and social service network and protect the public from disease, Mr. Zolin said. He scoffed at the idea that the measures might be unconstitutional.
"Their idea of freedom of movement is the freedom to sleep in the streets," Mr. Zolin said, "and what kind of freedom is that?"
Some of the deported have managed to come back, the police say. But outraged human rights advocates say they may still carry their complaints to Russia's highest court.
"This is terrifying," said Sergei A. Kovalyov, a human rights advocate who is also a member of Parliament. "We are all children of the Soviet era, the Stalin era. We have seen deportations before. We must raise our voices against this."
But on the bustling streets here, there is little sympathy for the beggars huddling in subway stations, the vagabonds lurching past gleaming new shops and the wrinkled women pleading for rubles.
Some are alcoholics, ex-convicts or prostitutes. Some are old people who were swindled out of their homes when real estate was privatized, or immigrants whose dreams of a better life in the big city have crashed around them.
There are few homeless children in Moscow, and none have been deported, the police say. Ninety-three percent of the people forced to leave the city have been men, mostly between the ages of 30 and 60.
"They are lazy bums who make begging a way of living," said Larisa, 47, an engineer who was hurrying home from work and would not give her last name. "I work hard to get by. Why don't they?"
But Mr. Ryazanov, the grizzled man imprisoned in Social Rehabilitation Center No. 2, which is run by the police, said deportation would worsen his already precarious situation.
"In Moscow at least I have a job," said Mr. Ryazanov, who loaded vegetables in a local market before he was detained. There is little work in Frolovo, the town in southern Russia where he grew up and where he will soon return, he said.
"There I have no job, no family, no home," he said. "There I will be homeless and a thief. How else will I survive without stealing for food?"
It is not that homelessness did not exist during Soviet times, although fewer people slept on the streets then. But Communist leaders prided themselves on their country's guarantee of employment and housing for all. Homeless people who threatened that image were considered criminals.
Article 209 of the Soviet criminal code defined vagrancy as a crime punishable by at least one year in prison, the police say. That law, along with others restricting movement from the provinces to the city, helped prevent the homeless from surfacing in large numbers here.
But with the collapse of Communism, those laws were abolished. And as tens of thousands of people poured into the capital, fleeing ethnic strife or seeking economic opportunity, city officials found themselves unprepared to deal with the growing population of street people.
Today, New York City has 25,000 government-provided shelter beds, a number that homeless advocates consider woefully inadequate. Moscow has 25.
"We need more shelters," said Vladimir L. Bychkovsky, who runs Social Rehabilitation Center No. 2. "We'd like to do more for these people, but we can't. We have to send them to the streets."
By the end of 1997, city officials hope to have more than 800 beds. But those will be reserved for the homeless from Moscow, who are detained but not deported.
Outsiders -- even Russians from other cities -- will continue to be shipped out unless they are granted permanent residency here, a privilege reserved for the very lucky or the very rich.
Temporary permits are available for vacations or studies or medical treatment. But the only people from outside who are allowed to live here permanently, city officials say, are those who can persuade a Muscovite to give up his or her home -- in effect swap residences -- or those who can afford to buy an apartment here, which cost anywhere from $10,000 to $150,000.
Human rights advocates say this, too, is unconstitutional. These requirements prevent most average Russians, who earn about $100 a month, from living legally in the nation's capital.
Without a permanent residency stamp in the internal passports that all Russians carry, most people are barred from finding on-the-books jobs, from renting government-subsidized apartments, from attending public schools and from receiving free, routine medical care, city officials say.
"Without this stamp, they're entitled to nothing," said Siobhan Keegan, an Irishwoman who is the medical coordinator of Doctors Without Borders, the international relief organization that treats the homeless here. "The lucky ones find temporary work. The rest, they beg."
Social Rehabilitation Center No. 2, one of 12 detention centers, holds 100 people in 10 small cells that smell of unwashed bodies and steamed cabbage.
The homeless are detained and deported, but rarely rehabilitated, Mr. Bychkovsky said. The police buy tickets and load the prisoners on the train. Some accompany the homeless to their destinations. Others do not.
In either case, the homeless people usually return to a life without homes, without steady work and with dim prospects of finding either.
"We, the police, we can't solve this problem," Mr. Bychkovsky said. "Half the people we send out find their way back. Poor people will always come to Moscow, because it's easier for them to find jobs here."
Mr. Ryazanov came to Moscow and found off-the-books work in the vegetable markets. Rashid Safin of Nizhny Novgorod in central Russia and Viktor Sosnovsky from Ukraine found work building country houses. They slept in gardens, under bridges, in alleys before they were detained. Soon they will be sent home.
So they listened jealously as Vitaly Mladchenkov, 28, an ex-convict, told his story. He is from Moscow, so he can live legally in this city and is entitled to a shelter bed and subsidized housing.
But entitlements mean little these days. More than 20 million Russians wait on city lists for housing, officials say. Mr. Mladchenkov says he slept on the street for three years while he waited for an apartment. And since the city's 25-bed shelter is usually full, he doubts that he will find a spot there either.
"So when I get out of here," he asked, "where will I go?"
No one said anything, not the homeless men sitting next to him, nor the watchmen guarding the door.
Mr. Mladchenkov shrugged. He knew the answer. They all knew the answer. "I will live in the street again," he said matter-of-factly. "We will all live in the street again."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chrysler Earnings Top Forecasts, Lifting Auto Stocks

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation reported third-quarter earnings today that were considerably above analysts' expectations, as ever more Americans have been choosing sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks, which have high profit margins, over cars. The report produced a broad rally in auto stocks.
The shift toward light trucks and away from cars, on which auto makers are offering larger rebates and other sales incentives, helped Chrysler earn $680 million, or 93 cents a share, on sales of $14.4 billion. 
 Analysts had predicted that Chrysler would earn 71 cents a share, according to a survey by First Call. In the corresponding quarter a year earlier, Chrysler earned $354 million, or 45 cents a share, on sales of $12 billion.
Investors responded by bidding up the shares of not only Chrysler, which rose $1, to $32.75, but also of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company. G.M. stock rose $1.75, to $51.875, and Ford stock closed at $32.875, up 87.5 cents.
"All the autos are up as a result of Chrysler," said Kenneth A. Blaschke, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. "The Street is a little more optimistic about Ford and G.M.'s earnings potential."
David B. Healy, an auto analyst with Burnham Securities Inc., agreed. "The market is expecting some pleasant surprises from Ford and G.M. as well," he said, cautioning, however, "I wouldn't bet the ranch on it."
G.M., which had lackluster sales in the third quarter, is expected to report its earnings on Tuesday. Analysts are expecting earnings of 75 cents a share. Ford is due to release earnings on Wednesday, and analysts expect it to earn 52 cents a share, according to First Call.
In response to Chrysler's report, several analysts raised their full-year earnings estimates for the company. Mr. Healy raised his 1996 earnings estimate to $5 a share from $4.65. Mr. Blaschke raised his estimate to $5.14 from $4.74 for 1996, and his estimate for next year to $5 a share from $4.25.
Chrysler's earnings in the third quarter included a one-time, after-tax charge of $55 million to pay for early retirement buyouts for 576 salaried employees in the United States and Canada, said Gary C. Valade, Chrysler's chief financial officer.
Analysts were hard pressed to find any bad news in the company's report. Their only offering was that Chrysler's current strength could beget future weakness. More than other auto makers, Chrysler has profited as buyers have traded in their cars for mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickups.
Chrysler officials said that next year they would be able to build 190,000 more utility vehicles and pickups than this year. The company is adding a new utility vehicle for the 1998 model year, called the Dodge Durango. But other auto makers are also scrambling to build more trucks, a trend that analysts worry could create a glut.
As Chrysler's fortunes have improved in the United States, the company has started to look further afield. More than Ford and G.M., Chrysler has traditionally focused on selling its cars and trucks in North America, but it is increasingly looking abroad for sales and production.
In the last two months, it has announced plans to build a pickup truck assembly plant and an engine factory in Brazil, to set up a vehicle distribution subsidiary in South Korea and to open a regional headquarters in Singapore for Southeast Asian operations.
Chrysler has also set aside a nest egg to help it get through the next economic downturn. The cash hoard for Chrysler's automotive division had grown to $7.5 billion by the end of September, while it stood at $6.4 billion a year earlier.
That could signal a higher dividend soon. In response to the hostile takeover bid last year by Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor, Chrysler promised to raise dividends or buy back additional stock when its auto-related reserves reached more than $7.5 billion.
Chrysler also announced that as a result of the pact it reached with Mr. Kerkorian in February it had bought back $452 million of its stock in the third quarter. It expects to buy back another $400 million in the fourth quarter, bringing its buyback total for the year to $2 billion, Mr. Valade said. It has promised to buy back $1 billion more in 1997.
Chrysler also had good news today on its labor relations. It said the United Automobile Workers union had ratified a three-year labor contract with Chrysler, with 73 percent of workers voting in favor.
Chrysler has also reached a labor pact with the Canadian Automobile Workers, but G.M. faces a 12-day-old strike by 26,000 of its Canadian workers. Because of ripple effects from the strike, G.M. announced today that it had laid off 1,350 workers from the second shift at a Cadillac factory here and 1,661 workers at 11 parts factories in the United States and Mexico.
