HEADLINE: As Zoning Debate Rages, Giant Stores Settle In

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
New York City is engaged in a great civics debate about whether to revise its zoning rules to encourage the development of big-box superstores like those in the suburbs. The stakes, both sides say, involve everything from the character of neighborhoods to the city's ability to set its own economic agenda.
Real life, meanwhile, has not waited. The big boxes are here. The arrival of Kmart in Manhattan is a case in point. 
 The second largest retailer in the nation after Wal-Mart and a crown prince of big-box style, Kmart waltzed into Manhattan for the first time early this month, opening the first of two giant stores. Because the stores are in commercial retail zones, they are opening without being subjected to a public hearing, let alone a review of what impact more than 280,000 square feet of new discount retail trade might have on the city's business or residential environment.
In Queens and parts of Brooklyn and the Bronx, the large-format invasion is even more pronounced. Altogether, more than two million square feet of new shopping space has opened there in the 1990's or is now under construction. Home Depot and Toys 'R' Us, in particular, have used loopholes in the existing zoning law to build giant stores in areas zoned for manufacturing.
So what gives here? The answer, in a word, is the market: the business niches and the chinks and loopholes of the old law are fueling a retail invasion, even as politicians debate how to direct the city's retail destiny.
The growth in retailing has become a part of the debate itself. While opponents contend that loosening development rules will wreck neighborhoods and shatter small businesses, city officials say the growth underlines the need for revisions in the zoning code. Existing restrictions, especially in the old manufacturing zones, are being twisted and distorted, they say, with some businesses forced into legal contortions to fit loopholes while others are frozen out entirely.
"The clear signal is that the market wants to come in, and where you provide opportunities, it comes," Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission, said. "But it's a very confusing climate. Right now you have a whole segment of stores that are not regulated at all, or not regulated appropriately, and some that are completely barred, and it makes no sense."
For the last two years, the Giuliani administration has pushed a rezoning proposal -- now being revised by the City Planning Commission in preparation for a vote in the next two weeks -- that would allow more retailers in the city's old manufacturing areas, large tracts of which were abandoned by industry over the last two decades. The plan would allow stores in many cases to open "as of right," meaning without special permits or community approvals.
The zoning code was last revised in 1974, when New York's economy appeared to be teetering on the edge of the abyss and manufacturers were fleeing the city. The code was changed to prohibit large stores from manufacturing zones because it was felt that those retail uses would pay higher rents that would drive out factories. But among the loopholes that have allowed stores to rush in is the fact that hardware, stationery and toy stores are allowed, even as they have grown to supersize in the modern format of a Home Depot, Staples or Toys 'R' Us.
Opponents of the rezoning proposal say that the Planning Commission and the administration have winked at the exploitation of loopholes, then used it to further their argument that the code must be changed.
"The reason a Home Depot is able to open is that the city wants the store and so it tortures itself into thinking it's a hardware store, when it's certainly more than that," said Stephen DiBrienza, a Democrat City Council member from Brooklyn. "And the reason there's a Staples is that they twist themselves into thinking it's a stationery store, when it's more than that. You can't be lax in the categorizing of stores, then say that because some exist and some don't, it's a good reason to do a massive revision under the guise of making it more uniform."
Adding to the confusion is disagreement over what the laws are about in the first place: the city may see zoning as a lever to encourage development, but some believe that it should be a brake, used to preserve and protect neighborhoods.
Preservation-minded residents around the new lower Manhattan Kmart say that neighborhoods like theirs are being forgotten as the city focuses on manufacturing zones. Kmart -- already open at 34th Street and Pennsylvania Station and opening next month on Broadway between Eighth and Ninth Streets -- chose to locate in commercial retailing zones, which do not require community review.
The store, to open in mid-November, will be housed in a building with a venerable retailing history -- from the late 1890's through the 1950's, it was home to Wanamaker's, and was one of the anchors of a 20-block shopping strip called Ladies Mile, which extended from Union Square to Herald Square. Some residents say the neighborhood is no longer suitable for giant retailing. Today, it is a mix of residences, businesses and manufacturers, but the high-density commercial zoning -- an echo of the Wanamaker's days, and thus amenable to a 140,000-square-foot Kmart -- remains.
Leaders of the local block association say they had one meeting, last month, with Kmart officials, who answered questions for about two and a half hours.
"We have been left out of the process," said Arlene S. Koenig, the president of the East Eighth-Ninth Street Block Association. City Hall has sent a signal that New York is open to these types of stores, Ms. Koenig said, setting off a kind of land rush. "It sets an atmosphere where businesses can come in regardless of the impact," she said.
Jesse Masyr, a lawyer who represents Kmart and Home Depot, said he does not believe retailers are rushing in before a City Council vote potentially changes the rules to a more level playing field for all retailers. But he said that by aggressively pushing the idea of rezoning, the Giuliani administration has sent a clear message that has not been lost on his clients. "It was a positive signal to my clients about the administration and its feeling toward large-scale retail users," he said. "If it fails, the loser is the city."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map: "A CLOSER LOOK: Superstores Keep on Coming" shows locations where superstores have recently opened throughout New York City. (Source: New York Department of City Planning)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE SENATE;
Four Western Senate Races Are Too Close to Call

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 11

 BODY:
The West, land of wide-open spaces, is also the land of wide-open Congressional races this fall, especially races that could help decide which party ends up in control of the Senate.
Within the 13-state region, where issues like the environment and gun control can be as important to many voters as the economy and health care, four of the seven Senate contests to be decided on Nov. 5 appear too volatile to call. 
 Poll takers and political experts say that here in Oregon, as well as in Colorado, Wyoming and Idaho, only a few points separate the candidates and that the dynamics of each race could easily change as money and resources are poured in, not just by the candidates but increasingly by outside interests like the national political parties, labor unions and environmental groups.
"There's still a lot of play in a number of Western contests, and a lot could happen over the next three weeks," said Stuart Rothenberg, editor of The Rothenberg Political Report, a nonpartisan newsletter that monitors Congressional elections.
Three races are notably volatile because the incumbents -- Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, Hank Brown of Colorado and Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming -- all Republicans, are retiring.
In Idaho, the incumbent, Larry E. Craig, a freshman Republican, has run afoul of environmentalists and is struggling a bit in a state that his party usually takes for granted.
In two races, the Republican incumbents -- Ted Stevens of Alaska and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico -- face no serious opposition.
In another, the incumbent, Max Baucus of Montana, a Democrat, seems assured of re-election after trimming his ideological sails a bit and spending copiously to fend off a concerted Republican campaign to paint him as one of the most liberal legislators in the country.
The Republicans control the Senate, 53 to 47, with 34 seats being contested this fall. If Democrats can hold their own and pick off as few as three Republican seats -- and they think they might get some in the West -- they will regain control, providing Vice President Al Gore hangs onto his job, which carries the power to break Senate ties.
The race here in Oregon, as wide open as any in the West this fall, pits the President of the State Senate, Gordon Smith, a conservative Republican with a knack for legislative consensus, against Tom Bruggere, a mainstream Democrat who made a fortune in computer software and is making his first elective bid.
Earlier this year, Mr. Smith, who is 44 and has made millions in the food-processing business, almost won a special election to replace Senator Bob Packwood, the Republican who resigned after he was accused of sexual misconduct. Given the visibility gained in that earlier race, along with the high visibility he enjoys as Oregon's highest ranking State Senator, Mr. Smith probably has an advantage over Mr. Bruggere in name recognition.
But Mr. Bruggere, 50, can offset that somewhat through a small Democratic edge in Oregon in party registration and also, he hopes, by hitching a ride on the coattails of President Clinton, who is running very strongly here.
The contest sounds ideologically like what it is: a conservative Republican who opposes gun controls and believes in a free market economy and fiscal restraint versus a mainstream Democrat who favors abortion rights and believes government should play a large role in helping the needy and the aged.
"My opponent is your classic, extremist Democratic liberal," Mr. Smith said at a Rotarian luncheon the other day in Salem, the state capital. "He believes big government should run your life."
Mr. Bruggere, speaking the next day in East Portland at another Rotarian luncheon, countered that his opponent had a "callous concern" for Oregonians and argued that "government isn't the enemy when it isn't overbearing."
Most of Mr. Smith's support can be found in rural areas, especially along the eastern side of the Cascade Range, where Republicans have long predominated. Mr. Bruggere's strength, by contrast, lies mainly in the state's urban enclaves, especially in the northwest in Portland, the biggest population center and long a Democratic stronghold.
But ultimately, political experts say, the race could be decided by the 20 percent of the Oregon electorate that is independent, particularly those living in and around Portland.
Mr. Smith has recently been trimming his conservative sails to try to win over those voters, who tend to be moderate, generally with a strong interest in protecting Oregon's reputation as one of the nation's most environmentally sensitive states.
Mr. Bruggere, sensing an opening, has accused his opponent of being a polluter, noting that the Smith family's frozen-food company has been cited for runoff violations. And a number of national environmental groups, among them the League of Conservation Voters, have run radio and television advertisements that portray Mr. Smith as environmentally insensitive.
Mr. Smith has countered by asserting that Mr. Bruggere is a tool of radical environmental groups.
The National Republican Senatorial Committee, which plans to spend at least $10 million for television and radio advertisements in contests around the country, has made the race here a target, as well as those in Colorado and Wyoming.
The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee says it plans a similar campaign in many of the same states. But its last finance report indicated that it had only $5 million to spend, and thus far none of its advertisements have shown up here or elsewhere in the region.
Throughout the fall, most polls have rated the Smith-Bruggere race a tossup, with Mr. Smith and Mr. Bruggere alternately ahead, though seldom by more than five points.
"This race should go down to the wire," Tim Hibbitts, a leading Portland pollster, said the other day.
The Colorado race is also a tossup between a conservative Republican, Representative Wayne Allard, who represents the state's eastern quarter in Congress, and a moderate Democrat, Tom Strickland, a Denver lawyer.
Mr. Strickland has long been an active member of the state's powerful environmental movement, which has given him a base of support. But the Rocky Mountain state, with most of its residents now living in and around booming Denver, is also a pro-growth state in many ways, and Mr. Allard, who has frequently voted in Washington to ease environmental requirements, has much support in that part of the voter spectrum.
What is more, the Congressman has thoroughly embarrassed Mr. Strickland politically by uncovering a number of instances where, as a lawyer, Mr. Strickland represented clients caught up in pollution suits.
In Wyoming, normally a safe state for Republicans, the closeness of the Senate contest is a surprise.
The Democratic candidate, former Secretary of State Kathy Karpan, has managed to stay within half a dozen or so points of her Republican opponent, State Senator Mike Enzi of Gillette, by portraying herself as a moderate on environmental issues, especially on land use, and by portraying Mr. Enzi as too closely allied with the religious right. She has also run an advertisement in which she toted a shotgun to underscore her opposition to gun control.
"She'd be a Republican in most states," said Larry Hubbell, a political scientist at the University of Wyoming.
In one of its most concentrated advertising campaigns against a Democrat running for the Senate, the National Republican Senatorial Committee has broadcast numerous spots showing Ms. Karpan standing next to President Clinton. She has countered with an advertisement that shows her holding a pair of hip waders to be used to make her way through "Republican mud."
In Idaho, as in Wyoming, the Republican, Senator Craig, should be an easy favorite, given that Idaho is one of the nation's most Republican states. But this being a 1996 contest in the West, his Democratic opponent, Walt Minnick, a businessman who in a previous political incarnation was an aide in the Nixon White House, has thus far managed to stay almost within striking distance by repeatedly reminding voters that Mr. Craig once supported a Federal plan to store nuclear waste out in Idaho's wilderness.
In the remaining three Senate races in the West, while neither Senator Stevens of Alaska nor Senator Domenici of New Mexico has been seriously challenged, Mr. Baucus of Montana was given a bit of a scare early in the year.
With plenty of help from Washington, again from the National Republican Senatorial Committee, Mr. Baucus's opponent, Lieut. Gov. Dennis Rehberg, narrowed the race by painting the Senator as just about the most liberal legislator in Washington. But then Mr. Baucus countered, using his incumbency to raise a multimillion-dollar war chest and pointedly adopting some ideologically moderate positions, including support for a balanced budget and welfare overhaul.
The latest polls show him out front by a dozen points.

HEADLINE: A Drug and Sports Scandal Swirls Near Argentine Chief

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 14

 BODY:
When his re-election campaign was slipping last year, President Carlos Saul Menem called on his good friend, the soccer star Diego Maradona, for an endorsement.
Maradona, the international soccer star whose appeal with voters is undiminished by his repeated brushes with drug charges, gladly agreed. The two appeared together in campaign advertisements and at rallies, and Mr. Menem won the election by a large margin. 
 Today, however, Maradona is a friend whom Mr. Menem probably could do without. The world-renowned soccer player and his associates are enmeshed in a drug scandal that threatens to taint the Pink House, the presidential palace where Maradona and his friends were frequent guests.
So far, neither Mr. Menem nor anyone in his administration has been directly linked with the scandal, but his close association with those involved has prompted new questions about the integrity of the President among a populace that had grown accustomed to his socializing with international celebrities and the Buenos Aires jet set.
At the center of the scandal is Maradona's manager, Guillermo Coppola, who was arrested on drug charges last week after police uncovered more than 500 grams of cocaine in a large vase in his apartment.
Mr. Coppola, a well-known sports agent who has been linked to organized crime, is a close friend of the President's private secretary, Ramon Hernandez.
Maradona and Mr. Coppola were at the presidential palace the night of Mr. Menem's re-election victory party in May 1995, and the two were present to console the President when his son Carlitos died in a helicopter accident last year.
Judge Hernan Bernasconi, who is handling the Coppola case, said Mr. Coppola was a notorious drug trafficker, and Gregory Phillips, head of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration's office in Argentina, told local news agencies that Mr. Coppola is on the agency's list of drug traffickers.
Since his arrest last week, Mr. Coppola, who has said he is "totally innocent," has dominated local television and newspaper coverage, while Government officials have tried to play down any connection between the sports agent and the President.
Vice President Carlos Corach said there were no links between Mr. Coppola and top Government officials, and Raul Delgado, the President's spokesman, said: "There has been no discussion of the Coppola case, nor any worry. Nor should there be."
But Mr. Coppola and Mr. Hernandez were often photographed together at trendy night spots, and Mr. Menem's adult children, Zulemita and Carlitos, often sat with Mr. Coppola at his table in his popular disco.
Political analysts said that the scandal had greatly damaged Mr. Menem's image and that the President was upset, mainly because it comes at a time when his popularity is at an all-time low and he is trying to recapture political leadership by attacking corruption.
On Friday, television stations showed Maradona pushing through crowds of reporters and onlookers as he tried to visit Mr. Coppola in jail. Unable to get through the crowds, a weeping Maradona, who recently admitted that he is addicted to cocaine, gave up and went home.
Many soccer fans blame Maradona's drug habit on Mr. Coppola, who was charged with dealing cocaine to his teammates when Maradona played for Napoli in the Italian league. The charges were later dropped.
The Coppola case is not the first time that people close to Mr. Menem have been associated with the drug trade. In 1991, Amira Yoma, the President's sister-in-law and appointments secretary, was one of several Government officials indicted on drug-related money-laundering charges.
Although a judge later dismissed the charges for lack of evidence, the scandal shook the Menem Government, forcing those involved to leave their posts.
Manuel Mora y Araujo, a leading pollster, said that depending on the outcome, the scandal could further erode Mr. Menem's approval rating, which is currently at 18 percent.
"People are waiting to see if Coppola will go trial and be convicted, or if this is just a scam," Mr. Mora y Araujo said.
Juan Pablo Baylac, a Congressman from the opposition Radical Party, even went so far as to say the drug scandal had been concocted by the Government as "smoke screen" to hide Argentina's recession, unemployment, and labor unrest that Mr. Menem is struggling to resolve.
"Even if Coppola has close links to the President, we're not talking about major international drug organizations," the politican said. "You can't imagine Pablo Escobar leaving 500 grams of cocaine inside a flower base at his apartment for the police to find. It's like a bad third-rate narco movie."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
Two Approaches to Repairing Cities

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
When Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp skirmished during last week's debate, Mr. Kemp accused the Democrats of not doing enough to improve the plight of American cities. Mr. Gore said the Democrats had done plenty.
With a volley of statistics, the Vice-Presidential candidates seemed to contradict each other, leaving listeners to wonder what they were talking about. 
 At the heart of the exchange was not so much a difference in numbers as it was a difference in philosophy about how to regenerate depressed urban areas.
Stated simply, Mr. Kemp advocates making tax incentives available to any business willing to move into a Federally designated depressed area. His is a free-enterprise approach that envisions little government involvement and assumes that neighborhoods will improve naturally as commerce takes root.
Mr. Gore and the Clinton Administration like tax incentives, too, but they say government should be more involved, first by tying tax breaks to the hiring of workers from the depressed area. And they say tax breaks are not enough. They want the Federal Government to provide grants to help communities near the new businesses in various ways, including job training programs to improve the labor pool.
"The approach combines the best of all present and past theories," said Andrew Cuomo, the assistant secretary for economic development at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. "A business isn't going to move into Harlem just for the tax breaks. The neighborhood has to be safe and there has to be a trained work force."
In the Republican view, that approach involves too much meddling by the government, particularly in doling out grants, said John C. Weicher, who was a top aide to Mr. Kemp when he was the HUD Secretary. "I don't think the Federal Government should be running around deciding who is the best qualified person in New York or any neighborhood," Mr. Weicher said. "You leave those decisions to people with money of their own at risk."
The Clinton-Gore program was, in large part, borrowed from Mr. Kemp, who proposed in 1980 that "enterprise zones" be created in decimated urban and rural areas. The zones, which would offer tax advantages to businesses, had been tried with some success in Britain.
But the Republicans were never able to get the proposal enacted. A somewhat different proposal finally made it through Congress and was signed by President Clinton in 1993. The Democrats had changed the name to "empowerment zones" and had added grants and social programs. The legislation authorized the creation of only six urban and three rural empowerment zones, in contrast to the 300 zones that had been proposed by Mr. Kemp.
In the debate, Mr. Kemp said the Administration had "abandoned the inner cities."
"There's a socialist economy," he added. "There's no private housing. It's mostly public housing." He complained that there were only nine empowerment zones and "a few little tinkering with tax credits around the country for inner cities."
Mr. Gore defended the Administration, saying that it had created 105 "empowerment zones and enterprise communities around the country."
In fact, a Federal panel chose six cities as empowerment zones in December 1994 from among dozens of competitors. Three rural zones were also designated. To appease the losers, the Administration created 95 "enterprise communities," 65 urban and 30 rural areas that received $3 million grants and smaller packages of tax incentives.
The cities named as empowerment zones were New York, Chicago, Baltimore, Atlanta, Detroit and Philadelphia-Camden, N.J.. Each received $100 million in grants and the right to $250 million in tax incentives for businesses over 10 years.
There is little data yet available to demonstrate whether the program will work. Democrats say anecdotal evidence is positive. Republicans are skeptical.
Some of the cities, like New York, have had trouble getting started, largely because of local politics and rivalries. In New York, the program was delayed for more than a year and nearly died in a bitter dispute between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki, who was involved because the grant money is passed to the states from the Federal Government. Also, some civic leaders in Harlem voiced reservations because it would bring outside businesses -- particularly businesses that might not be black-owned -- into the neighborhood.
New York's zone includes part of upper Manhattan and part of the lower Bronx. The board for the Manhattan section has received more than 180 applications, from local businesses to the Gap, the national clothing retailer. The Bronx section is still in early stages of organization.
A number of cities and states created economic zones in the past, using only tax incentives, but the results have been mixed at best, Mr. Cuomo said.
"We think we took the best lessons from enterprise zones, improved upon them and added the elements that were lacking," he said. "We learned from the shortcomings and linked the tax incentives to hiring within the zone."
A business that moves into the area and hires local residents can deduct $3,000 from its annual tax bill for each local employee. The grants would help pay for local infrastructure improvements and for security to make the areas more attractive.
The aid package also contains incentives for construction of low-income housing, a provision squarely at odds with the Kemp approach.
"The last thing some of these areas need is more low-income housing," said Mr. Weicher, now a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, a moderately conservative research group. Further, he said, the incentive to hire employees from the zone may be impractical, because many blighted urban areas are lightly populated. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (79%); 

COMPANY: CLINTON ADMINISTRATION (80%);

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Travelers Earnings Increased 23% in Quarter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Travelers Group Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose 23 percent in the third quarter as profits surged from its Smith Barney brokerage unit and property and casualty insurance businesses.
For the quarter, the company earned $591.8 million, or $1.18 a share, up from $481.4 million, or 96 cents a share, a year earlier. All figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May. 
 The results were sharply higher than Wall Street's estimates of $1.09 a share, according to a survey of analysts by Zacks Investment Research. Shares of Travelers surged $1.125, to $53, on the Big Board.
The most recent quarter included a $15 million gain from the sale of investments, while the 1995 quarter included a $32.1 million gain from investment sales. Travelers' revenue in the quarter rose to $5.62 billion from $4.51 billion.
Travelers joins other finance companies benefiting from a surging stock market, low interest rates and a record year so far for corporate mergers that helped bolster investment banking profits over last year.
"It seems to be a pretty good report over all," said Ken Menke, senior equity manager for the Florida State Board of Administration, which held 1.07 million Travelers shares in June.
Travelers said earnings at Smith Barney, the second-largest retail brokerage firm in the United States, behind Merrill Lynch & Company, rose to $208.7 million, from $177.9 million a year earlier.
Travelers' total life insurance earnings rose to $159.1 million, from $126.5 million a year earlier. Property and casualty earnings from its 82 percent stake in Travelers/Aetna Property Casualty increased to $201.8 million from $106.7 million, on a rise in insurance sales.
Travelers Group formed Travelers/Aetna by merging its property and casualty insurance subsidiary with Aetna's unit that insures homes, autos and businesses. The combined insurer, based in Hartford, began trading publicly in April.
Travelers/Aetna also reported results yesterday, The company earned $247 million, or 62 cents a share. Revenue totaled $2.46 billion. The company's insurance operations excluding Aetna recorded a profit of $109.9 million, or 37 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
Primerica Financial Services' profit rose to $67.7 million from $57.8 million. Consumer finance fell to $54.1 million from $65.3 million a year earlier primarily because of higher loan losses.
Travelers' chairman and chief executive, Sanford I. Weill, said, "Smith Barney demonstrated earnings strength in the quarter, despite the traditionally slower summer months for the securities industry."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Average Tops 6,000, Continuing Six-Year Surge
Continuing one of the most powerful market advances in history, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at more than 6,000 points for the first time, surging 40.62 points to 6,010.
It has risen 154 percent in the six years since the current run began, thanks both to stepped-up stock purchases by individual investors saving for retirement and to the prolonged slow-growth economic cycle. [Page A1.]
 
Archer Daniels to Plead Guilty
Archer Daniels Midland has agreed to plead guilty to conspiring with competitors to fix the prices of two agricultural commodities and pay $100 million in fines. The fines are by far the largest ever obtained by the Government in a criminal price-fixing case. [A1.]
 
AT&T Close to Naming President
AT&T may announce a new president as early as tomorrow. C. Michael Armstrong, chief executive of Hughes Electronics, is the leading candidate, several people with knowledge of the search said. [D5.]
 
Acura Switching Ad Agencies
Acura has dismissed its longtime agency, Ketchum Advertising, and awarded its $125 million account to Suissa Miller, according to people familiar with the decision. [D8.]
 
Chrysler Earnings Are Strong
Chrysler reported third-quarter earnings of $680 million, or 93 cents a share, on sales of $14.4 billion. [D4.]
 
An Anxious Day at Goldman, Sachs
Goldman, Sachs is expected to name the firm's first managing directors today. But while the 115 people who get the new title will be receiving a promotion, only 35 to 40 of them will make partner. [D10.]
 
Pfizer Earnings Climb 22.7%
Pfizer earnings rose 22.7 percent, to $514 million on surging sales of newer drugs. [D4.]
 
Flavored Six-Packs of Stolichnaya
Carillon Importers, the marketer of Stolichnaya vodka, is seeking to battle back in the vodka wars -- now being won overwhelmingly by Absolut, the Swedish brand that the company once imported -- with the simultaneous introduction of six more flavored versions of Stolichnaya. The Stoli six-pack is being pitched together in a $5 million campaign by Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners in New York.
Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D8.]
 
TRW Plans Job Cuts
TRW plans to cut 2,300 jobs and take a $233.4 million charge to improve competitiveness in its automotive business. [D4.]
 
Motorola to Build Satellite Network
Motorola plans to build a $6.1 billion satellite network, called M-Star, that can send voice, video and data to companies worldwide. [D10.]

NEW YORK
 
Crush Is On for Yankees Tickets
Billy Crystal got World Series tickets, but as a famous Yankee fan who served as master of ceremonies for the unveiling of Mickey Mantle's monument, he had connections. A scalper named Willie managed to get eight bleacher seats. But for many others, it was no sure thing. It was, predictably, a ragged, hectic scene in the Bronx as tickets for up to four World Series games to be held in New York went on sale at 9 A.M., instantly becoming the most valuable currency in town. [Page B1.]
 
Questions in Officer's Death
An off-duty police officer who was fatally shot on a Brooklyn street Sunday night may have been conducting an unauthorized hunt for someone who mugged his friend, officials said, and two of his fellow officers were suspended for their role in the incident and the subsequent investigation. Brian Jones, 27, a four-year veteran housing officer assigned to lower Manhattan, was shot in the back of the head -- most likely by a fellow officer -- during a gun battle in East New York. Police officials said they had arrested Antoine Windley, 25, of Long Island City, Queens, in the incident. [B1.]
 
Crew Survives Freshman Year
For Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, who arrived in New York City a year ago talking passionately of the need for a campaign like the civil rights movement to improve public schools, it has been a sobering year. After a freshman hazing that only New York can offer, Dr. Crew concedes that his achievements have been modest, but says that just surviving the first year has been no mean feat. [B1.]
 
The Aftermath of a Verdict
Few felt their hearts sink more than Nathaniel and Mary Gaines when Police Officer Francis X. Livoti was acquitted in the choking death of Anthony Baez. When a Bronx judge set Officer Livoti free, the Gaineses could not help asking what now lay ahead for them. Their son, Nathaniel Gaines Jr., was fatally shot in the back on a subway platform last July by a transit officer who was later charged with manslaughter. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Scrutiny for Union Dissidents
A few weeks after Cecile Clue, a subway conductor, began urging other transit workers to sign a petition to recall their union president, Damaso Seda, she was dismissed. But an arbitration board reinstated her, with full back pay, using words like preposterous to describe the charges against her. Ms. Clue is a leader of New Directions, a hard-line dissident group in the 32,000-member Transport Workers Union Local 100, and she is one of many prominent members of her faction who have had to fend off disciplinary actions. [B3.]
 
Blue Skies for Columbus Parade
The unexpected summery weather, with a high of 74 degrees in Central Park, was a gift from nature for thousands of Columbus Day Parade-goers along Fifth Avenue. [B3.]
 
A Bus James Bond Might Love
Engineers have unveiled something new for the daily traffic battles on city streets: a prototype bus that uses cold-war-era technologies developed by the Pentagon. The vehicle is made of structural materials similar to those used in Stealth bombers and may incorporate the electronic suspension that allows Army tanks to fire accurately while racing across rough terrain at 40 miles per hour. New York City is hoping to bring a test model here, although there is no formal agreement yet to do so. [B4.]
 
Kmart Ushers In a New Era
New York City is engaged in a great civics debate about whether to revise its zoning rules to encourage the development of big-box superstores like those in the suburbs. The stakes, both sides say, involve everything from the character of neighborhoods to the city's ability to set its own economic agenda. Real life, meanwhile, has not waited. The arrival of Kmart in Manhattan is a case in point. [B7.]
 
The Surprise of Times Square
Times Square and 42d Street are turning into one of the hottest entertainment and shopping zones of any downtown in the United States. But what is most remarkable about this area is that it bears no resemblance at all to the scenarios laid out by planners, civic activists and politicians for most of the last two decades. The Arts. [C11.]

When Vice President Gore and Jack Kemp skirmished in their debate over the plight of American cities, citing a volley of statistics, they seemed to contradict each other, leaving listeners to wonder what they were talking about. HEADLINE: Torricelli Accepts 'L' Word, But Also Says He's Moderate

SERIES: NEW JERSEY'S SENATE RACE -- Tomorrow: Richard A. Zimmer.

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., Oct. 14

 BODY:
New Jersey needs a senator who will work for a balanced budget while protecting Government programs that help the state the most, Representative Robert G. Torricelli said today in an extensive interview that detailed the case he has been trying to make to voters in the race for the open Senate seat in New Jersey.
Attacked as "liberal to a T" by commercials for his Republican opponent, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, Mr. Torricelli agreed that he supports liberal positions on some issues, like abortion, the environment and gun control. But he called himself moderate on other issues, including immigration. He spoke in favor of continued Federal benefits for needy legal immigrants, but said he favored excluding the children of illegal immigrants from public schools. 
 Referring to his view of the role of government as "the real philosophical difference" between himself and his Republican opponent, Mr. Torricelli said that both of them favored a balanced Federal budget, but that the choice for New Jersey voters was to decide which candidate they trusted to remain fair as deficits were reduced.
"I believe in a strong government activist role, but it is a limited role," said Mr. Torricelli, who met for more than 90 minutes today with editors and reporters of The New York Times.
"In my mind, the role of the United States Government in this economy is to insure that the work force is educated and trained, that there's a modern and efficient infrastructure, that the cost of capital is kept low, and then, get out of the way."
Mr. Torricelli, a seven-term Congressman from Englewood, took aim at Mr. Zimmer for supporting many of the Federal spending reductions included in House Speaker Newt Gingrich's Contract With America. "People simply need to know the price of becoming this self-proclaimed deficit hawk," Mr. Torricelli said.
Mr. Zimmer, who during three terms in Congress has attempted to blend socially moderate views with a passion for cutting taxes and spending, met with editors and reporters later in the day in New York, and an article on that interview is scheduled to appear on Wednesday.
Seeming relaxed and confident, Mr. Torricelli threw his jacket over the back of his chair and chewed on a large muffin between explanations of why he thinks his positions on issues like Medicare, education, the environment and crime will appeal more to New Jersey's middle-of-the-road voters.
Politics have become too complex for a candidate to be unequivocally liberal, moderate or conservative, he said. He said that Mr. Zimmer's portrayal of him in television advertisements as "foolishly liberal" was not swaying voters.
"It's so simplistic and so absurd," Mr. Torricelli said. "It's not working."
Staking out what he said were moderate views on immigration, Mr. Torricelli criticized the limits on food stamps and other benefits for legal immigrants that are included in the new welfare law and said he would work in the next Congress to restore those benefits.
Mr. Torricelli added that public support of illegal immigrants, on jobs, health care and education, was too much of a lure and needed to be restricted. He said the current ban on work by illegal immigrants was ignored so often it "has no meaning."
In explaining his position against benefits, including public schooling, for illegal immigrants, Mr. Torricelli said: "The point is that at some point you've got to draw the line. This can't go on. We have up to a million illegal immigrants coming to the United States every year. It's estimated in Texas and California, 25 percent of local taxes are going to educate or provide health care for illegal immigrants. It can't be maintained."
The contest between Mr. Zimmer and Mr. Torricelli has received widespread attention, not only because it is one of 14 races for open Senate seats around the country, but also because of its extensive use of negative television advertising. .
A man known for his keen political instincts, Mr. Torricelli said he had been unaware of the bruising nature of a Senate race when he decided to pursue the seat opened up by the retirement of Senator Bill Bradley.
"I'm not a person who is usually associated with being naive," he said with a grin. "But I guess I was."
He said that much of the television advertising by his opponent has been based on misleading information, but he denied that his campaign had engaged in such tactics. "There is almost no issue on which half-truths can't be distorted," Mr. Torricelli said.
Mr. Torricelli said he would refuse to criticize Mr. Zimmer on anything other than his legislative record. "I'm going to get elected to the U.S. Senate, but I'm going to keep my dignity," he said.
But minutes later, Mr. Torricelli indicated that he planned to criticize the tone of Mr. Zimmer's advertisements. "I have bet this campaign on the fact that Mr. Zimmer's outrageous personal attacks against me will rebound to my benefit," he said.
As Representatives from New Jersey, where taxes have historically been high and recently, voters have rebelled against their high levels, Mr. Torricelli and Mr. Zimmer have both voted in favor of a balanced budget amendment and cuts in capital gains taxes. Mr. Torricelli's support for such programs, however, has been more recent than Mr. Zimmer's.
Mr. Torricelli said he supported Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's reduction in the state income tax, but he said he agrees with critics of the cuts, who now assert that property taxes are going up as a result. "My concern is that the state has only engaged in an income tax shift," he said.
The Congressman also criticized the Republican Governor's proposal to equalize spending and educational standards among poor and wealthy school districts in the state.
"I think the goal is to raise the floor to insure that every child is reaching some minimally accepted standard of education," Mr. Torricelli said.
"Somehow, that has been reinterpreted to put a ceiling on the quality of education that school districts want to meet in some of our suburban areas. The common denominator is being lowered, rather than simply lifting those who are not getting the quality of education."
A legislator known for sometimes taking views contrary to his party's leadership, Mr. Torricelli also criticized some aspects of President Clinton's budget plan. He said the administration had not done enough to end subsidies that encourage the use of public land for grazing and mining. "The ability of people to rape the natural resources of the United States without paying a fair price to the taxpayers is outrageous," he said.
A member of the House Committee on Intelligence, Mr. Torricelli also took shots at a familiar target when he condemned the level of spending on the Central Intelligence Agency and other intelligence agencies. "It's out of control," he said. "It's unnecessary and it is extraordinary duplication, and enormous savings that are possible."
Asked if he thought his criticism of the C.I.A. had led the agency to try to provide his opponent with information intended to hurt his campaign, Mr. Torricelli responded, "I'm not going to comment on that."
The candidate defended the role he played 10 years ago in helping the daughter of a fugitive from a Federal investigation, Harvard Jee, a South Korean businessman who had fled the country. He said he never thought to explore the whereabouts of Mr. Jee and he did not think that his decision to assume responsibility for the 15-year-old girl was anything extraordinary.
"I cannot believe that anybody thinks because this child's father had legal problems, that she shouldn't have been deserving of help," he said. "She was abandoned by her family."
Mr. Torricelli attempted to reverse the criticism that the Jee case has prompted from Mr. Zimmer, whose campaign has called for a Federal investigation into Mr. Torricelli's relationship with Mr. Jee.
He said Mr. Zimmer "has now made clear that having gotten the same call, about the same 15-year-old girl who was not attending school and had no place to live, he would not have offered his assistance," he said.
"I did," Mr. Zimmer said.

HEADLINE: For Clinton and Dole, A Nobel-Level Query

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In honor of William Vickrey, who had just three days to savor his Nobel Prize in Economics before his death (front page, Oct. 12), President Clinton and Bob Dole should be asked in the Oct. 16 debate to reply to one of Vickrey's most critical (if counter intuitive) insights: that "the insane pursuit of the holy grail of a balanced budget in the end is going to drive the economy into a depression." 
 The seven times in history when our nation's budget was "balanced" (the last under Herbert Hoover) brought on depressions. As Vickrey wrote, "If households and businesses had been held to balancing their budgets in the manner proposed for the Federal Government, there would be no mortgages, no bank loans, no corporate bonds and many fewer houses, telephones and automobiles." His deep concern was that our society has sacrificed basic needs like social welfare in the name of a principle that makes no economic sense.
The candidates for President should explain why it is acceptable for us to borrow to make our futures better but our Government refuses to borrow to insure a brighter tomorrow for us all.
 
ANDREW HUMM
New York, Oct. 12, 1996

HEADLINE: A Thriving Fundamentalist Congregation Feels Most Comfortable in the Mainstream

SERIES: An American Place: More Prayers Than Politics.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 14

 BODY:
"In 1976 I prayed on it and felt that God would have me start a church," said the Rev. Joel Cochran, who at the time was a 28-year-old associate pastor for a conservative Akron congregation. So he returned to his home in nearby rural, northern Stark County, a place just beginning to suburbanize, and started going door to door.
"I'd say, 'Hello, my name is Joel Cochran and I'm with a group of people interested in starting a new, independent Christian church.' And I'd get these blank stares." He got 16 adults and 5 children to the first meeting. They held Sunday services at a local public school auditorium for three years. 
 The young pastor had little children, but was gone every night, making home visits to build a following. "It was self-exploitive," he said, "but my wife was willing. We had no choice, it was sink or swim. After three years we were established. We had 200 members. We could acquire real estate."
They bought five acres of Earl Day's farm along state road 619 for $15,000 and erected a modest church of 12,000 square feet, the Chapel in Marlboro. The new sanctuary held 350. Mr. Cochran stressed Bible study weekly, he started a youth program to appeal to young suburban families moving in and worked to broaden himself, reading three newspapers daily, two newsmagazines a week and two books each month. He practiced a moderate fundamentalism, condemning abortion and homosexuality, while accepting Halloween and Rotary.
By the mid-1980's he was running two Sunday services. Still, he felt there was more to do. "We just couldn't get above 470 on Sundays," he said. "We couldn't take it up to the next notch. I thought about it and prayed about it and realized if we could just build a new sanctuary." In the next few years, the church raised $1.2 million and in 1991 dedicated a 14,000-square-foot addition, featuring a handsome, airy sanctuary with a nave of walnut and red oak pews that can hold 1,250.
Today the Chapel in Marlboro is one of Stark's fastest growing churches. Its members tend to be conservative Republicans, part of the Christian Coalition constituency. These suburbanites are fueling the expansion of Stark's biggest churches and the Chapel is not the most dramatic example. In less than a decade, Canton Christian Fellowship, an independent charismatic church sitting on a hilltop overlooking Belden Village mall, has grown from a handful of organizers to nearly 1,500 members.
At the same time, mainline denominations are fighting to hold their people here. Membership at the Church of the Savior United Methodist in downtown Canton, where President William McKinley worshiped, has been shrinking and now stands at 370.
Because the Christian Coalition has emerged as such a formidable force in the national Republican Party and because politics is the principal context the media uses when reporting on these churches, there is a tendency for outsiders to think of their pastors as political activists. That is not so in Stark County. While religious leaders have strongly held conservative values that they seek to spread, and that their members search out, these pastors also know that being too political can undermine a congregation's growth.
Abortion is a good example. Mr. Cochran, who is 47, will forcefully make his view against abortion known through his biblical teaching, but he does not carry it into the political arena. He leaves it to his members to bring politics to the church and then sets limits, because, as one of his assistant pastors said repeatedly at a recent Sunday service, "Church is a place to put your daily life behind, a time for you and the Lord."
In late September, when National Right to Life Committee members were lobbying Congress to outlaw a late-term procedure they call "partial-birth abortion," one of the Chapel's worshipers, Sarah McGuire, who belongs to a local Right to Life chapter, asked Mr. Cochran for permission to distribute leaflets at church. Mr. Cochran agreed. "We put the leaflets in our adult Sunday school classes and asked the teachers to mention they were available," he said. "We did not put them in the sanctuary, we did not hand them out -- that would have gone over the line."
A week ago, when a group called Life Chain staged an anti-abortion protest vigil nationwide, including at several sites in Stark, there was no mention of it at the Chapel. "I was aware of it," Mr. Cochran said. "But no one from the church mentioned it to me, and it's not my place to take the initiative."

Politics
Conservative Beliefs, But No Partisanship
Too much politics, Mr. Cochran knows, divides people and that is the last thing he wants members to feel on Sundays. His top two priorities are to spread Christ's word and grow his church, which now has five pastors, owns 52 acres and must raise $11,458.19 a week at the offering to meet its budget. "If I don't have to, I don't want to alienate people," he said. "If a person believes Bill Clinton is wonderful and I say he's not, I've lost the opportunity to tell him the most important message of all, that Christ loves him."
Jennifer Hubbell considered joining the Chapel. She was impressed with Mr. Cochran's intellect, she loved the youth program -- she has three children and a fourth on the way -- and enjoyed the warmth of the Sunday services. "It's a very vibrant church, you leave feeling so good about the beliefs you hold," she said. But the Hubbells did not join, in part because she felt a bit out of step with the church's conservative values, calling it "a little too fundamentalist for me." While Mrs. Hubbell, a Republican, does not personally believe in abortion, she says she favors giving women a choice. "I'm fortunate to have a husband who supports me," she said, "but I'm not poor and I understand that things can be different for someone not as lucky as I am."
Abortion is something Mr. Cochran feels he cannot be silent on, but Presidential politics is different. And so, while Mr. Cochran's members assume he supports Bob Dole, they are not sure. As Paul Eldridge, a longtime worshiper says, "Joel doesn't get into the politics a big lot. I'd guess he's voting for Dole, but I don't know it."
While there is a small Christian Coalition chapter in Stark of lay people from these churches, it meets just a few times a year and its main task is providing the Coalition's national voters' guide to churches at election time.

The Pastor
God's Word Matters, And So Does Joel's
There are many reasons more important than politics that bring so many to the Chapel in Marlboro each Sunday. They come because it is a "Bible church" that emphasizes Scriptural readings and they enjoy the way Mr. Cochran supplements these lessons with an impressive knowledge of current events that comes from reading The Wall Street Journal daily, Newsweek and U.S. News and World Report.
They like that he has a fundamentalist interpretation, but does not claim to speak for God. "He has humor and humility about it," Mr. Eldridge said. "He'll give his view, then say, 'Thus spoke Joel Cochran.' "
They notice his attention to detail. Brian Pol, a businessman, and his wife, Sheila, a nurse, are the church's newest members. "Our second Sunday we visited," said Mr. Pol, "Joel says, 'Good morning Brian, good morning Ashley, good morning Sheila' -- he has 1,000 members!"
Mr. Cochran works at knowing names. "When there's a new family, I pray for them all week and as I pray I envision them," he said. "Then when I see them, the name pops back. It's a discipline. But much of the Christian life is a discipline."
Rita Burke has belonged to more rural fundamentalist churches that have a sour view of much of the secular life. She was a little uneasy one morning as she took her boys out of Sunday school class early so they could get to an Indians-Tigers game. "Joel saw us leaving and he was so sweet," she said, "he was talking to the boys about the Tigers."
They come to the Chapel because of its flourishing youth program, which attracts 200 boys and girls every Wednesday night and is so well-run, even townspeople who do not belong send their children. The Awana program, a Christian version of Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts, complete with uniforms, is particularly popular. Instead of merit badges, children wear small plastic crowns on their chests. They earn red plastic jewels for these crowns when they memorize Bible verses, green jewels for doing chores at home, blue jewels for attendance.
The kindergarten through second graders are Sparks (Sparks for Jesus) and each week earn bonus Sparky Bucks to be redeemed for toys at the church store. When jewels were handed out on a recent Wednesday, Andrew Conner, a new boy, said to 6-year-old Ben Mihalik, "You can get jewels for making your bed? I didn't know that."

Theology
They're Confident, But Not Overbearing
They come because it is a young, independent, self-made and prospering church and they are upwardly mobile, middle-class suburbanites, Christians like Jeff Burke, a salesman at Terry's Tire Town who plays electric guitar with the Chapel's choir. "I like being around successful people on Sundays," he said.
And they come because they have conservative values, and get confidence from Mr. Cochran that those values will prevail. These are realistic people in many respects. They know this election does not look good for the candidate whose values most of them share, Mr. Dole. After the Vice-Presidential debate the other night, Mr. Pol said, "Gore won by far," and Mr. Burke said, "Did Kemp get his butt kicked or what?"
"I don't think we're going to get it," said Mr. Burke, who supports Mr. Dole because of his stand on abortion, his tax plan and "the kind of person he is." He thinks Americans are being lulled by a good economy. "It's like the Bible says, 'Their God is their stomach.' "
But they take Christ's life to heart and are quite sure they will win in the long run. The Chapel in Marlboro is one of a half-dozen flourishing offshoots in Ohio of the Chapel in Akron, which holds five services each Sunday, attracting 10,000 members.
When Mrs. McGuire gets discouraged that the political movement to ban abortion is stalling, she shifts her effort to a local crisis pregnancy center where she works to persuade one young woman at a time to save the baby for adoption.
They see themselves helping shape a conservative era that has forced a Democratic President most of them do not trust to announce the end of big government, to retreat on homosexuals in the military and oppose gay marriages, to sign a welfare bill that will scale back entitlements and emphasize self-reliance.
On a recent Sunday, Mr. Cochran used the weekly Bible reading, Genesis 19, Lot's life in Sodom, to discuss the President's signing of the Defense of Marriage Act, which bars Federal recognition of same-sex marriages. Mr. Cochran focused on aspects that the church's young families could relate to. He said what a relief it is that they will not have to explain to their children, and their public schools will not have to teach, that homosexual and heterosexual marriages have equal standing.
In an interview later, Mr. Cochran said when dealing with such matters, he takes guidance from St. Augustine. "He said we must always love the sinner and always hate the sin."
During his 20 years as pastor, Mr. Cochran has had one man confide about having homosexual urges. They spoke about two dozen times by phone over 18 months. "I said to him, 'Feelings you may not be able to help, but behavior you can. So let's focus on behavior.' " The pastor discussed the importance of self-discipline and recommended a Christian counseling group. "I told him, 'Your feelings will change as your behavior changes.' I've been around long enough," said Mr. Cochran, "to believe over time, the feelings will change."
Living midway between Democratic Cleveland and Republican Columbus, the citizens of Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County have a history of voting for the winning Presidential candidate. This is the 30th article in a yearlong series that seeks to explore the forces shaping the political debate at the grass roots. (Previous articles are available to computer users on The New York Times on the Web, at http://www.nytimes.com/specials/canton.)

CORRECTION-DATE: October 19, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about the Chapel in Marlboro, a fundamentalist church in Canton, Ohio, misstated the size of the membership of another church in the city. Membership and weekly attendance at the Savior United Methodist Church in downtown Canton have been shrinking, but since the early 1990's the membership has declined from 1,103 to 987 members, not 370. Average Sunday attendance has declined from 420 to 370 in the same period.

HEADLINE: Journal;
To Thine Own Self Be True

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
At 73, Bob Dole is a little long in the tooth to play Hamlet.
But there he was in New Jersey over the weekend, trying out his latest to-be-or-not-to-be soliloquy. "Should I get tougher on Clinton?" he asked the crowd. "You won't get mad at me if I get a little tougher?" 
 By yesterday, after 24 hours of further vacillation, Mr. Dole had firmly decided that he would take off the gloves in tonight's debate (though the word "firmly" must always be used with caution in proximity to either Presidential candidate). Now he must confront Bill Clinton in the most inhospitable debate forum for fisticuffs -- a town-hall meeting where he'll be surrounded by 120 "real people." And he must do so on a night less than three weeks before Election Day in a year when the debates thus far have failed to draw audiences anywhere near as large as those of '92.
How did Mr. Dole paint himself into this corner? Conventional wisdom blames the press for intimidating him into silence until now by threatening to shout "Hatchet man!" the moment he "goes negative." But raising serious questions about Clinton Administration ethics, phrased precisely and respectfully, is not the same as railing about "Democrat wars" or crying "Liberal!" or invoking Paula Jones. The obvious questions Mr. Dole might ask tonight -- whether about the rifling of F.B.I. files, potential pardons for the McDougals or an influence-seeking Indonesian campaign contributor -- have been aired daily by the press itself. If Mr. Dole had articulately raised some of them weeks ago, he wouldn't so easily fit the Clinton/Gore playbook's current description of him as "desperate."
By being so indecisive about how to act on the Clinton character issue, Mr. Dole has not only given the President a free pass, he has dramatized a big character issue of his own. Mr. Dole's habit of equivocating and reversing himself has been a damaging pattern of his candidacy from the start on a variety of fronts, not just on the matter of challenging White House ethics. He's visibly wavered so often that his leadership capabilities are as much in doubt as who hired Craig Livingstone.
During the primaries, Mr. Dole waffled about how to go after Pat Buchanan's extremist views much as he has waffled about challenging Mr. Clinton, refusing even to criticize Mr. Buchanan for his anti-Semitic rhetoric. When Mr. Dole's campaign officials made the embarrassing gaffe of returning a $1,000 contribution from the gay Log Cabin Republicans, the candidate dawdled for months before finally chastising his own errant staff. On abortion, he has quickly retreated under fire on nearly every stand he has taken this year, including his "not negotiable" call for a tolerance plank in the G.O.P. platform. Most self-destructively of all, Mr. Dole abruptly reversed his career-long stands in favor of affirmative action and against supply-side economics to prove himself, as he put it, "another Ronald Reagan, if that's what you want."
This recent history helps explain why so many Americans don't regard Mr. Dole as a leader, but as a split-the-difference Beltway legislative mechanic. If he can't stand up to fellow Republicans, not to mention his Democratic opponent, how will he stand up to a Saddam Hussein? If he can't command his own campaign, how can he run the country? Even his own conservative allies now raise the Dole character issue -- as typified by last week's Charles Kraut hammer column faulting Mr. Dole for lacking the "political courage" to match his "physical courage" of 50 years ago.
Mr. Dole's character failings hardly cancel out his opponent's, but they are devastating to his hopes of presenting himself as a plausible Presidential alternative. His equivocations, reversals and avoidance of confrontations fuel the polls in which voters doubt he is tough enough to push through a 15 percent tax cut and balance the budget at the same time. Dole admirers, by contrast, point out how appealing it is to find a politician who honestly expresses his ambivalence in public rather than sticking to a phony, robotic script. That's true enough. But while Hamlets can be appealing, their chances of inheriting the White House are by definition no more likely than their ascent to the Danish throne.

HEADLINE: More Insurers Balk on Breast Reconstruction

BYLINE: By SUSAN GILBERT 

 BODY:
LAST January, on the day before Mary McKilligan was scheduled to have the second phase of breast reconstruction after a mastectomy, her insurance company told her that it would not pay for the operation. Although coverage had been approved several weeks earlier, the company, United Community Health Plan in Latham, N.Y., said it was reversing its decision on the ground that the procedure was cosmetic and therefore not medically necessary.
It took eight months of phone calling and letter writing for Ms. McKilligan, her surgeon and her lawyer, they said, to convince the insurance company that the operation was essential to restoring her appearance to what it was before her cancer surgery. Ms. McKilligan, 58, a social worker in Endicott, N.Y., is scheduled to have the reconstructive procedure on Oct. 21. 
 "If she hadn't pushed, and if my staff and I hadn't pushed, this wouldn't have been covered," said Dr. Lawrence Kerr, her plastic surgeon in Binghamton, N.Y.
She is not alone, according to the surgeons who do breast reconstruction surgery. In a survey of 2,000 surgeons around the country conducted by the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons in June, 84 percent said they had had as many as 10 breast cancer patients who were denied coverage for breast reconstruction in the previous year. In recent interviews, several surgeons confirmed they had run into problems with reimbursement, saying that the problem had grown worse in recent years as insurance companies had become more cost-conscious. And they say that they are seeing denials from managed care plans as well as the traditional fee-for-service health plans.
"If we asked an insurance company in 1990 for permission to do a breast reconstruction procedure, they'd say, fine," said Dr. James Hoehn, a plastic surgeon in Albany. "All that's turned around now. We're having more problems getting breast reconstruction approved."
Dr. Garry Brody, president of the society, said the situation was worse for breast reconstruction than for other kinds of reconstructive surgery. "No insurance company would deny reconstructive surgery for an ear or nose that is lost due to cancer," he said. "There's something about the breast that they resist."
"It's probably economic," he added. "There's a lot more breast cancer than ear cancer." Breast reconstruction can easily cost $10,000 or more for the initial procedure and from several hundred dollars to several thousand dollars for each follow-up operation, surgeons say.
Richard Coorsh, a spokesman for the Health Insurance Association of America, said he did not know for sure about insurance policies on breast reconstruction because the association had not surveyed itsmembers about them. But, he said, "It's my sense that in most cases there is reimbursement for breast reconstruction and that it's not viewed as a cosmetic procedure."
The list of more than 100 insurance companies identified by the survey as having denied or restricted coverage for breast reconstruction reads like a Who's Who of the insurance industry. It includes Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New Jersey, Aetna, Cigna, Travelers, Metlife and Sanus (now NYLCare, a division of the New York Life Insurance Company).
"Our policy varies from state to state, depending on the regulations," said Dr. Samuel Wartburton, chief medical officer for NYLCare Health Plans in New York. "Reconstructive surgery is usually covered, but not all the time."
Dr. Harriett Steinert, regional vice president of medical care for Cigna Healthcare of the Tristate Region, could not explain why Cigna was named a dozen times in the survey. "Cigna pays for all of the reconstructive procedures," she said. "I have to wonder, could there have been a mistake?"
One problem confronting women with breast cancer is the varying interpretation of which surgical procedures fall under the category of breast reconstruction. The American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons states that reconstruction can involve several operations, depending on the patient's needs and choices.
The initial operation to form a new breast is done either by inserting a prosthesis of silicone or saline beneath the skin or by transplanting tissue and muscle from the abdomen and back. Another operation is usually performed to construct a nipple.
Breast reconstruction may also entail surgery to reduce the size of the healthy breast in order to make the breasts look symmetrical. Surgeons say that this is the only option if the reconstructed breast cannot be made large enough.
Dr. Andrew Kleinman, a plastic surgeon in New Rochelle, N.Y., said he recently had a breast cancer patient whose insurance company refused to pay for an initial reconstructive operation that was performed immediately after her mastectomy. It was not until Dr. Kleinman threatened to file a complaint with the state insurance commissioner and a state senator that the company agreed to cover the procedure. He declined to identify the managed care company involved because he was afraid that it would drop him from the plan.
The survey found that most of the problems with coverage involved secondary operations for breast reconstruction. Women were denied coverage for these procedures even if they lived in states where coverage for breast reconstruction was mandatory.
Thirteen states require insurance companies to pay for breast reconstruction, but only two, Maine and Maryland, specify that this must include the various secondary procedures, including reduction of the healthy breast. In the remaining 11 states, it is up to the insurance companies to decide which kinds of surgery are reconstructive and which are not.
In New York, which has no law requiring insurance companies to pay for breast reconstruction, several surgeons said that insurers used to cover the various secondary procedures. "In the past, they were not questioned," said Dr. Richard Sleeper, a plastic surgeon in New Hartford, N.Y. "Now, insurance companies consider them cosmetic."
To Mary McKilligan, her planned breast reduction operation has nothing to do with vanity. The implant that was put in after her mastectomy in February 1995 created a new breast that was much smaller than the other one. Her doctor had told her ahead of time that this would be the case and that she would need to have the healthy breast reduced in order to have a normal appearance.
"It was part of the original plan," she said. "If I had thought I wouldn't be able to have the breast reduction, I wouldn't have the implant in the first place."
In the end, she convinced her insurance company to do more than just pay for her breast reduction. Community Health Plan has just rewritten its policy to include reduction of the healthy breast as part of breast reconstruction after mastectomy.
"We were not being as sensitive as we should have been to the patients," said Dr. Jerry Salkowe, medical director for Community Health Plan's Upstate New York region. "If you're going to cover reconstruction after surgery, it should give patient the maximum benefit. Other insurance companies should do what we're doing."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Revise Its Estimate Of Layoffs

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Acknowledging a flaw in a key statistic in the debate over economic insecurity, the Labor Department said today that it would revise upward its tabulation of the number of layoffs in the mid-1990's after an academic researcher found a problem with the Government's figures.
The department's Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated in August that 8.4 million people had left their jobs involuntarily from 1993 through 1995, 7 percent less than the 9 million people found to have been permanently laid off in the bureau's previous analysis covering 1991 through 1993. The two surveys, based on responses from 50,000 households questioned by the Census Bureau in February 1994 and February 1996, overlap for the year 1993. 
 The figures appeared to show that the strong job creation and steady economic growth of the last few years had helped ameliorate the problem of job displacement, even as the nation grappled with feelings of economic anxiety.
But Henry Farber, a labor economist at Princeton University, has found an anomaly buried in the data that raises questions about the accuracy of the figures. Mr. Farber discovered that the proportion of people who did not respond to the most recent survey was far higher, at about 9 percent, than for the previous survey, which had a nonresponse rate of about 1.8 percent.
Mr. Farber informed the B.L.S., which agreed that it had made a mistake. To make the two most recent surveys comparable, the bureau said it would adjust the layoff figures for both of them.
Thomas Nardone, a supervising economist at the bureau, said today that the new figures were still being calculated, but that the revised layoff figure for the most recent survey would be higher. Mr. Farber said that the new numbers should show that layoffs in the most recent period were equal to or even slightly higher than during the previous period.
"It does look like job losses are going up," Mr. Farber said. "The anecdotal evidence we've been getting about this is now being supported by the data."
Mr. Nardone said the bureau had considered whether it needed to adjust for nonrespondents but decided not to do so in the mistaken belief that the percentage of nonrespondents had been the same in both surveys.
"We're being very careful in checking the numbers this time," Mr. Nardone said. "We feel it's very important, since these data are used so much."
The recalculation, which Mr. Nardone said should be complete before Election Day, would seem to weaken the Clinton Administration's argument that the worst of the job losses are over. And it could give more ammunition to the President's Republican challenger, Bob Dole, who has built his campaign around the argument that an underperforming economy is shortchanging most people. Mr. Dole's economic advisers had pointed out that although the layoff figures for the last few years were down, they were still high for this point in the economic cycle, compared with previous recoveries.
The threat of losing a job continues to worry many Americans, despite a general mood of economic optimism, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, conducted from Thursday through Sunday. Twenty-seven percent of respondents said they were very concerned that they or someone in their households might lose a job over the next two or three years. Twenty-nine percent said they were somewhat concerned, and 43 percent said they were not at all concerned.
But the poll also found that 67 percent of respondents felt very or somewhat economically secure, with 32 percent saying they were somewhat or very insecure.
The poll, of 1,438 adults nationwide, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

HEADLINE: On Homeless, Moscow Takes Cue From West

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Moscow Sends Homeless to Faraway Hometowns" (front page, Oct. 15): Who could stifle outrage at Moscow's deportation of its homeless? But who would expect less?
Given Moscow's former nomen klatura, who snapped up homes during the city's massive privatization, and given the soaring unemployment and poverty exacerbated by International Monetary Fund and World Bank policies, the deportation of 6,000 do-nothings seems minor. 
 In defense of Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov's plan, United States policy toward illegal immigrants seems different only in scale.
If other rich nations do it, why not fence out a Russian sea of rural destitution from an (envisaged) Muscovite island of metropolitan opulence?
In fact, Moscow could raise some desperately needed foreign exchange by inviting House Speaker Newt Gingrich, Gov. Pete Wilson of California and their French counterparts, for example, for a seminar on how to keep those pesky immigrants/homeless from snatching our jobs, public housing, public schools and Medicare.
Long live Mayor Luzhkov! Vive le roi!
 
ANDERSCORR
San Francisco, Oct. 15, 1996
 
The writer is the author of articles on the worldwide squatters' movement.
