HEADLINE: PLAYOFFS;
Yankees Pitchers Take Swings as Strawberry Sits

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
Darryl Strawberry looked groggy and sounded concerned as he limped out of the shower yesterday, the big toe on his right foot heavily wrapped. His teammates had just completed a three-hour workout at Yankee Stadium, but Strawberry missed it because he was lying on a trainer's table.
Although the Yankees called the injury a bruise and said Strawberry would be ready to play in Game 1 of the World Series on Saturday night, the player offered a bleaker prognosis. Strawberry hobbled gingerly on his right foot and is anxiously awaiting more medical tests and more X-rays to be administered today. 
 "I kind of got a feeling it may be broken," he said. "That's what it feels like. I've had a broken toe before. It's not going to stop me from playing. I'll tape it up."
So Strawberry's terrible toe was the big news as the American League champion Yankees returned to baseball after one day of celebration and relaxation.
It was a strange scene: Kenny Rogers, Andy Pettitte and Ramiro Mendoza all poked more homers than the idle Strawberry as the pitchers took batting practice -- swinging practice, really -- to ready themselves for the World Series to be played in either Atlanta or St. Louis. No designated hitter will be used in the National League city, so Manager Joe Torre will have rusty pitchers flailing bats and either Cecil Fielder or Tino Martinez in the dugout.
Torre added to the intrigue yesterday by claiming that he prefers a four-man rotation and then suggesting that Rogers could be replaced by Brian Boehringer or Mendoza as the Game 4 starter if Rogers's inflamed left shoulder hampers him. Huh? As disappointing as Rogers has been in the post-season, with a 10.80 earned run average in two starts, going with one of the rookies in the World Series would be a risky move that could open Torre up to a torrent of criticism.
"It was a disappointment because I just don't think he's right," Torre said of Rogers's three-inning outing in Game 4 of the A.L.C.S. against Baltimore. "He looked out of whack physically. He's having trouble getting his arm up to where his release point should be. I was more concerned watching him the other day."
Torre expressed more optimism about Strawberry, who solidified his status as the left fielder with three homers in the last two games of the A.L.C.S.. But Strawberry fouled a 3-2 pitch off his right toe in the sixth inning of Game 5, felt pain immediately and said, "I knew something wasn't right." The Yankees will monitor's Strawberry toe and watch the calendar to see whether he will be on the roster and whether he will start over Tim Raines.
"If he can't play and he's not healthy, he won't be on the roster," Torre said. "I don't see that happening. I have played with a broken thumb. The whole thing is being able to function. As long as he can do what he can do, he'll be out there."
Surprisingly, Strawberry, who would be appearing in his first World Series since 1986, when he played for the Mets' championship team, was not depressed.
"If it gets better, that's great," Strawberry said of his toe. "If it doesn't and I don't play, then that's fine, too. We've got enough players to pick up the pace. I've got to be positive and see if I can help the team."
Despite his honesty and humility, Strawberry was not tossing in the socks on his season.
"Even with a broken toe, things can work out," he said. "You can tape it up. You can do things. I'm able to do things. With just a little bit of pain, I'm able to swing."
So can the Braves and the Cardinals, but Torre declined to set his rotation for the World Series. Since Torre spoke of the Cardinals as being more of a right-handed-hitting team and the Braves as being more of a left-handed-hitting club, the manager may have been hinting that he will start David Cone in Game 1 against St. Louis, but Andy Pettitte against Atlanta. The 24-year-old Pettitte, who is younger and more economical with his pitches, is the more viable candidate to pitch three times in the Series. But Torre supposedly favors a four-man rotation.
Rogers said he has no physical problems, feels fine and "just struggled" in his two post-season starts in allowing 6 earned runs and 10 hits. As long as he is healthy, Torre said, Rogers will be on the roster as a starter or reliever. If his toe does not stop him, Strawberry will be there, too.
"Heck, yeah, I want to start a game," Rogers said. "I'm capable of more than I'm doing. The last thing I want to do is hurt the team. I contributed to this, whether people want to believe that or not. I know I got one good one left in me."
 
INSIDE PITCH
One team official said the Yankees told their scouting and player development staff members that the team would not pay for them to attend any World Series games in New York or on the road. They can purchase their own tickets if they wish, but the Yankees will not provide room and board. Most teams that reach the Series treat their employees to the games, but the Yankee owner GEORGE STEINBRENNER instituted the policy to save money. . . . Manager JOE TORRE said he received congratulatory messages on his answering machines from friends who cried as they were speaking. YOGI BERRA phoned Torre and SANDY KOUFAX sent a telegram. . . . MARIANO DUNCAN was given permission to miss the workout because of a family commitment.

HEADLINE: In One Poor African Nation, Democracy Thrives

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: BAMAKO, Mali, Oct. 13

 BODY:
At every dusty intersection in this sweltering city of red clay streets and smoke-belching motor scooters, beggars with clouded eyes blinded by water-borne parasites or with limbs gruesomely twisted by polio cluster around stopped cars, pleading for a small donation for food.
In the traffic nearby, vendors hawk a score of the newspapers that have blossomed here like mushrooms in a spring rain. But given the prevailing poverty, most of the reading is done by the knots of people who gather around the sidewalk stands to scan the headlines, saving their precious coins for more vital purchases. 
 In the space of four years, Mali has become one of this continent's most vibrant democracies. But as everyday scenes like this one in the run-down capital illustrate, the dramatic political transformation has only slowly begun to change the harsh facts of life for a country that is among Africa's poorest.
Countries all around it have begun to reverse the tide of democratic change that swept much of West and Central Africa at the turn of the decade. Elected governments have been overthrown and elections have been rigged, with the change of course justified by theories that democracy can only flourish when a country develops a middle class and sustains economic growth.
But like only a handful of other African states, Mali, with only modest natural resources, has resolutely clung to its democratic system. Despite the country's hardships, its leaders and people alike now describe democracy as one of their principal assets.
Malians of all stripes spoke proudly of their achievement when Secretary of State Warren Christopher made his first trip through sub-Saharan Africa last week after nearly four years in the job, explaining his choice of Mali as his first stop by calling the country "a democracy that listens to its people."
Largely because of its democracy, Mali is now host to the largest Peace Corps contingent in Africa and ranks in the top tier of the United States' aid recipients on the continent. Similarly, the Netherlands and Canada have chosen Mali as a favorite place to commit their aid. Foreign assistance accounts for about 20 percent of Mali's national budget.
More important, Malians say, their democracy has allowed them to make consensual decisions on the use of scarce resources, helped them limit corruption and favored stability in a region known for its coups.
"Democracy has given us social dialogue as a method of government," said President Alpha Oumar Konare, in an interview in his office on a hilltop overlooking Bamako, the capital. "The more people participate, the more importance they attach to the work of building our nation. With participation and transparency we have managed to limit the ethnic tensions that tear at so many African countries and avoid the waste that has ruined so many others."
Mr. Konare was elected in a multi-party election in 1992, a year after a popular uprising and a military coup that ousted a 23-year dictatorship.
To help prevent Mali's democracy from remaining a mere abstraction to a population that is overwhelmingly rural and uneducated, Mr. Konare's Government has introduced several innovations to the region. It has encouraged the spread of independent radio stations whose broadcasts reach the countryside and started an ambitious program of administrative decentralization.
Perhaps the most dramatic measure, however, was the creation last year of a sort of annual national open forum. During the event, which lasts for several days in December and is broadcast live on national radio, the Prime Minister and members of Government publicly answer the questions of citizens who come or write from all over the country.
"This may have all started to please the outside world," said Tore Rose, the resident representative of the United Nations Development Program, "but the important thing is that people have come to believe in their right to criticize and question their leaders, and that is a very powerful agent for change."
The basic realities of Mali could hardly be starker.
Two-thirds of this vast country consists either of desert or unusable wastelands, and most of the Mali's 10 million people eke out a living as farmers or herders on the banks of the Niger River, which cuts a broad swath through the capital on its arching path to the northeast. The per capita income is about $250.
Eighty percent of the country's women are illiterate, as are 70 percent of the men. And by almost any other common measurement, from life expectancy to infant mortality, Mali sits at or near the bottom of the list for Africa. Education and population control have become top priorities for the Government.
Nevertheless, foreign aid officials say that making careful choices now can make the difference between perpetual misery and slow but meaningful progress for Mali. They say that the transition to democracy was an important part of the process.
"You look at Mali, with an annual economic growth rate of about 5 percent and a population growth rate of about 3 percent, and if you project that into the future, it will take this country about 50 years to attain the standard of living that the Ivory Coast enjoys today, and 100 years to reach the level of present-day Thailand," said one senior Western aid official here.
"But if a country like Mali can raise its growth rate to seven percent and get its population growth down to 2.7 percent a year, in only 35 years they can reach the level of prosperity of a Thailand. Democracy is helping them get there, and that puts some light at the end of the tunnel."
Already, foreign experts say, the dramatic opening of the economy has begun to transform Mali's prospects. The privatization of state mining companies and changes in the investment code have encouraged major gold producers from the United States, Australia, South Africa and Ghana to prospect in rich fields in the west and south of the country, and production is rapidly rising.
Although Mali has long been touted as a natural granary for West Africa, because of the huge inland delta created by the Niger River, little of its potential has been exploited. Recently, both Malian and foreign investors have begun sinking money into projects aimed at increasing the amount of land under rice cultivation, with a goal not only of meeting the country's own needs, but also of becoming a regional exporter.
Similarly, French investors have recently begun exporting large amounts of green beans, grown mostly on small farms, to supply their country's gourmet market. Cotton and livestock production, meanwhile, have benefited greatly from a 1994 devaluation of the region's French-backed currency and from two successive years of good rains.
If Mali is to achieve the more ambitious growth targets, diplomats and aid experts say, it will take not only good policies, but a dose of continued good luck with imponderables like this arid region's fickle rains.
For the time being, many Malians say, even though they remain poor, they are proud of the chance democracy gives them to participate in a commonly determined future.
"As for me, I am very happy with the change," said Adama Sangare an 18-year-old patent medicine vendor in an open-air market. "No country can develop with only one person's thought and without a real discussion. Since Malians began discussing things, we have grown confident that we can find a way forward."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mali's democracy gives its people some hope of emerging from their extreme poverty. Youths sought handouts from drivers in Bamako, the capital. (Robert Grossman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Bronx, Welcoming the World Series as a Reflection on Home

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
The game of baseball is a muddle and a mystery to Karmelia Wilmot, who immigrated to America from Jamaica two years ago. The rules for stealing bases, the strategies that prompt a batter to bunt -- none of it makes sense to her, despite her repeated efforts to watch the sport on television.
But she likes the Yankees, and she is no less than ecstatic that part of the World Series will be played in Yankee Stadium. It means that television sets all around the country will be tuned in to the sliver of the Bronx that she calls home, and it makes her feel special -- like she is living at the center of something important. 
 "When my husband and I first came here and we told people back home that we were living in the Bronx, they said, 'Oh, that's the ghetto'," Ms. Wilmot, a 25-year-old college student, said as she stood with her dog atop a tiny bluff -- a bump, really -- overlooking the ramparts of the stadium and a section of blue seats in the upper deck.
"But when I told them that I could see into Yankee Stadium every time I walked my dog, they realized that it wasn't," she said.
On game days, fancy cars inch along the suddenly crowded streets; people wearing expensive sweaters and designer sunglasses wait at the corners for the stoplights to change.
"It makes me proud that they come here," Ms. Wilmot said. "There are even blimps up in the sky -- right over my apartment."
For Yankee fans throughout the region and elsewhere in the country, the team's journey into the World Series represents a heady cause for celebration. But for many residents of the borough in which the team plays, an area known less for the glitter of New York City than for the grime, the Yankees' triumph seems to represent something more complex and meaningful.
It is a vindication that good things happen in a place so often associated with the bad. It is even, for some people, revenge. George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, is considering abandoning the stadium, saying that its location discourages attendance. Others have also suggested the team would prosper better elsewhere.
And yet the Bronx Bombers have made to the World Series, and in recent days, people have ignored the neighborhood's reputation and have camped in the streets overnight just to lay claim to a remote piece of real estate in the bleachers.
"Everybody else has to come to us for a change," said Dudley Ballentine, 62, a mason who lives in a poor part of the Fordham section where no building is unsullied by graffiti and the brick row houses wear elaborate iron gates over doors and windows.
Mr. Ballentine donned a Yankees cap even though he was several miles from the stadium and simply going about his morning shopping. A friend happened by; he, too, sported a Yankees cap. A man standing half a block away ran to his van to snatch his own, then adjusted it with great care on his head. Several children passing by on bicycles shouted, "The Yankees are the best!"
Although they all lived in a neighborhood suffused with precisely the elements -- drugs, poverty, danger -- that Mr. Steinbrenner has cited in his complaints about the Bronx, few people expressed strong hostility toward him or the team. They seemed too wrapped up in feelings of pride over the Yankees' victories to ponder anything else.
Black and white, employed and unemployed, English-speaking and Spanish-speaking, residents of the Bronx said they felt, in ways they could not quite define, that the Yankees' accomplishments reflected well on them.
Their smiles and happy voices suggested that professional sport, for all its greed and terrible manners, still serves a touching and inspirational function for many people, taking them outside of themselves and encouraging them to revel vicariously in the triumphs of virtual strangers.
"I just feel like we're all getting a recognition that's overdue," said Anne Marie Siligato, 32, who was standing outside Concourse Plaza, within view of the stadium. Years ago, it was a fancy hotel used by many Yankee players. Now, it is a senior citizens center.
The Bronx has lost so much over the years, Ms. Siligato said, that keeping the Yankees is a special symbol to her that the borough still has great vitality. "We need this," she said. "It shows all of those people who are afraid to come here that's it not so bad."
Ms. Siligato said that she finds herself thinking optimistically about the Yankees' winning streak, which comes after a lengthy drought, as a metaphor for the Bronx and the way that its fortunes, too, could change with perseverance.
Olivia Guzman, 23, a waitress at a Puerto Rican restaurant a few blocks from the stadium, expressed the same sentiment, though on a more personal note. "It gives you motivation that hard work and hope pay off, if you just keep moving forward," Ms. Guzman said as she swept crumbs off the chipped red tiles on the floor of the restaurant.
She said there was another reason that having Yankee Stadium in the Bronx made her proud: It is an arena in which the sorts of diverse, disconnected people who sometimes live tensely together in New York City put their differences aside.
"In spite of all the stuff that's happening in politics, where everyone is beginning to look at everybody else in a strange way, we're all one, just cheering and having a great time."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Turn Mixed After Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday, as traders consolidated their gains after the recent rally and the market awaited today's data on consumer prices.
The market's next move is expected to be pegged to the Consumer Price Index, with analysts predicting a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent. If the figure comes in higher than expected, investors may again feel that inflation could accelerate and force interest rates higher. A figure below predictions could bring a rally, analysts said. 
 Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, said the bond market had settled into a trading range based on the premise that economic growth had slowed and inflation was steady in the last quarter.
"The market is prepared for a three-tenths of 1 percent rise in the September C.P.I., both in the overall and core number, which would keep people guessing about what Federal Open Market Committee will do at its next meeting on Nov. 13," he said.
Mr. Hoffman said that a smaller rise would be welcomed by the market and the Fed, while a bigger jump could prompt the Fed to tighten monetary policy by raising interest rates.
In yesterday's trading, the 30-year bond rose 1/32 , to a price of 9829/32 to yield 6.84 percent, unchanged from Friday. There was no trading Monday, the Columbus Day holiday.
Economic data yesterday had minimal impact on the market, with the September Atlanta Fed index painting a mixed picture, while the weekly Mitsubishi index of retail sales showed a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent for the week ended Oct. 12.
Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, estimated that today's price index would show a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent, with the core rate up three-tenths of 1 percent, compared with August's gains of a tenth of 1 percent for both.
"While the immediate outlook for the Treasury market has clearly improved versus, say, a month ago," Mr. Delaney said, "the magnitude of any further price gains in the next week or two would appear to be severely limited."
Elsewhere in the government securities market, bids for yesterday's weekly Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills were weaker than expected and rates turned higher.
The rate for the three-month bill rose to 5.01 percent, from 4.96 percent a week ago, while the six-month issue increased to 5.11 percent from 5.07 percent. Traders said that the noncompetitive bids were average for the three-month bill, while weaker for the six-month. Tomorrow, the Treasury plans to announce the size of auctions for two- and five-year notes next week; rising supply will again affect pricing.

HEADLINE: Japan Seeking Way to Evolve 2-Party System

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Political candidates are doggedly bowing and pleading for votes across Japan in anticipation of elections on Sunday, as Japan engages in a national experiment aimed at producing a more responsive political system.
The election is a landmark because it is the first using new electoral districts and methods of voting, conceived so as to lead Japan in the direction of an adversarial two-party system. 
 "This election will trigger drastic, far-reaching change in Japanese politics," said Takao Toshikawa, publisher of Tokyo Inside Line, a political newsletter. "But it will take time."
Many experts say that any change will be a very gradual process that will take several elections. Even then, some doubt that Japan will end up with anything looking much like a Western two-party system.
They say that in a consensus society, where issues are not much debated, where legislators want to be in the ruling party to dispense pork-barrel projects, a single party is likely to dominate for the indefinite future.
Issues are playing only a minor role in this campaign. The problem is not so much that there are no issues as that the major parties are on the same side of them.
There has been little discussion of foreign policy or trade or relations with the United States, and the focus instead has been on how to streamline and weaken the nation's bureaucracy. Each party insists that it is the only one that is really serious about eviscerating the powerful Government ministries.
The public mood is far more cynical and apathetic today than in the last general election campaign, in 1993, when there was a giddy enthusiasm that Japan was on the verge of a political revolution not unlike the one in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
For decades, Japan had been virtually a one-party state, for the Liberal Democratic Party had been about as certain to win elections as the Communists were in the old Soviet Union. And critics said the parallels did not stop there, in terms of the ruling party's corruption, authoritarianism and arrogance. But then in the 1993 elections the Liberal Democrats were ousted, and there were feverish expectations of a revolution that would transform Japan.
That revolution fizzled after its flag-bearer, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, resigned after just eight months in office, and by mid-1994 the Liberal Democrats had clawed their way back to power as part of a three-party coalition. Early this year, a weary and unpopular Socialist Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, handed power to Ryutaro Hashimoto, putting the Liberal Democrats back in the top post as head of the governing coalition.
Now Mr. Hashimoto is campaigning with a vengeance, hoping for a victory that will erase the humiliation of 1993 and restore the Liberal Democrats to their traditional role as titans of the Japanese political scene.
Mr. Hashimoto called the election for this month -- he had until next summer to hold it -- in part because he is riding high in the polls. By almost all estimates, his party will win the largest number of seats in the next Parliament, maybe even an absolute majority.
"We are aiming to win a majority of seats," Mr. Hashimoto said at a news conference on Monday. "But I don't exclude an alliance with individuals and parties who share our views on reform of the bureaucracy, reform of the economy and other important issues."
Most people expected Mr. Hashimoto to still fall short of a majority, forcing him to cobble together a coalition government. But some recent polls suggest that the Liberal Democrats may eke out an absolute majority, which would be a stunning achievement that would have seemed impossible in the party's dark days of 1993.
Such a victory for the Liberal Democrats, especially at time when the opposition seems fractured into many groups, might also mark a step backward, at least temporarily, to the old days when Japan seemed a one-party state.
"If the Liberal Democrats win a majority, it's like a turning-back of the clock," said Shigenori Okazaki, who follows Japanese politics for SBC Warburg, a securities firm in Tokyo. "It would be back to the old days, and we wouldn't be able to expect much in terms of Government reform."
Under the new electoral system, passed during the brief period when the Liberal Democrats were out of power and nursing their wounds, 300 members of Parliament will be elected from single-member districts around Japan. Another 200 will be selected by proportional representation, on the basis of a second ballot that the voter will cast for a party rather than a person.
This contrasts with the old system, where there were large districts that could each elect three to five members of Parliament. A small party used to be able to elect one of the members with just a small minority of the vote; now it needs to get more votes than any other party in the district.
The new electoral system is supposed to encourage small parties to merge so as to form larger parties that have a real chance of taking power, instead of remaining perpetually in opposition. For now, though, Japan is still a good distance from a two-party system.
The main opposition party, the New Frontier Party, includes many of the onetime revolutionaries of 1993, but their public support has eroded sharply because of a series of political missteps this year and because of their close ties to a Buddhist group that the Liberal Democrats hint is a dangerous religious cult.
A new party, the Democratic Party, emphasizes many of the same demands for far-reaching change but projects a fresher image.
Then there are the Social Democrats, who changed their name from the Socialists this year. They were once the reliable opposition party of Japan but are now expected to lose about half their seats in this election. The Social Democrats had to abandon virtually every position they ever held in order to gain the Prime Minister's job two years ago, so they are widely criticized as wishy-washy opportunists.
"The main debating point in this election is whether we can change the way politics operate in the broadest sense," Naoto Kan, a leader of the Democratic Party, said in an interview.
He emphasized that there is a growing public sentiment that the way to revive Japan as a whole is to cut the bureaucrats down to size and put politicians in charge of them.
Mr. Kan is perhaps the most popular politician in Japan today because he took on the bureaucrats in the Health Ministry, which he heads, and ultimately defeated them. Largely because of Mr. Kan's backing, the Democratic Party has emerged as a credible force and a wild card in the election.
Yet voters seem skeptical that anything will ever change. And some experts think this is not cynicism so much as realism.
"For all the hype and fanfare, this election is quite insignificant, especially when you think of the high hopes that politicians are building up with voters, saying they are going to break down the bureaucracy that is choking the country," Christopher Redl, a political analyst at ING Baring Securities in Tokyo, said. "That is not going to happen."
Mr. Redl and some other analysts, Japanese and foreign, say the fundamental problem is that in Japan, politicians do not matter much. Key decisions are made by career bureaucrats, and it has rarely made much difference who has become Prime Minister.
"Japan's Parliament is simply a rubber stamp organ for the bureaucracy," said Mr. Redl, who left the United States to work as an aide in Parliament.
"Japanese politicians are not lawmakers," he said. "Japanese bureaucrats, Japanese civil servants, are legislators, and they have been for the entire postwar history."
One issue where there is disagreement among the parties concerns a national sales tax that is scheduled to rise from 3 percent to 5 percent next April. The New Frontier Party criticizes the increase, while the Liberal Democrats say it is necessary -- and darkly hint that the New Frontier might try to raise the tax even higher.
In the past, the United States has sometimes felt a strong stake in Japanese elections.
This year, though, the United States does not seem to have a major stake in who wins the election, and trade or security relations with Washington are not an important theme in the campaign.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Japan's Vote: The Contenders"
Voters in Japan will go to the polls on Sunday in the first elections under a landmark new electoral system, in which each district sends one representative to Parliament, instead of several as in the past, reducing the power of smaller parties. These are the main parties.
 
THE LIBERAL DEMOCRATIC PARTY
Leader: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto
Seats in Parliament: 211 seats in what is currently a 513-member lower house of Parliament. (The lower house is the key body, and it will have 500 seats after the election).
 The Liberal Democratic Party is the dominant party in Japan, having ruled the country for most of its postwar history. The Liberal Democrats, contrary to their name, are conservative.
 
THE NEW FRONTIER PARTY
 Leader: Ichiro Ozawa
 Seats in Parliament: 160
 The New Frontier, the leading opposition party, is a coalition of forces that unseated the Liberal Democrats in 1993 and captured the public imagination with their promise of far-reaching changes. But the New Frontier's support has dwindled this year, and many voters now see it as emblematic not of change but of old-style politics.
 
 THE DEMOCRATIC PARTY
 Leaders: Yukio Hatoyama, the grandson of a Prime Minister, and Naoto Kan, the enormously popular Health Minister.
 Seats in Parliament: 52
 The Democratic Party, which was formed last month, has tried to edge the New Frontier aside to claim the mantle of the reform party. The Democrats are popular with disgruntled, apathetic voters.
 
 THE SOCIAL DEMOCRATS
 Leader: Takako Doi
 Seats in Parliament: 30
 The Social Democrats changed their name from the Socialists this year and are expected to lose many seats in the election. Miss Doi, a former party leader who is one of the few prominent women in Japanese politics, has come back to lead the party during the campaign and try to save it.
 
 THE COMMUNIST PARTY
 Leader: Tetsuzo Fuwa
 Seats in Parliament:15
 The Communist Party in Japan is not at all red and only the slightest shade of pink. Indeed, the Communists have considerable support from small business owners, are campaigning against high taxes and are expected to gain seats in Parliament because of their image as just about the only party in Japan untainted by corruption and opportunism.
(Reuters)

HEADLINE: Zimmer Says He's a Centrist Who'd Shrink Government

SERIES: NEW JERSEY'S SENATE RACE: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
Differentiating himself from his Democratic opponent in the race for the open United States Senate seat from New Jersey, Representative Richard A. Zimmer says that if elected, he would emphasize cutting government spending and taxes and making government less intrusive.
In a detailed interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times, Mr. Zimmer noted often that he favors limiting the cost and scope of the Federal Government. He also sought to distance himself from Republican leaders by describing himself as moderate on issues like environmental protection and abortion. 
 Mr. Zimmer, a Republican, and his opponent, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, have sought to position themselves as centrists in a state known for its middle-of-the road voters. But in separate interviews, there were clear differences in emphasis between the candidates: Mr. Torricelli advocated a more activist view of government, and Mr. Zimmer supported a more limited one.
"I am a pro-choice, pro-environment, pro-reform Christie Whitman Republican," Mr. Zimmer said, seeking to counter political attacks from Mr. Torricelli, who has characterized Mr. Zimmer as a conservative acolyte of Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, and a supporter of cuts to popular middle-class programs like Medicare, education and conserving the environment.
Mr. Zimmer said that he often agrees with Mr. Gingrich on fiscal matters like reducing spending and balancing the Federal budget, but that his views on many social issues are more moderate than those of the Republican mainstream in Congress. "I'm a New Jersey Republican," he said, reciting a list of occasions on which he had broken with Republican congressional leaders in recent years: on requiring companies to grant employees family leave, on increasing the minimum wage and on a woman's right to an abortion.
"The world looks different from New Jersey than it does from Arizona or Georgia," said Mr. Zimmer, who discussed the Senate campaign for 90 minutes late Monday afternoon at The Times. An article about a similar session with Mr. Torricelli, on Monday morning, appeared yesterday.
In addition to trying to highlight the ideological differences between himself and his Democratic opponent, Mr. Zimmer also attacked Mr. Torricelli personally. He questioned Mr. Torricelli's fitness to serve as a Senator, saying that he had voted in Congress to maintain Federal subsidies and other economic benefits to industries that had contributed to Mr. Torricelli's political campaigns, including the sugar, dairy, cotton, peanut butter and aerospace industries.
"Over and over again, Bob Torricelli has voted for this sort of corporate welfare," Mr. Zimmer said. "It showed that his loyalty was with the people who give him the campaign contributions."
Mr. Zimmer also accused Mr. Torricelli of having benefited financially from an initial stock offering by a mutual savings bank, which Mr. Zimmer said Mr. Torricelli had known about only because he was a member of Congress and was informed by a politically connected friend. "He got special preference," Mr. Zimmer said.
Mr. Torricelli, who has said he did nothing improper, has criticized Mr. Zimmer for such personal attacks. Mr. Torricelli said he had declined to challenge Mr. Zimmer on anything other than his legislative record. "I'm going to get elected to the U.S. Senate, but I'm going to keep my dignity,' he said.
Sitting at attention in a straight-back chair, Mr. Zimmer toyed occasionally with cookies on a plate in front of him, though he seldom paused to eat. His tone was earnest, and he looked intense and serious. Occasionally, he also seemed ill at ease in response to a stream of questions on everything from the overhaul of welfare to educational aid to negative campaign advertising. At one point, Mr. Zimmer was asked if he sometimes failed to connect with voters.
"That's what you seem to report, so there may be some truth to it," he responded.
The contest between Mr. Zimmer and Mr. Torricelli has attracted considerable attention nationally, because it is one of 14 races for open Senate seats and because of its extensive use of hard-edged, negative television advertising.
A recent editorial in The Star Ledger of Newark criticized the relentlessly negative nature of many of the commercials, and dismissed as "an abomination" a Zimmer commercial that simulates a newscast and refers repeatedly to a Torricelli "scandal." Each candidate has accused the other of misstating and distorting his voting record.
Mr. Zimmer, in the interview, firmly resisted the suggestion that his ads went beyond acceptable bounds. He said Mr. Torricelli was to blame for the tone of the ad campaigns, because a group supporting the Democrat had been the first to broadcast negative commercials last summer.
"TV advertising is hideously expensive," said Mr. Zimmer, noting that it was hard for people who are not well known statewide to introduce themselves to New Jersey voters. "You've got to break through the clutter."
He added, "Our ads have been, that we have put on the air, principally positive."
Mr. Zimmer defined a negative campaign commercial as one that was inaccurate, deceptive or focused on a candidate's personal life. By those standards, he said, his television ads have not been negative.
"I'm telling the truth about his record," Mr. Zimmer said. "It's important that the voters also understand the way that Bob Torricelli has performed in office."
Mr. Zimmer also contended that Mr. Torricelli's commercials, which say that Mr. Zimmer voted to reduce Medicare services, educational aid and environmental programs, were inaccurate. Mr. Torricelli has made similar claims about Mr. Zimmer's ads, and he has also derided them for being personal assaults and deceptive.
Throughout the interview, Mr. Zimmer emphasized the ideological differences between the candidates. He maintained that Mr. Torricelli was a liberal who had come only lately to appreciate the importance of reducing taxes, balancing the Federal budget and overhauling welfare.
"I've come to understand that when you raise taxes, elected legislators spend every dollar of the new revenue, and then some," Mr. Zimmer said. "And that's why I've become such a hawk on cutting spending."
Mr. Zimmer defined a liberal as "somebody who wants to spend more money, have higher levels of taxation, more bureaucracy, more intrusion in our lives."
"The liberal generally supports traditional forms of welfare and is not as aggressive in crime prevention," he said. "That's my definition of a liberal, and I think it fits Bob Torricelli pretty well."
At the core of his conservative political beliefs, Mr. Zimmer said, is the conviction that government must be made smaller, more efficient and less costly. He said he would not vote for any measure that would produce a net increase in taxes.
Mr. Zimmer said that the only Federal program that he would not consider cutting is Social Security. "The only way we are going to balance the budget is by putting the broad range of spending programs on the table," he said.
That would include spending on social programs favored by liberals, he said, as well as military and aerospace spending historically supported by conservatives. He proposed cutting the space station program, for example, as well as a number of subsidies and related benefits for the sugar, mining, cattle, dairy, cotton and peanut butter industries -- all subsidies that Mr. Zimmer said Mr. Torricelli supports because of campaign contributions that he has received from those industries.
Mr. Zimmer also contended that he himself was not subject to influence from campaign contributors, including the Republican National Committee and a national Republican Senate campaign committee. Mr. Torricelli has asserted that Mr. Zimmer had been heavily influenced in his bare-knuckle campaign tactics by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.
"I have never been influenced by the people who contribute to my campaigns," Mr. Zimmer said.
Mr. Zimmer also disagreed with his Democratic opponent on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to equalize spending and educational standards among poor and wealthy school districts in New Jersey. Mr. Torricelli said he was concerned that the proposal would in effect place a ceiling on how much some suburban districts would spend on education.
But Mr. Zimmer said that more affluent districts could vote to approve budgets that were higher than the equalized spending plans, and he said he approved of such local control. "If they can make the sale to the communities they serve, they'll have no problem," he said.
The Congressman also disputed Mr. Torricelli on the Democrat's contention that the new Federal welfare law would be too harsh on children and needed to be amended.
Mr. Zimmer said he had been troubled by the issue until he heard testimony at a Congressional hearing from a man who worked with abused children in Chicago and who described himself as a liberal Democrat. The man, whom Mr. Zimmer did not name, said that to improve the lives of children on welfare "you've just got to stop sending checks indefinitely to people, to teen-agers who have children before they're married, before they graduate high school," Mr. Zimmer said.
Mr. Zimmer also said that he supports giving states the option to decide whether to permit the children of illegal immigrants to attend schools.
"I believe that we should not prescribe to the states what they should do," he said. "Public education is principally a state responsibility."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
As Dole Weighs Tougher Image, Poll Finds He Already Has One

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
Bob Dole and his advisers have agonized publicly over how hard to attack President Clinton in their second and final debate tonight, but a majority of Americans have already concluded that Mr. Dole is more combative than Mr. Clinton and is spending more time attacking than explaining what he would do as President, according to the most recent New York Times/CBS News Poll.
That finding is the latest complication for Mr. Dole, whose advisers view the 90-minute encounter in San Diego as their candidate's last hope for a dramatic breakthrough in a campaign that has been remarkably static from the start and, judging by the new poll, remains so. 
 Perhaps the most discouraging news for Mr. Dole is that voters' attitudes toward him and Mr. Clinton remain virtually unmoved since October 1995. Even after the first Presidential debate in Hartford, the Vice-Presidential debate in St. Petersburg, Fla., and tens of millions of dollars of dueling television commercials, Mr. Clinton remains ahead by 17 points.
That may be even less likely to change because voters say they are paying less attention this year than they did in 1992 -- and they find the campaign less compelling. Only 44 percent of registered voters described the 1996 contest as interesting, while 50 percent called it "dull." In early October 1992, 57 percent said that campaign was interesting, and that figure rose to 78 percent later in the month.
As Mr. Clinton holed up yesterday in Albuquerque, N.M., to prepare for the debate, Mr. Dole turned decidedly tough on the campaign trail in San Diego, "setting the tone," in the words of Scott Reed, the Dole campaign manager, for a newly aggressive posture tonight.
Shedding, at least for now, concerns about reviving his lingering "hatchet man" image, Mr. Dole recited a catalogue of every scandal that has touched the Clinton White House as he accused the President of presiding over one of the most unethical administrations in the nation's history.
The unusually public ruminations in the Dole camp over his newly negative tone is a consequence of the campaign's determination to redirect a campaign that seems stuck in an electoral groove, according to the Times/CBS poll, which questioned 1,126 registered voters nationwide.
The survey, which was conducted by telephone from Thursday through Sunday and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, found that Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore had maintained their double-digit lead.
Fifty-three percent of the probable electorate favor the Democrats, and 36 percent support Bob Dole and his running mate, Jack Kemp. Ross Perot and his Vice-Presidential choice on the Reform Party ticket, Pat Choate, who were excluded from the debates, pulled only 5 percent from the probable electorate.
In the modern era of polling, no Presidential candidate has ever rebounded from such an overwhelming deficit as that faced by Mr. Dole this close to Election Day. Though President Harry S. Truman defeated Thomas E. Dewey in 1948 in one of the nation's most celebrated political upsets, a Gallup Poll taken in mid-October that year had given Mr. Dewey only a five-point edge.
The quandary for Mr. Dole is that the more negative he gets, the greater the chance that he could exacerbate the reputation he is trying to shake. Or he may figure that since he cannot shake the perception anyway, he may as well go all out.
Some Dole aides are concerned that the town-meeting format of tonight's face-off, featuring questions from people in the audience, may make it tougher for their candidate to pull off an attack successfully.
Although the Clinton campaign has waged a more sustained advertising drive critical of Mr. Dole, 50 percent of registered voters said it was Mr. Dole who had spent more time "attacking" Mr. Clinton, while 40 percent said he was spending more time "explaining" what he would do as President. By contrast, 68 percent said Mr. Clinton was spending more time explaining, while only 19 percent said he was spending more time attacking.
These perceptions reflect, perhaps, Mr. Dole's highly unfavorable public image. The former Kansas Senator's unfavorable rating is 41 percent; his favorable rating is 29 percent. The President's unfavorable rating is 36 percent; his favorable rating is 47 percent.
Mr. Reed, the Dole campaign manager, blamed the press for Mr. Dole's reputation as an attacker. "Bill Clinton has spent $45 million on misleading and false advertising linking Dole to Gingrich, but the media coverage has been the exact opposite," he said.
Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, agreed, saying, "The media have failed to report that over 90 percent of the ads run by Clinton and the Democrats are completely negative attack ads, while at the same time letting him pretend to reject negative campaigning."
But George Stephanopoulos, a senior adviser to Mr. Clinton, said Mr. Dole was perceived as belligerent because he is. "All you ever see him doing on TV is carping, attacking, whining," Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
Despite all the talk of gutter-level oratory, the public perceives this campaign as far less negative than usual, at least thus far. But the findings could indicate that the public has become inured to candidates lambasting one another. Whatever the explanation, only 11 percent said this campaign was more negative than usual; in October 1992, 29 percent thought the campaign was more negative than usual.
Three weeks before Election Day, even some Dole advisers said privately that they were wondering if the contest would ever get closer. The horse-race numbers are reminiscent of Walter F. Mondale's campaign against President Ronald Reagan in 1984. A Times/CBS News Poll taken two weeks before that election found the candidates' standings almost identical to this year's nominees: Mr. Reagan had 54 percent, and Mr. Mondale drew 36 percent. Mr. Reagan won that election in a landslide, with 58.8 percent of the popular vote.
While Dole aides view tonight's debate as their best last chance, the poll found that the earlier debates had little effect on the candidates' standings. Sixty-two percent of the voters polled who viewed the first Presidential debate said they thought Mr. Clinton did the better job. But 74 percent of viewers also said it did not affect their opinion of the President, while 53 percent said it did not affect their opinion of Mr. Dole.
Similarly, 60 percent of the voters polled who watched the Vice-Presidential debate said they thought Mr. Gore had done the better job. But half the viewers said it did not affect their opinion of either contender.
One explanation for the public indifference toward the campaign is that the race has never been portrayed in the news media as close. Seventy-eight percent of those polled expect Mr. Clinton to win. Half the people who plan to back Mr. Dole said they believed that Mr. Clinton would win, and 96 percent of Mr. Clinton's backers said he would prevail. The President may be reaping the support of those who want to side with a winner.
Another reason for the low interest is that voters seem relatively content. On the economy, a classic barometer in Presidential contests, 72 percent of those polled said the national economy was good, and 58 percent said Mr. Dole would not deliver on his tax-cut package.
In an interview, Mr. Reed asked if there was "any good news" in the poll. The most hopeful finding for Mr. Dole is that he may have made some headway in selling his economic program. Forty-three percent of registered voters now prefer cutting taxes to reducing the Federal budget; last month, only 35 percent took that view. But 51 percent still put more priority on reducing the deficit.
Moreover, 50 percent said the Government could reduce the deficit and cut taxes at the same time; in August, only 41 percent said that was possible. Still, 45 percent said the Government could not accomplish both at once.
On the theme Mr. Dole is expected to emphasize tonight, Mr. Clinton's ethics, there is an unmistakable difference between the two candidates. Seventy percent of registered voters polled said Mr. Dole shared the moral values most Americans try to live by; only 55 percent said that of Mr. Clinton. Similarly, 52 percent said Mr. Dole had more integrity than most people in public life, while only 36 percent said that of Mr. Clinton.
The survey also found that the intense advertising campaigns had given no advantage to either candidate. Fifty-five percent of the registered voters polled said that in the past week they had seen some commercial on television that supported Mr. Dole, while 49 percent said they had seen one that supported Mr. Clinton. Yet, only 11 percent said that any Presidential candidate's advertising had helped them decide which one to support. A larger proportion, 26 percent, said they had seen some advertising that made them more confident that they had settled on the right candidate.
The poll also underscores how Mr. Perot has become a bit player in this campaign. Sixty-two percent of registered voters surveyed said Mr. Clinton was addressing issues that matter to them, and 55 percent said that of Mr. Dole. But only 31 percent said the same of Mr. Perot, whose emphasis on political reform and deficit reduction significantly influenced the campaign dialogue when he ran four years ago.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Thursday through Sunday with 1,438 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,126 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 36,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, race, sex, age and education.
Some findings related to voting are reported in terms of an overall "probable electorate," which uses responses to questions dealing with voter registration, voting history, and the likelihood of voting in 1996 as a measure of the probability of particular respondents' voting in November.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for voters who said they watched or listened to the first Presidential debate it is plus or minus four percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Chase and Citicorp Register Solid Earnings for Third Quarter

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation and Citicorp, the nation's two largest bank holding companies, recorded solid if not spectacular third-quarter earnings results yesterday, and analysts said the industry remained on track for a third consecutive year of record profits.
"By and large, it was an O.K. quarter," said Judah Kraushaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. "The broader trend we are seeing is a slowing of revenue performance and some leveling off in consumer credit costs. But commercial credit costs are still well under control, and that last factor is giving many banks room to cover a pattern of higher expense growth than we anticipated going into the quarter." 
 Lawrence W. Cohn, a banking analyst at Paine Webber, said that unless something "really odd" happened to the economy, "we would expect earnings to continue to grow."
"The economy is O.K., asset quality is still excellent and interest rates are cooperating," he said.
Chase, which passed Citicorp earlier this year as the country's biggest banking company following its merger with the Chemical Banking Corporation on March 31, said third-quarter earnings rose 12 percent, to $858 million, or $1.80 a share, from $764 million, or $1.58 a share, during last year's third quarter.
Revenues were up nearly 4 percent, to $3.93 billion, Chase said, from $3.78 billion a year earlier. The merger was accounted for as a pooling of interests and, accordingly, the earnings include the combined results of Chase and Chemical as though the merger had been in effect for all periods presented.
Chase said revenues grew across its business lines despite some signs of weakness in its credit card portfolio.
Credit card payments delinquent by 90 days or more rose to $469 million from $440 million. But as a percentage of outstanding charges, delinquencies fell to 1.96 percent, from 2.04 percent.
For the nine months, Chase said it earned $1.62 billion, or $3.28 a share, after restructuring charges and merger-related expenses, down from the $2.13 billion, or $4.47 a share, it made in the first three quarters of 1995.
Chase also said that between now and 1998 it intended to buy back up to $2.5 billion of its outstanding shares. Stock buybacks tend to buoy share prices, but Chase's announcement and results left investors unmoved yesterday.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Chase shares were unchanged at $82.50 each.
Citicorp said good growth in corporate and consumer banking helped lift net income in the third quarter by 7 percent, to $935 million, or $1.85 a share, from $877 million, or $1.79 a share, a year earlier.
Citicorp said third-quarter earnings included a one-time $40 million after-tax charge related to the United States Savings Association Insurance Fund, created by Congress to recapitalize the savings and loan industry.
Excluding that charge, Citicorp said it earned $975 million during the period, up 11 percent from a year earlier.
Revenues at Citicorp totaled $5.36 billion, up 8 percent from last year's third quarter. Excluding the savings and loan charge, revenues grew by 9 percent, to $5.4 billion.
"Citicorp is the only one of this group that continues to make me smile," said Robert B. Albertson, United States bank research director at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "Achieving 9 percent growth from their global franchise is an increasingly hard number for others to realize."
Profits from corporate banking, which provides loans and other services to clients, were up 34 percent during the period, to $520 million, from $389 million a year earlier.
But profits from the company's consumer banking business fell 10 percent, to $466 million, from $515 million a year ago, dragged down by the charge to help the thrifts.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Citicorp shares closed at $95, up $1.625.
Other banking companies reporting earnings included Nationsbank, the country's fifth-largest. It said net income jumped 18 percent in the quarter, to $625 million, or $2.12 a share, from $530 million, or $1.95 a share, during the third quarter of 1995.
Also, First Chicago NBD Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest banking company, said earnings were little changed at $358 million, or $1.09 a share, compared with $357 million, or $1.07 a share.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Conrail to Merge With CSX,In Biggest Rail Deal Yet
Conrail, the freight railroad that dominates the Northeast, said that it had agreed to merge with CSX, a far larger railroad that blankets the Southeast, Middle Atlantic and eastern Midwest. The $8.4 billion deal would be the biggest since the industry was deregulated in the 1980's, and it would leave most of the nation east of the Mississippi with just two big freight railroads. [Page A1.]
 
Texas Instruments Earnings Fall
Texas Instruments had lower earnings, indicating the continued uneven performance of the semiconductor industry. [D2.]
 
Berkshire Hathaway in Acquisition
Berkshire Hathaway agreed to acquire Flightsafety International, the leading pilot training company, for about $1.5 billion. [D4.]
 
Chase Manhattan and Citicorp Gain
Chase Manhattan, with a 12 percent earnings gain, and Citicorp, with a 7 percent rise, led a string of banking companies that reported solid results. [D4.]
 
Stocks Mixed on Earnings Concerns
Stocks closed mixed after touching records, as investors began questioning whether share prices already reflected a rosy outlook for profits. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.22 points, to 6,004.78. [D12.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed, as traders awaited inflation data. The yield on the 30-year bond was unchanged. [D22.]
 
Strong Earnings on Wall Street
The good fortune of robust stock and bond markets showed up again in sharply higher third-quarter earnings at Merrill Lynch and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and a modest increase at Paine Webber. [D10.]
 
Netscape Aims at Lotus
Netscape's strategy for survival and growth in the market for Internet software will be to try to sidestep Microsoft and compete directly against I.B.M.'s Lotus unit in the market for so-called groupware. [D2.]
 
Coke and Pepsi Duel Over Earnings
The eternal rivalry between Pepsi and Coke flared again as they posted quarterly earnings reports on the same day for the first time in at least 20 years. Some said Coca-Cola was trying to steal Pepsico's thunder, but both had disappointing results. Though its earnings rose, Coke had falling beverage volumes and $455 million in one-time provisions, while at Pepsi, net income declined 77 percent. Market Place. [D12.]
 
Layoffs Statistics to Be Revised
Acknowledging a flaw in a key statistic, the Labor Department said that it would revise upward its tabulation of the number of layoffs in the mid-1990's. [D5.]
 
Trader Pleads Guilty to Fraud
A securities trader whose stock market bets caused a group of college endowments to lose $137.6 million will plead guilty to fraud and pay $182,000 to settle civil actions. [D8.]
 
Editors Demand Independence
The professional association of magazine editors announced a pointed policy to preserve editorial independence. [D11.]

HEADLINE: Born in Crisis, Conrail Defies Skeptics With Turnaround

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Since Congress created Conrail in 1973 to try to salvage something out of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad and five other dying railroads, there have been numerous instances when it was close to being broken up and sold. Yet the railroad always managed to snatch another chance to demonstrate that it could become viable.
The rescuers were determined legislators on Capitol Hill, chief executives who refused to throw in the towel and union leaders who came through with crucial concessions. 
 Through the late 1970's and early 1980's, the Federal Government poured billions of dollars into rebuilding the carrier's tracks and equipment and providing the financial life raft that enabled the management, under the guidance of the Government, to turn the railroad around.
The turnaround was led by L. Stanley Crane, a longtime railway executive who, after finishing his career at the Southern Railway Company at age 65, took on what he later called the greatest challenge of his life in 1981. Despite widespread doubts, he believed that Conrail could be viable and profitable.
After shedding tens of thousands of miles of track, workers and outdated work rules and after gaining new freedoms under deregulation of the railroads, Conrail surprised even Mr. Crane when it began turning a profit by 1983. The profits began to mushroom in subsequent years.
Even after Mr. Crane, with the eventual cooperation of the many unions, put the carrier back on its feet, there were skeptics that it could stand by itself.
In 1985, the Reagan Administration sought to sell Conrail.
Elizabeth Dole, then the Secretary of Transportation, was convinced that the railroad needed a strong arm to lean on and picked the powerful and cash-rich Norfolk Southern railroad, with a bid of $1.2 billion, as a purchaser.
But Mr. Crane, who argued that the carrier should be sold to the public through a stock offering, dug in and ended up fighting a bitter battle with Mrs. Dole.
Mr. Crane mobilized his staff, members of Congress, shippers and even some Wall Street firms to convince the skeptics that Conrail could compete by itself and should be sold to the public.
The growing profitability of the railroad, the fact that its assets appeared worth much more than the $1.2 billion offer and strong support from labor, which feared that a takeover would lead to further job cuts, began to have an effect.
Eventually Congress agreed that the Government should sell Conrail to the public in a stock offering. In March 1987, Conrail returned to the private sector with an initial offering at $28 a share that raised more than $1.6 billion.
Those who invested were not disappointed. The stock was split 2-for-1 in 1992. Yesterday it soared $14.125, closing at $85.125 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.
Not only has Conrail survived, it has thrived, becoming a strong competitor that has been able to win back some of the traffic that it lost to the trucking industry, by shipping truck trailers on flat cars quickly and at low cost.
Its survival has been vital to the Northeast economy, which during the 1980's saw many industries leave the region.
In the process, though, the railroad has shrunk severely. In 1976 it had 96,000 employees. It has shrunk to about 23,500. The track network has decreased significantly, too.
But what is left is in good shape and efficient, analysts said. They added that Conrail was now in a position to take on the trucking industry even more aggressively.

GRAPHIC: Chart: Chart: "Heirs of Railway History"
Conrail and CSX are the modern descendants of many of the oldest and most famous names in American railroading. Here are some crucial date's in each line's history
 
CONRAIL
 
1831 -- Conrail's earliest ancestor, the Mohawk & Hudson Railroad, begins operating between Albany and Schenectady, N.Y.
 
 1846 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad begins operating between Philadelphia and Harrisburg.
 
 1853 -- Mergers of the Mohawk & Hudson and nine other lines creates the New York Central Railroad.
 
 1867 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt acquires the New York Central. Over the following years he obtains control of a number of other roads and folds them into the New York Central, building up both a vast Northeastern transportation empire and a formidable reputation as a ruthless tycoon. By 1914 the railroad's network stretches from New York to Chicago, and a far-reaching rivalry develops between the New York Central and the Pennsylvania for dominance in the Northeast, especially in passenger service between New York and Chicago.
 
 1946 -- After a century of expansion and nearly uninterrupted financial success, the Pennsylvania Railroad is the largest railroad by revenue and freight tonnage in the country. But after World War II, the line is beset by declining traffic and huge costs, and it omits a dividend for the first time in decades. The New York Central runs into comparable difficulties after the war.
 
 1957 -- The chairmen of the arch-rival Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads begin to talk about merging their ailing companies. The merger is finally consummated eleven years later, creating the Penn Central Corporation in 1968. But the companies' finances continue to deteriorate despite a near-monopoly in New York and southern New England, and the Penn Central declares bankruptcy in 1970.
 
 1976 -- The financial conditions of railroads in the Northeast reach such a chaotic state, with most major lines bankrupt, that Congress establishes two Government-sponsored corporations to take over their operations. The new Consolidated Rail Corporation, or Conrail, takes over the freight operations and most track and facilities of a number of railroads, including the Penn Central, Erie Lackawanna, Reading, Lehigh Valley, Lehigh & Hudson and Central of New Jersey lines, giving it control of almost every mile of railroad in the Northeast. Intercity passenger service and ownership of some track is assumed by National Railroad Passenger Corporation, or Amtrak. Conrail also inherited some commuter rail operations, which it soon sold to Amtrak or to local government authorities.
 
 1981 -- With Federal financing, Conrail spends heavily to rebuild aging facilities and severely prunes its now heavily redundant network, running up losses of more than $1.5 billion.
 
 1984 -- With the help of favorable legislation and labor concessions, Conrail turns a profit for the first time.
 
 1987 -- The government's 85-percent stake in Conrail is publicly floated in the biggest initial stock offering to date, raising $1.6 billion. The remaining 15 percent of Conrail's stock is owned by its employees.
 
 1996 -- After years of spurning merger offers, including from Norfolk Southern, its partner in an intermodal freight venture, and despite registering strong objections to other big railroad mergers like last year's Union Pacific-Southern Pacific combination, Conrail agrees to be acquired by CSX Corporation for $ TK billion.
 
CSX CORPORATION
 
1827 -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad (the B.&O.), the first railroad in North America, is chartered to help Baltimore compete with New York and Philadelphia for export traffic from the rapidly developing Midwest, which at the time moved mostly by river or canal.
 
 1832 -- The Portsmouth & Roanoke Railroad begins operating in southern Virginia. After a number of mergers the company grows into the Seaboard Air Line in 1875, serving much of the Southeast.
 
 1836 -- The Louisa Railroad begins operating in northern Virginia. It combines with many other lines over the years to become the Chesepeake and Ohio Railroad (the C.&O.), a major railroad in the central part of the East Coast and Appalachians.
 
 1900 -- In the golden age of railroading, the B.&O. and C.&O. develop a rivalry almost as intense as that between the Pennsylvania and the New York Central. After World War II, the B.&O. becomes especially famous for the quality of its passenger service.
 
 1962 -- As passenger trains begin to be eclipsed by air travel and truckers gain ground against rail freight haulage, most major railroads face declining profits or rising losses. In the resulting wave of consolidations, the C.&O. acquires the rival B.&O. The two lines and another they acquired together are reorganized into the Chessie System in 1973.
 
 1967 -- Seaboard Air Line merges with the Atlantic Coast Line, another major Southern railroad, to form SCL.
 
 1980 -- SCL and the Chessie System merge to form CSX, which becomes one of two dominant carriers in the southeast (the other is the Norfolk Southern, formed by merger of the Norfolk & Western Railway and the Southern Railway in 19tk.)
 
 1996 -- CSX agrees to acquire Conrail, heir to the reorganized remnants of a number of Northeastern railroads, for $ TK billion.
 
(Sources: Hoover's Handbook; Trains Magazine)(pg. D8)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: REGISTRATION;
20 Million 'Motor Voters' Increase Rolls

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Since a new Federal statute commonly known as the "motor voter" law went into effect last year, registration rolls have increased by nine million, a study made public today showed.
That represents 17 percent of the 54 million people who had been unregistered in states covered by the new system, according to the study, prepared for the League of Women Voters and the N.A.A.C.P. by Human Serve, a New York-based bipartisan voter registration organization. 
 For the 18 months from January 1995 to last June, some 20 million people either registered to vote for the first time, reregistered or updated their registrations using the law, the National Voter Registration Act of 1993.
"It shows that many more people will register if it is made simple," said Frances Pivin, Human Serve's co-director.
The law requires states to offer registration through state agencies such as driver's license offices, hence the name, motor voter.
About 8.8 million people, or 44.4 percent, registered at a department of motor vehicles, the report said. About five million, or 24 percent, of them registered through the mail. Voters also registered at other government agencies like unemployment offices, libraries or military recruiting offices.
The study used data from election boards in the District of Columbia and 43 states covered by the act.
Six states were exempt from the law because they either have Election Day registration or do not have voter registration. Vermont did not start complying with the law until August.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: CALIFORNIA;
Dole's Plan: Bet the Ranch on One Shot

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
A week ago, few people in the tight little world of big-time politics were talking much about California, despite its treasure trove of 54 electoral votes. After 27 Presidential trips to the state in less than four years, it seemed to belong to Bill Clinton, and Bob Dole was spending neither a lot of money nor a lot of time trying to take it away.
But then the weekend brought a new Field Poll showing Mr. Clinton only 10 percentage points ahead. That was followed by a decision by the Dole campaign to pour major resources, previously earmarked for swing states like New Jersey, Ohio and Pennsylvania, into a last-chance gamble on California, where the final debate of the campaign will take place in San Diego on Wednesday evening. 
 The experts could not have been more surprised if Mr. Dole had said he was running for Pope.
Most people here still consider the Republican nominee "just a terribly long shot" in California, in the words of Gerald Warren, the former editor of The San Diego Union Tribune, who worked in the Nixon White House. The man who took the poll that started the commotion, Mervin Field, said he thought the new tactics might constitute a feint of some kind, "because on our numbers, it's hard to see how Dole can make it."
In fact, the Field Poll has shown less progress for Mr. Dole than Republican strategists claim. In June, the President stood at 44 percent in a four-way race (with Ross Perot and Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate included). In July, he had 48 percent, in August 45 percent, and in the most recent poll, taken Oct. 7 to 9, he had 48. In September, after the Democratic convention, Mr. Clinton leapt to 55 percent, but that was a transient "bounce."
"The way we analyze it," Mr. Field said, "there's a hard-core Clinton vote of close to 50 points, enough to win easily in a four-way race, to which he can add some soft support from time to time. Dole has never reached 40 percent in our polls this year, and he continues to trail, 5 to 3, among women."
Steven Merksamer, a Sacramento lawyer close to Jack Kemp, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, pushed hard for a beefed-up Dole-Kemp effort here. He argued that Republican nominees have traditionally made up ground in the closing weeks, from George Deukmejian in the 1982 governor's race to George Bush in the 1988 Presidential race to Pete Wilson in the 1990 governor's race.
"Dole can do it, too," he said, "if he and Kemp spend four or five million on television and campaign hard in the great swing areas like the Central Valley and the Inland Empire running east of Los Angeles out toward Riverside. They need to be in here, one or the other, half the time these last three weeks."
The areas targeted by Mr. Merksamer were strongholds for Ronald Reagan, full of middle-class Democrats who crossed over to back him. They gave strong backing in 1992 to Ross Perot, who took nearly 21 percent of the California vote.
Like Mr. Merksamer, Mr. Wilson has pressed for a livelier Dole campaign. Last Friday, he told reporters in Southern California, "My advice to Senator Dole is to come out to California and spend time and money here because, frankly, California offers you a far more fertile ground, I suspect, than almost any other place in the country."
But a former aide said the Governor's real goal was "not the top of the ticket, because it's not going to happen for Dole, but farther down," meaning the close races in several House districts and for control of the State Assembly.
Bill Bradley, who publishes a California political newsletter, agreed.
"Dole is confronted with pretty bad choices across the country, whether Ohio, Indiana or Florida or here," Mr. Bradley said. "He won't win California, but a rip-roaring campaign in the last two weeks could save a half-dozen House seats and help the Republicans keep the Assembly, where they're in trouble."
Searching for an explanation for what seems to them an illogical decision, many in California see Speaker Newt Gingrich behind it.
A Democratic landslide in California, they reckon, could cost the Republicans a half-dozen seats or more, depriving them of control and Mr. Gingrich of the Speakership. Fear of such a debacle unless Mr. Dole worked harder, several said, lay behind his hopeful assertion on television Sunday that Mr. Dole would win here by 6 points.
There are other theories as well. Mr. Warren, for example, mentioned the Congressional argument but also suggested that California's ability to attract national publicity -- in a way Michigan and Ohio do not -- "gives Dole a chance to practice what you might call 'the politics of contagion,' whereby reporters out here see progress, even if it's limited progress, and their stories energize people in Florida and New Jersey, in Indiana, a lot of states."
Samuel Popkin, a political scientist at the University of California at San Diego, at first pronounced himself flabbergasted by the Dole move.
"They are charging up Hampburger Hill," he said. "If this works, I'm General Westmoreland and Dole's Vo Nguyen Giap. If it works, I'm General Custer and he's Sitting Bull."
After a night's reflection, Professor Popkin said he still gave Mr. Dole scant chance of carrying California. But he described the decision to campaign heavily here as consistent with earlier surprises, such as resigning from the Senate, embracing supply-side economics and naming Mr. Kemp as his running mate. All, he said, were "designed to ring the gong and get the tube to notice."
Mr. Dole's biggest problem in California, as in so many other big states, is Mr. Clinton's popularity, especially among women.
"The President never had the ups and downs here that he had in other parts of the country," said Bill Carrick, a senior adviser to the Clinton campaign. "He kind of fits California, on issues and in demeanor and personality, too. People see him focused on the state. Bush looked at it as a tacky place, lots of neon, in-and-out burger joints, but Clinton likes it just fine."
Since 1990, at least a quarter of the Republican women in the state have lost their partisan moorings, voting for Mr. Wilson but also for two Democratic senators, Mr. Clinton and many lower-ranking Democratic nominees.
Bob Mulholland, a top strategist at Democratic state headquarters, said that on other issues as well, Mr. Dole was a bad fit for "the most pro-choice, pro-environment, anti-tobacco, least religious, most Asian state in the union."
If Mr. Dole spends millions here, he said, "We welcome him. It's gift to the Clinton campaign, because he can't spend that money in closer states."
Kam Kuwata, one of the state's top Democratic consultants, conceded that "the President is not beloved here, certainly no Ronald Reagan."
"But the economy is moving in the right direction, and Californians give Clinton some of the credit," he said. "Clinton has a message -- moderate now, a New Democrat, whatever that means -- and Dole is running a tactical campaign, all about whether he attacks or not, where he campaigns and so on. Californians reward a candidate with a message."
Mr. Dole continues to be pictured as a loser here. The San Francisco Chronicle reported in a color-splashed front-page feature on Monday morning that residents of Leisure World, a big retirement community in conservative Orange County, found Mr. Dole uninspiring as a candidate and too old to be President.
Monday night, television stations reported that 20 California Republican leaders, headed by Mayor Lanie Wheeler of Palo Alto, had endorsed President Clinton.
"They're in the same boat we were in the '80's, running twice against Reagan," Mr. Carrick said. "You're behind in the big states, time's running out, and some desperate logic says, well, may as well try California."
