HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Pound Remains Strong vs. Mark And Bolsters the Dollar, Too

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen and the German mark yesterday, helped in part by the continued strength of the British pound and rising oil prices, currency traders said.
A rise in the pound tends to aid the dollar as investment flows out of the yen and other currencies in Europe, particularly the mark, dealers said. 
 "The start of this whole move in the dollar was the rise in sterling versus the mark," said Seth Garrett, chief dealer at CS First Boston.
The pound surged for the third consecutive session, as investors jumped in to capitalize on the rally. The pound rose as high as 2.4492 marks, its highest since Dec. 22, 1994.
"Right now, a lot of people have to buy sterling," said Mark Gargano, managing director of currency derivatives at the First Union National Bank.
"They are getting caught at these levels," Mr. Gargano added, "surprised at how fast it's moved up."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the pound advanced to $1.5870 from $1.5785 on Monday, its highest level against the dollar in a year.
The dollar also rose to 1.5407 marks, from 1.5289 marks late on Monday, its highest since May.
Against the yen, the dollar rose to its highest level since January 1994. It climbed to 112.18 yen from 111.55.
The yen was hurt by a surge in crude oil prices, coupled with increased expectations that Japan would hold domestic interest rates steady.
Japanese polls show that the ruling Liberal Democratic Party is likely to lead the next coalition after the general election on Sunday, maintaining its present policy of delaying an increase in Japanese interest rates.
Also, Japan relies heavily on imported oil and is especially vulnerable to a rise in oil prices, which are denominated in dollars.
Currency traders also cited pent-up demand for dollars after the dollar spent the last several sessions in a very narrow trading range.
The dollar finally broke through stubborn technical resistance yesterday, attracting considerable interest.
Stocks and bonds in the United States ended little changed yesterday, but the recent strength of American assets continues to bolster the dollar, traders said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The committee system as a way around rules against bribery.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WITH just 19 days until Nov. 5, political action committees are presumably eager to elect the best Congress that money can buy. But how can they be certain that legislators will deliver once they have taken the money? For that matter, how can politicians induce special interests to give them the wads of cash needed to get to Washington and stay there if they are barred from selling their votes?
In recent years economists -- notably those who studied or taught at the University of Chicago -- have begun to analyze "political markets" with the same bag of tricks they use to assay supply and demand for, say, lipstick or mini-vans. And one of the more striking recent contributions is from Randall Kroszner of the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business and Thomas Stratmann of Montana State, who explain the rise of the committee system in Congress as a way around all those inconvenient, market-inhibiting rules against bribery. 
 Clearly defined property rights and enforceable contracts are critical to successful capitalism. Once you sign on the dotted line, a vast body of law and tradition stands behind economic transactions. But paradoxically -- well, what seems paradoxical to many economists who eat, sleep and breathe their discipline -- is that the political system buttressing most successful capitalist economies works with very different rules.
Interest groups are welcome to buy what is euphemistically called access to members of Congress. But as Mr. Kroszner and Mr. Stratmann note in their paper published by the University of Chicago's Center for the Study of the Economy and the State, they cannot enforce "fee for service" contracts with elected officials: say, agreements to subsidize ethanol fuel or to protect consumers from low-cost, high-quality Mexican tomatoes that compete with Florida's finest. By the same token, elected officials cannot maximize their revenues because they cannot offer formal performance guarantees.
What to do? The Congressional committee system, the two economists argue, is a "second best" alternative that has evolved to serve buyers and sellers. Specialized standing committees offer opportunities for repeated interaction between lobbyists and legislators. This makes it practical to enforce implicit contracts: Congressmen who don't consistently further the fortunes of their benefactors can be denied campaign contributions in the next election cycle. Note, too, that committee appointments are based on seniority, giving interests the opportunity to invest in a whole Congressional career.
There is, of course, no way to prove the cause and effect here. But Mr. Kroszner and Mr. Stratmann have amassed some provocative statistical evidence from the House Banking Committee. For more than a decade this committee has been preoccupied with the turf battle between commercial banks and securities underwriters and insurance companies over the right of banks to expand into securities and insurance.
To no one's surprise, committee members get three to six times as much more money from the primary combatants -- banks and investment firms -- than other members of Congress. What may surprise, though, is that there is far less overlap in giving to committee members: where the typical Congressman will get modest sums from both bank and investment political action committees, contributions to Banking Committee members are highly specialized. What's more, the concentration of contributors as well as the amount contributed rises with committee seniority, presumably a response to their increased influence and credibility.
One straightforward implication, the authors suggest, is that legislative gridlock is no accident. "With competing interests hiring different committee members," Mr. Kroszner argues, "there is little willingness or ability to forge a consensus."
It also has implications for term limits. Limits would indeed interfere with special interests' efforts to cultivate relationships with individual legislators, making it more difficult to buy reliable influence.
But "term limits are a blunt instrument," Mr. Kroszner contends. They would make Congressmen less responsive to the wishes of constituents: elected officials who cannot be re-elected cannot be punished by the voters. Moreover, term limits prevent legislators from gaining experience, arguably making them less effective.
By contrast, Mr. Kroszner argues that limits on years served on individual committees would accomplish much of what is seen as good about term limits without the bad. It would still be harder to buy influence, and impossible to invest in a legislator for the long haul. "Congressmen would thus find it more valuable to cultivate constituents and less valuable to serve political action committees," Mr. Kroszner concludes.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Slip on Fear Of Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices ended slightly lower yesterday, hurt by concerns that the economy was not slowing enough to avoid a pickup in inflation.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 7/32, to 98 22/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, edged up to d 6.85 percent from 6.84 percent. 
 Maureen Mooney, a market analyst with GovPx, a bond pricing service, said trading volume was high yesterday, with the value of the total amount of securities traded at more than $100 billion for only the second time in four months. The last time that happened, she said, was Sept. 26, a day after Federal Reserve policy makers met on interest rates.
Bond prices received a small boost after the Labor Department reported a modest increase in consumer prices. The rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index for September was within expectations, however, and only prompted a little buying.
And one economist, James Padinha, with MMS International in San Francisco, argued that the C.P.I. report suggested that the Fed should raise short-term interest rates next month.
Noting that the September figure brings the year-to-year increase in consumer prices to 3 percent, he said that "right now the 1996 inflation rate is on track to come in at 3.2 percent."
"In short, the combination of a high overall inflation rate and core rate that is not all that much kinder than the 1995 increase favors tightening more than it does a stand-pat policy," he said.
Dragging the market lower yesterday was another Labor Department report that showed weekly earnings adjusted for inflation increased by eight-tenths of 1 percent in September, compared with 1.2 percent in August, revised upward from seven-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts say while real average weekly earnings are up only 1.4 percent in the last 12 months, many remain concerned about a tight labor market, and yesterday's reported suggested that wage pressures were building.
Traders said the Government securities market also came under pressure by talk of selling by foreign central banks and some hedge funds, which took some loses as a number of European bond markets slumped. The Federal Reserve makes it a policy not to comment on central bank activity.
Still, the consumer prices and earnings reports provided little reason for the Federal Reserve to take action, said Jack Ablin, director of fixed income and senior fund manager at the Private Bank of the Bank of Boston.
"There was nothing in the reports would give the Fed reason to be concerned," he said.
Late short-covering by speculators betting against the market pulled up some prices by late in the day, even though there were those that were disappointed by the inability of the market to cash in on the C.P.I.
Elsewhere, the Treasury announced that it would sell $18.25 billion in two-year notes and $12.5 billion in five-year notes next week, in addition to the $26 billion in three- and six-month bills at its regular weekly auction on Monday. Traders said some selling yesterday might have been related to the anticipation of more supply, which would put downward pressure on prices. In when-isued trading, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.94 percent and the five-year, 6.28 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slides Against Mark On Bank Official's Comments

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar weakened against the German mark yesterday after supportive comments from a German central banker encouraged investors to take profits against a recently surging British pound, currency traders said.
A member of the Bundesbank's policy-making council, Hans-Jurgen Koebnick, voiced strong doubts about the ability of weaker European countries like Italy and Spain to fix serious economic problems in time to qualify for a proposed single European currency in 1999. 
 Mr. Koebnick said Italy and Spain would probably not be among the first nations to join Europe's planned currency union in 1999, but are likely to join by 2002.
He also said European Union members must eschew apparent budget gimmicks to meet the entry requirements for European economic and monetary union.
The comments bolstered the mark and hurt the Italian lira, traders said, with the mark hitting a two-week high just shy of 1000 lire.
"All these statements saying Italy and Spain may not be able to join the union until 2002 and discussions about creative accounting have caused people to run for cover and buy marks and sell lire," said Ben Strauss, trader at Bank Julius Baer & Company.
Investors shifted funds to the mark and Japanese yen, which had fallen to attractive buying levels after a strong rally by the pound against major currencies in recent sessions, traders said.
Dealers also cited intraday drops in United States stock and bond prices for the dollar's decline. Demand for American investments typically determines the relative demand for dollars.
"The dollar has come off its highs and I blame two things: today's fall in U.S. asset markets and the unwinding of sterling trades," said Kevin Lawrie, global manager of foreign exchange at Mellon Bank.
In late trading in New York, the dollar fell to 1.5391 marks from 1.5407 marks on Tuesday. The British pound fell to $1.5830 from $1.5870.
Against the yen, the dollar retained most of Tuesday's gains to finish slightly higher at 112.27 yen. The dollar failed to match Tuesday's high of 112.39 yen, which was its highest level since January 1994.

HEADLINE: Bargain U.

BYLINE: By Harold Howe 2d; Harold Howe 2d is a former U.S. Commissioner of Education and a retired senior lecturer at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

DATELINE: CONCORD, Mass.

 BODY:
A recent study by the College Board found that once again the average tuition for four-year colleges in 1996-97 rose above the rate of inflation. Private colleges now cost $12,823 and public institutions, $2,966 -- just under 6 percent more than last year.
These tuition increases make news, for good reason. Many families can't afford to send their children to school or must rely on loans and scholarships. 
 But the truth is that even at these prices, higher education is still a bargain. The total bill for a student living in a dormitory and joining a meal plan is an average $18,000 at private colleges and $7,000 at public institutions. Full-time students attend colleges for about 200 days a year, so the daily costs come down to about $90 and $35. For what amounts to less than the cost of a room at a Holiday Inn, plus a couple of meals, consider what the student gets:
* A room and three meals a day.
* Free counseling services, both personal and academic.
* A luxurious student center for socializing and recreation.
* Lots of green grass for fun and sun-bathing.
* Job placement services.
* Unlimited opportunities to meet and date potential mates.
* Free advice from presidents, deans and other functionaries.
* Arts and entertainment, including varsity sports, classic films, local drama and almost any kind of music.
And, of course, students receive the serious attention of faculty members intent on improving their skills and knowledge. This pays off in the long run, as college graduates will probably earn more money and have a more interesting life than those without degrees.
Yet, as prospective students increasingly demand campus amenities as well as a good curriculum, tuition doesn't come close to covering the total cost at most institutions. That is why most also rely on public and private donations.
Certainly, the Federal Government should do as much as possible to help middle- and low-income families send their children to college. But why blame only colleges for tuition increases? Colleges are giving students what they want -- and much more than what they pay for.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Consumer Inflation Rises, but With Some Quirks

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Consumer inflation quickened in September but the moderate increase was dominated by seasonal quirks and reimposition of the tax on airline tickets, a Government report showed today.
Analysts remain confident that Federal Reserve policy makers will leave short-term interest rates unchanged at their meeting in mid-November while still expecting inflation to creep higher over the coming months as a tight labor market and this year's surge in oil prices make their full impact. 
 The Labor Department reported that its Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month. The gain was in line with expectations of analysts and prompted little reaction in the financial markets. In August, the price index rose one-tenth of 1 percent.
The September increase means that more than 40 million beneficiaries of Social Security and other Federal programs will receive a 2.9 percent raise at the beginning of the new year, up from 2.6 percent in 1996. Benefits are raised automatically by the amount the price index increases between the third quarter of 1995 and the third quarter of 1996.
The average Social Security benefit for all retired workers will rise $21, to $745, while an aged couple who both qualify for benefits get a $36 increase, to $1,256.
After falling or staying the same for five consecutive years, consumer inflation has turned up this year to run at a 3.2 percent annual pace through the first nine months as prices for food and energy have accelerated after acting as moderating forces throughout most of the 1991-95 period.
Today's report, said Asha Bangalore, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, "is not comforting" at a time when unemployment hovers just above 5 percent and when there seems little sign that food and energy will soon be restraining influences again. The September results probably just bought the Federal Reserve a bit more time before it decides to tighten monetary policy, she added.
At the same time, another report indicated that wage pressures were increasing. The Labor Department said average weekly earnings rose by a hefty eight-tenths of 1 percent last month after an even stronger surge of 1.2 percent in August. This resulted from a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in weekly hours plus a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in hourly earnings minus the three-tenths of 1 percent rise in consumer prices.
The head of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, Joseph E. Stiglitz, told a luncheon meeting of economists that inflation was "stable" and that higher pay would not put this at risk.
"Real wages are not going up so fast to be a threat to inflation," he said.
Besides the 10 percent excise tax on airline tickets, which was reimposed Aug. 27, the September results reflect sharp increases for apparel and new cars, both quirky because of statistical problems in the seasonal introduction of new lines.
New vehicles climbed six-tenths of 1 percent, the largest increase in more than five years but the department noted that its sample included a noticeably larger proportion than in recent years of the newest models, the 1997 model year.
Similarly, the index for apparel swung from a decline of 1.4 percent in August, when introduction of fall and winter clothing was slower than usual, to a five-tenths of 1 percent advance as the proportion of the higher-priced new goods returned to normal. This sharp turnaround accounted for two-thirds of the acceleration in the overall index, the department said, even though apparel accounts for just 5 percent of it.
For the third consecutive month, the price index rose the same amount whether the erratic food and energy components -- over which Federal Reserve policy has negligible influence -- are included or not.
While inflation remains at bay, the risks of acceleration remain, said Oscar Gonzalez of John Hancock Financial Services in Boston. "As usual, we are looking at the past and the Fed is looking at the future," he said.
Food prices climbed five-tenths of 1 percent last month as the indexes for dairy products and for meats, poultry, fish and eggs accounted for 80 percent of the advance. Pork has jumped 13.4 percent over the last year while beef is up only 1.1 percent, the Government said. Gasoline eased four-tenths of 1 percent but energy as a whole was unchanged after three consecutive declines.
The index for used cars posted its first increase in six months, the report also showed, while the tax-spurred leap in airline fares was 2.9 percent.
For the New York metropolitan area, prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent in September -- matched by Los Angeles and Philadelphia -- but New York's 12-month increase, at 3.1 percent, was scarcely higher than the national rate of 3 percent.

HEADLINE: Canada Trims Key Interest Rate

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The Bank of Canada lowered its key bank rate today by a quarter of a percentage point, to 3.75 percent, reducing interest rates in Canada to their lowest level in almost 40 years.
The cut came on the heels of a series of weak economic statistics accompanied by a stronger Canadian dollar in the last few weeks. 
 The rate reduction quickly prompted Canada's six big chartered banks to lower their prime lending rates to 5.25 percent from 5.50 percent, the lowest level since early 1959.
It was the ninth rate cut by Canada's central bank this year and the eighth independent of an easing by the United States Federal Reserve. The Bank of Canada has now eased by 4.5 percentage points since May 1995. Its previous rate cut was on Oct. 2.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Peso Hits Year's Low In Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The peso fell to its lowest level of the year today, continuing a weeklong slide strengthened by investor anxiety concerning Government economic policy after Sunday's decision to cancel a long-planned privatization of Mexico's petrochemical industry.
The Mexican currency, which has been relatively stable at about 13.3 American cents since midsummer, has fallen 3.3 percent since the beginning of last week and reached 12.7 cents today, its lowest level since December. 
 The Mexican stock market, which has also had a bad week, recovered slightly today, closing up 11.84 points, or 0.36 percent.
The peso's fall today came despite a rise of three percentage points in interest rates at the central bank's weekly auction Tuesday. The central bank has also been trying to shore up the currency this week by raising liquidity targets within the banking system, a move that makes pesos scarcer.
Some analysts had predicted the decline, saying that with inflation rates in Mexico expected to top 25 percent this year, the peso, by maintaining its value against the dollar, had in effect risen significantly. The analysts said that evidence of that was Mexico's rising level of imports. When a currency rises in value, imports become cheaper and people tend to buy more from abroad.
Several analysts predicted that the currency would drop further, perhaps reaching 12.5 American cents by the end of the year.
Alejandro Valenzuela, a Treasury Ministry spokesman, said the peso's recent slide had been expected. "The float system we're using for the peso exchange rate is working well," Mr. Valenzuela said. "It's not in a free fall. The peso is adjusting to the level the market dictates -- when it's cheap, investors buy it, and when it's expensive, they sell it. The market mechanism is working. We need to get used to this kind of period."
Others attributed the peso's slide to investor worries about which way the Government would take the Mexican economy after President Ernesto Zedillo reversed course Sunday and canceled the sale of 61 petrochemical plants, a step that the president had touted as a centerpiece of his modernization efforts and had promised to defend.
"If you're an investor, when they renege on a promise to privatize, this is a yellow flashing light, saying that the dinosaurs within the ruling party are gaining power and Mexico is not moving forward," Michael M. Churchill, an economist at Polyconomics Inc., an emerging-markets research firm, said in a telephone interview from Morristown, N.J.
"There was quite a bit of foreign investment that pulled out after this Mickey Mouse petrochemical arrangement was announced," Jaime A. Campbell, a broker at CBI Securities here, said.
Mr. Campbell said some Mexicans had begun selling their pesos for dollars after a couple of influential Mexican radio talk show hosts began warning listeners that the government would devalue the peso in December, a reminder of the peso crisis of December 1994. "People think, December's coming, there's going to be another devaluation," Mr. Campbell said.
Technically, the Government cannot devalue the peso, because its value has been allowed to float freely since a disastrous government attempt to support its value in December 1994 that failed to halt its plunge and pushed Mexico to the brink of bankruptcy. By its inaction, though, the Government can allow the peso to fall.
Throughout much of this year, the Central Bank has actively helped to keep the peso's value stable at about 13.3 American cents, occasionally by buying pesos and more frequently by ordering a rise in liquidity within the banking system, which withdraws pesos from the economy.
The Banco de Mexico soaked up 40 million pesos on Monday and Tuesday through that maneuver.
A number of analysts warned in recent weeks that the peso was becoming overvalued, and some had expressed modest concern about Mexico's trade figures. Although the country's trade surplus continues, imports have been growing faster than exports since April.
Shafiq Islam, chief emerging-markets strategist at Credit Suisse in New York, said that because Mexican exports were influenced by petroleum shipments, "rising oil prices have been masking the underlying weakening of the trade balance." For the first nine months of the year, Mexico has experienced a "nonoil trade deficit" of $2.8 billion, Mr. Islam said.

HEADLINE: PLAYOFFS;
It's Hardly a Super Bowl But the Merchants Smile

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Three days after the Yankees won the American League pennant, Mitchell & Ness had shipped its entire stock of expensive, authentically styled shirts and jackets to the four New York-area Yankee Clubhouse stores.
"They ordered $60,000 in merchandise," said Peter Capolino, president of the Philadelphia maker of nostalgic baseball clothing. "That's a huge surge." 
 Yankee goods -- from a 1903-style Highlanders shirt to a 1961 jacket -- comprise half of Capolino's business, followed by the Dodgers, which make up 25 percent.
"I lit candles every night for a Yankee-Dodgers World Series," he said.
Apparel sales are always an economic barometer of success for title-winning teams, especially if they have a national following and also because T-shirts and caps are available so rapidly. The 43 local Modell's stores began selling the Yankees' American League championship goods Monday and anticipate brisk sales through Christmas -- if they win the World Series. "Dramatically less if they lose," said Peter Lindenbaum, the vice president of merchandising.
The team's 34th World Series will also spur at least two more capacity crowds at Yankee Stadium, more money in hot dog vendors' and parking lot operators' pockets, more subway fares paid and more business for local taverns and souvenir shops along and near River Avenue. "It's their Christmas season," said Clint Roswell, a spokesman for Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer.
The excitement will undoubtedly spur continued consternation over the team's future in the Bronx, and whether the Yankees will move to Manhattan or New Jersey.
But as a magnet for major local economic activity, the World Series is not the Super Bowl.
Unlike the Super Bowl, the fall classic is a four-of-seven-game affair played in two cities, not a single event played at a single predetermined warm weather or domed site. It lacks the huge buildup that often results in a crescendo of visitor spending at local hotels and restaurants.
The New York City Comptroller's office estimates that the direct economic impact of the World Series -- from gate, concession, media, lodging and restaurant revenues -- will range from $11.4 million for two games at Yankee Stadium to $22.9 million for four games, following some $14.3 million for the playoffs.
(The figures exclude the city's overtime costs for the police and sanitation, taxes paid by the Yankees and Stadium maintenance costs.)
The Super Bowl in January at the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans is expected to generate a direct economic gain of $124.7 million, according to the MetroVision Economic Development Partnership Foundation.
The World Series estimate doesn't equal the economic impact forecast for other local events, such as the Grammy Awards, the World Cup soccer tournament, the Gay Games, the New York City Marathon and the United States Open tennis championships. All those were scheduled well in advance.
But even if it's not a huge economic engine, "in terms of visibility and promotion, the World Series is great for New York," said Jeanine Moss, a spokeswoman for the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau.
For Major League Baseball, in its first full season since the 1994 players' strike, having the Yankees in the World Series is a dream come true.
The New York market virtually guarantees high viewership. New York is the largest market to play in the World Series since 1988, when the Dodgers, from the No. 2 television market, beat Oakland in five games and got a 23.9 rating.
In 1992 and 1993, the World Series- champion Toronto Blue Jays hailed from a market that is not rated by Nielsen. A Baltimore victory over the Yankees in the American League Championship Series would have put the No. 23 market, with 989,000 TV households, in the World Series as compared with New York's 6.7 million.
Having a team from the No. 1 market play Atlanta (No. 10) or St. Louis (No. 20) in four to seven telecasts is a boon for the Fox Network, which endured low ratings in the first season of a five-year, $575 million contract. Having the Yankees in the Series can only make it easier for Fox to sell its 30-second spots, which are priced between $250,000 and $300,000.
"The Yankees attract so much media attention, and it's attention about the team, not about baseball's problems,"said Vince Wladika, a spokesman for Fox Sports. "Of course, that's a benefit to us."
And the New York spotlight can only help baseball. The Yankees are ranked third in licensed merchandise sales, and the business expected to be done if they win the World Series will help accelerate baseball's gradual post-strike revival.
"When you talk to marketing executives, many of them are in New York, and they really feel the excitement," said Brandon Steiner, a Manhattan sports marketer. "A big market like this accelerates things and pushes baseball to the forefront."
Many key marketers from baseball's official sponsors will be among the elite to get seats in Yankee Stadium and the National League ball park.
"The Yankees are a national team, like the Dallas Cowboys," said Marla Miller, group licensing director for Major League Baseball Properties. "Last year, Cleveland was phenomenal. But the Yankees could be bigger."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Unexpectedly, Apple Halts String of Losses

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Defying Wall Street predictions of yet another money-losing period, Apple Computer Inc. reported a $25 million profit for its fiscal fourth quarter today.
The surprisingly strong financial results, which were reported after the close of the market -- and sent Apple's stock price up 7.6 percent, to $28.25 in after-hours trading -- were the best news the company's chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio, has been able to report since taking the company's reins last February. 
 And yet, with revenues off sharply from last year, and profits coming mainly from drastic cost cuts, Apple's future is far from certain. The company was unwilling, for example, to predict that it would be able to report a profit for the current quarter.
Wall Street analysts, many of whom have been skeptical about prospects for the company's survival, were clearly caught off-guard by the announcement of Apple's profits. A consensus report of 23 brokerage firm analysts, as compiled by First Call, had forecast a loss of 30 cents a share, or about $37 million.
Until this quarter, fiscal 1996 had been disastrous for Apple. The computer maker, based in Cupertino, Calif., lost $69 million in the first quarter, more than $700 million in the second and $32 million in the third.
Even now, financial analysts said, while the company has at least temporarily stanched the financial hemorrhaging, Apple's recovery is far from complete.
"Amelio and his gang have done a good job of solving the short-term issues," Todd Bakar, a computer industry analyst at Hambrecht & Quist, said. "But they still have a way to go on solving the long-term challenges."
And some analysts said the quarter's positive results were bookkeeping flourishes that were part of a carefully orchestrated Apple effort to provide good news that could be crucial for consumer confidence as it enters the big Christmas quarter.
"This was all premeditated," John T. Rossi, an analyst at Robertson Stephens, said. "They have to win hearts and minds of people for the December retail season. They can't have stories chiming impending doom."
Apple's executives said that while revenues were down almost $700 million from last year's fourth quarter, they were slightly higher than in the third quarter, which ended on June 30. The executives pointed to continued vigor in the education market, a traditional Apple stronghold, and a rebound in corporate sales.
Despite widespread belief in the financial community that corporate users have been deserting Apple's Macintosh platform, the company said it had recorded a $50 million increase in United States corporate sales for the quarter. The company did not provide a total for worldwide corporate sales.
"The question before us is not, 'Will Apple survive?' but rather, 'How will Apple establish leadership in the emerging digital era of the Internet and multimedia?' " Mr. Amelio said.
For the quarter, Apple's revenues were $2.3 billion, compared with $3 billion in last year's fiscal fourth quarter. Net income fell to $25 million, or 20 cents a share, from $60 million, or 48 cents, last year.
For the fiscal year ending on Sept. 27, the company reported that revenues dropped to $9.83 billion, from $11.06 billion in 1995.
Apple's executives said that next week the computer maker would introduce an addition to its line of portable Powerbook computers -- a part of the market where the company has lagged significantly compared with laptops based on Intel chips and Microsoft software.
Even after introducing the new models though, the company will still need to increase production of the new product in the next three months. As a result, Apple expects Powerbook sales to decline by as much as $150 million for the current quarter, Fred D. Anderson, the company's chief financial officer, said.
That is an important reason Mr. Anderson said he was unwilling to predict the company would be profitable in its first fiscal quarter of 1997. He said the company did not expect to reach "sustainable" profitability until its second fiscal quarter.
One strongly positive sign for Apple was the improvement in its gross profit margin in the fourth quarter -- an indication that it may be better able to survive the fierce price wars of the personal computer industry. The company said its gross margins had risen to 22 percent, from 18.5 percent in the third quarter.
"We feel good about these margins and believe we're making progress toward sustainable gross margins in excess of 20 percent," Mr. Anderson said. He also said the company had succeeded in reducing inventories by nearly $400 million since June and had ended the quarter with more than $1.7 billion in cash and short-term investments.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Market Place;
The big drug makers continue to ride a wave of rising sales.

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim 

 BODY:
PHARMACEUTICAL stocks are on a roll for a third consecutive year, propelled by relatively new products and a renewed ability to raise prices and generally outfox the managed care industry.
Several of the strongest drug makers have posted robust third-quarter results, pleasing investors with per-share earnings a penny or two more than most analyst expectations. Merck & Company, the Schering-Plough Corporation and Johnson & Johnson, the diversified health care giant, each reported double-digit percentage growth in after-tax profits yesterday, as had Pfizer Inc. on Tuesday. 
 Among the star products, sales of Pfizer's Norvasc blood-pressure drug soared 41 percent in the quarter to $471 million, and Merck pushed Zocor, its treatment to reduce cholesterol, up 47 percent to $725 million.
Sales of Schering-Plough's antihistamine, Claritin, was up 73 percent, to $323 million. Johnson & Johnson said that its treatment for schizophrenia, Risperdal, had become the most frequently prescribed antipsychotic drug.
Steven B. Gerber, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company in Los Angeles, said that drug stocks had been selling at a premium about 15 percent above market averages. But he noted that premiums of 20 percent to 30 percent had been the rule a few years back, before high drug prices briefly became a political concern.
A number of drug makers defended themselves then by vowing not to raise prices faster than the rate of inflation, which was running at a 2.9 percent annual rate in the 12 months ending Sept. 30. Drug prices industrywide have gone up by 3.5 percent to 4 percent this year, Paul Brooke, an analyst with Morgan Stanley, said. More importantly, sales volume is up, even to health maintenance organizations, which have seen double-digit percentage growth in monthly drug costs on a per-member basis, he said.
Merck, which paid $6 billion to buy a prescription-drug managed-care company, Medco Containment Services, in 1993, is benefiting, with Medco selling nearly $1 billion in Merck drugs this year, Mr. Brooke said. Merck does not disclose details of its Medco sales, but the bonus for Merck could reach $3 billion by 2000, according to projections by Cowen & Company.
Barbara Ryan at Alex. Brown & Sons said that the drug makers with the biggest market shares would gain even more of the H.M.O. business because they could offer the best price rebates to beleaguered managed care companies. "The rich are getting richer," she said, referring to the pharmaceutical companies. "The others are trying to stay afloat."
In addition to holding their own in price negotiations with H.M.O.'s, Mr. Gerber said, drug makers have benefited from faster Food and Drug Administration approvals of new drugs, fewer expirations this year of important drug patents and a "fairly good" stab at lowering internal costs. "They still have very far to go," he said. "I wouldn't characterize any of the major pharmaceutical companies as being terribly lean."
Net income rose 21 percent at Pfizer, 16 percent for Merck, 15 percent for Schering-Plough and 20 percent for Johnson & Johnson in the quarter, over the comparable period in 1995. Sales were up 10 percent each for Pfizer and Schering, 14 percent for J.& J., and 19 percent for Merck. The dollar's strength abroad cut overall revenues by about 2 percent, except at Pfizer, where the foreign exchange impact was 5 percent.
There were strong increases in prescription drug sales in the United States, ranging from 19 percent for Pfizer to 23 percent for Merck.
In discussing drug companies that will report earnings in the next few days, several analysts praised Bristol-Myers Squibb and American Home Products. Ms. Ryan said that Bristol had effectively filled the gap caused when Capoten, its blockbuster blood-pressure drug, lost its patent protection recently. American Home Products has paid down debt it took on when it acquired American Cyanamid. "They are buying their own stock and generating a lot of cash," she said.
Mr. Gerber said Bristol-Myers and American Home were his favorites, too, along with SmithKline Beecham, Warner Lambert and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer. Out of favor for now is Pharmacia & Upjohn, which belatedly determined that it would not meet the earnings numbers it had told analysts to expect. Pharmacia has much of its sales in Europe, where the strong dollar has meant reduced revenue, he said. "They are the exception, a disaster," Mr. Gerber said.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 726 words

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Investments With Votes As the Interest

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IF only New York were here.
For an insight into what campaigns are really all about, and why the line "All politics is local" rings so true that some people must credit Shakespeare (try former House Speaker Tip O'Neill), come to Los Angeles and head south for about an hour. Take the San Diego Freeway, which is like the Long Island Expressway with palm trees, past the Los Angeles Airport and the spaghettilike interchanges that Johnny Carson used to parody, and down to the harbor. This is the area's pot of gold. 
 The ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach are prospering with imports and exports. And they stand to prosper even more with a particularly valuable export from Washington: Pork.
If only New York were here instead of there. Then it, too, might know how it feels to be courted. The Clinton Administration (with assent from Newt Gingrich) just kicked in $400 million in low-interest loans, the last piece of financing for a new high-speed rail link to a downtown terminal. The project, the Alameda Corridor, is also getting $46 million in Federal grants, and just two days ago Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros hinted that communities along the Corridor's route might qualify for special Federal breaks. If the President is re-elected.
There is more.
Washington rescued Los Angeles County's health care system with $364 million, provided speedy earthquake relief, $430 million for a community development bank, a $40 million loan for the Long Beach waterfront, $128 million for the Los Angeles Police Department and millions for mass transit.
BENEFICIARIES of this munificence say they got it on merit. So do the White House and members of Congress. Beverly O'Neill, the Mayor of economically depressed Long Beach, notes that her city suffered severely from military cuts and that the Corridor will help not only Long Beach but the whole country. But there are many needs and many meritorious projects, and nobody who knows politics doubts that the Presidential campaign has a great deal to do with Washington's generosity to this area, as opposed, for instance, to New York City.
New York did get $114 million for its Police Department, empowerment-zone status, and money for housing and to renovate Pennsylvania Station and empowerment-zone status. "Then it sort of stopped," said an adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Democrats grumbled about the White House helping Mr. Giuliani, a Republican who has yet to endorse his party's ticket, though that is likely to happen soon. But mostly it was higher-level politics.
The President figures he needs Democratic Los Angeles to counter Republican areas of all-important California, which delivers a hefty 54 electoral votes: a fifth of the 270 needed for victory. In a state with a mercurial voting history, the White House is taking no chances.
"The Clinton-Gore administration takes New York for granted," said Bill Cerrell, a Democratic campaign consultant here. "This is the battleground."
SOMETIMES, Mr. Clinton seems more of a presence in Los Angeles than does its own Mayor, Richard J. Riordan. Mr. Riordan has been vacationing in Canada lately and isn't very outspoken when he is around. Unlike Mr. Giuliani, he has not used his platform to promote an urban agenda.
It is not his style, nor does it have to be. Mr. Riordan's re-election next spring is considered safe, thanks in part to Washington's largess. Not that he has done anything to get the goodies, except maintain his neutrality in the Presidential race. "What is he supposed to do, turn his back?" asked Bill Wardlaw, a Riordan friend and chairman of California's Clinton campaign. "No matter what the motives were, they have done all these wonderful things for the city."
Like the Alameda Corridor. It will carry goods to a downtown terminal without hurting local traffic or residential communities, explained Yvonne R. Avila, communications director for the Port of Long Beach, sitting in her office with its view of ships and containers and huge gantry cranes like the ones along the harbor in Brooklyn. A visitor noted a photograph on the conference table of a windblown Bill Clinton.
"He was here, Aug. 8," Ms. Avila said. "To talk about the importance of the port to the economy." She paused. "It was really a campaign appearance." One of many out here. But not back there.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Essay;
Sleaze at the Top

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Whose money is buying those anti-Dole TV spots saturating the airwaves, and what are the secret sponsors getting for their investment?
Thanks to the reporting enterprise of The Los Angeles Times and The Wall Street Journal (whatever became of The Washington Post and "60 Minutes"?), we have learned that a good chunk of Clinton campaign money comes from "the Asian connection" -- millions from Indonesia's Riady family, from its $6 billion Lippo banking interests in California and Hong Kong, and the Asian money-raising prowess of its hired hand, John Huang. 
 Mr. Huang, who involved President Clinton personally in prying an illegal $250,000 out of a South Korean company, also helped steer $425,000 to buy those TV spots through a gardener and his wife. That resident alien couple, related to a Lippo bank partner, went home to Indonesia and then sent over $295,000 of their contribution. That's an election crime no matter what Al Gore says.
But set that aside for future prosecutors. Focus on simple sleaze: it's wrong for Bill Clinton to solicit money from a powerful family in cahoots with a foreign dictator to affect the American election.
Focus, too, on obstructing justice in the Whitewater scandal: between the time the Clinton confidant Webster Hubbell was forced to leave the Justice Department and went to jail, it was a Lippo retainer who gave him the comfort to remain hushed.
What has the Riady family been getting for its campaign money investment? Plenty; Clinton's Asian connection helped turn around U.S. policy on human rights.
Fact: In 1992 President Bush launched a formal review of whether Indonesia, with its military thugs terrorizing labor organizers, was failing to live up to "international labor standards" and should be denied duty-free access to U.S. markets.
Fact: Clinton's former campaign manager, Mickey Kantor, when he became U.S. Trade Representative, resolutely kept that review from being terminated throughout 1993. But at the same time, James Riady, Webster Hubbell and a Little Rock lawyer, Mark Grobmyer, worked over President Clinton to forget about the support Candidate Clinton had promised the people of East Timor, targets of bloody repression.
Fact: On Feb. 16, 1994, Kantor suddenly changed -- he rejects the word "reversed" -- policy by declaring the Indonesia review ended.
That $40-million-a-year gift to Indonesian exporters and bankers reduced our human rights leverage in East Timor. It presaged Clinton's flip-flop three months later that removed all trade pressure on China to encourage democracy.
Grant that other policy arguments by hungry U.S. executives and eager advocates of engagement carried weight. But heavy money plus top-level persuasion provides basis to believe that American foreign policy was improperly influenced by the back-channel dealings of Clinton's "Asian connection."
Now to Huang, fondly called "aggressive" by Clinton. For two years, this richly severanced Lippo operative held the sensitive post of Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Economic Affairs. That job requires a Top Secret clearance, sometimes one for Special Compartmented Intelligence.
Thus, Huang was privy to U.S. trade bargaining positions, internal reviews of policies toward Indonesian and Chinese interests, even electronic and satellite intelligence from the National Security Agency.
Surely the F.B.I. conducted a full field investigation of Huang before he was granted his top-security clearance. Oversighters should ask: Did its summary reveal to Craig Livingstone the background to Lippo's agreement with the F.D.I.C. to cease and desist from violating laws about money-laundering?
Clinton's Asian connection carries no "gate" in its slug. The scandal's coverage cannot be dismissed as being driven by a partisan Congress or a procrastinating prosecutor or an opposition candidate.
For a change, the story is being ferreted out by reporters and editorialists. Some are uncomfortable about the sleaze they are uncovering, but want to be on firm ground when asked later: "Where were you when American foreign economic policy was put up for sale?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Progress Is Made in Talks On G.M. Strike in Canada
Progress was made in ending a two-week Canadian strike against General Motors that has crippled operations in the United States.
G.M.'s chairman met for two hours with the union's president and the two agreed on broad principles, leaving details for their negotiators to work out next week. But a contract will be subject to worker ratification, making it unlikely that plants could reopen quickly. So it was likely that factory closings and layoffs will spread across the Midwest. [Page D4.]
 
Ford Earnings Meet Expectations
Ford reported third-quarter profits that barely met analysts' expectations, while disclosing heavy losses in its European and South American operations and a drop in profits from car loans and leases. [D4.]
 
Compaq Reports Strong Profits
Compaq Computer earnings exceeded analysts' estimates, on strong gains in revenues, earnings and profit margins, which it attributed to successful new products, cost-saving efforts and an increase in its share of the personal computer market. [D5.]
 
AT&T Board Discusses Presidency
AT&T's board met for several hours and discussed a potential candidate for its presidency, but an official announcement was unlikely until early next week. AT&T, the nation's largest long-distance carrier, is scheduled to release its earnings today. [D9.]
 
Sears Profits Rise 22 Percent
Sears said third-quarter earnings rose 22 percent, caused mostly by strong sales of apparel, hardware and furniture. [D9.]

Time Warner Cash Flow Rises
Time Warner and U S West had informal discussions about a settlement between the two companies over ownership of Time Warner Entertainment. Time Warner also reported a loss of 43 cents a share but said cash flow rose 32 percent, to $964 million. [D8.]
 
Stocks Again Set Records
A late rebound lifted stocks to new highs. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 16.03 points, to 6,020.81, bouncing back from a 35-point drop and surpassing Monday's record close by nearly 11 points. [D12.]
 
Treasury bond prices ended slightly lower, hurt by concerns over inflation. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond edged up to 6.85 percent from 6.84 percent. [D19.]
 
Mexican Peso Continues Slide
The Mexican peso fell to its lowest level of the year, continuing a weeklong slide strengthened by investor anxiety concerning the Government's privatization program. The Mexican currency, which has been relatively stable since mid-summer, has fallen 3.3 percent since the beginning of last week and reached 12.7 cents, its lowest level since December. [D6.]
 
Drug Makers' Stocks and Profits Up
Pharmaceutical stocks are on a roll for a third consecutive year, propelled by strong earnings that reflect relatively new products and a renewed ability by drug makers to raise prices and generally outfox the managed care industry. Market Place. [D12.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE STRATEGY;
Searing Images From Debates Past Are Continuing to Haunt Dole

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
If Bob Dole was skittish about going negative in Wednesday's debate against President Clinton, he had good reason to be.
When he began attacking Walter Mondale in their 1976 Vice-Presidential debate, Mr. Dole sealed a reputation as a partisan hatchet man, which he has been trying to live down since. And his ticket lost the race, too. 
 "It became his touchstone," said Burdett Loomis, a political science professor at the University of Kansas. "Any time he begins to look negative, people start asking themselves, 'O.K., is he going to turn the car into the guardrail?' "
The other most notable time he went on the attack was during a debate in his hard-fought 1974 Senate race in Kansas. Mr. Dole won that election, but barely, and he lost the respect of some of his supporters, who booed him on stage.
"People in Kansas have not completely forgiven him for that," Mr. Loomis said.
These two searing debate experiences, both occurring when Mr. Dole trailed in the polls, have to have been part of Mr. Dole's calculations as he considered his strategy for the debate, his last chance to appeal to a nationwide audience before the Nov. 5 election.
While Mr. Dole pointedly referred tonight to some of the ethical problems involving the Clinton Administration, he seemed careful to avoid the mean-spirited edge that has characterized his past debates. President Clinton studiously avoided responding, so there was little combustion between the candidates.
Mr. Dole has always been sharp and fast on his feet. Running for re-election to the Senate as the Watergate scandal was unfolding, he was asked if he wanted President Richard M. Nixon to campaign for him in Kansas. "I'd settle for a flyover in Air Force One," the once-and-future Nixon loyalist replied.
His challenge has been to check his bitterness, which was so evident in the debate with Mr. Mondale.
That debate is remembered chiefly for Mr. Dole's comment that all the wars of this century were "Democrat wars." But it was a rough night even before that.
Mr. Dole used innuendo to attack Jimmy Carter, saying, "Some of those who lust for power are not really concerned about people," a reference to Mr. Carter's Playboy interview in which, asked about adultery, he said he had had "lust in his heart." Mr. Dole also said the Democrats had cut unemployment in the 1960's by having a "full-grown war in Southeast Asia." And he disparaged the debate's sponsor, the League of Women Voters, for rating his legislative career as mediocre.
After Mr. Dole's statement about "Democrat wars," Mr. Mondale quickly hauled out the characterization that had already been slapped on Mr. Dole's career: "I think Senator Dole has richly earned his reputation as a hatchet man tonight."
It was a reputation Mr. Dole burnished, willingly or not, as President Nixon's hand-picked chairman of the Republican National Committee and in the debate that capped his 1974 Senate race.
In his final moment before thousands of people at the Kansas State Fair, Mr. Dole, already frustrated and angry, asked his opponent, Dr. Bill Roy, an obstetrician, about abortion. Dr. Roy fudged his answer, and Mr. Dole pounced. "You heard him stand here today and say he was for abortion on demand," the Senator declared. "I want to know how many abortions you've done." Many in the audience, including Mr. Dole's own supporters, booed him.
But Mr. Dole had successfully turned the race away from himself and focused it instead on Dr. Roy's character.
After the ticket's 1976 loss, Mr. Dole went to charm school under the tutelage of Dorothy Sarnoff, a speech-dynamics consultant in New York, who told him to keep his face animated so that he did not look "mad" all the time.
By 1978, he was able to joke about his debate performance. "I'll never forget the Dole-Mondale debate, and don't think I haven't tried," he said at an annual dinner of journalists and politicians, the Gridiron Dinner, that year. "President Ford was supposed to take the high road, and I was supposed to go for the jugular. And I did -- my own."
Mr. Dole had also moderated his legislative stance and became more bipartisan, promoting food stamps, school-lunch programs and the Women, Infants and Children program. He talked more directly about being compassionate, a theme that is a staple of his speeches today.
But those who thought the nice Bob Dole had vanquished the mean Bob Dole were disappointed in 1988, when he barked in a television interview that George Bush should "stop lying about my record."
Samuel Popkin, a political scientist at the University of California at San Diego and a former pollster for Mr. Clinton in 1992, said that Mr. Dole has probably concluded that his debate in 1974 was a good move because it won him the election. The lesson from 1976, he said, "is that you better aim carefully. Don't use a shotgun, use a stiletto."

HEADLINE: Clinton and Arkansas Have Long Ties to Indonesian Family

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The 10,000 miles between Little Rock, Ark., and Jakarta, Indonesia, shrank when Bill Clinton became President.
The commercial ties forged between an Indonesian banking family and Arkansan entrepreneurs began while Mr. Clinton was Governor of Arkansas and multiplied soon after he moved into the White House. 
 James T. Riady, the wealthy son of a billionaire banker from Indonesia attended the inauguration of his friend Bill Clinton. Then Mr. Riady spent the next two months making the rounds in Washington and Indonesia, accompanied by Mark Grobmyer, a Clinton golfing friend from Arkansas, letting it be known that he was a close backer of the new American President and that he could set up deals for American entrepreneurs in Indonesia and China.
And on April 19, 1993, Mr. Riady and Mr. Grobmyer met President Clinton in the Oval Office for a brief private visit.
The next day C. Joseph Giroir Jr., the Arkansas lawyer who hired Hillary Rodham Clinton in 1977 for the Rose Law Firm in Little Rock, organized a new corporation in Little Rock whose purpose, he says, was to match the Riady conglomerate with United States companies looking for business in China and Indonesia.
The Little Rock corporation had no trouble finding business. Since Bill Clinton's election the Riady family has forged international business alliances with American companies in Arkansas and elsewhere, some with the help of Mr. Giroir's corporation, which also helped the family open a Wal-Mart in Indonesia and plan a power plant in China.
Mr. Grobmyer also did well, traveling through Indonesia on behalf of his own company, Commerce International, where he passed out business cards describing himself as a White House liaison, said Riady business associates, even though he did not hold a White House position. Mr. Grobmyer did not return telephone calls seeking comment on the accusation.
In many ways, the Riadys and their associates operate here like other powerful corporations, such as the Archer Daniels Midland Company, the agricultural giant close to Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential candidate. They give large campaign contributions, gain high-level access and develop business ties with a politicians' associates.
But the millions of dollars the Riadys and their associates have contributed and raised for President Clinton and the Democratic Party have now become an issue in the Presidential campaign, largely because the Riadys are foreigners.
They have close ties not only to Mr. Clinton but to leaders in their own country and those in China, their ancestral home, and a nation whose relations with the United States are uneasy, if not rocky. Indeed, in the Hong Kong office of the patriarch of the family, Mochtar Riady, are two photographs of himself: one with President and Mrs. Clinton and one with Prime Minister Li Peng of China.
While James Riady, associates say, has discussed Asian-American relations with President Clinton and President Suharto of Indonesia, the White House rejects any suggestion that the Administration changed any policies as a result of the Riadys' contacts with the Administration.
"We've specifically denied that there was any alteration in our policy," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary.
Still, the Clinton policy of emphasizing commercial diplomacy, often playing down human rights, especially in Asian countries with fast-growing economies, has been appreciated in Indonesia and Little Rock.
"At the beginning we had some problems," said Arifin M. Siregar, the Indonesian Ambassador, referring to the Administration's early criticism of Indonesia on human rights. But, he added in an interview last year, "the relationships now are much better."
Mr. Siregar said Mr. Clinton "came to be familiar with Indonesia" as a result of his longstanding ties to Mr. Riady, who worked in Arkansas in 1977 as a banking intern and who was sponsored, he has said, by Mr. Clinton.
Wayne Forrest, the executive director of the American-Indonesian Chamber of Commerce, said, "The Clinton Administration's commercial efforts on behalf of American companies in Indonesia have been surprisingly good, given what might have been when they first came to Washington."
Mr. Forrest, speaking of Mr. Riady, said, "We've always felt he was a credible Indonesian voice to interpret for Clinton what goes on in Indoensia."
Mr. Riady's business partner, Mr. Giroir, is also pleased with United States policies in Asia. "The Clinton Administration has been very good for international businesses, including mine," he said in an interview this week.
In Asia, the Riady family controls a $12 billion empire revolving around financial services and real estate and operating under the umbrella of the Lippo Group. The companies have alliances with Asian and Western investors.
The family's American ties include deals in Asia with banks and insurance companies from North Carolina, Alabama and New York. The family started doing business in the 1970's with an influential Arkansas family, the Stephens.
In 1984 the Riadys applied for and received approval from Federal regulators for an investment in Worthen Bank of Arkansas. Mr. Giroir, then the managing partner of the Rose Law Firm, worked on the application..
Another Rose firm lawyer who worked for the Riadys in Little Rock was Webster L. Hubbell, who joined the Clinton Administration. When Mr. Hubbell faced legal and financial problems in 1994 after stepping down as Associate Attorney General, he traveled to Indonesia to work for a Lippo affiliate.
Mr. Giroir became an international businessman after leaving the Rose firm, in the late 1980's. He incorporated the Arkansas International Development Corporation on April 20, 1993, to bring together the Lippo Group and American companies that wanted to do business in China and Indonesia. Mr. Giroir's company helped negotiate the deal in which Wal-Mart, the Arkansas based-retail giant, opened a store in a Lippo mall outside Jakarta.
Another Riady-Giroir project involves plans to build a $1 billion power plant in southern China in partnership with the Little Rock unit of the Entergy Corporation, a New Orleans utility company. The project is on hold pending completion of the financing.
Mr. Giroir says he has been working with two other Arkansans on possible Asian deals with the Riadys: Paul Berry, a lobbyist with close ties to Mr. Clinton, and Mark Middleton, who was a special assistant to Mr. Clinton until February 1995.
When Mr. Riady wanted Mr. Clinton to send a get-well letter to an Indonesian business partner of the Riady family, he turned to Mr. Middleton for help, said Mark Fabiani, an associate White House counsel. A letter was sent in June 1995 but was not signed personally by the President. Mr. Fabiani says President Clinton was unaware of the routine courtesy letter.
Mr. Grobmyer said in a 1995 interview that his Indonesian activities included helping strengthen the "sister-state relationship" between Arkansas and Indonesia, exploring the development of Indonesian resorts and trying to get American companies to look at overseas business opportunities.
Mr. Grobmyer explored possible Asian business deals, among other things, for the American Ecology Corporation, said past and present company officials who spoke on condition they not be identified.
The officials said that Mr. Grobmyer promised to introduce American Ecology officials to influential Asians and touted his ties to the Clinton Administration. Mr. Grobmyer helped set up a 1994 meeting in Jakarta between Lippo officials and a representative of American Ecology, the officials said, but the meeting did not lead to any business.
Mr. Grobmyer was in Jakarta then, too, in connection with an economic summit attended by Mr. Clinton. Mr. Riady planned to fly a number of Arkansans business executives to Jakarta for the 1994 meeting, but Bruce Lindsey, one of President Clinton's closest White House advisers, told the Senate Whitewater Committee he vetoed the idea. American Ecology said it dropped its relationship with Mr. Grobmyer's company in 1995.

PUB-DATE: October 17, 1996

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1000 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
A Spicier Mix, but Will the Voters Bite?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
What Bob Dole wants the American electorate to do on Nov. 5 is quite straightforward: he wants it to fire Bill Clinton as the nation's Chief Executive, not something the country does casually.
So tonight, in the second debate between the two men, he sought to supply new reasons to do so. When a teacher asked about Washington, Lincoln and national unity, he accused Mr. Clinton of violating "the public trust" of his office and running a White House where scandals and "ethical problems" were commonplace. But he sounded a little half-hearted, reluctant to grapple with the issue in any detail and with sustained intensity. 
 Modifying the decorous style that characterized the early stages of his campaign, he gave confrontational answers for much of the 90-minute joint appearance, on issues ranging from health care to drugs to the military.
"I keep my word," Mr. Dole said again and again, by way of suggesting Mr. Clinton does not.
But by the end of the evening, not much of it seemed to have stirred the invited audience here in the city where the Republicans held their national convention in August. If that proves to be case with the wider audience as well, it will be bad news for Mr. Dole, who badly needed to alter the status quo.
"It was a wash," said Nelson Polsby, a political scientist at the University of California at Berkeley. "And remember, most of the people who are going to vote had made up their minds before the debate took place."
Not a single direct question about the President's character or about scandals involving F.B.I. files, the White House travel office or the Whitewater affair was asked by the 113 people at the University of San Diego. Evidently sensing that the audience disliked Mr. Dole's harsher jibes, Mr. Clinton said, "No insult ever cleaned up a toxic waste dump or helped an elderly person."
The President refused to get involved in a slugging match, remaining Presidential and reassuring in his demeanor. He kept his voice low and his gestures small, talking directly to his questioners and calling many by name, in the informal town-hall format. He seemed the picture of confidence, though his face betrayed considerable irritation at his opponent's barbs.
He tried hard to project an image of sweet reason, telling the audience with a smile that he felt one way, Senator Dole the other, and it was up to them to say which was right.
The President completely ignored several of the Republican nominee's assaults on his ethics, including one on the 30-odd Administration aides who, he said, were under investigation, had been fired or indicted. And when Mr. Dole argued that the nation's economy was growing too slowly, he loftily replied, "If you believe the California economy was better in 1992 than it is today, you should vote for Senator Dole."
In his closing remarks, Mr. Dole briefly raised several of the issues on the conservative agenda that have been remarkably absent from the campaign -- issues such as term limits, school prayer and protecting the United States flag against desecration. He said nothing, however, about banning abortion, a conservative cause that has cost him support.
Mr. Dole also emphasized several issues that have a particular relevance to California, such as the cost of providing social services to illegal immigrants. He stressed his opposition to affirmative action, which Mr. Clinton supports and which is the subject of a proposition on the ballot in the state this fall.
The Republican's attacks represented an admission that his early tactics, built around a promise to cut taxes by 15 percent and balance the budget at the same time, would not by themselves do the job when the economy, by most measures and in the view of most Americans, is doing well. Tonight, he tried to redefine the campaign by making it a referendum on Mr. Clinton's performance.
Behind in most national polls by about 15 percent with only 20 days to go, he risked alienating voters who, the same polls show, already consider him too negative. He clearly thought he had no other choice, but he was careful not to press too hard; after raising the character issue at the beginning of the face-to-face encounter, he spent most of the evening on broad policy issues.
He also specified, though in a low voice, almost in passing, that his complaints had to do with "the public, not private ethics" of the President. It fell considerably short of the full-throated condemnation of Presidential character that many of Mr. Dole's aides had promised.
"When you don't have any ideas, I guess you say the other candidate's ideas are old," Mr. Dole said in one of his sharper asides, but he also used humor to soften his belligerence and restrained his sardonic tendencies.
If the challenger often sounded frustrated and a little desperate, his situation warranted it. No Presidential candidate who trailed by as much as he does at this late stage has ever won. The biggest turnaround ever produced by a final Presidential debate would not have been large enough to help him; that took place in 1980, when Ronald Reagan trailed Jimmy Carter in the pre-debate Gallup Poll, 39 percent to 47, and led him afterward, 46 percent to 43.
Mr. Dole's aides said last weekend that he planned to commit considerable time and money in California, which has long been regarded as all but locked up for Mr. Clinton. Democrats here remain confident, and the President's campaign has made a large purchase of television advertising in Florida, which is one of Mr. Dole's better big states.
Behind this strategic maneuvering lies concern about what appears to be the closest of this year's contests, that for control of the House. One major question is whether the Republicans will change their approach and tacitly admit the likelihood of a Dole defeat so that they can argue that with Mr. Clinton remaining in the White House, voters should support Republican House candidates so as to provide a check on his power.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE SCENE;
Candidates Fling Barbs and Strive for Folksy Tone

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
They began their debate here tonight by taking neighborly strolls to chat with their questioners, more than a hundred uncommitted San Diego voters.
But within minutes, Bill Clinton and Bob Dole were prowling the red carpet, each trying to land a blow before retreating to his corner, to lean his left elbow against his lectern and brace for the counterpunch. 
 As the night wore on -- and the smiles faded as the criticisms mounted over Medicare, malfeasance and economic growth -- the men began moving closer to each other, occasionally locking stares and addressing one another directly across three or four feet of crimson, the questioners seemingly forgotten.
With 15 minutes to go, Mr. Clinton walked right behind Mr. Dole's lectern, staring him down as he explained a position on Social Security. Mr. Dole turned away, gazing out over the audience instead as Mr. Clinton spoke to his right temple.
Even as they flung barbs, each candidate vied for the folksiest presentation. In 1992, after the first town-hall debate, President Bush was roundly criticized for clinging to his lectern, while Mr. Clinton waded into the crowd. Both men missed no opportunity to wander the room tonight, and both turned questions back on audience members to display an interest in their lives.
"Did you say you're unemployed?" Mr. Dole asked Iris Siefert, who had inquired whether the candidates would encourage baby boomers to plan for retirement rather than rely on Social Security. "See, the first thing we have to do is get you a job."
In jean jackets and suits, t-shirts and elegant blouses, the 113 questioners -- selected during the last week by the Gallup Poll because they had stated no definite preference for President -- sat in a patient semicircle through each peppery exchange. No audience member directly chided the candidates for testiness, as some did in a similar-style debate in 1992.
But question by question, they tried to nudge the candidates toward substantive issues, from the preservation of Medicare to whether American troops were required to insure peace in the Middle East.
The candidates, however, would not be easily led. From the very first question, Mr. Dole signaled the tone of the evening with a move that might be called a switch-and-bait: He turned a question about uniting Americans into a critique of Mr. Clinton's Administration, which he said generated "scandals almost on a daily basis."
Mr. Clinton did not rise directly to the bait, addressing the questioner by name and calling for an end to partisanship in order to set up a partisan point: "When we do that instead of shutting the government down over a partisan fight over the budget, we're a better country."
The moderator, Jim Lehrer, had the power to sharpen questions and redirect the converstation. But the talk-show format notwithstanding, Mr. Lehrer, of the Public Broadcasting System, proved to be no Oprah Winfrey, calling on each questioner and ducking out of the way.
The scene for the final debate of the 1996 campaign was the 44-year-old Shiley Theater at the University of San Diego, a collection of Spanish Renaissance buildings pillowed in the hills overlooking Mission Bay north of downtown San Diego.
It seemed an incongruous setting for such a dour debate, which began at 6 P.M. here, while the palms trees were still casting shadows across the manicured lawns. While one dormitory was speckled with a few Dole and Clinton signs, other obsessions than politics were suggested by the wet suits draped over the balcony railing, drying in the late afternoon sun.
Ross Perot, who participated in all the debates in 1992, was not invited this year, but he was not forgotten here. His name was engraved into a hillside facing the debate site in enormous white letters.
Mr. Clinton relied heavily on town-hall forums during his 1992 run for the Presidency, but, as he noted this afternoon, he has not participated in one for a long time. Still, he seemed to have lost none of his form, walking right up to the edge of the semicircle to answer some questions, scooping the air with both hands to emphasize his points, and even asking audience members to raise their hands to indicate how many were in managed health care programs. But Mr. Clinton was asked some easy questions, for example what he would do to expand family and medical leave, a program Mr. Dole has criticized.
Mr. Dole has been meeting regularly with voters in town-hall-style sessions that his campaign calls "Listening to America." But attendees have been carefully screened by the campaign, and the questions tended to float in slow, steady and down the middle of the plate.
He occasionally slipped into legislative jargon -- "He puts his money in the out years," he complained of Mr. Clinton's defense budget -- but Mr. Dole displayed flashes of his sense of humor, arguing at one point that he perhaps deserved some sort of preference in the Presidential race becuase of his disability. "Maybe we can work that out -- I get a 10-point spot," he said to Mr. Clinton.
But Mr. Dole did not smile as often as his aides, who frequently remind him to do so, might have wished. At the end, he did not smile as he shook hands with Mr. Clinton. Mr. Clinton's expression was not visible on camera, or to viewers in the back of the crowded hall.
More than a few of the visitors and staff members ho gathered here today had hoped for a sweeter, more inspiring exchange. Outside the room where reporters and spinners beavered away before, during, and after the debate, the Rve. Paul Donovan, a Jesuit, sat at a piano, trying to lower the stress level by softly playing Tinpan Alley tunes like "Someday My Prince Will Come" and "Wanting You."
Even before the debate, Father Donovan bemoaned what seemed to him a more personal and nasty tone creeping into American politics. "I was telling the people at Mass yesterday that every fourth October has become an insult contest for the self-righteous," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Last night's debate in San Diego had a neighborly, town-hall look, but with the two candidates prowling the stage, locking stares, it had an edgier feeling. No member of the audience directly chided the candidates for testiness, as some did in a similar-style debate in 1992. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)
